content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)Game Name: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified Original Release: 2013 Genre Tags: Action; Tactical; Third-Person; Strategy; RPG; Sci-Fi; Story Rich My Overall Grade: B+ Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 10-25 hours Multiplayer Aspect: None Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Fans of the intellectual property; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseursREVIEWThe Bureau: XCOM Declassified is an action-tactical, third-person shooter that incorporates cover systems, tactical pausing, and squad commands to make for riveting combat scenarios.  The story is fairly enthralling and while the characters are definitely cliché, I thought they were diverse and interesting enough, with the exception being the unquestionably boring main character.  It is far from perfect, but I enjoyed it, that much I know.  I think if you like games in this style, then you will probably enjoy it too; but if you’re someone who easily dislikes things that aren’t absolutely perfectly crafted, you may want to reconsider trying this.  This game is not like other X:COM games you may have played; rather it is a different type of game altogether that is simply set in the X:COM universe.  Evidently, this bothered many people; but I find it hard to understand why some people feel the core gameplay is so absolutely terrible.  The style of play is very similar to the Mass Effect series.  You combat in third-person shooter style, with the ability to use tactical pausing and to issue commands (move, target, use ability) to squadmates.  There is an XP and leveling system for both your main character and squadmates, with a handful of different squadmate classes to work with.  It certainly doesn’t have the most refined, expansive, and exemplary combat/gameplay mechanics out there, but I thought it was good enough and enjoyed playing the game.The story is somewhere between mediocre and good.  I liked the atmosphere and setting of an alien invasion in 1960s America.  The narrative and characters are undoubtedly cliché at times, but I felt it was all intriguing enough to hold my interest as I played through the game.  Some of the plot developments do come out of nowhere, but ultimately I thought they actually helped to make the story more interesting.I didn’t experience any jarring bugs or glitches and I thought the graphics and soundscape were pleasant.  Some of the cutscenes had a grainy look to them even after I turned film grain off, but it wasn’t the end of the world— the in-game graphics were still crisp and attractive.  For me, the most egregious negative aspect of the game was the checkpoint autosave system.  I don’t like playing a game on a PC in this day & age and not have the option to quicksave and/or make multiple saves.  (You can, however, also load up the start of any level and continue playing from there, if you missed something).  But, to be honest, the checkpoints were extremely frequent and never really caused any true frustration.The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a decent game that suffered from overzealous people’s unrealistic expectations.  Not every game can be the best game ever or the best game of the year.  If you are someone who only likes to play a few games a year and wants them all to be absolute top-notch games, I can respect that and I will then suggest that you might not want to play this.  The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a moderate-to-good game that will appeal to those who enjoy the style of gameplay it offers and who play enough different games that they understand they can’t all be the best but they can be good enough.Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

content:
Posted: September 8, 2013
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is for me, the surprise of the year. It received a slew of mediocre review scores which painted a pretty bleak picture. However, upon playing it myself, I have found the game to be incredibly enjoyable.You are thrust into the shoes of William Carter --  an agent with a troubled past -- in the midst of an alien invasion. With the military essentially being wiped out and all communications jammed, it falls to the XCOM organisation to deal with the alien threat. As an XCOM agent, you will spend much of your time in the undergound base: delegating mission assignments (where your fellow XCOM agents can gain experience), exploring, completing side missions and talking to the various personalities within the facility. Many comparisons have been made between the XCOM base and the Mass Effect Citadel, which I would say are apt. When you're done with the base activites, you can head out into the field. Most of the time you may choose between minor (side) and major (main) operations. The minor operations are fun little deviations, providing insight into what the people of that region have been through. You may happen upon individuals who have been infected by the aliens (this renders them basically catatonic) or dismembered bodies  scattered thoughout.In terms of gameplay, you lead two squadmates into battle, stopping (well, nearly stopping) time in order to provide them with orders. To me, it feels like Enemy Unknown, except in third person. Along with providing them orders, you level them up, allowing them to use new and varied powers. If you play it as a straight up shooter, neglecting to order your AI squadmates around, you may have a bad time. I believe this is where a lot of the negative attitudes towards the gameplay comes from. The AI needs direction or they will get themselves killed.A typical encounter would see you approach the enemy, getting yourself into cover and your allies. Pausing time, surveying the battlefield then deciding how to proceed. Perhaps you make your sniper cloak, move around to flank the enemy, then hit them with a critical strike? Perhaps you have your engineer throw down a rocket turret, which you then lift above cover to rain hell upon your enemies? Each battle is varied, giving you a lot of strategic options. This is something that I loved about The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.The story goes from somewhat generic to "Wow, this is batshit insane!" As I made my way through, I became more and more engaged, to the point where I couldn't put it down.The game does have its problems, but they are minor. If you have any interest in the XCOM universe and tactical shooters, I highly suggest you give this game a shot. It may surprise you.+Outstanding graphics and atmosphere. +The story takes some time to warm up, but once it gets going, it is captivating.+Great tactical battle interface. Ordering your allies around is pleasant and easy.+Good sense of progression. As you advance through the story, you and your allies level up, becoming powerhouses capable of taking on the most menacing of enemies. +The XCOM base and its personnel are well designed. It's nice to walk around talking to each of them and completing their side quests.-Lip syncing at times is woeful.-Voice acting can be hit or miss.-On higher difficulties, grenade spam can be a problem.-The AI are bullet magnets. If you do not tell them what to do (constantly), they will die.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Rating 7.5/10Overview: Cover Based- Third Person ShooterThe Good:+I really loved the 1960's American setting. Both artistically and technically the developers did a good job making this game feel alive. +The game takes place across a series of locations each one unique in its own way. The game has a lot of good set pieces +Side quests are fleshed out and fun to play + The game allows you to take 2 squad members with you into battle. You can customize your squad any way you like. There are four classes to choose from:  support, sniper, engineer, and commando. Each class has its own set of abilities and weapons to choose from. You pick whatever you want to suit your playstyle. + The game has a wide variety of abilities not only for the main character but your squad as well. The abilities are varied for each class and serve a very practical purpose in battleThe Average:The story starts off strong and is constantly building up to something...problem is, the story starts getting too convoluted for its own good. Eventually it gets so ridiculous it becomes hard to care about the story. By the end of the game I was playing it just to see the next setting. The characters are also one dimensional and a bit stereotypical. The game doesn't do a whole lot to change up the game play formula. Every side quest/main mission plays out the same way, kill lots of enemies, move on to the next area...repeat. The Bad:- Your teammates are completely useless. First they don't manually use there abilities, you have to manually select them for them to use it. Some people may like this, I did not.  The second major problem is that they make very stupid decisions resulting in death. The pop out of cover at the wrong time and get shot at, move to locations where the enemies are, etc.   The third major problem is that they do very little damage, 99% of the kills will come from you. For a game that is supposed to be a "tactical" shooter , there is nothing tactical about it. Because of the stupidity of your teammates the game plays out like a solo third person shooter. You only have teammates to choose their abilities. ConclusionFor all the fun I had with this game, it does have some serious faults. I would have liked to see more variety in the gameplay and stronger A.I. I still think its worth playing especially if you like cover based shooters.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified was not well received by mainstream reviewers, but I personally enjoyed it a lot. Overall, it feels like a stripped down version of Mass Effect, but the combat stands out above other cover shooters. The game has a lot of flaws, but I encountered no bugs in the core game. The Hangar 6 DLC, however, would freeze briefly every few seconds and rendered the game nearly unplayable. The Bureau's combat puts you in control of William Carter, a rather generic protagonist with a gravelly voice. Conversations in the game are carried out with a radial menu lifted directly from Mass Effect. The dialogue isn't terribly interesting, and some of the characters facial animations appeared to not actually be finished. Their mouths move with odd robotic motions, and their eyes look eerily dead. Carter himself, and some of the other core characters have much better, albeit repetitive animations. The story is forgettable overall, but moves the game on well enough. It doesn't come anywhere close to the likes of Mass Effect though, and the fact that the developers chose to base their game design so heavily on Mass Effect is unfortunate given the weak story. Even still, the combat made the experience worthwhile.Combat in the Bureau is at it's core a cover shooter in the vein of Mass Effect or Gears of War. It also gives you a pair of squadmates and allows you to give direct orders to them. The rookies you start with only have one or two abilities, as well as a command to focus on a specific target, and move to a location. Choosing where to move your squadmates is where the game gets a lot of it's strategic depth. You have to take into account how long they'll be exposed for, how far the nearest ally is if they need a revive, where the enemies are, how much protection the cover offers, and how easily they can use their abilities from their location. Overall it makes for a far more interesting experience than your standard cover shooter. Abilities range from dropping mines, shield domes, artillery strikes, and others.The combat isn't perfect though. Your squadmates seem to move into stupid locations occasionally, either exposing themselves to unnecessary fire, going down somewhere difficult to revive them, or both. It's not quite clear why this happens, but it doesn't happen very often at least. The encounters feel somewhat repetitive, but they ramp up in difficulty at a good rate. The weapons are fairly standard for a cover shooter; human and alien variations of the standard rifle, pistol, sniper and so on. Enemies on the other hand provide a bit more variety, healing their allies, granting them shields, spawning new enemies, or even mind controlling your squadmates.The graphics generally look good, with a variety of scenes ranging from idyllic small towns to metallic alien structures. Some elements though stand out like a sore thumb. An ugly low res skybox in one of the first scenes of the game is jarringly bad to look at in stark contrast to the cutscene that precedes it. Other elements like a destroyed tank with an ugly texture and a low poly model, or the abyss below an alien tower filled with an ugly brown fog that would have been acceptable years ago, but looks disappointing today. The rest of the game, however, especially the weapon reload animations look and sound good.The Bureau's worst offense however, is sure to be a dealbreaker for some fans of the mainstream XCOM games. The only thing The Bureau has in common with XCOM itself is the aliens and the weapon types. Unlocking new weapons is done merely by picking them up off the ground rather than researching them. Dying only puts you back to the latest checkpoint, and while you can lose squadmates permanently if they bleed out in some difficulty settings, I'm fairly sure if you die yourself they'll be back with you at the last checkpoint. By removing research, permadeath, and forcing the player down a linear path, I'm sure some players will deem the game unworthy of the XCOM title. While these issues did grate on me at first, it was the combat that kept me playing and enjoying every minute of it. Even though the story is just average, it isn't particularly time consuming like it is in Mass Effect. While I feel the game could have played more to it's strengths, it was still well worth the time and money while on sale. I wouldn't hesitate to reccomend this game to fans of Mass Effect, though fans of the classic XCOM games or Enemy Unknown will not enjoy it unless they also enjoy a good cover shooter.

												I love XCOM (old and new). I like third (and first) person shooters. This should have been right up my alley. The concept is, but the execution falls flat for me.My AI squad mates are imbeciles: running in front of turrets, running INTO the explosion radius of grenades, etc. I guess maybe I'm supposed to micro-manage the crap out of them, but that's not very fun -- especially when I'm struggling with getting my own damn guy to actually go into cover, move around simple objects, etc. 90% of the game boils down to me shooting an alien, cranking off my healing power to keep my idiot squad mates alive, shooting another alien, running to revive a downed♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥that walked out of cover, shooting an alien, cranking off my healing power again...lather, rinse, repeat.It's not a terrible game, but it's just not for me. I don't have the patience for this kind of nonsense.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015



Picked a bad day to quit drinking... 
A Screenshot of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified
By: SABINA




Highly recommended. I absolutely enjoyed every minute of this game, it stands on it's own in the franchise. From the convincing, immersive 1962 atmosphere to the gorgeously rendered and extremely detailed environments, it is immensely engaging and entertaining from start to finish. The tactical combat system is smooth and satisfying without being too easy, just the right balance of simplicity and complexity for me. I found the characters, especially the protagonist, to be realistic, believable people. Agent Carter is the quintessential tragic antihero with a scarred past, bad habits, and post traumatic stress disorder. A cynical misanthropist, but a man of the highest honor, we can't help but hope he finds redemption in saving the world. The expertly written story draws you in and helps greatly to suspend disbelief in an otherwise unbelievable nightmare. I would like to see this subject matter treated more in gaming, I think it is a richly complex, provocative and potentially horrifying, largely untapped genre. The Bureau is by far the best game to address it so far.

Posted: July 5, 2014
												The Bureau is a strange game. It's essentially a Mass Effect game without the plot choices (save for a few near the end). The squad controls like a Mass Effect 3 squad. You order them to cover and use abilities (like warp blast and lift...). There's a main mission hub where you talk to your companions with dialogue wheels. It's Mass Effect-lite.It's pretty well made and the combat is engaging enough. I really enjoy the rare game that tries to capture cold war era America and I think The Bureau succeeds here quite well. Everything about this game is very 1962.If you like the XCOM lore or are just looking for a decent third person squad shooter to spend some time with, you could do much worse. Skip the DLC though.

content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												After reading some of these comments of people who don't like the game because it is not what they know - they know so little - I decided to create a review where I tell you:Buy this game!My reasons:- The story is good- It is the real beginning of XCOM and told in a way I can believe- It is not like a DLC to XCOM, Enemey Unknown, but instead a game of its own- The graphics are great- I like the sound- The gameplay is fun- The characters are real characters - at least some of them. Not just soldier xy.- soldiers who are not in your team can be on their own missions and level in these missions- all soldiers have ... "magic" :)What you have to understand is, that this is not a game where you run around with guns blazing.You have to move from cover to cover, give your two teammates commands and use the special commands ("magic", whatever) as often as possible.You have to manage your two team mages, THAT is your job.NOT killing as many enemies as possible yourself.If you are one of these idiots who writes in Killing Floor or other Coop games things like "don't steal my kills", then you will hate this game because you are an idiot and idiots can't like this game.I do not say, that everyone who hates the game is an idiot, or that all idiots will hate this game, I just wanted to mention the possibility :)If you did not understand the above sentence, don't bother to play the game. It is not for you.A little bit about the game and not about the mindless haters:It is real time when you explore the level or do combat.But all the time you have the option to pause the game and queue commands for yourself and your mates.Because the game is not really paused but instead is running very slow, you still have to act quickly.Sometimes one of your mates will attack the enemy in a mindless way, he will leave his cover and storm toward the enemy.Without any valid reason.YOU have to manage them and bring them back to cover.You have to use your men and their abilities, like decoys, to either just bring the enemy down with force or get your men in superior positions, for example you can flank the enemy. All levels are in a way, that you CAN do it in different ways.And depending on your choice of mates and your own weapons you have totally different "magic" abilities and ranges of weapons.Depending on your weapon/ability choice you have to stay away from the enemy or you HAVE to close in.Do you want to use shields and shotguns? Or do you want to use sniper rifles and rocket turrets? Your choice.The game is fun. From the beginning to the end.The end is not drawing on and on and one like in other games. There is a story and they did not kill the story to make the game longer.There ARE moments when you want to eat your keyboard, because you did something wrong.Mostly it is not the game but you, who is doing it wrong.There are shortcuts to move from cover to cover, or to to jump over cover to be able to run towards the enemy or even to jump over the cover to use the cover from the other side which is VERY interesting in boss fights.But if you are under stress, you make errors and use the wrong combination.Then you die and you hate the game.But the game is really good, it is fun and it is not too long.It took me over 20 hours to finish it, that is more than ok.I tried to do every mission and talk to everyone who wanted to talk to me. I checked the maps for schemata for better equipment and did not rush the game.I like the game. It is NOT like XCom-Enemy Unkown, it IS a game of its own and if you can't understand that, then you will not like the game.It has not the replayability like XCOM Enemy Unkown, because there are not so many choices where you would want to try the different approach. If you once decide to sacrifice someone, why would you save him the next time? The cirumstances are the same. I saved him! :) And the weapon choices are only choices for yourself. For you men it is more like, new weapon? Ok, use it.It is not a sandbox game. It is not a openworld game. It is not multiplayer.If you need these to be happy, stay away.If you are a gamer and like good games with stories, get it and have a blast for 3 days. Then back to your long term games :)

content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												As far as games go, I can't think of too many that are more demonized than this one. Most people went into it thinking they were going to get some sort of polished up grid-style xcom team FPS and the reality is that while this game doesn't quite fall into that category, it isn't exactly the worst thing ever either. The game itself has a fairly interesting storyline that fits in “ok” to the XCOM universe despite not making a whole lot of sense until late game. Most levels consist of you running from point A to point B and collecting whatever tidbits of information (if any) and special items/weapons in addition to killing anything in your way. The combat is a bit frustrating at first as your cohorts movement commands are issued in a way relative to their position which makes using their abilities a bit difficult if they happen to be out of range. Also, they seem to be incredibly bad at dodging anything so expect to have to babysit them for the entirety of the game. As far as strategy goes, I managed to find a sweet spot with scout and commando but other class mixes are viable all the way until the last few battles (your experience may vary). Overall, the game came off as a bit tedious and I kind of sloughed through the last few hours of "level plus multiple respawns". Additionally the plot revolving around the main character (Carter) is pretty nonsensical and random which made it kind of difficult to get “into” the story. I would only recommend this game for diehard fans of XCOM who want to see another take on the popular franchise.

content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified not only fails to grasp its strategy based roots but struggles to smoothly incorporate some of the most basic elements of gameplay.Set in the 1960′s you take the role of William Carter, a CIA agent with the task of delivering a mysterious object, as things don’t turn out as planned Carter finds himself caught within a global alien invasion. After showing the ability to command, Carter is brought into the XCOM project to combat the new alien threat and keep it hidden from public domain.While the story has plenty of potential, filled with plot twists and interesting concepts that promised much however the abysmal animation quality and equally poor dialogue stomps on any attempts for the story to blossom. As your character speaks to others, it won’t take long for you to notice the constant repeat of three animations that just feel artificial, along with poor voice acting that simply changes tone every sentence making it impossible to take anything they say with any care. Plot holes run amok with many of the side quests, and dialogue not connected to the main focus of the storyline.The Bureau tries to blend the turn based strategy of the XCOM series with real time cover based shooting. Promoting teamwork and RPG elements to overcome challenges works well on paper but poor execution through AI simply makes many of the strategy components redundant. Often finding my partners simply refuse to take any useful cover unless directly told to do so, however when they take position the poor AI simply takes over, soon making them move out of cover instantly. The AI will often struggle to perform basic tasks, watching myself go down right next to an ally as they simply stand on my face watching my hp slide down to zero.While enemies are based on those featured in previous XCOM games, within The Bureau they lack the identity and unique traits that made combat diverse, tense and tactical. As you progress through the game, enemies will remain the same except for an additional armor or shield bar with the word elite lazily thrown after their names.Character progression within the game is very limited, offering little combat customization. As you and your squad levels up you are given the choice between two new upgrades, often being the choice between duration and damage. This design has been taken from XCOM: Enemy unknown which worked fine within the game design however playing as a single character through the whole story, and only having two teammates with you at all times means characters simply feel too limited, with a maximum of three skills per class, you’ll soon find your preferred attacks and have no reason to add diversity to your tactics throughout the entire game. Skills are activated by bringing up a battle HUD, giving you access to your own and team skills, during this the game will slow down giving you more time to plan and consider your options. Though slowing down the game reduces the pressure, the game continues to play making many tactical attacks an impossibility. Many times I found myself trying to time my snipers critical strike with turrets and protective abilities however the moment a skill is selected it will begin to play out giving you little time to organize the ambush you planned in your mind, often resulting in a messy and inconsistent first attack.One of the huge holes apparent within the game seems to be a lack of co-op within the game, the structure of combat and the storyline feel setup for two players. Situations where the main character become split up for short periods of time from the team, as well as the dependency on tight coordinated teamwork scream out for two player interaction. Many flaws within the game, specifically the unreliability of the AI would be overcome and none apparent with a second human player. With a second player the game could be incredible enjoyable and the fact developers missed this opportunity is a great disappointment.The Bureau is definitely not one of the worst games available for sale, but simply tries to do so many things, it does none of them well. Barely meeting the line of mediocre in any aspects of gameplay giving it no identity on the market, and as such simply giving no reason to buy it especially at a full AAA title price.edit: Fixed typo.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												I really enjoyed The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.It's a tactical cover-based shooter in a thirdperson view.You're playing one of the agents of XCOM, fighting back an alien invasion on the earth.It has a pretty nice '50s/'60s style which fits the game perfectly and looks pretty neat (sure, no high-end graphic but it has still some nice and atmospheric visuals).It's very linear and you'll always see when a fight is going to happen (you'll spot the covers you can use).I found the gameplay and fights to be quite enjoyable. Though, the A.I. has some flaws (and i just played on a low difficulty, so maybe it might be worse on higher difficulties).It plays like every other cover-based shooter, with the exception that you can give your 2 companions orders (there are maximum 2 you can take on missions with you). Opening up this menu will trigger a super slow-motion, giving you time to activate skills, place your companions on specific points on the map or heal yourself. You also have to be careful/tactical as the characters won't take too much damage, so run&gun isn't the best option here.Between missions you're always going back to the underground base of XCOM, where you can find some people to talk with, read some notes and do some smaller side-missions, which was a nice idea in my opinion.You can also recruit different soldiers which have different classes and therefor different skills they will use, e.g. one can use a shield, another one can place a turret and the next one can make himself invisible.If you're a die-hard fan of the old XCOM games, you might be dissappointed, as it is not the typical turn-based strategy game, but apart from that i found it to be pretty enjoyable.Worth a look if you like SciFi and tactical third-person shooters.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified isn't bad, it just isn't very good. It's a bit threadbare, feeling like several incomplete ideas that have been rushed out the gate.Realistically, I suspect The Bureau was completed on a small-ish budget after lingering around in development hell for a few years. Something about the game makes it feel like it's ten years or more old, if it wasn't for some of the DirectX 11 effects looking so sparkly it'd be easy to think it was from the early 2000's. Many of the locations are bare and empty places, feeling like they've been built in a rush, and often with several such vacant sets stitched together without any combat or events to distract, assumably to give the impression of covering a lot of ground in a mission. Other areas have clearly had some time and attention spent on them, and the locations and missions waver back-and-forth on this attention / quality scale, leaving the experience feeling quite jarring. You'll wander from a well-realised street, strewn with debris, bodies and signs of previous life... into an area that feels like it's been imported from a PS2 game.The mechanics of the game basically play out like Mass Effect's combat, or Mass Effect 3 more specifically. It's a cover-based shooter where you run around with two squadmates, you have abilities with cooldowns, can issue orders and give movement directions to your squad. Enemies come in multiple varieties, some with shields and some with armour, with a few enemy types creating interesting tactical choices (a unit that supplies shields to all other nearby units, for example, if taken out the shields drop and make the fight easier). Unfortunately, where Mass Effect shines in making you care for your squad, here they are just flat cardboard bodies waiting for you to pull their puppet strings. They also keep respawning in front of you whenever you cross through a 'loading door' (frequent area transitions where the game loads the next section as your character very slowly opens a door and looks left and right before giving you control again), which is a bit distracting.In fact, I felt the game lacked polish in general. I fell through the level geometry and died twice in eight hours of play, once whilst just running down a straight corridor. Audio logs can be found and played, although walking away from them they fade until inaudible (if I have to stand still to listen to them, they may as well be written text!). The controls aren't terrible, but movement feels clunky and stiff, for example; when you run there is absolutely no strafing, not even in a limited fashion, leaving you to clumsily course-correct with your mouse as you charge forward. You also tend to pop in and out of cover randomly at times, especially if strafing in cover, and controlling your squadmates feels awkward (fortunately the game slows down time during this).Much of the story is told over radio as you run between fights, although there are some cutscenes that deal with exposition. The game also uses a dialogue wheel, just like the Mass Effect series, allowing you to choose between being vaguely rude or agreeable, it's a nice enough touch, although it felt a bit redundant with such small scope for actual meaningful choice. Levels are basically linear paths that open into combat arenas, the main missions last 30 to 60 minutes each, with side missions from 15 to 30 minutes roughly (I only did a couple, they felt fairly pointless). The game isn't overly long with six main missions, the story is mildly amusing with some interesting characters (although the main player character really started to grate on me). The plot felt like it tried to raise the stakes too high a number of times implying that Earth has basically been wiped out and already lost by the midway point of the game, then later claiming it's not as bad as implied, which breaks the suspension of disbelief somewhat.Imbetween the missions, the game flirts with the idea of being an XCOM-style strategy game where you pick missions and kit out your squad, but with only six main plot missions and (I believe) seven side-quest 'minor missions', it doesn't feel like there's a lot of variety or choice. The equipment feels limited, with only a handful of weapons to equip and the only other equipment slot being a 'backpack' which acts as a kind of modifier for ammo, health regen, or ability cooldowns.Overall, not a bad game, just not a particularly good one. It feels like it didn't succeed at being the mixture of genres it wanted to be, and it's not particularly good at being any ONE genre either. The plot is so-so, and the clunky and unpolished feel doesn't help. But if you don't mind all this and want a simple squad and cover-based shooter, this might entertain.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												It is games like this that make me wish STEAM had a "Neutral" button instead of a strict "Recommend/Don't Recommend" button. I have mixed feelings about this game, allow me to break it down like this:The Good:> Interesting story with an intriquing plot twist.> Enjoyable 1950's era environment.> Nice variety of weapons and equipment ("backpacks") to enable most any playstyle.> Graphics are decent, the game is built on the Unreal engine, its not current big budget graphics but I don't mind them.The Not-So-Good:> They tried too hard to make a tactical squad based third person shooter with cover mechanics that feels very clunky. The cover mechanic requires you to sprint at a wall and basically super-glue yourself to it. This system doesn't seem to want to let you "leave" said wall if say, a grenade is thrown at you, which happens A LOT.> The story itself is rather short, you can power through it without any trouble in a couple hours.If you are looking for a tie-in game for XCOM: Enemy Unkown, this is NOT it. This game has little-to-no relation to Enemy Unkown and contains none of the base management mechanics that Enemy Unkown has.So, in short, this game is worth a look if you get it on sale or as part of a Humble Bundle, but I just cannot recommend buying it at full price. I would put it in the $15 game bracket. Its better than bargain bin game quality but should not command a higher price than around $15.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												After all the bad press surrounding slapping the famous XCOM (sic.) brand on a TPS there is a surprising decent game left behind.  You are Agent Carter, a cynical broken man thrust into the limelight after an Alien invasion now tasked as the tip of the spear against this new threat.There are many elements and ideas drawn from the previous games but it is a strictly linear and pre determined experience.  You operate out of XCOM headquarters between the main story missions.  You have free run of the base and are able to go on minor side missions, perform investigations inside the base and sent agents out on missions on their own to gain experience and new equipment.  Sadly even though the base has vast Engineering and Lab sections, they are cosmetic.  You can't perform research on new equipment or ideas or perform autopsies.  The only way to get new equipment is to find it during a mission and the only way to learn about various elements is to click on one of the copious clickables in the world.Carter can bring two additional henchmen with him on a mission from one of the four classes.  They are all pretty standard tropes from other games but do add an interesting element to the game.  Do you go all out attack with commandos and snipers, sit back and dig in with engineers and support specialists or a combination of the four.  You can move henchmen around the battleground, conveniently littered with waist high walls, flank enemies and use the various abilities in conjunction with Carter's unique ones for a multitude of strategies. But...A warning: The friendly henchmen AI is some of the worst you'll ever see.  They'll jump out of cover, run left, run right, turn a full circle, jump over another wall landing right next the nearest enemy before coming back to you.  They need to be babysat at all times or they will be useless.Where the game shines is in the fantastic recreation of cold-war early sixties America and the digital acting.  The influence of Mass Effect is obvious but still welcome and the story?  Well, let's just say it takes quite the left turn near the end!Update for badge!I'll give it 7.5/10 on the AAA scale of 7-10

Posted: January 6, 2016
 The Bureau: XCOM Declassified   Overall Score: 4/5  If you're a fan of tactical games I invite you to give this game a try.I'm nearly 14 hours into this game and I'm really enjoying it.I didn't play any other of XCOM games so because of this game I will also try XCOM : Enemy Unknown.RPG Elements: (4/4) +You get to customize your agents by how they look (yes, even painting their clothes) and changing their names.+Choosing of 4 different classes to each agent (Recon/Support/Engineer/Commando)+Choosing of 6 different roles to each agent (Defensive/Assault/Survivalist/Smart etc..)+Choosing equipment and abilities.Storyline: (3/4)+The storyline is clear and understandable but a little obvious and expected.+Character voices are well made that give extra content to the storyline.-Some dialogues are boring but most of them stick to the storyline, you can skip them if you want to.Gameplay: (3/4)You get to play as 3 agents on the same time.+Give orders and launch them on the enemy style (Pause menu with abilities just like Game of Thrones (2012) and Of Orcs And Men).+Different types of enemies including boss fights. Different maps and different levels of difficulty. (Can be challenging for those hardcore players).+Basic and easy to use cover system.+Side missions which include base investigations and minor operations.-Gameplay is repetitive if you play it for a long period.Tactics point of view: (4/4)+Take advantage of the different classes and roles that this game gives to you, and use it on the battlefield.On your back: A medic for health/revive recovery, mabye a skilled marksman? Or a scout with Invisible ability.With you: Engineer who can deploy turrents or Support who can buff your teammates.On your frontline: Skilled soldier who will help you in you fight against the aliens.+And ofcourse pick equipment like Frag/C4 grenades , Assault Rifle , Pistols , SMG's , Lazer guns ...+Move your agents to strategic points on the battlefield and plan wisely against the enemy.Enjoyment: (8/10) Repetetive: (3/10)Replayability (7/10)Frustraiton (4/10) - When you play cat&mouse with the agents to revive each other while fighting a boss with aliens around.Boredom (3/10) - Only in-between missions.You're more than welcome to also check my screenshots for this game [link below] to see what this game has to offer.http://steamcommunity.com/id/xDMikeW2k14/screenshots/?appid=65930&sort=newestfirst&browsefilter=myfiles&view=imagewall Overall Score: 4/5  * Skip it.** Not Recommended.*** Give It A Try.**** Recommended On Sale.****** Recommended On Full Price.Thanks for reading.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2013
												A decent squad based third person shooter. Nothing more. The Bureau brings nothing new to the table but is still mostly enjoyable. The 60's style is done very well, even though the sci-fi elements detract from the experience at times making it feel like a 90's or even 00's game. It doesn't mix the settings properly I guess.The graphics are solid, nothing special, but not bad either. They get the job done, like most games. Same goes for the voice acting. The effects on the other hand are done very well.The gameplay itself is hit and miss. There's no research to be done, so if you pick up an alien's weapon you can fire it right away. It's something I missed, especially after playing last year's Xcom. There are mini missions to be completed and agents can be sent on different missions to level up and gather gear. Those missions can not be played so it basically comes down to selecting which agents you want to go.Each agent has abilities that can be unlocked by leveling up. They're all fun to use and there's plenty of variation to mix things up during battle. The battles play out in real time and with the press of a button time can be slowed down to make more tactical choices. Later on you'll have no choice but to use it as more and tougher enemies will be deployed. Without it you'll have a pretty hard time, let me tell you.Also, If you're agents are down you'll have a certain amount of time to help them up. If you don't help them in time they'll die and you'll lose them forever. So it's important that you work together and manage them in the best way you can to prevent them from dying. Near the end of the game this becomes much less important because your other agents will be around level 4 or 5 already.The Bureau is actually pretty lenghty. I finished it in about 14-15 hours on Veteran so I guess it can be completed in roughly 13 hours or so, if you stay alive the entire time. That's actually pretty decent in an age where most action (adventure) games can be completed within 7-8 hours.If I had to rate The Bureau I'd give it a 7/10. It's frustrating at times, but fun enough to play and finish. The only issue here is the price, because even though there's plenty of content the game itself just isn't fun enough to pay full price.[Rating: 73/100]

												I seriously wanted to like this game.  I've been a huge XCOM fan since forever.  This game is just so maddeningly mediocre any true XCOM fan should just forget it exists. Pros:-Shooting aliens with M14s I guess-Retro 60s theme is neat-Mutons are terrifyingCons:-Faux RPG elements are minimally important-Map design is brutally linear-The gameplay isn't interesting and sometimes frustrating when cover doesn't work right in a firefight-Squad routinely abandons perfectly good cover to walk into searing barrages of enfilading plasma fire-Squad is less than useless, never had them kill more than 20% of the enemy even when fully upgraded and constantly spamming their abilities-The story gets pretty ridiculous by the end-Blaster launcher is boring as hellBottom line is you're playing a squad based tactics game where the squad is useless, the tactics are simplistic and the maps are so small as to prevent critical thinking.  Then you slog through to an ending that isn't very good.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												I wanted to give this game a proper chance, I really did. Even as a serious X-COM nut I know the plotlines have always been 'meh' and after FiraXCOM was announced I was more accepting of this as a spinoff (like Command and Conquer: Renegade, which I liked). It was still a daft move to make the first XCOM game announced for years the one that closest resembles X-COM: Enforcer, the lowest point of the series.This game however is a perfect example of what happens when you force a franchise into somthing unrelated. I like the 1960's and I like the Men in Black angle but by cramming in lacklustre combat and a horribly broken squad command interface into a game that was not designed from the start to be something different has hampered the game horribly.I said 'lacklustre combat' but I suspect that is being generous. 'Broken' is more like it. To squeeze as much as possible from the squad command gimmick the only way to do serious damage is by flanking the enemy. That in itself wouldn't be too bad if a) you weren't being constantly forced down linear pathways with little chance to spread your tactical wings and b) most importantly, the squad AI wasn't atrocious. I even tried getting them to stay in place while I flanked as they kept with the lemming act when I gave them the move command. What did they do? The followed me. There is no 'halt' command, before you ask. Add to all that bugger all ammo capacity and you'll spend the game running for a thousand guns just to take care of a handful of mooks.The graphics are mediocre at best, the base command is even less than what you got from Mass Effect 2 (at least you could choose your research there) but the worst crime in my eyes is the plot. The 1960's was a troublesome time with not just the Cold War but rights movements for women and people of colour. Does any of this get to the game? There's one Soviet agent which is nothing more than 'you can recruit this dude to be a generic squad mate,' only a handful (2 on my admittedly amateurish count) of comments about one of the star agents being a woman and not a single sausage about the amount of black agents and scientists (Again, this is the sixties, that would have been huge and quite interesting). I keep thinking they missed an opportunity by not doing something like Expeditions: Conquistador; imagine if your squaddies had personalities. Likes and hates and all that jazz. Some are progressive and some are more traditional. Do you stick by your guns and rely on women and coloured folk despite the anger you'll recieve or will you bow down to social pressure and prejudice?Between the lack of care for anything happening in the 60's and all the sci fi weaponry there is no reason this couldn't have been set in modern day, the eighties, or even in World War 2. It takes effort to make one of the most interesting decades in the last century that generic.Add to that the most generic hero character ever (seriously, the guy is every bland hero trope imaginable; WW2 veteran, dead family, alcoholic, tortured past, gravelly voice, etc) and a plot that makes Independence Day seem high brow and it's a total loss on story as well as gameplay.The tragic thing is when I look back at the original vids (the ones which sparked the public outcry) it looked really good; the old 'man in black' conspiracies mixed in with the Stepford Wives. That could have lead to some interesting investigative angles and could have created a properly eerie alien plot. If it was allowed to be it's own thing instead of having a brand name forced on it (a brand name not unfamiliar with being abused, admittedly) and not reworked time and time again for stupid reasons we would have had a much better game. For those who whine about the Devil May Cry reboot (which I say was solid), that was at least in the spirit of the originals. The Bureau reeks of the sort of soulless boardroom mandates that I would have expected from EA.Would I recommend it? It's better than the Syndicate Reboot, but then very little isn't. The word 'generic' appears in the above text a lot. That should tell you everything you need to know.Quick edit: Yes I know this is a 2K Games published title and not EA, that was a stab at the people who could turn Syndicate into a FPS far worse than Goldeneye: Rogue Agent (which had the excuse of being unfinished and rushed and was still reasonably fun) and the sort of people who looked at the Divine Comedy, social, theological and political commentary that it was and say to themselves, "Yes, this is perfect God of War clone material!" That's right; I am comparing the Bureau to EA's Dante's Inferno.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I don't think I've ever felt so burned buying a game day one. Do not let the XCOM name fool you. It has nothing to do with the overall story. If anything this game makes a mess of the overall narrative of XCOM. The story is below average with one little unexpected twist but if anything it's more unexpected because up until that point you don't expect much after hearing all the character's dull droning and uninspired dialog. The graphics range from sub-par to bland. Strange phenomenons appear all the time, from the shimmering hair of one of your colleagues that change from blond to brunette, all the way to identical twin guards that also bare a striking resemblance to a scientist you just passed down stairs. The game play is standard cover-based shooting. You move, kill aliens, wave ends, then keep moving; sound like some real white knuckle action? If so, get out more. Sometimes you find an alien weapon and get to use it...that's it. No research, no testing, no means of duplicating the tech. You just have it now and so do your teammates.Speaking of which, your A.I. partners are dumb as suicidal rocks. You give them orders, to which they either ignore so they can do what they want or they follow orders and keep following them regardless of whether or not they are about to die by continuing to obey. They rarely kill an enemy and are more of a liability than a useful asset. When they take too much damage they fall and you have a short amount of time to get to them before they die for good...not that you'd notice. More than a few times I had a teammate warn me I was standing near an alien-thrown grenade. I would jump out of the way while the A.I. teammate that warned me would sit there and get blown up.This game was short. I beat it along with all the achievements on the first time around. The DLC mission "Codebreakers" was horrible. Not only is it an obvious mission that was cut out of the original product to make more money and incentivize pre-orders, it is the SHORTEST MISSION IN THE GAME AND ADDS NOTHING TO THE STORY! What do you get to show for it? Another backpack mod thing that you probably won't use.I've played some bad games in my life but this one hurt. I like the XCOM franchise but this one was nothing but a cheap cash-in that used the XCOM name to boast sales. Do yourself a favor and buy XCOM: Enemy Unknown or continue to play it  if you already own it. This game is only XCOM in name, not in game play nor spirit. Learn from my mistake.

												As an XCOM fanboy I had to try this one out. And hooboy, it sounds like a stinker. Third-person shooter somehow related with XCOM and set in the 1960's for some reason? And while the original XCOM was fantastic, the franchise has suffered from corporate rule (although the reboot is alright).  Plus it's apparently been through development hell with switching studios and even switched from FPS to third-person tactical.   But this one really surprised me. The setting, as hokey as it is, is pulled off really well and has an entertaining flavor about it. The gameplay mechanics of controlling 1-3 dudes via pseudo time-stop and the cover system works well enough. The gear upgrades are something you want to work for, so that's like the original. By the end though, it's mostly about dropping all those special abilities, and cover and shooting doesn't matter as much. Eh. The story is, surprisingly, not♥♥♥♥♥♥ Like, wow. What are the odds of that?  Maybe it was my low expectations but this one was a pleasant surprise. Anyway, it's on the humble bundle right now, so I reccommend it.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												X-Com for MonkeysThis may be a good game for those who drool over the UFO's, conspiracy theories, alternative histories as well as those who love the 50's and the 60s (even though they weren't even born then). This is not such a great game for everyone else.The game plays like a straight B movie, at best.It pains me that this game used the Unreal 3 engine instead of Mafia's II Ilusion engine, even though 2K Games owns the former. The differences are apparent and Mafia II came out 3 years ago. The game's facial animations are pretty lifeless, the lip sync is nonexistent, the anti-aliasing is somewhat noticeable, there are some texture pop-ins in the background in open levels, the fire/explosion effects are bad as well. It is ridiculous to still be playing with such graphics in Q3 2013, but at least the game allows you to get a 100 FOV which makes you see a enough of your surroundings,.The overall visuals resemble some sort of a grainy pallet, as if you are watching the game through the lens of the late 70's camera.Walking around the Xcom base is one of the best highlights of the game, at least it seems so at first. Once you soak in the fact that most AI models are pretty much lifeless the feeling wears off pretty fast.Unlike in the Enemy Unknown you will have opportunities to sneak up on enemies and be able to set up mini-ambushes, although your element of surprise won't last longer than 2 seconds, the enemy will always know where you are, and why shouldn't they? There is always only one approach to beating the level. The levels are linear although they do provide for some flexibility with cover. And this is the first game that I have seen (since Splinter Cell Conviction) that allows you to switch cover diagonally.The game loads the level as you progress - each time you open a door a new portion of the level loads while your character cautiously looks around, it's pretty clever.The game is moderately easy even on the hardest difficulty wherein your agents DO get permadeath, however you can always reload the checkpoint and start over. That kind of defeats the purpose of the Ironman feature that Enemy Uknown had. But then again, Enemy Uknown did not feature the main protagonist. Or maybe it makes little sense to compare the two games since they have been in a paralleldevelopment for quite some time. If anything, this game's combat is closer to Mass Effect than anything. You can heal your squad in an instant, you can pull enemies out of their cover, zap the enemy's shield, set up turrets, use drones, except somehow you manage to do so in mid-twentieth century America.The squad AI is so-so. Sometimes they are able to kill the enemy by themselves and sometimes they rush out into the battlefield and get knocked down and later bleed out if you don't rush into the hail of bullets yourself in order to try to save them - which kind of defeats the purpose of a smart squad especially when you are on the defensive - major minus. However, it does feel good when you send an enemy to outflank a turret while you get the turret's attention. Moments like that work in the Bureau's favor.Your squad mates are sure to run out of cover into the open when they are being flushed out with the grenades. And keeping them in line by rallying them to yourself does not work in the midst of the battle. However, all of this DOES push you forward to be decisive in your actions. Should you take a little too long to outsmart and outgun the enemy you are likely to lose a squad-made.As for the enemy AI, well, 90% of the time they expose their heads from out of cover - so sniper rifle is essential, even with its 15 bullet ammo capacity. So even on the hardest mode all you need is one head shot to kill a medium strength alien.There are a few things that bothered me. Some of the human tech you have from the beginning is way too advanced. Stealth? Automatic Squad Heal? Smart turrets? What's cool about the X-Com games is that you always faced overwhelming odds with realistic human tech at first - it's the way of the underdog. It's the challenge that counts. And that's what I expected to get from this game.The game did not do a good job of building up the tension. The prologue mission has you killing aliens left and right. Your character is a natural right away. Okay, he fought the Japanese and then some Vietnamese, but still...Sure there is a story: it tries to capture the step by step alien invasion across the US and has you traveling to various hot-spots and points of interest. Recruiting new soldiers doesn't cost a thing. So you may never run out of soldiers. What's nice is the constant dialogue between you and your squadmates - helps with immersion and everything.The game is, by all means, playable.B for effort.

number of helpful: 55 of 77 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a story about the struggles A Good Game encounters while it desperately tries to escape the clutches of its evil stepmother, A Bad Game.The Bureau is a tactical third person, cover based shooter that takes place during the 1960s in the United States.  You play as William Carter, an agent with the CIA, and command 2 other soldiers as you fight off an alien invasion.  The main draw of the tactical portion is the "Battle Focus" where you slow down time to give orders to your agents, executing movements and plans. There's some light RPG elements that accompany it, where you maintain a small roster of fellow agents and level them up, picking up abilities as they progress through the levels. Let's talk about the evil stepmother!Even when you ignore the XCOM stuff, the story is a mess (XCOM fans, read below, but spoilers beware).  It's very generic sc-fi stuff, but it suffers from some weird pacing and organization issues.  The characters have no personality to them, they're just scarecrows with voiceboxes.  Obviously, the bulk of the game is spent fighting, but even that has its issues.  The squad AI can act pretty wonky, and they require a fair bit of micromanagement.  Multiple times, especially towards the end of the game, I would watch one of my squadmembers try and fire at something below him and achieve nothing more than hammer the window ledge for a minute straight.  Enemy grenades are aplenty, and your squad members do a good job of diving out of the way, but this leads to issues whenever they dive into the corner right next to the grenade or decide to charge through enemy fire to get another piece of cover.  I was pretty active with assigning targets and using abilities, but in the beginning I was still scoring 95% of the kills myself.  As your agents advance through the ranks, they get more abilities which help them carry their own weight, but they don't become much handier with a gun.  The squad management stuff is also frustratingly vague- when you recruit a new agent, you can pick a background for them that gives some sort of passive bonus, but the game doesn't give any hard figures as to what it does.  You get a blurb, so maybe you'll get a vague idea of what the bonus confers, but sometimes you don't even get that.  This is also a problem with equipment.  Your agents get two pieces of equipment, a weapon and a backpack, and the backpack features a description of what it does but never gives hard values, and a lot of them seem to do the same thing.  For example, you'll find mulitple backpacks that reduce incoming damage, but a lot of these offer bonuses on top of reducing damage, but there's one backpack that only reduces damage.  Does it reduce more damage?  Who knows!All this aside, there is a shiny nugget of Good Game underneath it all.  There's a small bright spot in the story that probably lasts for about 20 minutes or so towards the end that was waaaaay more interesting than anything else that had happened so far, but then they decide to throw it away and keep on marching ahead.  The Battle Focus portion has some control issues, but overall I was really impressed with the way plans were executed.  The agent creation system was really interesting, as well, and it was a shame that it didn't offer much more depth or give you much of a reason to use more agents.  I'm convinced that there's good ideas sprinkled about the game like breadcrumbs, and if someone could follow it, there'd be something beautiful at the end.I still had fun with the game, despite a long list of complaints.  At its core, it's a solid, if unremarkable, third person cover shooter.  While I have no desire to ever replay the game, and I'm going to uninstall it after this, I certainly don't feel as it was a waste of my time.  I would never encourage something to buy it, but I'd never discourage someone from buying it, either.What I paid for it: 12.50What I would pay for it: 10.00Everything in the review is based off of playing it on Veteran difficulty.FOR XCOM FANS:As an XCOM title, the game fails miserably, both from a narrative and mechanical sense.  From a narrative sense, my first complaint is that XCOM is an international effort. I get that the game is a tie in, but I don't think I ever heard once the justification of why the organization is called XCOM.  The actual name of the organization is "Bureau of Operations and Command", and then they just start calling it XCOM.  There's also the timeline issue.  The game takes place in 1962, and during the course of the game you get all sorts of crazy, alien technology.  In 1999/2015, when the aliens come back, instead of just shipping over the technology/knowledge on how to beat them, I have to watch my Squaddies die brutal deaths all over the globe because the Air Force lost a Laser SMG in warehouse?  The Council only gets the barest of nods- if you have subtitles on, during the ending scene, someone with the name "Councilman" speaks.  Which, honestly, could just be a happy accident.Granted, a lot of this can be handwaved away with the word "Spin-off", which is fine.  They pretty obviously co-opted Sectoids into this, but if you were to remove them and all instances of the word XCOM, this would be unrecognizable as an XCOM title.  Which takes us to how the game fails XCOM mechanically.XCOM, for the most part, has been a game about overcoming insurmountable odds and crafting your own stories as you play through a game.  Yes, there may have been a Squaddie O'Malley in other people's games, but only your Squaddie O'Malley managed to kill two Chryssalids in a warehouse by himself before meeting his untimely end to panic induced friendly fire during the next mission.The Bureau strips all that out.  Between the fact that soldiers are incredibly hard to lose- once they go down, there's a bleed out period where they die if they're not revived but you have plenty of time to bring them up. Between that, and the game focusing on characters that already exist, you just don't care about your agents. I still know the name of the 6 soldiers who went on my last Temple Ship Assault, but I couldn't even tell you the name of one of my agents from the game.  They were just "Level 5 Sniper I" and "Level 5 Engineer II".  By removing any tension, and making the player character a tough, disaffected badass who growls more than talks, it just turns into a shootbang gallery where fancy special effects happen sometimes rather than a tense, careful advance against enemies who are far more powerful than you.If you came here for an XCOM title, I'd advise you to keep looking.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
-Quick Review-You play this game as "Agent Carter", whom is tasked with the responsibility of trying to save the human race from a new global threat. The game takes place in the 1960's making the aesthetics and technology seen in this game very engaging and interesting. -Detailed breakdown review-Story:  I don't want to spoil anything about the story, basically you play as "Agent Carter", you're a member of a top secret organization that was originally intended to fight against the Soviet Union in the 1960's but a new threat reveals itself and you've been called to save the whole human race.while the story sounds pretty sterio-typical "save the humans, because you're a freaking super hero!" there were some very interesting twists and turns in the story, I highly recommend at least one play through on the easiest difficulty to at least see how the story unwinds.Game Play: As has been the theme, I started playing this game the wrong way. This game is more like a "turn based FPS", because you go into "strategy mode" which puts everyone in slow motion, and you give orders to your agents to do various attacks.This is the first Xcom game I've played, but I've been told the games tend to be very strategy oriented, ergo this is actually a black sheep of the Xcom family. As far as black sheep go... I found myself enjoying the story. I've been trying to finish the hardest difficulty which has opened a whole new world of hurt, but that's not important right now.The game is put in a 3rd person shooter perspective, but you will need to rely on your NPC allies, by giving them orders... flanking, upgrading technology, and various other things to take into consideration. The game is far more challenging than one might initially let on.  Achievements: Basic achievement categories: Beat the game, Do this new thing ___ amount of times, Beat the game on the hardest difficulty, do this thing differently, buy our DLC to get 100% on your achievements.Yes, this game requires you to buy the DLC, which as always, is very disappointing to see. but maybe someday I'll return to this game to get the DLC. But at this point I intend to try the hardest difficulty, if I can't beat it I'll call it good and pack it away and move on to another game, but I digress.Price: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is $19.99 I've spent 19 hours playing this game (10/11/14), I will probably put in about 5-6 more hours to beat the game again on the hardest difficulty (if I can make it), this game is worth its value, in my opinion. I got the game in a humble bundle, which I would recommend to anyone wanting to buy it, or at least wait for a steam sale of 50% or better. Conclusion: This game seems to be best played by someone who likes a mix of shooter and strategy. I found the game interesting and fun to play, but as I've said, to many who have played other Xcom games this is a black sheep.I recommend this game to someone who is looking to play a different styled shooter game. You could play through the game using your own shooting ability on the easiest difficulty if you wanted, the story itself will take only about 7-12 hours.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update December 30, 2014:Here's the URL to see my review for The Bureau: XCOM Hangar 6 R&D

content:
Posted: May 6, 2014
												If you haven't heard about this game, let me be the first to tell you that you aren't missing out. Do not buy it until it is on steam sale (which should be relatively soon at this rate). Here are a few reasons why I say this about The Bureau: XCOM Declassified: 1) The game is extremely buggy. I fell off the map into oblivion at least a dozen times for one reason or another. I even have a screenshot of it occurring and me simultaneously dying. Top this off with a few animation glitches, enemies not spawning or allowing you to progress, and you are setting yourself up for repeating some parts or entire battles in a mission. 2) It has an autosave feature only. No option like in XCOM: Enemies Unknown for what kind of save system you want. This is atrocious when mixed with all the bugs in the game aforementioned. 3) The game is disappointingly short. It took my crappy laptop longer to download the game than to actually play through it--and I completed every side/optional mission as well (My achievements are proof of that). 4) Your companions/troops are utterly useless to you. I have screenshots that show just how little they actually contribute to the mission. Hardly any kills, don't know how to use cover effectively, die too often, and literally run into grenades after avoiding them due to a slight time delay in their detonation. It is unbearably annoying, and doesn't improve as they level up. 5) After you get about halfway through the campaign, you just repeat the same tactics nonstop. This gets repetitive and detracts from the overall interest in the game. You defeat the enemies in the same methods over and over, and it doesn't leave you feeling like you accomplished anything truly. 6) Getting anywhere in the base is simply a pain in the ♥♥♥. You cannot sprint inside the giant labyrinth that is XCOM headquarters, so it takes forever to go from person to person to talk to anyone for missions. Also, there is a decontamination room in between the lab and the rest of the base. While this feature is neat to travel through the first couple of times, after about 30 times you start getting really agitated/impatient, really quick. 7) The storyline is not all that immersive for the player sadly enough. A few moral choices here and there, but in the end it is linear, monotonous, and unfulfilling. These are just a FEW of the issues I have had with this game. It was not worth the $45 that i paid for it, but I hope some of the other XCOM games I received with the pre-order bundle prove to be more worthwhile. I give this game a rating of "an out of this world letdown". This is mainly for all the hype it received, especially in comparison to its predecessor, and by definitely not meeting any of those expectations. Go play XCOM: Enemy Unknown instead--it has an expansion as well which will be a better investment for your money without a doubt.Edit: Since some people think I was/am "too harsh" in my review and believe all reviews or critiques must have positive aspects in them, I now need to make the following statement:If a game has a ridiculously overwhelming amount of negative aspects to it that far outweigh the scarce and miniscule amount of "positive" aspects within it, then they are simply not worth mentioning in a review. I played the entirety of this game to ensure readers that I make a THOROUGH review based on my impressions of the gameplay itself experienced firsthand. Most of the time my reviews tend to be positive even...however, this game was so insanely bad that I could not help but try to sway others to not waste their time like I did. Also considering I was one of the few people to pre-order this game based off of the beautiful game known as XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I needed to make sure I got my $45 worth out of this atrocity, no matter how terrible it truly is and forever shall be. I hope you all enjoyed my review and I thank you for your time reading it and this comment :) Hopefully, you do not make the same mistake I did in purchasing this game at a high price.TL;DR: The game is incredibly bad. Do not purchase. Ever. Unless on steam sale (75% off or more only applies here). Do not feed them more money for it at full price. Hell, the Steam Store Score (triple alliteration ftw) for this game should give you an alert to how bad it truly is if nothing else...some people like it...but far more do not care for the game in comparison--and for good reason.

content:
Posted: February 27
												Oh wow, does this poor game have issues.It doesn't know what it wants to be, and it doesn't know who it's trying to appeal to.At its core, this is effectively Mass Effect, but set in a weird alternate 60s XCOM universe. As a Third Person Shooter, it's too derivative and rough to appeal to TPS fans on its own merit. As an XCOM game, it deviates too much from the XCOM canon and gameplay for it to have much appeal to die-hard XCOM fans either. Where it racks up credit is in its story... however, that isn't plain sailing either. Essentially a story about a secret war against an Alien invasion that took place in 1962, it covers your perspective as Agent William Carter, as he gets sucked in to the conflict and finds himself on the frontlines. While it starts off great, the dev's complete boner for setting the game in the 60s and the general confusion of whether this game is a prequel or an alternate reboot create a number of issues and inconsistencies that the devs didn't have either the time or the skills to iron out. For instance, the game makes a big deal out of the 60s paranoia, in this case about alien infiltration... but when your own character starts manifesting paranormal abilities like levitating opponents and healing critical injuries, no-one bats an eyelid. It's not even brought up. Later on, the game tries to claim XCOM managed to cover up a countrywide alien invasion - complete with kilometre-tall alien citadels and whole fleets of UFOs - with some radio operators, a couple of helicopters and a few good men. Yeah, sure thing.From a technical and gameplay standpoint, it's a bit shaky. Weapon balance and challenge is all over the place, with the game insisting on limiting your ammo and dropping aliens behind you. Level design and graphics aren't bad, but rough edges are everywhere - e.g. lip syncing is weird, with everyone looking like they're speaking through gritted teeth. So the story is a bit sketchy, it can't work out what it is, and plays like a beta version of Mass Effect 1. Why did I give it a thumbs up?Because it does an amazing job of translating the tense, creepy atmosphere of XCOM into a TPS. There are very few games that try to depict an alien invasion as an X-Files style approach, and this actually manages it. Some of the missions actually felt like they'd directly transplanted some of XCOM:Enemy Unknown's levels directly into a TPS. The game feels like it runs a checklist of X-Files-style sci-fi - alien viruses, abductions, gadgets, government agencies, saving the world, paranormal abilities - it's all here, and the devs clearly enjoyed themselves weaving everything together. Despite it's rough edges, the story is surprisingly good - you genuinely don't see some of the twists coming and the finale is pretty spectacular. About the worst I can say is that it deviates so much from the XCOM canon that it might as well be unrelated. Still, if you're generally a fan of sci-fi, it shouldn't be an issue.If you're a fan of Mass Effect, XCOM, and X-Files.... then consider grabbing this in a sale. Just don't expect an XCOM:Enemy Unknown prequel (even though it starts playing the EU theme at end cinematic).

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												Like a fair number of other games today XCOM Declassified is a case of the mistaken identity.  Bureau is a great game solid 3D person action with surprisingly deep tactical elements, great visuals, and nice (for the pulp genre) story.  The problem is the game has a lot more in common with Mass Effect than with XCom.  Combat, squad management, agent powers, level design... everything is patterned after Mass Effect.  Even story really - loose team-building part, replace Reapers with Outsiders, replace indoctrination with infection... few more similar changes... put the whole thing on 1960s Earth = Mass Effect Deja Vu.The bottom line, if you are looking for an XCom game - you might as well pass.  If Mass Effect streamlined for combat missions and set in 60s sounds interesting - the game is more than worth the price tag.Note: Keep in mind the game really is tactical, on anything but the easiest difficulty expect to spend more of your time commanding the squad than pulling a trigger.

												I truly wanted to like this game.  After having played the excellent XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I had high hopes for this game.  The problem I have with this game is the squad AI. 												I wanted to give this game a chance. When i saw it being compared to mass effect i was intrigued, but ultimately i was left frustrated by gameplay mechanics that are at odds with each other. The Bureau wants you to use its squad command system so much, yet stacks all the odds against you by forcing you down a linear corridor of cramp combat areas with practically zero room to make any worthwhile tactical decisions. Even when you attempt to move your AI partners to flank an enemy, half the time they just get downed almost instantly by pinpoint accurate enemy fire. Add to that horrible weapons with small ammo capacity yet a LAUGHABLY abundant amount of ammo crates littered across the battlefield. The combat is just not fun in ANY way, shape, or form.It's a real shame because the story seemed to be pretty decent (minus the completely lifeless and uninteresting generic squad mates), but i just could not bring myself to push forward. I could forgive a game with solid and fun gameplay but a weak story, i would still have a fun time albeit with some regrets. This, however, is just a painful and frustrating experience.

												I loved this game. No idea why it's getting such a low average rating.The gameplay is sorta like Mass Effect, just with less progression steps for leveling up the classes. The difficulty is a very nice challenge on max, with most checkpoints quite adequately placed to not annoy you if you have to retry segments.Story wise it is fantastic, with a great twist I will not spoil. It is not letting you affect the story too much, so that may at some point turn people off a bit, but if you get over your desire to control it, the story is awesome regardless.Play-through length is good, for completionist and max-difficulty runs it goes long enough to feel it is worth its price, while still giving you the option to skip some parts or lower difficulty so you can speedrun the others on replay runs if you feel like it. Replayability is not huge but still it gives you good reason to go at it a couple more times and still enjoy it. But again, I think it's worth it even for a single play-through.The DLC alternative campaign is a good addition as well.
