content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												As a long time XCOM fan, I was uncertain about the direction of The Bureau.  Here was a series that I loved with strong tactical strategy roots that had influenced the genre for nearly two decades... and it's newest release was going to be a third-person shooter.  I assumed that the game was a way to use the XCOM name to cash in on yet another Call of Duty clone.  Fast forward a couple of years and I realized that I was wrong.The XCOM 2 announcement got me hyped up on the series once again and I decided that instead of playing through another war in XCOM: Enemy Within (which would've been a blast, even if it were my billionth war) I would try something new and actually give The Bureau a go.  It was a good decision.The story in the game is enjoyable, though it gets a little weird and unexpectedly complicated toward the end.  Base building doesn't make an appearance in this game, however, there is an XCOM base where you spend your time in between missions and it is quite well done.  Different scenes play out as you wander through the base depending on events that you've experienced and choices that you've made.  For example, after defeating each new enemy type that you run across you can often see them being studied (in one way ot another) in your laboratory.Combat, the meat and potatoes of this game, is significantly more fun than I had been assuming.  You issue commands to your squad mates (who come in Recon, Engineer, Support, and Soldier varieties) which include utilizing the abilities that they possess.  These squaddies level up and gain new abilities on a skill tree exclusive to each class that is reminiscent of XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  Two agents of the same class could use their abilities in different ways.The feel of the combat itself reminds me of Mass Effect 2.  The cover system, the use of alien abilities (some which are very similar to biotics), and even the large variety of weapons to choose from in the game and their varying strengths and weaknesses.  However, it can not be overstated that the AI in this game is less than amazing.  You'll find yourself micromanaging your agents often as they can't seem to utilize themselves to be anywhere near as efficient as when you hold them by the hand and tell them what to do.  On a few occassions, I watched in horror as one of my agents moved away from an enemy grenade, only to realize that the best cover was were that grenade was and return to it to his imminent death.All in all, this is a good game with plenty to offer that I recommend to XCOM fans and shooter/RPG fans alike.  As long as you can get past the AI it is a solid game with around a couple of dozen hours of content if you're playing on a difficulty level that challenges you.

												One of the most underrated game ever due to X-Com fans hating change. This is basically the Command and Conquer Renegade version of X-Com series.If you are into Agency/FBI like games you got to get this game. It is one of a kind. Not much games out there that is set like this one. Sure there is no stealth like Hitman series but, it is war.  You can say the same for Condemned series, but that is horror. I've seen far worst Agency like games than this, if anything it comes out on top of the list.Sure, there are a couple of issues with this game though. Here are some cons, but, they are very small.- Hold shift for running and cover at the same time can get you trap from running away from the wall(cannot be changed).- You need to press shift again to vault over.- Scanning is pointless in this game as there is no encyclopedia, even for DLCs to look back at for info. Other than that it is for a steam achievement for main game.- Hangar 6 DLC AK47 and Micro Wave Gun is not updated or cannot be accessed for Main storyline, they do not exists in the main story.There are some stuff you should know when you buy this game.a. There are no secrets to unlock, so don't bother scrolling around unless you want to read all the letters.b. "Hangar 6" DLC is a prequel to the game and should be played first before Main story.c. Code Breakers is an optional "Operation" that should be bought when discounted. It is just an extra mission for Main game(was a Pre-order DLC). Very Short.d. You cannot scan documents or letters.e. Do not buy Light Plasma Pistol DLC. I do believe one of the DLC's come with it. I don't remember how I got it. But I could access it in main game. I don't even have the Light Plasma Pistol DLC.f. You do not unlock anything at all for playing highest difficulty other than one steam achievement. As for DLC go ahead play Rookie mode and enjoy the story.There are also 4 endings for the Main Story line. So you can replay it 4 times or load back save checkpoint.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2016
												Personally I love the noir feeling of the game and how it takes place in the past rather than nowadays, or in the future. It isn't like the other XCOM games, which is a welcome change. I like the leveling up system, and that you can customize Carter and your squadmates, though more customization options would have been nice.The combat feels like Mass Effect, and has its own charm to it. I like the action mixed with having to use tactics. Battle focus is a neat thing as well if you want to know more about your enemies. Though sometimes the AI behavior can make combat a bit frustrating. It's pretty silly when I want to flank an enemy and I see my squadmate running towards me through the middle of the battlefield.The characters and missions are, to my mind, interesting. The information you get through the dialogues and documents adds lore to the XCOM universe. And I actually really enjoyed the main story. It had a neat twist. I liked the occasional choices you could make, even though they were quite insignificant, it did make some difference in a few aspects.I'd recommend this to anyone who is a fan of XCOM and doesn't mind the different approach!

Posted: February 3, 2016
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a vapid tactical TPP shooter.Unless you are a die hard XCOM fan, keep out.And even if you are, it'll most likely leave you dissatisfied.PROS:+ the setting+ little details(squaddies going on a smoke break if standing idle for a while, the protagonist's hat falling off his head when suffering major damage)+ the story has some cool twistsCONS:- the gameplay- imbalanced difficulty(once you get the hold of alien weaponry- the odds skyrocket in your favour)- very limited soldier customization- zero mission diversityI've completed the game for the sole reason of feeding my inner XCOM fanboy while waiting for the release of XCOM 2.The game starts slow and makes a horrible first impression.I couldn't resist the feeling that Declassified is suffering from a disturbing case of schizophrenia;not knowing whether it wants to be an action TPP title or a tactical cover-based shooter.It fails at both.Gotta admit- after pushing myself through the first 2 or 3 missions it started growing on me, mainly because of the awesome setting.However, it isn't enough to make The Bureau a good game.So much locked potential remaining.Would love to play a solid TPP XCOM shooter one day."Never half♥♥♥♥♥two things. Whole♥♥♥♥♥one thing." - Ron Swanson

number of helpful: 45 of 71 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is an interesting hybrid between a traditional third-person shooter and a strategic game, with elements of role-playing game; but the impression is a game crippled by a troubled production.It offers a glimpse in the history of XCOM through a tactical third person shooter, without becoming a simple mindless shooter. The Bureau requires a good amount of tactical thinking, which really makes it feel like a true XCOM game. Lack of strategy, however, might make the game less appealing to some XCOM fans, but the majority of players will revel in the tactical gameplay.The Bureau builds up adequately on a lot of ideas taken from XCOM. As a result it is entertaining and generally true to the XCOM canon but its potential is, more often than not, half-expressed. I like the fact that it forces teamwork, has a great atmosphere and solid graphics. The aliens tend to attack with various and difficult to kill forces from the beginning - that's good as well. Unfortunately later on the magic kind of disappears - the story becomes silly, fights get easier and the interface irritates more and more. But taking all things into consideration, The Bureau is a solid, well made game.Considering the game’s fraught development history and arguably ill-conceived premise, The Bureau is practically a best-case scenario.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												What a fantastic game.It's been a long time since I enjoyed a game more than this one. It's a great hybrid game where the "action" meets "rts" and it does a great great great job at it. There are quite some similarities with Mass Effect and Brothers in Arms playstyles.This game has everything you need:+Good graphics+Great voice acting+Amazing atmoshpere and world design+Ambient sound is top notch+Great story (I really really liked it. Liked how it unfolded, liked how it was told. Even when you start to think that you are at the very end - the game still continues with another twist in your face)+Game lenght. It's a decent ~12-15h long campaign (if you like to explore the world (even tho it's quite linear), do some side missions and so on).+Progression. In nearly every mission you will find some new gear to play with. That way everything stays fresh and the combat is always fun.+Enemy design. If you have played the other XCOM games, you will know what to expect, but it's very well done.+Difficulty. This game is not a cakewalk, especially at the very beginning. Prepare to get your whole squad killed at one point or another ^^ The only cons for me are:-A bit slow-paced at the very start. Especially, if you like to talk with every npc, read every note and so on - the early game might go on for ~2-4 hours. The very start of the game is probably the least fun (looking from the combat perspective, because you don't have many skills and perks and the guns doesn't do a lot of damage).-80% of the fights consist of: encounter several waves of smaller dudes, and then a big dude comes in to a play.This game is definitely underrated and I don't know why people give so many negative reviews about it. Just don't listen to them! This game is a gem if you enjoy 3rd person shooters or good games overall. Oh, and I didn't encounter a single bug throughout the whole playthrough.

Posted: December 24, 2013
												Extremely underrated squad based cover shooter. This was my sleeper hit of 2013. The story is a prequel to X-com Enemy Unknown and ties in directly to that game. Gameplay reminds me of Gears of War but with squad commands. I think this game got alot of hate because it was an Xcom shooter and many people wanted to hate it. There are also some lite rpg elements with leveling, squad choice and mini quests inbetween missions at the Xcom base.     Game isn't perfect, missions are very linear and disguised corridors, base stuff could have been better, story was alittle weak in the middle. The climax was amazing though both from a story perpective and gameplay.

												Whoever says this game is bad is just angry it's not a strictly TPS game. The OG XCOM games were not FPS they were turned base. Is this turn based? No, it's just a different take on the games. You play as a man and run around shooting aliens. It's fun. What you do with your teammates is what you do in all the old XCOM games, you tell them where to go and who to shoot. I don't see why people are complaining so much about the game. I find it really really cool what they tried and did here. I would say it's worth it, go look at the humble bundle right now and get it or look for free keys in the discussions or a game key website. Have fun!

												The Bureau is a rough diamond. It has many flaws but the thing it does right, it really does right. The weapons feel great, the tactics are deep and the story pulls you in with twists and turns. My only problem with the game is the friendly agents, they are very mediocre in combat and needs constant babysitting to function well. And most of the time the only two agents you will ever need is the soldier for his amazing taunt ability and the support for his support skills. If the game is on sale then i really recommend that you pick it up. Because it's not worth it at full price as it is a little on the short side, unless you're going for all achievements.

number of helpful: 13 of 14 people (93%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2016
Product received for free
												The game's industry sure loves to have its titles go through development hell sometimes. Aliens: Colonial Marines suffered this fate when Gearbox decided to use resources for Aliens on Borderlands 2 after seeing how successful the first one was. The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a similar story. This is a game which has exchanged hands within many internal 2K teams for half a decade while being put off to instead focus on Bioshock 2 after 2K saw how well the original Bioshock sold. However, unlike Sega’s sci-fi catastrophe, 2K’s sci-fi title is actually not horrible trash. In fact, it is very much playable. That being said, sometimes it is better to be trash quickly forgotten. It pains me to say that, after getting into the story and very much enjoying my time with the game, I cannot deny that The Bureau is still the very definition of mediocrity and deserves its 60% mixed Steam rating which I see as a “6/10”. For each moment I was enjoying this game, I was noticing a ton of wasted opportunity.  The story is pretty straight forward. Aliens from XCOM: Enemy Unknown have invaded in the 1960s instead of in present day. It is up to the player to lead a small squad of soldiers with unique abilities into heavily outnumbered situations and save humanity. The game’s cast is diverse enough to be interesting though they do very easily fall into overdone archetypes such as “hot-headed partner that shoots before he thinks”, and “commander that treats the mission with utmost importance”. Voice acting is good. The story of this game actually expands upon the lives and troubles of everyday people more than the other XCOM games do. The player will actively find notes and dialogue from people during various stages of the invasion and see how the aliens have ruined the lives of actual distinct people with their own small backstories which the player can choose to investigate, rather than generic NPC’s with no voice in the main strategy turn based games of the franchise that just get shot at the same way every time.However, those moments end up being merely window dressing or side show attractions for the otherwise extremely linear and generic (destroyed town, stereotypical high tech alien buildings, etc) levels in this 3rd person shooter. There really isn’t any interaction at all with everyday people you meet despite you seeing into their lives and one of the big themes of the game being about keeping the alien invasion a secret so that everyone on Earth doesn’t panic. In all the trailers and even the game’s cut scenes, the game emphasizes keeping the whole alien invasion under wraps while tricking the populace that it is in fact the communists which are attacking. Neat idea, horribly executed. Aside from people in the XCOM base mentioning efforts of spreading propaganda which you never see, and a few notes referencing it while on a mission, the idea is never expanded upon. So when the player sees whole towns destroyed by what are obviously extraterrestrials, the whole idea that XCOM is keeping everyone from finding out is ludicrous to say the least.Also speaking of protecting the entire Earth, aside from one potential Soviet (which doesn’t even end up mattering), literally every other character and member of your squad is American. One of the coolest parts of XCOM for me is the forming and growing of this elite global task force comprised of men and women from every country in the world. It made the conflict truly feel like I was fighting for the survival of the whole world and helped me differentiate between my various soldiers who all eventually became important characters in their own right in my XCOM Enemy Unknown/XCOM 2 playthroughs despite really just being randomly generated characters. For me heroes like specialist “Vapor” with her bandana and ranger “Athena” with her baseball cap from my XCOM2 playthrough will always be remembered.In this game on the other hand, everyone is a generic American. After going through the entire game with mostly the same soldiers, I can’t remember a single one’s name or even what they look like.  The original gameplay demo showed off in 2010 of this game showed off a first person shooter with investigation elements. The player was shown taking pictures and analyzing scenes of alien attacks. Sadly, there is no such gameplay element in this version of The Bureau. All you do is walk from point A to B killing all aliens in your path while the lab back in home base magically finds out how to use alien tech without any input from you at all. This kills off a lot of the progression in the other XCOM games which made the acquisition of new gear so rewarding. In this game you just find it on the field lying there for you to pick up without any prior knowledge or training on how to use the weapon.Now gunplay is just like your generic 3rd person shooter. The weaponry on offer honestly starts off very weak with just basic American guns of the 60s at your disposal. They don’t feel satisfying to shoot and don’t do that much damage. 50% of Steam players failed to beat the first level. That should be telling of how boring the gunplay is at first. However, if you stick at it, eventually you will gain access to alien weaponry, and those guns do feel much more powerful and rewarding to use (Even if they are just “alieny” laser versions of Earth weapons). The main meat of the gameplay is instead in the tactical mode where you can issue various commands to your squad mates such as moving to a specific location or using an ability at a target location such as putting a shield dome or a turret down. Some people find this to be gimmicky but I found that for the most part it works alright. For some reason the command marker moved like a regular unit so would be blocked by walls and stuff but that’s a minor annoyance. It was actually fun to micromanage all my units during heated battles, especially the later ones where a few mistakes can easily wipe your whole squad out.Now onto the main complaint of most people and why this game deserved to be “mixed” on Steam. Squad AI is not good. When playing on lower difficulties where you and your squad mates can still die very very easily, but will be ready to fight again after a simple co-op game style “push e for a few seconds to revive”, the bad AI isn’t too much of an annoyance. But on harder difficulties where a revive only stabilizes squad mates I honestly think the game is borderline impossible. With the AI constantly making your squad mates being open to enemy fire and there not being any option to let your squad mates auto their abilities, aka you must babysit them all the time, while enemies charge you in real time I don’t see anyone having fun playing the higher difficulties. In fact, I salute the 1.5% of players who were able to stomach the cancer such an experience would entail and beat the whole game. So then what is wrong with playing it on a lower difficulty? Simply that it ceases to be an XCOM game at that point and becomes more of a very very poor man’s Mass Effect. In fact, that is basically what I am trying to get at. The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is an above average generic 3rd person shooter about aliens invading America, not all of Earth, in the 1960s. It is not a true XCOM game. I recommend it only during a sale for anyone looking for a fun 3rd person shooter that isn’t expecting too much. Die hard XCOM fans will probably enjoy the added lore (which doesn’t really make sense since wouldn’t the modern XCOM know of aliens if they invaded in the 60s) and hate everything else this game represents. Now that I look back at it. Yes, I did have fun. But I also recognize this game is just 2K milking the XCOM franchise.Also it runs fine on my R9 390x maxed out. But DirectX11 mode causes graphical flickering issues.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Suffering from a heavy case of casual and consolitis, the Bureau is the result of a lengthy development hell. A mediocre shooter for the masses that bears the X-COM name without including any of the things that makes X-COM, X-COM. Mainly that missing element is depth.Features have been either overly simplified or cut entirely to fit the forced mold of a 3rd person cover based shooter. So you have no base building, researching or resource management. Capturing aliens is now a plot point, alien weapons can be used as soon as they're found, soldiers have a generic pre-assigned personality stopping you from making up your own backgrounds for them, and so on. Squad size is now also limited to 3 and the main character can't die. The level progression is also screwed up which means the game gets easier as you progress. There's no tactic to anything, just spam everything you've got.So one wonders what was the point in making this game and calling it X-COM. You could argue that it's easier to move the game with brand recognition but I bet you the audience of this game doesn't even know or care what X-COM is. The Bureau was made by 2K Marin whose previous outing was Bioshock 2, a game set in the same time period, making alot of the assets feel reused aswell. The writing is mediocre and boring so I ended up skipping most of the dialoque as a result.The Bureau is the bad of Mass Effect and Bioshock rolled into one.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2016
												Graphics 10/10Story 8/10gameplay 9/10elements 7.5/10overall: 8.5/10graphics: graphics are amazing, polished like a third person bioshockstory: the game is rather confusing at first and somewhat fails to retain a coherent flow however towards the end the game starts to intermittently make sense. The game does well with illustrating a mutual story with the protagonist  vs the antagonist i.e. the bad guys can be seen from a positive perspective instead of them just being savages. Overall the story has mystery and a few choices that make the game interesting enough to want to finish.gameplay: the game has a blend of strategy and cover to cover combat. Once you get used to it this happens to be a fun way to fight instead of just point and shoot. cool weapons and nice perks.elements: by elements i mean voice acting, AI, hud, and other somewhat significant aspects of the game I feel can make the game fun or awful. The Ai is pretty decent but your teammates can be ♥♥♥♥tards sometimes. voice acting is good at times and bad at times, nothing enough to make the game annoying. the HUD blends very well with the game and is easy to understand; it also fades so you can enjoy the graphics more.I enjoyed the game because the gameplay is interesting and fun, the campaign is good not great, snd it looks beautiful. A pretty good game to get on sale.

content:
Posted: January 30, 2016
												Is XCOM version of the Mass Effect good?Yes it is but could be even better. Graphic is really nice not best though,but doesn't feel like old game. Level design and envrioimental story-telling is simply amazing,there are story bits laying around the map so you can learn more about the game lore and each map is unique and fun to explore even though they are very linear. There is so many little details that wandering through your base after every mission always feels fresh.  Be it a simple npc chat or new props laying around, simply game feels more alive. Sounds and music are top tier, reloading is so satysfying with that "bing" if you know what i mean. Music is also very nice to hear. Animations in this game fluid and smooth. Its the first thing I always look at in the game, its animations of the characters. You can feel how your characters moves under the certain conditions, you can feel that *weight*. Story? Is not bad, it kept me entertrained through the entire gameplay, each character was memorable and interesing to talk to. And ending? Despite its missing a boss battle it was more satysfying with the multiple choices at the end. Not to mention that little secret which was really interesting and I didn't see that coming.Tactical gameplay? Yes there is and its not bad at all. AI respondds properly to your orders, use cover efficiently and is not stupid. There is a little too much of micromanaging later in game but it pays off if you are a good tactician. You have 5 classes, which 4 are only locked for your teammates and you can customize your 3man squad ( inlucding you and your own perk set ), there is definitely a lot of room for strategies. In my game I went with commando (aka tank) and engineer and I was suprised I was able to combine abillities several abillities together.For example Engineer was placing a turret, but enemy was behind the cover. I lifted the turret up ( thanks to your psy abillities ) and it could fire while floating in the air. I could also order a commando to *shield* the turret with his abillities to make my turret stay alive for a little bit longer.There is also a blind-shoot , where you can shoot blindly from behind the cover, and this is what XCOM EW could use. Blind shooting and combining several solider abillities together. Not to mention that when you issue orders , character talks and people respond to you. Its a small thing but I appreciate this kind of stuff. Games feels a little bit more alive.Now some minuses: This game would be even better if you could manage your base, yeah you are leader of the strike team not the base so it makes sense. But maybe in the next game . . .? AI companions are getting stuck sometimes.  Not many enemy variety, I was hoping to see some bugs  Some items felt useless, especialy backpacks. There is way too many of them and I endep up using only the first one from the beginning through my entire game. console-port feel, a slight but still clunky sometimes. But play fine with the mouse+keyb  A bit short for XCOM game? 15 hours? Its not bad but game could use more side-mission and improvent system for side-ops for your soldiers. FPS problems in certain areas and slow downs , and also phyX never worked for me because it was crashing my game always. Had to disable it entirely to play smoothly.Maybe this game was not worth at the premiere release but now? For few bucks? Definitely worth it, you can even replay it on the higher difficulties and try different setups/builds. Just don't buy DLC because they are useless.I would rate this game 7.5/10

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												Let me start by saying that I am *not* a "purist" when it comes to the XCOM franchise.  I didn't play the originals and only started playing XCOM when I played the initial reboot from 2013 (which is an amazing game).I looked at a number of the reviews of this game and saw a lot of anger about it that seem to sound off more about what it isn't rather than was it is.What it is not:-It's not the classic XCOM style of play.  Know this first.  Go in knowing that, and you're off to a good start.-It's not turn-basedWhat it is:-About the closest I can come to describing it is that it plays a lot like "Mass Effect" using the XCOM universe's storyline-It's a prequel to the classic XCOM games that occurs in the 1960's.-It's like "Mad Men" but with guns-It's third-person real time squad based combat.-It's a definite challengeThis game isn't as engaging as the 2013 XCOM reboot, but it's still a boatload of fun.  I haven't fully completed it at the time of writing this review, but I'm truly enjoying "nibbling" on it a couple of times a week.  I play a mission or two at a time, then come back to it later.I am using Xbox One controller with my PC configuration and this game makes excellent use of full controller capability.If you're a fan of Mass Effect style games and like the XCOM storyline, this game is a real gem to own.  Again...judge it for what it is, not what it isn't.-Hitman

content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												Metacritic score (~67) is not that far off. Not impressed so far, although I'll update my recommendation if my opinion changes. It's not that the game is terrible, but it gives lots of hints about the game that it wishes it could be, but fails to be. And I think I would like THAT game more than I like this cover-based third-person real-time-strategy shooter hybrid that can't make up its mind on what it wants to be and ends up second rate at either.The things that the devs put a lot of effort and care into look/work great. Unfortunately, those things don't seem to encompass quite enough, and not in the most key areas. Examples: When you go into the AI-teammate command mode, time doesn't stop, it only slows down to something like 25% speed. The writing is... um, not the worst, but I'm bored of these people already and I only just met them. AI's kind of dumb early on, although supposedly later on in the game it stops feeling like escort missions and they actually hold their own.It's not without its good elements. I like the setting itself; care definitely went into that, if not necessarily the dialogue. Where it's not a dark corner with fog and darkness covering up the extremely flat and featureless textures in unimportant corners and other corner-cutting measures, the world looks decent. The promise of what it could be/could have been is still a significant part, however.It'd probably be a fun multiplayer co-op game, to be honest. Ditch the AI and just choose different classes and run through a campaign with 2-3 of your friends.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2015
												-- Foreword - 3D VISION --First of all I have to clarify that I played The Bureau completely with NVidia's 3D vision and used a fix by the community to enhance the quality of it. If you do not know 3D vision check out NVidia's forum: https://forums.geforce.com/default/board/49/. What's the point of 3D vision? It changes the immersion you feel in a game. Characters are a bit outside of the screen and hallways in the game have a realistic deepth; that means it goes deep into your wall. It is like watching through your screen. It is something you have to check out yourself  as it is difficult to be explained. Do not make the mistake and compare it to 3D movies. The deepth and convergence is very different. It is more the kind of 3D you will see with the Oculus Rift or the HTC Vive.-- Substance of the game --First of all, I have to admit that I needed quite some time to get into the mechanics. So I stopped playing the game after 4 hours when I first started it one and half years ago, knowing at this time however that I want to retry it again someday in the future.This weekend it was this day and I got hooked this time and played through it in three days.-- What are the pros and cons? --Pros: - Great atmospheric setting, great story, great characters, great voice-acting- Decent graphics with very good science fiction design- A great variety of coloufull lights- It's the 50s! Everyone in the game looks very classy- Rewarding and satisfying combat system - First playthrough around 20 hours- Replayability because of the combat system and different difficulties - Decent skill system- A lot short well-written readings within the game that give you some background information of the storyCons:- AI of your squad:-->Let me explain: it might not be a big issue if you play on easy but it is going to be very frustrating on the harder difficulties; actually it was also the AI of my fellow combattants that stopped me from playing the game the first time. If you have the feeling a combat is too demanding change the difficult settings. It is possible during every fight.-->What's the issue? The AI sometimes is just not holding cover correctly. The combat system is missing commands about what the AI should do at a specific place you move one of your two characters. Sometimes it would just be better for your squad members to stay in cover and let you do all the hard work. But they always decide to get out of the cover and shoot the enemies, but not going back to cover in time so they brutally injured.- Level-UP system finishes for your main character at level 10 and for your squad members at level 5 - I could imagine a Game+ with more levels and maybe even more variety in skills- Dispatch missions are good to level up but not really fun because there is no interaction whatsoever- Story in the beginning a bit confusing***==> Conclusion: very atmospheric real-time strategy shooter with issues in the AI. Combat system is easy to learn and difficult to master with some very frustrating moments. Unique game in design and story.==> Rating: 8/10 (without 3D vision 6.5/10)

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												7 / 10. In short words: If you like XCOM:Enemy Unknown and it's former, ancient games, you won't like this.If not, you might like it.Beautiful graphics, but gameplay gets repetitive really quick, and the story stops getting interesting in the middle of the game. And the endings are letdowns. If it wasn't for a single good story part, I'd consider this 'wasted time'.There's no research or reverse engineering - which is what XCOM has been about since always. All you have to do is pick up enemy weapons and that's it. Nerd note: Remember that in XCOM, alien weapons are rigged to self-destruct if the owner dies, only rarely they fail to self-destruct. Also, they have DNA scanners, so the weapons cannot be immediatelly used by a race different than the one it's programmed for.Gameplay and dialog seems to have beem mimicked from Mass Effect, which would be a good thing if it didn't feel WAY too similar. XCOM base - which should be the most interactive and fun part of the game IMO - is just an interactive menu with sidequests, and nothing affects the game's ending. Even saving a fellow agent (which you can fail to do so) makes no impact in the game at all.The mix of FPS, squad management in the field and tactical combat is very fun, however. Unfortunately, it gets repetitive quickly. And your squadmates are, like the plot, expendable.For XCOM fans: while it IS fun to explore and see the XCOM universe in first person, you will feel tired and uninterested if you expect the same experience from other XCOM games.It is also very weird how quickly things go south for humanity and how everything seems to fall apart in days, in comparison to other XCOM games. You have to let that go to get any fun from it.

content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												I've had a few friends in my time. Shocking, I know. And therefore, I'm well-acquainted with a certain type of friend. Let me paint a picture here. He's always had your back, always been there when you needed him, but he has a couple of really, really painfully annoying quirks. For instance, remember that time a fly entered your flat? He just wouldn't shut up about it. It's always something small, something minor, but he ensures you pay the closest attention to it, regardless of how meaningless it actually is.Well, today I made such a friend in The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. Agent Carter is the kind of guy who's the first to let you know he won five bucks in the lottery, there's a strange car going by, or a slightly interesting sesame seed happens to be on his burger bun. How do I know this, you ask? Because that's the Bureau experience! Pass the 100th enemy craft in the past five minutes? Carter's right there, with an, erm, clever "WHAT IS THIS THING?" He always brings along two of his best friends who are personified in exactly the same way, fear not."Biggles," I hear you cry. "We get it. He's lame. But a character does not a game make! How can you possibly justify this negative review on one thing?"What a rude line of questioning! I found Carter unlikable from moment one, making, as I play through, it very hard for me to find him sympathetic enough to NOT walk him into enemy fire if only so he'll stop talking for one bloody second. But, okay. You want more complaints? Oh, I was picking out the mildest one and hoping this review could turn out somewhat nice.I suppose I do have one nice thing to say: the plot has a few mildly compelling elements.Erm, that's about it.Really? I have to do this? Fiiiine.Let's start with the most glaring sticking point: optimization. This game supposedly runs on Unreal Engine 3, which is a downright shame. I've never encountered an instance before where UE3 results in optimization this bad. It maxed out my reasonably high-end system despite looking like a 4-year-old console title. Even worse, despite this, it lags comparably to me on an early morning. I had to turn settings down considerably on a GTX 770 and hyperthreaded quad-core CPU to get the blasted game to stop stuttering. I could understand this if the title presented an interesting aesthetic or impressive visual fidelity, but it just... doesn't. It's going for 50s sci-fi, but missing the mark. A grain filter and some art deco font doesn't sell me on the concept, and that's all we have going here.The gameplay sadly doesn't make up for any of this. It's the most very boring and generic of shooters, masked by a faux-squad-strategy "mode". Sounds cool enough, sure, but it just doesn't work in practice. The game doesn't actually pause, rather slow down upon entering its "command mode or whatever", which means you're often left directing the game's AI to do tasks while you sit behind cover simply to avoid getting hit. Your own squadmates fail to take cover on their own, leading to a lot of stop-start gameplay, with no real payoff. Even worse, the enemy AI is as clever as your team. Nothing here provides a glimmer of interesting challenge.I simply can't recommend this game. I'll finish it, I'm stubborn like that, and this is very much a first impression, but I can't see this game lifting itself out of the rut it's so totally committed to burrowing. Whatever elements it introduces from this point, it will remain a buggy, poorly-optimized, generic shooter-with-a-gimmick. And to make matters wor-"WOAH, SOMEONE DIDN'T LIKE SOME GAME.""WHAT HAPPENED TO IT?""WHAT WENT WRONG?"OH SHUT IT, CARTERUPDATE 7/17:I did finish it. No, it didn't ever really get better.I enjoyed mildly the game's late plot twist. Though it was predictable, it was presented well.In the interest of not typing another 4 paragraphs of vitrol AS I WOULD VERY MUCH LIKE TO DO, let's leave it at "I didn't enjoy anything else, and the gameplay managed to get even worse."

number of helpful: 21 of 32 people (66%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 8, 2015
												A vapid, soulless ripoff of Mass Effect done extremely poorly, with the XCOM name slapped on it as if that's going to make it any better.The plot is completely ridiculous and is set up as some sort of prequel to the Firaxis XCOM games. Problem with that being that there are only token references to anything XCOM, with it becoming more and more obvious that it's a cynical cash-in the further into the game you get. Even if you remove the notion of it being an XCOM game entirely, the plot is absurd and extremely poorly-written, from the humans just "somehow" being able to hotwire alien doors down to the headdesk-inducing stupidity of the major plot twist. The main character is effectively "Gruff Growly McGrowlson" without any personality or noteworthy traits other than "he's a grizzled veteran." None of the other characters are interesting in any fashion, instead all being cardboard cutouts that exist purely to have NPC's around to move the plot forward.The AI, both friendly and enemy, is incredibly stupid. It's not at all uncommon for your guys to run directly into enemy fire, expose themselves entirely to said enemy fire even when sitting "in cover," get stuck on things, and so on. You're constantly having to give them orders and engage healing just so they won't get themselves killed. Enemies aren't any better, though at least they throw grenades on occasion to try to flush you out.The shooting mechanics are functional at least, but they're nothing more than that. The weapons themselves aren't satisfying to use, and the shooting itself is just your normal cover-based shooting that you've seen in Gears of War or Mass Effect... just completely unrefined and unpolished.The game's riddled with glitches and other technical problems, some of which are hilariously nonsensical. For example: it's an NVIDIA-optimized game, yet turning on NVIDIA's PhysX functionality causes the game to crash every single time you try to play it, until you disable the feature. Tons of animations glitches, sound bugs, and so on pop up all the time. Sometimes entire lines of dialogue are missing entirely, as if they just couldn't be bothered to implement them due to time constraints or something.It should be noted that this game started life as an FPS. More specifically, it started off as something that looked like a really crappy version of BioShock, yet was eventually retooled into what we have now, which is a garbage Mass Effect ripoff. There's no creative drive here. No soul. It's just a game that was cobbled together to complete a contract and be a cynical cash-in on the series' popularity. Except, nobody wanted it. Fans of XCOM want more XCOM. They don't want this crap.Needless to say, the game is awful. Don't buy it. Don't even look at it. Just let it be forgotten, as it should've been in the first place. If this weren't branded as if it's an XCOM game, it would've been completely swept under the rug as "just another crappy ripoff." Let that be so.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2014
												I tried to give it a chanceI honestly did. I went into it expecting a decent game that just used X-com names, and after all, it can't be worse than X-com Enforcer, now could it?Well, it can. Enforcer had its over the top, fast paced shooting with loads of weapons to amuse you. The Bureau has chest high walls to protect their chest high walls that you can sit behind.I only got about 3 hours in until I just plain could not play any more. With poor controls(Very obviously a console port that they didn't care enough about to make it work for PC), and absolutely awful AI. Several times have I seen the AI just run right into the open without any cover without any prompting whatsoever, and several more times did I wonder if the AI actually follows your commands or knows what end of their gun to point at the enemy. After some experimenting I found the answers to these questions.No, they do not know what end of their gun goes to the enemy, and they do not understand 'go sit in cover here so I can flank them' either. And speaking of flanking, you will need to do it. For the first few minutes I wondered why the aliens had titanium skulls, but then I realised a headshot and a torso shot are about the same. You get a flat damage bonus if you flank your opponent though. Good concept - but it just doesn't work with the braindead AI and clumsy controls. It isn't actually explained anywhere either, so unless you're quick to figure things out you'll blow all your ammo on an alien who is 'in cover' but still sticking most of his head and torso out for you to shoot(And deal nearly no damage because of this 'cover'), get frustrated, and quit.The story seemed interesting enough and I did want to see what was next, but I just can't justify spending more time on it than I already have. The story just can't carry the rest of the game and I can't really care enough to play further.Oh, and the glass physics were pretty good. It was nice to see parts of the glass shatter under fire without the whole window immediately collapsing. If only that attention to detail could have been spend on the rest of the game as well it may have been good

number of helpful: 15 of 21 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Note: To see this review in its true form (screenshots,formatting and such) go to: http://wildwoodgeek2.blogspot.com/2014/04/game-bureau-x-com-declassified.htmlThe Bureau: X-Com Declassified is a third person shooter/rpg that tries to mix Mass Effect and X-com in one package, the problem is it doesn't really do ether very good. in the game they try to have choices and real outcomes, but in the end they really don't do much. also the enemies are your standard "invader" kind of stuff, you know little green men, commanders that give shield upgrades, heaver troopers, big brutes, mechs, and really low HP suicide... blobs. where are the Thin men, the Chrysailids, or the cyber discs? or how about the alien cyborgs like in enemy unknown? my real big problem with the game is the fact that a lot of the weapons, buildings, and aircraft don't seem to be from the same universe as the Aliens in X-com: Enemy within and X-com: Enemy unknown. The player's character is annoying to say the least, his voice is the most generic "im a bad♥♥♥♥♥gruff" ever. they lines he says are cheesy and ridiculous. i seriously expected him to say something along the lines of "I'm here to kick♥♥♥♥♥and chew bubble gum... and i'm all out of bubble gum". and his back story? "oh his wife and kid burned alive in a fire, and because of that he gets drunk, so yeah".the Story its self is once again generic and pretty mild. "go here, do this!" oh and aliens! another thing it suffers from is the fact that a lot of it doesn't make sense. so the 1950 X-com didn't tell the 2013 X-com "oh yeah, aliens? they exist. also they hate us." why does the 2013 X-com know  nothing about what happened in 1950? why didn't the 1950 X-com give the 2013 X-com all the info they got in the field? also what the heck is with the zombies?!  there are no chrysalids to be found, so where did they come from? later on you learn that they are "sleepers", a zombie like human the aliens can control but then we are still left with the question, why? we see that with this they can put sleeper agents in the governments of the world, but why do it to random civilians that just become unaware of whats going on around them? what do they have to gain by doing that?  during the game your squad members will "hot wire" alien doors. how do they know how to do that? have they already fought aliens and know how to hot wire their doors? why is none of this explained? even if they burned everything related to the 1950 X-com how would they hide all of the destroyed towns? the huge craters? the sudden end of hundreds of family lines? in the beginning mission the top of a mountain is torn into chucks and floats above it surrounded in blue light, how could anybody NOT see that?game play itself is pretty annoying, almost all of it is hallway shooter kind of stuff, why not give us a more open-world? The fact that you can go into slow-mo and order your troops to do things gives it a little classic X-com feel, but in the end its like they didn't focus on the shooting game play, or the world. and that brings us to another problem, the World in this game. the world feels.... wasted. you know how Bioshock Infinite really made you feel like you where in a 1930s/40s world? with the Music and the surroundings? well this game has none of that. most the world is copy and paste, and the bits that aren't are covered in the stupid alien walls and buildings. and those things are 100% copy and paste. so in the end it makes a lot of the world feel like it was used over and over. to top it off there are invisible walls EVERYWHERE! "oh you can't jump over the crack in road sir! its too damn high!" one more thing, the weapons in this game sound and feel like pea-shooters none of them have that "bang" or "high pitched crack" to them. most people might not care about that but after coming from games like Battlefield 3,4 and Payday 2, it really is annoying.in a some-what hilarious outcome the game suffers from two of the annoying problems that Mass Effect had,  Your Choices in end they lead to a "good" or "bad" ending, thats its really, do this and you get a epic ending where lots of people live and everyone is happy, do the other and everyone dies... other choices don't feel like they changed much, and  guns magically appear in your hand during cutscenes, in the ME series we had the magic Avenger, in The Bureau: X-com Declassified we have the mighty M1-grand.in the end did any of us really expect a game that was killed and revived three times to be any good? didn't we learn from nuke-dukem? i feel like the game would be super epic if it was another turn-based game but set in the 50s. that would a great game. because this game is like taking Age of empires and turning it into a RPG/Third person game. and even if it was good the fans don't want a RPG or a third person game they want a X-com game! they want punishing turn-based gameplay. not this shooter crap.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2015
												tl;drSo, I 100%'d this game for Achievements.  It would probably take me about 10 less hours, but idling in menus added a bit.  If you're going for achievs, this is an easy game to get them all in... The only other time I would suggest this game is if you're a HUGE fan of XCOM and you NEED the lore.  5/10Long ReviewAlright, this game is rough.  It's like the developers of Mass Effect wiped their♥♥♥♥♥with the extra funding they had from the ME series, and churned out a♥♥♥♥♥♥show of a game called The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.This.  Is.  Rough.  The worst part is, you can often times see the potential this game has.  It's a game that WANTS to be good, WANTS to be a fan service... But it falls flat so, so early.  The main character is a boring, rude, monotone agent who constantly bounces between "caring", and "shut up, we have a job to do".  His "personality" actually adds to the overall failure of this game, I feel.  The cover system is atrocious.  You are either super glued to your cover, or you can't get into cover, on a game solely based around Third-Person Cover Shooting.  Like I said, Mass Effect with a pennies worth of funding.  That gets really infuriating when you're on the highest difficulty and some of the enemies advance to flank you, and you're bashing the multitude of buttons to get off cover and nothing is happening.  The abilities are boring and unimagitive...  Once again, comparing to Mass Effect, they pretty much ripped off the abilities.  Lift, Pulse Wave, Weaken...  Jeeeeeeeeeeeez.  The guns are all boring, with little personality in each one.  I could beat the game using the M1911 pistol, to be honest, since it seems to deliver one hell of a headshot.  In fact, most of the guns feel like they do NOTHING.  You're tickling a Sectoid with your Scatter Laser.  wat.  Running around the HQ QUICKLY becomes tedious.  You have to run back and forth, back and forth, etc. etc.  Pros:XCOM LoreA nice "old school" feeling... They did somewhat decent on thatInteresting view into some of the aliensKilling an alien every now and then results in some funny physicsDecent graphics and audioCons:Terrible controlsBoring abilities and gunsTedious legwork in the HQSticky or repelling coverRepetitive gameplay to the maaaaaaaax.  Trying out new guns, new squaddies, or new ability combos don't add at to the experience at all.Go play XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within, or any of the older XCOM's.  They'll probably offer the same lore in a different style, and they will actually be good.

content:
Posted: January 26, 2016
												Short version: I quite enjoyed this game despite its mixed reviews; I would recommend it to anyone who's a fan of the XCOM franchise and third-person shooter games.Short, short version: Is good game.  You buy.Longer version: When I bought this game I went into it noting the 'Mixed' status and numerous less-than-enthusiastic reviews, thinking it to be one of those games I could ignore for a while and then install and play when I was bored enough.  In fact I played through a number of other games before getting to it.I was surprised to find it both engaging and enjoyable.  A few people have said it has certain... similarities, shall we say, to the Mass Effect series and I'd have to agree.  It's a cover-based 3PS which involves a lot of hitting Space and going into slo-mo, issuing orders and flanking enemies.  It also has a radial conversation menu and various forms of pseudo-magical technology (most pertinently telekinesis and mind control).  Not only that but one of the squadmates' voices is done by Brandon Keener, who voiced Mass Effect's inestimable Garrus Vakarian (and he's not the only one; Courtenay Taylor, who voiced Angela Weaver in this game, also voiced Jack in the ME series - and there are plenty of others).  So that was nice.From a story perspective it has plenty of depth for what it is: a 60s themed alien invasion game.  This isn't Shakespeare and there's no point expecting it to be.  The whole story is based around giving you excuses to go out and shoot aliens and really, isn't that what you bought the game for?What the story doesn't have is complexity.  Don't bother looking for interpersonal nuances in this one because the conversation choices at most boil down to 'be nice' and 'be an a-hole,' with no difference in the outcome.You can't choose your character - or, at least, you can't at first.  You play through most of the game as Agent William Carter, a generic gravelly-voiced white dude with a tragic backstory who at least lacks stubble.  Later in the game you get to make a choice between playing for a little as one of three other characters but there's no character creation (or, for that matter, character development) in this one.The landscape is pleasing to me.  Sometimes you're in town, at other times you're in the middle of alien bases.  Sometimes it's both.  Wherever you are, though, the art style remains recognisably XCOM.  Running through alien architecture at eye level where normally you'd be directing a squad from above is definitely a novel approach.The UI is a little cumbersome at times but, having said that, I'm not entirely sure how I'd recommend the developers could have done it differently.  It works, it gets you through the game and it's not enough to drag you out of the game so hey, I could handle it.Mechanics are very simplfied in some ways - there is no research or XCOM base inventory, for example.  You pick up a weapon, you collect it for use by anyone in your squad who's trained to use that item type (anyone skilled in pistol use can wield a plasma pistol, for example, even if you've only ever picked up one of them).  There's no armour (though you can wear 'backpacks' and some of them do indeed reduce enemy damage).And this is the point: The Bureau is not like other games in the XCOM series and some people find that jarring.  If you want turn-based squad mechanics with research, base inventories and other stuff like that, go to a different XCOM game (or wait for XCOM2).  This is not what you're looking for.  This is something different.If, however, you're happy to play a 3PS game set in the same universe (if much earlier) with a story that doesn't require you to make notes on what choices you've made, this is a good one.

number of helpful: 14 of 20 people (70%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2015
												I still believe that it is possible to make a good FPS themed X-COM game... and maybe someday, someone will actually do that.  This, on the other hand, is the poster-child for "Cheap Console Port" and the very definition of a "Cash Grab."It's pretty obvious that someone was working on a random cover-shooter game when someone from marketing came in said "Hey, we just bought the rights to use the X-COM name!  So go and redo whatever you're working on to have some X-COM references in it, ok?"  In their frustration, the programmers then spent the last couple of months of development time spackling a thin veneer of X-COM over their product, rather than just finishing what they started and making sure it worked right.The end result was a this embarassing mess: Like the unfortunate cat from the Pepe Le Pew cartoons, this is very obviously a completely different game that got a quick stripe of X-COM painted over it's back and now the marketing skunks are trying to convince us that it's the real deal.Also, even a cursory look through the YouTube archieves shows a completely different game was originally planned - one that seemed far more interesting.  A game based on investigation, mystery, and uncovering secret plots.  Apparently that game got shelved, sadly, and instead they just pulled this game off the shelf and deceptively put it in the same box.Like I said, I'm not some "tactical purist" who thinks that an FPS X-COM is some kind of heresey.  I think it can be done.  I think it should be done.  Most of all, I believe that it can and should be done right.  Sadly, this game doesn't even come close to making the mark.  Maybe someday, someone will get it right.

content:
Posted: March 26
												I've  had quite a story with the game. My first encounter with the series was with XCOM Enemy Unknown. I loved the game and universe. I never bought The Bureau game on the release since it got bad critical reviews and had known stability issues. Screenshots and trailers also didn't make it easy to understand how the game plays.I decided to give it a try since I really enjoyed my first experience with XCOM Enemy Unknown and I love the era they chosen for The Bureau.I was really disappointed because the game wouldn't run. At the time I didn't want to figure out why the game was closing just over the minute after the launch of campaign and made a refund.The last sale I decided to give the game another chance but only because I figured that most issues were ironed out. I was wrong. The game didn't want to play longer than 1 minute. This time I really wanted to play the game and decided to solve this issue.Hopefully people found a few solutions in forums I could try to make the game run. Basically what others discovered PhysX caused crashing in most cases but my game wasn't really crashing. It was closing after a minute. I didn't know why but I had a hunch. I remembered another game had similar issue. The problem was in anti-piracy software it used which was outdated and had conflicts with OS. I though I would give this idea a try and use unconventional way to playI ran the game and played for a few hours. It never closed on me. I can't say I was surprised. Seems like I figured it out right and the anti-piracy software was causing troubles. I must say that beside steam there is another layer of protection which is most likely caused the issue.Downside is that I couldn't track my play time and achievements with Steam which is really unfortunate since I paid for the game. But at least I could play it this time.The game itselft surpassed my expectations and I enjoyed it very much. I love the combat system in XCOM Enemy Unknown but with The Bureau you have a chance to play it almost real time and from first person and the story was good too! If you didn't rush and had all possible conversations, read notes and listed to various records the game really gives you an in-depth look into what happened in there.The graphics are very good and stylish for the era too. I especially loved forest and space missions. It was cool to see where XCOM took it roots from.The ending was very satisfying too. You even have a few choices how you want it to end. I tried a few just for fun to see the outcomes and wasn't disappointed.This is very good XCOM game from 1st person perspective with great elements of strategy and skill. I played it on maximum difficulty level and was challenged enough to make my victories satisfying. Never lost a soldier. Had quite a few desperate situations but now I have something to remember fondly.I would very much recommend the game. It's unfortunate that it still has technical issues but don't make it stop you from enjoying it. If you have any issues with the game just search or ask around the forums. There is definitely a solution.Have fun!

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 3, 2015
												As of writing I'm only about 6 hours in but I feel compelled to write this review now while some impressions are fresh in my mind.Being a long time fan of the XCOM franchise I approached this game with a fair amount of skeptisism. It turns out that skeptisism was somewhat unwarranted. While I'm still not entirely sure if the game belongs in the franchise but it's more than capable of standing on it's own.Let's get deal with it's weaknesses first; of which it's biggest by far are the clunky controls. They make movement particularly during combat a bit of a gamble. Sometimes you can't get into cover, sometimes you can't get out, sometimes you just find yourself popping out of cover and not going anywhere. I can't help but feel this comes as a result of it's console affiliation. The sprint button is the same button used to take and leave cover. Moving around corners while in cover is not performed automatically like in most games, it requires it's own keypress. Another weakness appears to be the friendly AI; they're just not terribly bright. While they seem to know when a grenade is thrown and move away, at least first, they often just rush straight back to where they were _before_ the grenade has gone off! They require constant babysitting. Sometimes they'll stay where they're instructed to, other times they'll just go wherever they please. The enemy AI aren't Einsteins either - they have a tendancy to run back and forth between two cover positions - but they appear to be more capable than the friendlies. They actually move from grenades for a start, and are capable of flanking when possible.Now for what makes this game genuinely good. Firstly the outstanding visuals. The models, textures, lighting are brilliant. The levels are highly detailed making it feel like ones really in old 1960s America. The immersion is deepened by small touches like photos, audio reels, documents and notes, my favourite being ones that instruct folks to ask specific questions - like what sound does a dog make or where someone was when President Johnson was assassinated - to aid in identifying disguised aliens - because they aren't able to reproduce a "woof" sound and they have trouble with distinguishing Human names so won't know that President Johnson wasn't assasinated. It's the sort of thing one could imagine actually happening in such a scenario. Great little touch! The story itself while not all that original is told really well through discussions with NPCs and the documents and audio reels all over the place. You get fed the story in small chunks and the underlying mystery is slowly revealed. The sound is top notch and the voice acting isn't half bad either.The gameplay, now this is a bit a mixed bag. A key mechanic is the use of a "Battle Focus" mode which slows time to a crawl and allows you to issue orders to your squad. This is actually done extremely well. Moving a squadmate into cover shows the level of cover provided by that position - partial or full. Orders can be queued up for execution. They system works really well. Having said that I have a few qualms about it; I don't like the fact it just slows time down instead of pausing it altogether for example. At least it should be an option to do so. To use the main characters abilities you're required to execute them through the "Battle Focus" mode as well, you can't just push a button to do so. This is particuarly annoying when you want to heal your squad quickly, you have to open "Battle Focus", hover over the characters skill bar, click the skill or push the number associated with that skill. I would rather just be able to push the button. Back at base the player is given the choice of missions to run; the choice varies between storyline missions which must be completed at some point and side missions. Side missions are a great way to increase the XP of the player and his squad. And that brings me to another hit-and-miss part of the game; the RPG element. The player and his squad obtain XP through kills, XP translates into leveling up, leveling up translates into new skills and stats; the usual affair. That all works just fine. One can even customise their squads names and looks - a nice touch. What stands out though are the classes of squadies. Different classes afford different abilites on the battlefield. This works especially well and adds a fantastic dynamic to the game. Of course it's possible to specify the loadout of your squad but this is where I had a small issue; you get a selection of weapons which is all good and well, but nowhere are you told what damage the weapon does or what enemies it's affective against or anything. There is a shooting range provided at the base which I suppose one could aruge should be used for this but I'm not sure how accurate an assessment that would be. I would like to be told what range of damage I can expect and what distance it's effective over and if it's good for taking down shields or mechanical targets, that sort of thing.Overall, it's perfectly competent 3rd person tactical shooter set in a masterfully constructed world and set to an intriguing albeit unoriginal story. I would certainly recommend it.

number of helpful: 8 of 9 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2016
												Sneaking up and punching a Sectoid in the back of the head - 5/5 - would melee again.Wow - I overlooked this one on release, due to the bad press it received. So far, I'm impressed and the earlier reviews don't do it any justice.In a way I'm glad I did overlook it before because now I get the whole package for under £7!Had to retune the colours on my monitor for this one.It's not quite an XCOM/UFO game, but it is definitely part of the series - the atmosphere is good, with sense of time and place established throughout, although the dialogue and story are "DC comic-level". This is less than I was expecting. However - the story and dialogue improve a lot as the game progresses - it actually becomes pretty good and I am enjoying discovering the twists and turns of the plot as it unfolds.The gameplay has become easier (on veteran) and the missions "shorter". The only time I had to reload (2x) was for a "mid-mission" where the team were about level 3. That was the only frustrating challenge in the whole game. All the others have been legit "hard" battles and I've felt accomplished at scraping through, or that, "ok I deserved to lose that one" or whatever.The game feels as if Mafia II, Bioshock and XCOM were put into a gene splicer and shaken up a bit. Garnished with Alpha Protocol (although the "dialogue decisions" all lead to the same place).That's a good thing, IMO.It is one of the few games I've played lately where the cutscenes are of a lower quality than the game itself. They're not bad, but they're not good - the dialogue parts... I think they could've been a lot better. There doesn't appear to be any reason to give me a choice in many of the exchanges other than to hold my attention in an otherwise motionless and flat conversation - it means I get to push a button - and this distracts me from the disappearing-reappearing pistol and the fact my guy's arm is clipping through his body and the shotgun he's waving around looks glued onto the back of his hand...I can glitch some parts - through walls, escape the area, fall off things, have the "troops" appear in random places / teleport, and I keep wanting to cover against things in places I can't. It's possible to exploit a few things in order to gain an unfair advantage over the game. For some reason, my character occasionally is using weapons or waving a shotgun around like its a pistol - but that's only the cutscenes, as I've mentioned. The weapons themselves fell very "cartoony" and that's cool. This isn't Red Orchestra. I don't feel that I am doing anything other than playing a fun game with tense moments - it's not an immersive world like Portal 2, Dark Mod, RO, Long Dark or Deus Ex, etc... It's more along the lines of LA Noire or GTA kind of immersion. Easily broken and fallen back into, between chores or whatever.The voice acting - well... it's that one guy again. The guy from every Bethesda game among others... He must be the most worked-voice actor in the industry and I'm sick of his voice!!! He even voices two characters in a conversation in this game. Kinda sucks, but is forgivable. You'll recognise the voice when you hear it, I'm sure. He really annoys me now, because he's become a gaming cliché.Sound is otherwise excellent. Music is very good for the moment.I've found the pace to be pretty good. It matches the linear progression / corridor play of the game.During "combat" I've barely had to make any kills myself, and the "planning" phases generally have been 3-4x as long as the "action" phases.I've felt like a real badass when quickly devising a simple plan, having the team execute it exactly as I intended and the whole fight being over before I've even had a chance to aim my own weapon. That's a good team-tactics game, right there. There have been a few moments where I've just decided to speed things up by walking down the range with a shotgun, and that's also been very satisfying and much fun.I'm playing on Veteran, and I've only had to reload once, due to a control malfunction (wat is buttons i is noob?).Thinking of controls - the vibration in this game does not feel tied to what is going on at all. It's a little disconnected and I'm feeling that I want to turn it off as it separates me from the gameplay.The game follows the simple FFF tactics of games such as Brothers-in-Arms and Rainbow 6, etc... and the firefights feel like they have impact in the same way that Bioshock did. Much of the level and area design is a series of inter-woven corridors that zig-zag between areas with easy to reach flanks. The enemy is aggressive, reactive and are unrelenting in an "army of two" / "gears of war" way. That is, if they are alive long enough...I was wondering how the "tactical" side of the 3rd person shooter would manifest and I think they've done a great job with this "focus" system - it is easy to use and there's little room for error.Items are liberally scattered throughout - there's no need to conserve bullets or grenades so far, but exploration is very limited - there are not many things to investigate, but what there is... it's in-line with events and the characters have good banter.I'm finding it very enjoyable after the first few chapters and playing this game is making me want to quit my Deus Ex replay in order to play some of the old UFO/XCOM games again (esp. the new version of Enemy Unknown). I'll probably be playing this the whole weekend, might even get to finish it.Not sure about replayability, as it's like Mafia II in this way - not many different ways to tackle situations - however I think that I will replay this at least once or twice, as there are challenges and achievements to complete - plus some DLC missions to get into.There's definitely scope to "meta-game" - the liberal ammo and weapons everywhere mean that I forget to use grenades and I'm considering a run whereby I change weapons every time I see a new one. I'm at the end of the game now, and the last 50% has been the easiest part - I've veyr much enjoyed the "progress" through levels. Not lost a single agent, had to "retry" a mission on 2x when I got stuck without ammo in a particularly tough farmyard battle on a side-mission.Regardless - The Bureau is much better than I thought it was at release, going from the reviews and criticism it received - I'm enjoying it very much and it cost less than a gram of weed - definitely better than buying drugs.I like the fact that - when I take a smoke break - my character does too :)30 hours for an initial playthru is fairly decent. I think I've done and explored everything. The DLC I expect to add another hour or so. Plus a replay - that leads to anything up to 50 hours solid entertainment for less than £10, which is 50 pence per hour - that's very good value for money on any game, I think.Totally under-rated game.This one will definitely be keeping me up way past my bedtime this weekend.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2016
Product received for free
												Welcome to my review of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified!In A Nutshell: Pros: -Fairly Interesting Plot: Very Film Noir meets Retro Sci-Fi Convention-Decent Graphics and Audio-Good Eye for Detail with the Retro Elements (Like dated phones and propaganda posters)-Micromanagement with Teammates (Could be a Con?)Cons:-Wonky Controls (No Crouch button? Really?)-Team Management is Mandatory (Mine died if left to their own devices all the time. Whoops.)-Too Many Gimmicks (Is this a Shooter? Sci-Fi RPG? Tactical Combat Film Noir? What?)Full Review:   The Bureau: XCOM Declassified feels like a video game that has tried to be too many things at once. Part Strategy title, part Shooter, with RPG elements, team management, Noir vs. Sci-Fi themes, tactical combat, and more. It’s all over the place, but unfortunately it doesn’t do any of these things exceptionally well – or even moderately well, at times. It’s a game I was extremely excited to try, but ultimately was left feeling disappointed; the team management system isn’t my forte, but I struggled more with the clunky controls than anything else. I couldn’t toggle a key binding for a crouch, so if I approached a barricade the wrong way I’d just stand there getting shot in the face – that’s poor tactics, man. The very definition! The storyline is fairly interesting, and it’s an odd mix of old Hollywood Noir with the Sci-Fi aspect so many modern games utilize. I really enjoyed the blend, and the subtle details in the landscape; not to mention the cinematic events, which tied in the story nicely, even if their frequency felt a bit tedious at times. All in all, I think other games blend Strategy, management, RPG elements, and the shooter genre better, but if you can nab this one on sale – at least if you love the idea of using wonky controls to yell at AI characters to get shot at – it might be worth adding to your library. Because of my neutral stance I'm going with a YES recommendation here, but with reservations.In Conclusion: 5/10 This review is part of the Steamified Community Review program. For similar reviews and fantastic giveaways please visit http://www.steamified.com/

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												I'm surprised this game has so many negative reviews, since I enjoyed the game from start to finish.A lot of people stated that their squads are dimwits and always get killed, while they struggle with their own character to get to safety. This wasn't the case in my playthrough - I completed everything without a single agent killed. I suppose once you tailor your squad to YOUR playstyle, it will become much more managable. Sure, you have to micromanage your squad like all hell before the battle, but if you do things correctly, even the toughest battles are a breeze.....maybe I'm the 20% of people who actually enjoy the combat. Maybe.I suppose the negative criticism is also because some people are upset that this game isn't like Enemy Unknown. Sure, the game story/choices thing mirrors Mass Effect (there's even an "I should go" option), but the story itself, in my opinion, is enjoyable, even though it started to fizzle out in the end. Hell, even the combat system itself mirrors Mass Effect (crew placement-wise, pausable combat phase, etc).The sidequests are fun (though I can understant that it's sort of the same thing over and over again), and 60s atmosphere is great. The achievements aren't very hard to complete, though there are qute a number of missable ones. I recommend consulting a guide to single them out.

												The idea of a 1962 XCOM is attractive, with Cold War technology and mindset to go with it.But unfortunately the gameplay is just too repetitive to stay interested beyond the first real mission. Although a lot of hard work went into many details, in its core it is a very simple and ultimately boring game. Move to the next cover fight, move to next cover fight, etc. but without the tactics and strategy that makes the XCOM series a success. I was left with the feeling that beyond the styling - which is pretty good - this is just a poor version of Brothers in Arms.In end even at the current discount I'd recommend to skip it.This is a sub USD 10,- gameActually you can miss it altogether...And I'm sorry to say so because there are so many nice late 50-ies early 60-ies details in this game, it must have been a labour of love for many involved, but it got lost in a  simple and boring game. Even the story cannot save it
