content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Story: 9/10Great start, Great twist, Great choice in endings. Not going to go too much into this because it would require spoilers. Let's just say the beginning is REALLY important to remember throughout the entire game. It's where the great twist towards the end started planting itself. Gameplay: 8/10A better experience than mass effect. Uses the same sort of control ( keyboard mouse/gamepad ) set up as Mass Effect franchise but it's more responsive and more action packed. Running is actually useful and you can do tight turns while running without the clunky stop and move turning mass effect had/s. Cover is useful here and needed. If you're not in cover you're dead, this isn't a run and gun. You NEED to tell your squad what to do. Management of your squad is your duty. This isn't made easy for you by having overpowered teammates. Flanking enemy entrenchments and positions is key to winning. Falling back and moving is the only way to survive being pinned down. If you've played XCOM: Enemy Unknown you'll be familiar with the systems in play here. I will say it is dumbed down at the beginning but the Infiltrator boss fight is when the game shows it's real design. Enemies do NOT run at you like idiots they take cover and try to get you to reveal yourself by dropping grenades and setting up flanking maneuvers. As you progress enemies get more aggressive, the shielded enemies have a tendancy of flanking your team and trying to strike from vantage points. Enemies with higher health are more likely to push and attack aggressively, while enemies with lower health pools tend to hang back in cover while pressuring flanks. Glitches: Not really a problem. I've seen a bunch of posts about this game being glitchy and in truth, I saw almost no glitches. I had 3 things happen that didn't really break the game. To fix them I just simply picked the "reload checkpoint" option in the pause menu. 1. There was a sound glitch where sounds were sort of cut off as they were fading out. making it sound like there was a stutter in dialog or just simply dialog, music, or battle sounds being cut prematurely. reload checkpoint fixed this. 2. Squad member got stuck inside of something while reviving. During a mission a squad member was stuck in a bookcase when he went to try to revive a squaddie and even though I was down a team member it didn't make a difference I still finished the fight and he immediately became "unstuck" and teleported out of the glitch on his own. 3. This one didn't cause me trouble but I did have to "load a save" that was a couple of minutes behind my progress. I just lost about 3 minutes of progress and it wasn't even in a firefight but right before a boss fight. These gates are supposed to close and the way into the fight arena is supposed to be closed off. Well I spawned in a checkpointed save INSIDE the rubble. There's AMPLE checkpoints in the game and I never found myself "redo'ing" an entire fight. Sound(track): 8/10There's not really much to say about it, everything fits, from the 1960's music in the quiet streets of an overrun town to the creepy alien noises and loud bangs everything fits. The guns later in the game sound really good. Crisp reloading sounds let you know what gun you're using. Every gun's reload sound is different, some pop, some crackle, some wind up. You'll know when a squad mate is pinned down and can't attack, they're constantly telling you about their situation ( I'm pinned down! Need healing! I'm about to go down commander! We're being flanked! ) or asking for orders. They'll also yell out what they're using so you always know what's on cooldown ( Turret out! Cloaking! ) Length: 5/10Unfortunately, this is where I am a bit disappointed. The game isn't that long to be honest. My first playthrough trying to do everything possible without outside help of any sort ( walkthrough, videos, wiki ) clocked in at 17 hours of gameplay. I didn't get ALL the base investigations but I'm pretty sure I got most of them, if anything I probably missed out on 1 or 2 at most adding something in the 15 to 20 minute range. This is the only thing that's disappointing about this game. Although all missions felt handcrafted and well made some weren't longer than 10 minutes ( side missions ) some more would have been nice.Closing this out, Yes I recommend it. The campaign was a blast with really awesome moments. Everything felt handcrafted not just another generic "this is where you fight, this is where you walk" sort of campaign. It was refreshing to play a game with such a different look at the genre. This game felt... Special. It's the only way I can describe it. The addition of the squad management was really a nice touch. Giving out the commands on what to attack and what skills to use made me feel useful in the game and didn't make me feel like I was along for the ride. All engagements were engaging and I had to participate in the positioning of my squad which made me think more about my next step instead of mindlessly shooting at enemies that were running at me.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2014
												You are Gruff Mc Gruffington, the gruffiest agent to ever gruff in the sixties and lose his family in some freak fire accident.It's a squad based over-the-shoulder third person shooter in which you and 2 other agents of your choice with varying abilities and weaponry beat the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of hostile alien scum. With bullets. (AND LAZER BEAMS!)So you gruff around the environment from point to point, and so on, sometimes viewing various notes, documents, photos, and audio logs between fights.You can choose between a bunch of backpacks you find throughout the game which give you passive bonuses and make you look like a ghostbuster.The game looks pretty decent and doesn't seem to have many glitches, the main ones I found, besides hilarious physics, is sounds glitch out sometimes, and then theres the permanent nanomachines distortion anomaly at the bottom of my screen, I think the same thing happened inAlpha Protocol. Ha ha, oh Unreal Engine and your shenanigans.Your agent allies' AI is sometimes about as reliable as the Left 4 Dead 2 Survivor AI, so you will be cringing incredibly hard when you die for the 3rd time in a row waiting for your twitchy agent to revive you while Steroids Mc LaserTwat is busy murdering your other agent.You also gruff around in dialogue trees every now and then, where you got your several optional dialogue options, and then the "Let's get the f*** on with this game" option to the left.And that's about it. Gruff.And no, I haven't played any of the older XCOM games, however I imagine the dissapointment in long time fans is similar to how old fans of the Resident Evil series (myself included) were dissapointed when it started to derp somewhere around 4 and onwards (even know 4 is great and all, but them roots.)Definitely not a bad game, just damn annoying at times.So I guess give this a shot when it's on a good sale, if you're a fan of cover/squad based third person shooters/aliens/whatever.6.8/10

												I was afraid to start this game because of the multifarious reviews and comments but after completing XCOM: Enemy Within a few times I decided to give it a try because it was in my library for ages. Don't expect a game similar to the turn-based tactical shooter XCOM games, it's a completely different game and to be honest it's in my opinion a weird decision to relate the game to the XCOM Universe. STILL, after playing a couple of hours I'm actually enjoying this game. It's challenging, different (in a good way) and once again your team mates can die in combat permanently. The story has a cool twist, interesting characters (the main character also looks and sounds alot like Charlie Sheen, which is actually a bonus for me!) and the combat system is very unique compared to other games in the same genre. I'm playing with a controller so I can't really comment on the consoleport issues altho i'm encountering some framerate issues from time to time but nothing that would disrupt the gameplay in a hard way. If you're in doubt check some gameplay videos, it's definitely not a game for everyone but surely a nice pickup for a couple of bucks.

content:
Posted: October 1, 2014
												I did not expect to enjoy this game. My first reaction to hearing about it was to scream, in Spoony's words, BETRAYAL! But to my surprise, I ended up really liking it.There's no doubt that this game could be so much more. It should be bigger, and more complex. Some of its ideas deserve fleshing out far more. Sometimes the plot skips ahead in ways it shouldn't. And yet... I was engrossed. I liked the characters, the style, the atmosphere; I liked the writing, too. In a way it felt much more human and engaging than XCOM: Enemy Unknown. (At least the German scientist made sense!)And the combat? What can I say, I thought it was a lot of fun. I could actually imagine playing a proper X-Com game in this style. To be perfectly honest, I think I enjoyed it more than its successful strategic sibling, but that's probably because I couldn't quite get into XCOM:EU's weird mix of detail and streamlining, which I know other people loved. (My personal favourite is X-Com: Apocalypse, so maybe I'm just weird.)It's almost certainly not a game for everyone, but it's not a disaster, either. If you're in the right mood, it's a very solid experience. I don't regret playing it.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Coming into The Bureau, I was expecting a mediocre experience at best. In my 10 hours spent with it I've learned I was wrong. So far the combat has been incredibly satisfying. Lifting a Sectoid into the air and ordering a Sniper to use a critical strike to blow its head clean off its shoulders feels incredibly fantastic. I don't know how they did it, but it feels (to me at least) like an XCOM game. Graphically, the game looks good. Not great, just good. I must admit, I had no idea that there was PhysX suport and I haven't used it yet. The story so far has been alright. Nothing truly spectacular, although it does keep me on the edge of my seat trying to figure out who you can trust. Squad customization is not nearly as deep as it is in XCOM: Enemy Unknown, but it's there. So in short, I'm enjoying my time with the game a great deal. If you enjoy XCOM and are looking for a diversion, then I highly recommend this game. If you've never played XCOM before, then I suggest starting with Enemy Unknown, not The Bureau, because c'mon, Enemy Unknown was awesome.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Was very excited for this game, but sadly, it flopped.  Hard.Overview :The Bureau is a TP squad based shooter and is 2K Marins verson for XCOM.  Originally in 2010 being a FPS with really nothing to do with the original games.  The Bureau now combines TPS and strategy elements together and tries to be somewhat similar to the X:COM people know and love.  The game is real time, but if you want to assign an order to a squad mate, it slows time down to a crawl, which is Marins way of giving some love to classic X;COM fans.  Similar to waht Bethesda did with FO:3 with VATS.Pros : -Pretty fun squad based third-person combat (when it works).  -Upgrade trees, while not amazing, are kind of fun to go through the first time.  -It does take some thinking when faced with many enemies in a high difficulty. -It has enemies from from classic X:COM such as Sectoids, Mutons, and Outisders, etc, while also adding new enemies to the mix, though not many. Cons : -Has annoying bugs, for example, when I play, if someone is talking and I look away from them, I can't hear their voice at all.  Even if I don't move away from them, but just look away.   -Now I don't know if this is a bug, or a result of being unfinished, but if you tell a squad mate to go somewhere, many times they will move away from where you told them to be.  Many times, this has ruined strategies I had planned out because they got killed or something and I couldn't do what I planned.  -it has weak♥♥♥♥♥graphics,  -character models look awkward -voice acting isn't complete trash, but isn't good by any means, - it has weak story telling.    Some other things to point out are the boss battles (in my opinion) were really lazy, the way you gain more weapons is just dumb, all you have to do is pick up an alien weapon, and then you have it for the game.  I liked X:COM EU's way of doing it where you actually had to research it and build it, THEN you get the weapon.Last words :I really wish they made this more like X:COM EU but with the TPS setting, but sadly, we got this.  This could have been amazing, but it really isn't worth $50 at all.  If you are okay with dealing with bugs and annoying design choices and you love TPS's, then maybe pick it up if you see it for like 30 bucks, MAYBEOverall, it's a weak, one time playthrough game with very little heart put into it.  Sad as 2K Marin made Bioshock 2 which I thought was a phenomenal game.  The DLC also sucks as well IMO, but I won't write another review just for that.I rate it a 4/10

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified isn't everything it could have been, but it's not as bad as many have made it out to be. Taking the events in the game as standalone rather than a precursor to any of the other games helps. Where the game does shine is the freedom of choice you get compared to many other storyline/campaign rail shooters. It is however only towards the end of the game where gameplay choices start to open up. To get to that stage you have to deal with some repetitive gunplay and some mediocre controls. For example, the sprint/cover key is the same key, and cover seems to "stick" so you can't simply walk away from it. What ends up happening is when you intend to sprint past an obstacle you instead slam right into cover behind it, and then spend several seconds trying to get away from it. Many other games have done this a lot better.Your squadmates also have some serious dependency issues. They stick to your tail like glue, so when you try to flank an enemy while your squad has their attention, they instead give up their cover positions to chase you around. If you don't give them any direct orders for a few moments they tend to complain about it by saying "We need orders!". They do at least return fire without being told to.There is no research, new weapons are simply given to you as you progress. Given that at the start you're told that alien weapons self-destruct when their owner dies I was expecting a situation where you had to incapacitate an enemy and "capture" their weapon in order to get access to it and research it. This may have been the plan at some stage but it's been shelved. Now new weapons are strategically placed in certain spots in missions, and afterwards normal enemies drop them as well. The hardest choice you'll have to make is what weapons you want to start a mission with but there are so many around in a stage that you can easily switch to something else if you find ammo is short for the type you're carrying.There are two-ish skill trees for each of four classes. It's not really a tree as such but really just two lanes you can switch between whenever you want. Agents under your command tend to be rather generic so you never really form any kind of attachment to them.Overall I'm going to give it a thumbs up. Not worth full price but definitely worth a look on sale or if you were able to get it from the recent Humble 2k bundle.Happy gaming.AC

												I picked this game up on at around 4 buck sale for a 2k games weekend deal.  I can honestly say I am not disappointed one bit.  I can't believe the negative reviews this game is getting.  I love the time period that it represents; I always liked period pieces.  I have only played for 3 hours or more and can say the game mechanics are awesome.  I think people are expecting a turn based strategy game like most X-com titles, but this one is different.  It has some of those elements, but it has this combat system that you can give orders in slow motion to your team mates.  It's also from a third person perspective.  As some of the reviews have said it reminds you of Mass Effect.  It has a pretty good narrative going throughout the game, you make choices as to what you want to say just like Mass Effect.  I think what was most disappointing for the other X-com fans was it not being turn based.  If you can get away from the traditional X-com game idea you might enjoy this title.  I have not played enough of the game as of yet to determine if the story is any good.  The main character that you play is an WWII vet that joined the CIA and suffers a major loss in his life.  One of the things I would have liked to have seen is just like Mass effect, to be able to customize the main character.  You can by the way, customize your team, change their names and what they wear just like X-com.  All in all it's a great bargain title, I probably wouldn't have spent full price on it when it first came out.  8/10

content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												I'm a huge fan of the X-COM franchise since the beginning and was very satisfied with the remake 2K published in 2012.When The Bureau was announced as part of this franchise and the first pics were shown, I couldn't wait to see its release. But several things (mainly the third-person-perspective and the combat mechanism) kept me from buying it then.But thanks to the latest summer sale I decided to buy it and all of its DLC.Easy part first: the DLCs aren't worth it. One gives you an extra alien weapon, one gives you a short extra mission and the Hangar 6 R&D gives you a bit of a pre-story to the main game and some new - only (!) in that DLC available - weapons to fight through some simple 'survival' levels.A bit complicated is the main game. While in many other cases I have problems with the third-person-perspective, it worked well in this game. Also the combat system is working good and most time satisfying, but way to simple to fullfill the tactical needs of an old X-COM veteran.The graphic, the sounds and the characters really helps to create the right atmosphere for the game and also the different settings for the missions making it fun to play, even with a too much repetitive gameplay. And that gameplay is also the biggest issue of the game. You walk trhough the 'tunnel' maps knowing nothing will happen, until you come to a 'battlefield' (easily identified thanks to the huge amount of cover for your men and the aliens), where you fight some waves of enemies and then continue to the next 'battlefield'.The only thing that keeps me playing was the story, which had some weird twist and gets very unsatisfying in the end. But for me, the game was worth money and I didn't regret it any minute to have bought it.

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 7, 2015
												XCOM : enemy unknown turns into a real time third person shooter strategy game. This game puts seemingly difficult RTS commands and simplifies them just enough to make the game play as smooth as possible.XCOM is known for it's suspenseful cinematics and storyline incorporating an unknown attacking alien species. The story unfolds with special agent Carter who rendez-vous with other members of the "Bureau" aka people who deal with alien affairs. He attempts to deliver a package to a general then suddenly the general is shot by another agent. Shocked, Carter quickly turns to the other agent ready to take action when she quickly points out the change in eyes and behavior of the general who was under alien mind control. XCOM fans will be familiar to the play area as it will give friendly reminders that you've sort of been here before. It gives me a warm fuzzy feeling going from an RTS view to first person. The grid system sort of is there, but the command system is absolutely on point. By holding B (on a 360 controller), a command menu opens up and slow down times slightly as you make a selection of what to do. Player can choose from numerous actions such as move, pin down, and shoot while certain characters have specialized abilities (that can be unlocked by gaining experience). One character, for example has the ability to set up an auto turret while another can scope enemies with his sniper. The game is nothing short of exciting when it comes to game play as there can be a lot going on. Some players will like this as you will need to quickly command your troops where to go while ensuring you're doing your part to keep the enemy suppressed. Nonetheless, the command system is quick and efficient in it's means. Players won't have a problem designating commands. The shooting itself is alright with nothing exceptionally special and there is an option to scatter/throw a grenade. Any game that has that as an addition is greatly welcomed. There is also a melee feature players can use which is basic at best. It would have been nice to see them incorporate ways to capture aliens and maybe somehow incorporate what they did with Enemy Unknown, that way maybe you could upgrade or change your melee weapon. Basic movements are all there as you can take cover, roll, jump, and sprint. Although a little stiff, it's nice they put it in. When finishing a mission players will find themselves in the XCOM base where they can sort of roam freely talking to NPC's or managing their staff. The player may recruit new soldiers and send them off to missions or take those soldiers with them on a mission. Graphics make me feel like I'm PC gaming back in 2008 but don't interfere with game play. Pause menus are nice and user friendly. People actually move their mouths while they speak in game which I found a neat feature. Sounds are appropriate but aren't varied. I'd like to hear more ping sounds come off when I fire at the enemies cover.Overall a good game and would highly recommend it for those who seek a FPS / RTS sort of hybrid. I support it for this reason but cannot guarantee everyone will be satisfied with it's shooting/action styles.RATING : 7.35/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B- Sounds / Music B- Replay-ability C+ Overall  B-ScreenShots :  About to issue a command  Options I have within the command menu I'm in the back with my other two partners in which one of them set up a turret. I'm currently in the move command screen which is extremely flexible in telling your units where to go His mouth freakin' moves

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Looking at the overall 'Mixed' rating of this game, you'd be forgiven for not buying it, but then again, you might also be making the wrong choice.  I'll explain.  The Bureau's play style is different from XCOM: Enemy Unknown, XCOM: Enemy Within and XCOM 2.  It's very similar to Mass Effect games in that you command where your squad members go and what they do.  It's a "third person tactical shooter experience with strategy video game elements" -Wikipedia.  One has to wonder if the developers were playing Mass Effect during its creation considering development began in 2006 and finally released in 2013.  To complete missions, you recruit agents from a list of different available classes, each with their own background training, and then take any two agents from your roster into the field with you.  As they gain field experience, agents unlock their special abilities known as perks.  At certain perk levels, you decide between specialisations.  Being a huge Mass Effect fan, this game brought a smile to my face.   It was a lot of fun and I couldn't stop playing it.  I finished the campaign in a week.  Questions you should ask yourself if you are considering buying this game are: Do you like alien technology?  Do you like special augmented abilities?  Do you like plasma, laser and lightning weaponry?  How about combo kills that are announced when successful?   Did you enjoy the Mass Effect series?  Do you like the genre of science-fiction?  Then you should play this game. I decided to buy The Bureau on a steam sale because I received my copy of XCOM 2 in the mail upon release from...an online store...and I like to play games in chronological story order.  I also bought XCOM: EW and EU from Steam as well and I'm looking forward to playing them next.  All of this, of course, is building up to play XCOM 2.    Additional thoughts and criticisms:  Graphics wise, the game is par for the course for a game released in 2013, which is to say they're good even by today's standards.  The XCOM base of operations is highly detailed, roomy and there are plenty of NPCs to converse with between missions.  Scattered throughout, are also files to read, pictures to view and audio tapes to listen too; all of which adds depth to the story.  The voice acting is good, but I found the voice of Agent Carter, the main character you play as, reminding me a little too much of Batman's voice.  It made me laugh at times and took me out of the story momentarily.  Of course, it could be due to the fact that agents seem to be smoking non-stop throughout the game. The other criticism I have is that there isn’t much of any ‘new game plus’ upon completion of the campaign, save for playing it over with different classes of agents.  Also, and unlike in Mass Effect, there aren’t choices you make that have consequences in the story line other than if you play on the hardest difficulty and one of your field agents die, they are dead permanently and you have to rely on your other agents to fill in and begin leveling up a new agent.  Final thoughts:I finished the game wanting more missions to play.  I think that’s a good thing.  It was fun to play and I recommend it, especially on a Steam sale.

												This game gets a 5/10 at most and thats a generous score.  This game got a lot of flack with its release for not being similar to the other XCOM games and then was praised for its attempt at a different gameplay style so the reviews for this game seem to swing between "this game is awful" and "this game is a hidden gem."So let's take a look at both sides shall we?Declassified is a third person squad based combat game where you issue orders to your squad members who have specific classes and skills.  Unfortunately no matter what class your squadmates belong to they all share a similar characteristic between all of them, poo-brain.  Yes your squadmates have the worst case of poo-brain I have ever seen, its almost as if the brains from Futurama are invading Earth the same time the aliens are.Not only are your squadmates inheritly useless, the combat is very cut and dry and flanking seems to be non-existant when they drop boss mobs on you who will down any squadmate who decides he should run around for no reason, which is the biggest cause of stress in the game.  Your squadmates WILL NOT STAY IN COVER and need to be constantly ♥♥♥♥ing told to stay put or they will run around aimlessly getting downed. So as for gameplay the game is terrible as its a terrible version of Band of Brothers.Voice acting is okay however the lip sync looks awkward as hell.Graphics are fine if thats why you buy video games.The story is as good as good as it gets for XCOM games.THIS GAME IS ONLY FOR THOSE OF THE DIE HARD FANS OF THE XCOM FRANCHISE AND ARE WILLING TO PLAY THROUGH A CHORE IN ORDER TO LEARN MORE ABOUT THE XCOM UNIVERSE.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												It pains me to say it but I find myself unable to recommend this game. If I had to sum it up in a single sentence, I would say this: "So much potential with so little delivery." The game's advertising campaign played it off as an ominous 60s' men in black (not the movies) style adventure, filled with espionage and intrigue. I expected to be redacting documents and cleaning up alien hot zones to conceal the truth from eyes not yet ready to know. Instead, what I got was a disassembled and badly reconstructed 'Mass Effect' (the first one) shoot-em-up with a thin 60s' veneer thrown on for good measure.I play games for the story more than anything else. The adventure. The experience. And while The Bureau has an intriguing overarching plot, what you experience quickly becomes a tangled mess of two dimensional characters, deus ex machinas and plot holes. In terms of whether or not you want to include it in the canon of Xcom itself, I would say: don't. It raises too many questions and leaves to many open boxes unchecked.Mechanically and in terms of gameplay, I was not overly disappointed. Though reminiscent many other similar squad based games, the Xcom influence and interesting take on a tactical overview was certainly a plus. Though my poor PC found the game stressful at the best of times, I was still able to get a relatively enjoyable experience out of it.All in all, it is a game with no personality but alright gameplay. As previously stated, so much potential. So little delivery. I would rate The Bureau a generous six out of ten.

												This game is a little bit of a mixed bagOne one side you've got a very one dimensional gameplay feel a lot of the time where you end up doing the same thing over and over but the deeper you look the better the game actually gets. You can find little side missions by just looking around the main base which adds a very slight amount of things to do and the little notes and reports dotted around add to the story.The missions themselves are also mixed, the gameplay is actually pretty intense sometimes where you actually have to plan out what you want to do next and how you want to approach a level. This is good and the squad is a good idea, I get a similar attachment to my soldiers in the actual X-COM games. The friendly AI can be beyond stupid sometimes however and just move randomly without orders into enemy fire and create loads of problems.Going back to squads this is an element of the game I enjoy, being able to customise them (although limited) gives the soliders individuality and it's a small touch but changing their weapons and backpacks adds a little bit more strategy to an otherwise normal shooter.Overall the game's a bit generic in its gameplay but the styling is good and it certainly has its moments, I recommend this on sale to anyone who likes shooters and also the idea of the X-COM series. Maybe for someone who likes the look of X-COM but is intimidated by the strategy of that game.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												The Bureau – XCom Declassified was announced before XCom – Enemy Unknown and so – as many other all-time fans of the XCom/UFO-series - I was quite disappointed that 2K is going to make the sequel of one of the milestones of turn-based strategy games a shooter. With XCom – Enemy Unknown released and being a worthy successor to the series my initial rage faded away. So now that I don't have to treat The Bureau as a sequel but rather a spin-off, curiosity made me buy this title. And to my surprise I was quite pleased with the approach 2K took on the theme – at first.The XCom setting is transferred into the late 1950ies with the USA suffering from anti-communist paranoia. The first abductions, alien attacks and UFO sightings are misinterpreted as a soviet invasion by authorities. If you played any XCom titles you will get familiar with your enemies, weapons and abilities quickly. Also in the XCom-HQ, which you can roam and explore between field missions, you will find all the well-known departments like Engineering, R&D, Hangars and Infirmary. Merging the 1950ies with the XCom theme breathes new life into the franchise and works quite well. I liked to see my sniper wearing a vest and tie while aiming for a hostile commander or my Tech/Engineer wearing some ordinary janitor jumpsuit while blasting Sectoids into smithereens.During missions you control your own character and via the command interface, which significantly slows down the time and allows to scan the surroundings, you can issue orders to two additional agents. Even though it's a 3rd person view you will use well-known tactics you would use in the strategy games as hide and cover, flank the enemies and focus fire. Success heavily relies on the use of those tactics as well as yours and your agents special abilities like mind-control, critical strike and deploying additional equipment as turrets, mines and drones. So The Bureau actually is a tactical shooter and run and gun will get you killed.Unfortunately the game constantly prevents you from using these tactics. The missions are (as the whole game) heavily scripted and linear. Approaching a hostile encounter is always announced by a checkpoint save and a cliff, high boxes or another obstacle you have to jump off down into the battlearena. In the first half of the game these battlearenas are so small and the provided possibilities for cover so few, that you don't have much choice where to deploy agents and what tactics to use. In fact it feels like a longwinded tutorial.In the second half of the game the battlearenas get much larger and you have a lot of possibilities to flank enemies and can diversify your tactics. Unfortunately your character has a very restricted area of command. So I have my heavy gear guy flank the enemy on the right side while sending my sniper to a vantage point. But as soon as I move my character and any of my agents aren't covered by the area of command anymore, they start closing in to me ignoring any enemies or any order given beforehand.The poor technical optimization is the second major annoyance. Even though I have a decent gaming rig, I wasn't able to play with DX11 but had to turn down to DX9 and even then I had <30fps until I turned off the PhysX features. This game devours system resources without giving much back.But even more annoying than the above-mentioned are all the inconsistencies of the plot. You will find dialogues missing, making some answers given by NPCs meaningless. And despite the story has a nice twist in the later part of the game, you will feel there are parts missing and obviously the world and the plot were meant to be more fleshed out in the first place. At least the german voice acting is quite good.First playthrough ~20hrs.

number of helpful: 7 of 10 people (70%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												It has a nice aesthetic. The Space Age is primed for this type of alien invasion story, flying saucers and all. It's also a functional third-person cover shooter.Too bad it was made by people who apparently don't know how games work. Outside of the poor optimization of the PC version, the game offers repetitive gameplay, generic mechanics and an ambitious "commander" system. In said system, the player can give orders on the battlefield to his two squad-mates, which range from basic "kill that" to some nifty tricks and alien tech. Unfortunately, in order to use this system efficiently, you need someone to design good maps and whoever designed this game's maps was high on that day.Bad enemy placements, terrible cover positions and an idiotic AI. For the most part, one can ignore the many faults if they choose to just immerse themselves in the 1960s setting; but then, the final mission comes. The final mission, which involves a large map, where cover is useless, where the stronger enemies can cover distance you can't via super-jumps and in which both shooting and planning are thrown out the window. It's a mayhem that throws the player off, a sensory overload that makes the experience anything from tedious, to absolutely, physically painful. There is hard and then there is unbalanced; this is what this game is. It's painfully clear that, in order to increase difficulty, the designers thought they'd just throw everything in, including the kitchen sink. It's telling that the stage plays practically the same regardless of Difficulty Level. Doesn't matter if you play on Easy or Hard; what hinders your progress is that you need to employ stiff controls to be constantly on the move while everything's shooting at you. It's a cover-based shooter that suddenly decides to undo its core mechanic. It's like playing Super Mario Bros and the devs suddenly deciding that you need to sneak up on Bowser and snuff his life out with a dagger, because it's a stealth game now. No planning, no strategizing, just sheer laziness.I guess you can still get the game on a sale; it's the type of title that's good enough for 2-5 bucks. I still wouldn't recommend it, though. It'sa game which, after the experience is over, you feel like you have wasted way too much time for little-to-no reward. No.

content:
Posted: February 21
												I've always liked the XCOM games but not to the point of obsession or lionization. That's why the initial negative hype before this came out never really phased me. In finally diggging into the meat of the game, I found something else - third-person tactical action in the vein of Rainbow Six/Ghost Recon, but with an environment that's personally a lot more appealing (especially as personal politics shifts to the point of not being able to enjoy Tom Clancy games for the subtext, but I digress).There's some excellent design choices here too, with the UI, the period sets, the characters (even though your starting mission characters look like three older John Cenas), and the Sectoids and Outsiders and related technology. Some Mass Effect aesthetic in the dialogue wheels and some of the specificities of the tactical layout is welcome as well. Overall, it's worth checking out, especially if you liked the Clancy tac-action games, Hidden & Dangerous, or SWAT 4 and want something similar that's just divorced enough from military tropes.

												The game is fun at first but after a while the gameplay becomes repetitive. The boss battles basically sum up to shoot, shoot, shoot, find another gun, shoot, shoot, shoot, dead. The customization of your squad is a nice touch but the "skill sets" you chose for each class are confusing and some of them overlap. On a positive note, a good time can be had playing this game, if you play in short bursts; the idea of this game is great but, this series wasn't the right game to impliment it with. It tries to stay true to XCOM while at the same time adding new game mechanics, the controls conflict with each other. Would I recommend this game? Yes. Would I buy it at full price? No.

content:
Posted: June 1, 2015
												So, let's ignore that this isn't an XCOM Game.  Let's ignore that there is no strategic overview, no internal economy, no research trees, manufacturing, UFO combat, or any continuity in the new XCOM EU universe.This game is, at its core, a bland cover shooter.  There are three hallways in this game that you fight in: Main Street USA, Rural USA, and Generic Gray-Blue Spaceship corridor.   Fighting in deep space, on an alien planet, or on an Earthbound Alien base?  Gray-Blue Corridor.  Travel 600 light years to an alien satellite?  Gray Blue Corridor.  Head into earth orbit on a spaceship that should really be called the Firestorm?  Gray-Blue Corridors.   That's all this game is - walk down a hallway, crouch behind cover, and shoot aliens while trying to keep your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ AI team mates alive.While it seems there is the potential for some deep tactical action in your engagements, the extremely short leashes that your teammates are kept on interferes with their ability to flank the enemy.  You can try to set up a recon agent to shoot from an elevated position, but if you move forward to get in range of your shotgun, the short leash that your teammates are on simply means they will move up to the front lines with you.When you boil it all down, the game is just dreadfully boring.  The combat gets old dreadfully fast when you have to spend most of your time just keeping your AI alive on the higher difficulties and outside of picking one of three ending narrations you get, no other choice you make throughout the game has ANY impact.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												It's quite a fun game and yeah, it totally nails the cool B-movie 50's aesthetic - it looks really pretty, too. I actually enjoy the story, and you get to even wander around the base and talk to people and meet some crazy scientists and help them with stuff. Really, if it hadn't had the XCOM name attached to it The Bureau would've been (aside from the preconceived 3rd person shooter notions that are wrong) pretty decently received. Because it's actually a nice game.Let me explain.The thing about The Bureau is that in order to enjoy any sort of victory, you'll HAVE to constantly be controlling your team mates. You can think of it in terms of babysitting (as some have who didn't like it) or you can treat the game as turn-based that happens to play out in near real-time (with pause).What I mean by that is that in a turn-based game you have to control each of your characters, telling them where to go and what to do each "move" instead of letting them do the Mass Effect thing of allowing them their own agency while occasionally ordering them to do a specific action. Also, this is not a game where you can hunker down behind a wall and peek out to snipe at enemies - anyone who tries that will get killed quick, you or your teammates (or the enemies). Always be moving.Because of the real-time(with pause) gameplay mixing with the third person shooter aesthetic it can be initially confusing to try and mesh the strategy of one with the mechanics of the other, but so far it's been pretty darn cool. And hard. Mutons are no joke; tactical withdrawls while trying to flank a giant armored, angry alien is kinda crazy - especially when other aliens are all up in my place, too. I won't even start with the sectopods.The battlefields are pretty nice, as well. They are large enough to allow you to actually flank or otherwise move around in order to get the drop on enemies (or the other way around, enemies occasionally try and get around you, too). Enemy AI is nothing to ooh and ahh over, but you generally have options in battle, which is nice, and it's usually a challenge.Just to reiterate, people want to play it like ME3 or Gears of War or some other third person shooter with some partner AI, while it should instead be played more like a legitimate strategic/tactical game where you're not a main character, but directly controlling all three on your team. If you rely on the partner AI to do anything for you strategically you're going to watch them fail and you're going to repeatedly lose - and then hate the game. You need to be treating it as a realtime w/ pause game of action chess or something to get anywhere with it. The gameplay might not be for you, and that's okay, but if you understand that it's not an ordinary third-person-shooter and you're okay with that, you're going to have a good time.

												Oh well,if you consider this game was doomed since its birth, for being a x-com FPS style it turned out actually...decent.i am very harsh on x-com since its my favorite game of all time and i played every little copycat, original and dumb game was made on it.So lets start : first, this isnt a x-com game, this is a game that would be a xcom and 2k took some crazy measures to save it.Its a mass effect like shooter with cool combats , sectoids, some mutons and else.If you take all aliens out and put idk...bananas in their place, would be the same game, but not an x-com.The plot is kinda cool, well done with little flaws....at mid-game you actually get the feeling of being part of xcom(just for a little, the game seems to do everything possible to destroy this feeling)Its kinda creepy and cool to see how x-com "was born" but like i said, its was a measure 2k took to justify this game.With a good plot, a so so ending, a good mechanic, good music(time music) but with a poor and mixed character development and squad play i would give this game a 9 IF instead of sectoids and mutons the game were called "Aliens" and space bananas invaded.But when you carry the x-com brand you must do a pretty amazing job, when you dont you get a mediocre 6.5 and thanks god this will be the only son of this line.but if you want play, considering the game...its cool and enjoyable.but not a xcom game.

number of helpful: 14 of 24 people (58%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
												Positives: Wonderful setting, competent shooting mechanics, cool concept, beautiful art, functional music.Negatives: Frustrating AI, inconsistent characterisation, apparently baffling story (although I personally didn't get that far), an unlikable protagonist, other tiny problems with combat (described below).If you go into this expecting a game like Mass Effect rather than X-COM, you won't feel particularly cheated, but the gameplay just isn't as solid as a Mass Effect game.I wanted so badly to love this game - I loved the setting, I loved the concept, and I thought it was really wonderful that the developers were trying a bunch of new things. However, while this game isn't broken and it isn't terrible, there are just so many flaws that drag it into mediocre territory. After about 3 hours, I lost interest, and I simply wasn't having fun.The biggest thing that frustrated me was the inconsistent characterisation on display, especially from the protagonist. He's painted as a noir-like loose cannon that gets the job done, but this is just frustrating - he  bafflingly switches from treating characters with respect to ignoring orders just because, and seems seriously shaken up by the loss of a character he's just met despite being grumbly and disaffected about everything. It's as if the writers couldn't decide who they wanted him to be.I also have a few issues with the combat which were individually not deal-breakers but were frustrating when added together:- Control is often taken away from the player for unplayable cut-scenes which add absolutely nothing to the game- Weapons lack impact, many enemies take a frustrating amount of damage to put down- Combat scenes feel like they drag on too long consistently, additional spawning enemies feel frustrating- Because there is no crosshair outside of aiming, bringing up the sniper scope doesn't necessarily point it at the enemy you were looking at. Add this to the insane amounts of time between shots and for reloading the sniper rifle, and one of the most satisfying weapons becomes one of the most frustrating- Cover mechanics more complicated than they need to be when it comes to rounding corners or leaving cover- Team mate AI is often bad. Engineers stand in front of their own turrets taking damage without moving. Your squadmates mindlessly hang around detonating mines. And they never seem to do any damage - they seem to fulfill more of a babysitting role. I understand that this is to make the player feel empowered but I'd at least like my team of crack professionals to be competent!The tone of the game switches frequently - an audio log found in a university plays a professor reproaching his assistant for 'not following his intuition and relying on evidence'. Because that's what being a scientist is like....? And I seriously have to question why an institution that's meant to be the best of the best is so full of 'loose cannons who don't play by the rules'. If this is meant to tie in to any sort of X-Com canon, I've never considered my squaddies in other games to be dismissed alcoholics or police with a criminal history. It's a pity that this little thought was put into the setting and characterisation because the artwork is convincing and consistently impressive.I would have loved for this game to be so much more. I'd pick it up on sale if the above issues don't bother you much.

number of helpful: 14 of 24 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												This game is... problematic, to say the least.First off, it is NOT a terrible game; Gameplay functions as it should, bugs are rare, sound and music are solid as are the graphics for the most part.But the problems are that the story, aside from the few twists towards the end, is a generic alien invasion story that we have seen over and over. While other games with alien invasion stories try to put their own kind of spin or add flavor into execution that makes them worthwhile, this one follows a formula without any real intention of adding anything of its own.Characters are also a downside, they are just not interesting. Except one alien invader character who is, in the end, just not used in any interesting way. The final boss has a pretty cool voice, but that's about it.But my biggest axe to grind with this title, is in fact the title; why does it need to carry the X-Com franchise name? Considering it has zero elements from the source material; No base management, no real global defence, no strategy elements and the permanent death system is easily exploited and nullified because of its checkpoint save system.It could just as easily be its own game and not be measured and compared against its counterpart(s). Especially since before this one was released we got a genuine strategy X-com game, so this one is just... redundant. Yes, it was in production hell and we knew it would be released one day, but with all the delays and push backs, it is just disappointing that THIS is all they could come up with.It just has no real reason to exist.Shooting aliens in this game is fun, i will not deny that and in the beginning it does set up a very bleak, desperate setting to fight back an overwhelming invasion.Yet as the base becomes operational, that premise just does not live up to the pace that was set up at the beginning.The base itself too feels like its just there for window dressing.All in all, on basic mechanics and gameplay it does its job but on everything else it just falls flat.As an X-com fan, i would not recommend it.As a gamer, if you can get it cheap or as a rental, i would say check it out, who knows? you might find more things to like about it than i do.

content:
Posted: March 20
A really amazing strategic sci-fi shooterFirst of all, I had this game in my library for a while now. I tried to play it atleast twice, but somehow it just never stuck me to the chair. And not so long ago, I gave it a longer try than the previous two, and after that, I couldn't put it down. Strategic shooter seems weird at first, was for me - maybe because its not that usual? - but you have to keep trying, and you will fall in love with it.As I browsed the store not so long ago, I noticed that this game have mixed ratings. The most usual negative reviewers say that the game crashes a lot, and the game is either hard or hard (clumsy) to control. Hell, I even saw a reviewer saying that this game have bad graphics. Don't listen to them, crashes were probably a thing back when this game got released, work perfectly now. Problems with the controls? Get used to it, problem fixed. Game's graphics is neat, just check the pictures linked to the store.About the game, the story is interesting. Stars with something impossible, then alien invasion comes right up. Yeah, you will probably feel the lack of explanation of the story at some point, but no worries, everything gets in its' place by the end. - I recommend the Hangar 6 R&D DLC as well, since it also gives you the light plasma pistol DLC too, plus, it tells you how the whole invasion started. - There are also some side quests on the base as well, which rewards you with extra missions.And this awesome story plays in the '60s. And if this wouldn't be enough, the alien enviroment, the alien planet every sci-fi thing they made is amazing. The whole universe of the game is very well done, really.You can choose from a variety of alien guns, what I kind of miss is the lack of human weapons. There are also lots of skill for the main character and your agents as well (4 agent type, each has its own skill/perk tree).The difficulty. You will probably find this game very hard even on normal, but if you get to know the basics, how to play, how to use the necessary tactics in the game, it will be a piece of cake. Although, commander difficulty can give you a challenge, you can easily overcome it on your second playthrough.I think this game definetly worth a try (or three, if you're just like me), if you're not convinced by the reviews or either the store page itself, wait for a sale.PROSAmazing sci-fi enviromentThe story is phenomenal, and the twist in it... oh boy.Playing in the good old '60sThis strategic combat system is super coolPretty good charactersThe main campaign containts 11-12 hoursCONSThere should be a bigger list of weapons and grenades.Replay value is low (you finish it twice, then you're done, maybe getting back to it in a few months)Overall: 9.5/10

content:
Posted: August 12, 2014
												A consolified (read: dumbed down) entry in the XCOM series.Can only recommend for fans of the series who want to get in on the "XCOM Origins" Storyline and don't mind slogging through a wastelane of not giving a damn on the way.Levels are Final Fantasy 13-esque strings of corridors, an illusion of choice-of-action never really develops, and thus neither does immersion. I found myself far too often just holding sprint to reach the next blue marked button or yellow outlined door  (aka. plot point) without caring for my surroundings/the actual level at all.And even using the sprinting feature reaching the end of a corridor took far too long, making the game feel like a marathon simulator interspersed with interesting cutscenes. IMHO: Bad leveldesign. The controls and covermechanic also doesn't work half as well in third person as than it did in isometric, leading to some very frustrating deaths.Lastly, the main story was pretty slipshod, even measured against the other XCOM installments. There are several (read: too many) facepalming moments in the story, where the player has to wonder if this mankind is actually worth saving. The main character seems to suffer from severe mood swings, and the highly decorated woman-playing-a-man's-game turns out to be an unintentional comic relief character.If it weren't for the interesting backstory about the origins of XCOM I would've give 2/5, but even for a longtime fan of the series this game barely clears "meh" status.3/5

content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												While this game has a somewhat poor reputation because of not being strategy game, it's still a solid third-person action game.  It's not the next Mass Effect, but is still worth playing if you like sci-fi and third-person shooters.The atmosphere is great: a 1960s setting mixing Cold War paranoia and mysterious alien forces. I found the story to be interesting.  It also manages to slip in a pleasing bit of gameplay and story integration. And, if nothing else, facing a Muton on foot has definitely given me a greater appreciation for what my soldiers in the main series do on a regular basis.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
												Disclaimer: At the time of writing, I'm 6.1hrs in, and have up to the Laser SMGIf you forget the fact this carries the X-Com badge, and just want a shooter similar to Mass Effect (with AI Squad mates that have the lifespan of a gnat), but without any of the conversation depth, exploration, or moral choices, then it might be worth playing....However, it does have the X-Com badge, and it's the worse for it.   I can understand the enemies carrying a slightly different appearance (like a muton the size of a small pickup truck, or a Sectopod with a Sectoid in it), but unless there's some glorious retcon later in the plotline, there's absolutely no rationale for why your team (at a very low level) gets abilities like Group Heals, Shield Spheres, or the ability to.... telekinetically(?) Lift enemies and allies by waving your hand.    On top of that, one of the classes gets the ability to... summon?  an automated laser turret, yet another piece of tech that the "real" X-Com games never had.So, again, if they didn't call it X-Com, it might be okay...Except for the squad AI.    They have absolutely no sense of self-preservation, or peripheral vision.   I was playing on "Commander" (Maximum) difficulty, and had to lower it because the Squad would just do the most asinine things, causing them to be incapacitated, focusing more fire on me and causing my death as well.Couple examples that stick out.   1. We were both in cover behind a wall, sort of a bracket ( ] ) shape, with a gap in the middle.   I got taken out, and ordered him to revive me.   What'd they do?  Rather than take the one additional step to the side so they could run behind reasonable cover, they vaulted the wall, and made it about two steps before the enemy cut them down as well.2. I had positioned both squad members in a building that was gloriously defensible, Explicitly Moved them by the windows shooting at the enemies.   I Lifted one of the enemies, told them both to focus fire on that target.   Target dies, and suddenly one of the squad starts whining about healing, I look, and he is OUTSIDE, UNDER THE WINDOW, completely flanked.  The AI was so busy focusing on keeping Target A in the line of fire, it took cover in such a way that it left it's flank exposed, to the bulk of the enemies (which, BTW, both the main mass, and the target it was going after were accessible from the window cover)Incredibly frustrating, and just not worth dealing with.   Maybe if you pick it up on the Humble Bundle for a couple of bucks, but not worth more than that.

content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												In general, there’s little to recommend as far as The Bureau goes. The game essentially tries so hard to be 60s Mass Effect, but really only succeeds on the former front, in that it’s 60s as hell. Seriously, it’s the sole shining point here; The Bureau is inundated with shirt-tie-and-vest combos, classic cars, transistor tube radios, and chrome as far as the eye can see, which really injects the proceedings with a much-needed sense of atmosphere. Unfortunately, everything else solidly falls within the realm of mediocrity; the blandly-written protagonist is your typical gruff “tormented past, seeks redemption through fighting the new threat” archetype, and the gameplay that you experience through him is a weird, somewhat tedious fusion of third-person shooter and XCOM-style strategy. Don’t get me wrong, the visuals and effects of the abilities themselves are quite cool (especially in the late game, where you get access to turrets and airstrikes), but you have to hand-hold the inept AI that utilizes them so much that, in the end, you’re gonna be spending 50% of the time shepherding them through every action via Battle Focus (this game’s tactical view), and the other 50% running around and reviving them because they’re so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed fragile. Seriously, does the COM in XCOM stand for “Clothes Only, Men”? … (I’m so, so sorry.) Anyway, as a result there is a sort of franticness to the combat in that regard, but unlike its sister game Enemy Unknown, the management of lives is more frustrating than heart-poundingly tense due to the increased repetition and frequency at which “getting downed” occurs. In any case, if you end up purchasing this game (I personally wouldn’t unless it’s less than 7ish dollars), play on “Squaddie” difficulty or below, as there is less a focus on team micro-management, and more an emphasis on blasting aliens with space magic.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I recommend this game with a caveat. Read on. But first off: This is NOT an XCOM game. If you want XCOM, look elsewhere.This game looks pretty good, runs like absolute balls. Disable PhysX whatever you do. I went from 12 FPS in PhysX areas to 120+. It is NOT optimized for PhysX in any way. I played through the game on Veteran skill and I feel the challenge was overall fair. The combat is very reminiscent of the Mass Effect series, but I'd argue that it's actually better. The actual combat is pretty fun, although some enemies can feel overly bullet-spongy at times. Particularly the "miniboss" characters such as Mutons and Sectopods. This is compounded by the fact that you are forced to relocate around the battlefield constantly, as all the weapons have very limited ammo stocks, so you have to scrounge for ammo refills around the area. Keep in mind though that this is in no way a strategy game like its predecessor. This is a 3rd person squad-based cover shooter with tactical elements.The combat has plenty of variety in areas, enemy setups and equipment for your squad. Squad-classes are well diverse and you actually feel like you sometimes need a particular class in a particular battle to succeed, in difference from Mass Effect where you can go with basically anyone and still kick♥♥♥♥♥ I found myself dying a couple of times throughout the game and had to replay a few battles with better tactics, so I'd say difficulty and combat mechanics are spot on (aside the bullet-sponginess). The story is dumb. It's super dumb. I found myself cringing heavily during cutscenes when the characters were speaking. It really feels like no one in this game has half a brain to think with and they're regurlarly acting downright stupid and illogical at most times. Don't get me wrong though: The lore and the alien world/design is pretty cool and interesting. It's just the humans that are absolute toshpots. Especially the main character, Carter, seems like an absolute gorilla who thinks with his hormones.The game has issues with pacing. Sometimes it's easy to follow along the story missions and have a good pacing going, but then suddenly everything grinds to a halt and you have to faff about the base for 30 minutes (I hate all the running around) and then suddenly there are no story missions. Just side missions. So you HAVE to faff about pointless side missions. Not sure I'm a fan of that.In conclusion:Is this game any good? Yeah, I'd say it is. It has its problems absolutely, but I had overall fun. My absolute biggest gripe is the story and writing and how the main characters react to things. I won't spoil anything but some decisions in this game really made me want to eat my desk and the ending is absolute♥♥♥♥♥ Such a cop out story ending I nearly laughed. But I still recommend it as it was, for the most part, very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
A Paladin’s Review: The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. It's Really Not That Bad, For What It IsGenre: 3rd Person Tactical ShooterDeveloped & Published by: 2K Marin and 2K GamesPlatform support: Windows, PS3 and Xbox 360Business Model: Base GameCopy purchased by myselfRead the full and unabridged review on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]PreambleThe Bureau has had a troubled history. It spent a long time in development hell, changing studios and the game’s design multiple times. Though its 1960s aesthetic was the only thing that stayed consistent during this process. It was originally titled “XCOM”, a first person shooter with some tactical play. It was originally intended to be the focal point of the series’ reboot. The reboot of a beloved turn-based strategy game with mechanics that had become legendary by this point and time. (Yeah, it doesn’t take a genius to see where 2K might have gone wrong). The response to “XCOM” was severe dislike, leading to the game to be pushed back into the shadows of the public eye. Instead, XCOM: Enemy Unknown was released by a different development team and became really successful. Potentially leading the series to a new and bright future. The FPS “XCOM” wasn’t anywhere to be seen and there was much rejoicing. A year later, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified stepped from the shadows. In all of it’s glorious 1962 aesthetic, 3rd person tactical squad based action. It largely got mixed or negative reception. So, the question becomes: did The Bureau justify that reception? Well, let’s find out.   Turn-Based Tactics Combat SystemThere’s no turn-based strategy here. There is a tactical commander’s view that let’s you order your squadmates where to go, when to use abilities and on which alien/enemy targets. A large chunk of your game time will be spent going from combat spot to combat spot. As a whole, the combat is simply ok and it works. It has its satisfying moments now and again but it’s not the most exciting. Especially if you’ve played games in this genre before. However, one thing that I did like were some of combos you could make with different classes. Though I felt like they barely scratched the surface with class synergy and I’d like to see more useful combos in the future. Oh, I didn’t mention this but there are four classes in the game. Commandos (your bruisers), Engineers (deploy turrets and mines), Recon (Snipers) and Supports (medics). Each class has their own distinctive abilities and weapons. The weapons are reasonably weighty with a good amount of impact and firepower to make them all enjoyable to use. The cover system is a bit sticky and unwieldy at times. Far too often, I’d find myself trapped in a spot with no good way out. Or my agents would often find themselves in similar situations. Story and CharactersIf there is one thing I can say about The Bureau, it’s a story of conveniences. Somehow I’m supposed to believe that an alien invasion of this size would be kept secret from the public. The only reason I can buy this is that it’s the 1960s and communication was severely hampered. That somehow, I’m supposed to believe that an alien we captured becomes our ally in a quick heartbeat. Somehow, I’m supposed to believe that we can capture alien weapons and items with the “Venn Brace”. Which I can only assume is a magical tool we carry on our arms. (Where did that Venn Brace come from again?). A lot of this is either swept under the rug or just goes by you so quickly I think they’re hoping you won’t notice because SHINY. DLC ThoughtsI didn’t play the DLC and from what I can see, they don’t seem worth paying or plaything them. One is a gun pack, the other two are short uninspiring missions. I can’t help but feel like these were possibly cut from the final product to be sold as DLC. I didn't feel any particular compulsion to pick these up. PC Settings & OptimizationThe Bureau has a lot of graphical settings. There’s a reasonable amount of screen resolutions to choose from. Windowed mode, v-sync and film grain that can be turned off and on. It also supports up to 120FPS if you’re wanting that. Field-of-view is supported from 65-100 degrees. Any larger changes have to be made in a .ini file. PhysX is featured in the particles & clothing and can be disabled. You’ve got texture, world, shadow and effect detail sliders as well as anti-aliasing, anisotropic filtering, decal persistence, ambient occlusion and screen space reflection sliders. For the most part it’s a pretty decently optimized game. Though I did have several areas of combat situations where the framerate dropped pretty hard. A DX11 mode also exists that makes the game look somewhat better. However, it’s an incredibly costly mode for not a lot of gain which I couldn’t get it to run at a stable framerate. Final ThoughtsIt’s a good thing that 2K didn’t lead their reboot of the XCOM series with The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. Not to knock too harshly on the developers, but this would have killed the franchise dead. Now? I actually kinda want a sequel to this. A good sequel that stays with these developers, doesn’t get passed between multiple teams and doesn’t go through development hell. I think they have a good foundation started, but could use some more work to flesh everything out. As for XCOM Declassified currently, well, it’s just not that bad. It’s got a pretty good story and a decent enough combat system. It does try to be XCOM though it does lack many of the features of XCOM. There’s no research, no base(s) management, you can only command two other squadmates, it’s got less customization and less of the XCOM experience than it should. But for a 1960s take on the XCOM universe from a different perspective, I still kinda like it. It’s got a story with some pretty unique twists and turns, a pretty diverse cast of characters and seventeen hours of enjoyment. Read this review and others on A Paladin Without A Crusade[wp.me]

content:
Posted: September 18, 2014
												It's easy to see how this game got savaged not for being what it is, but for not being a different game entirely. But on its own merits I really enjoyed it. If it has a primary failing I'd say it's not enough.Almost everything begged to be expanded on just a little more, from the aliens to the tech to the main characters. It felt like there should have been at least one or two more main missions, a few more side missions, maybe some more viable weapons, maybe another enemy type... you see what I'm getting at. The game left me seriously wanting more - not just "replay it" more (though I'll probably be getting around to that soon enough) but just more content. The feel of this game would have benefited greatly from 2K Marin having just a little more time and money.But I still had a fantastic time with it. The weapons felt good, and upgrading to the alien weapons felt even better. The powers also felt great, and I never ended up regretting my choices. (Sure, they're kind of limited overall, but they're still fun.) Carter is well-built for holding and pushing at the enemy line, but can easily be played to sow confusion among the enemy's numbers. Your squadmates all had solid power choices as well, with each class fairly well balanced to its role and begging to fit different playstyles. I stuck mostly with the same squadmates throughout the game, as well as the same equipment, but am already considering how to change stuff up for next time. Nearly all the kills will still fall on your shoulders, but judicious use of your squadmates' powers will make it a lot easier - the Support agent's shield bubble is a lifesaver, and everyone else is full of ways to keep the enemies off your flanks or help crack a defensive point.I'm not much of a third-person/cover shooter player, but really, if this is a POOR representative of the genre, then I definitely need to play more. I'm not totally certain I'd buy this full price, but that's mostly because of financial considerations. I got it on sale and it was well worth what I paid.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												The Bureau is a very different take on the XCOM universe... it was set in 1960's, height of cold war, when a jamming wave blanketed the nation, and aliens invaded Earth. With comm blackout, information is slow to trickle in, but it appears the nation's military had been crippled, and only XCOM, a command setup to take control in case of full war, is mankind's last hope. At its heart Bureau is a tactical shooter where you control two other agents to deploy where you want them as well as deploy their special abilities, such as sniper hit, deploy turret, and so on. As the senior agent, you have abilities too, and you'll get more as time go on. Graphics are quite good and the desolation in the middle of 1960's America is quite evocative. Agents were wearing suits and appropriate hairstyles, esp. the ladies. There is also quite a bit of dialog, with choices you have to make (and they will affect the outcome, at least a little) a bit like Mass Effect series. Talk to other people in the base, for additional clues, expositions, notes, and whatnot that tells you more about the people you meet. Characterization is quite nice. Managing the agents during a sort of "Matrix-like super-slo-mo" mode known as "Battle Focus" is the key here, where you place the agents at vantage points so they can engage the enemy effectively is key. Flanking is often the best way, as are using the environment such as explosive barrels (yes, that too).  As agents gain "rank" they also gain special abilities they can deploy. The key is to deploy them at the right place at the right time, and that's your job as commander. The Aliens are nicely animated and sprints into and out of cover and will attempt to flank if possible. However, they are not very bright can can be outsmarted. Later you'll run into bosses, like Mutons and Sectopods (walkers), though most are just Greys. There are occasional elites and commanders. Commanders are tough as they can give shields to other units, but that just makes them vulnerable to strikes when they do that. Add drones, turrets, and you can be in a tough fight. This alternate history is a lot of fun to play in. It is highly recommended if you like the genre.

content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												It's a nice game when you are a fan of X-com, you get some more story behind everything and the atmosphere is spot on. The game itself is fun at the beginning, at least I could stomach it for a while, but it gets tedious after a few missions. It's the typical corridor shooter you expect these days, but this time you can predict exactly when you run into enemies. Encounter a group, run through some hallways, drop down and have another encounter... rinse and repeat.The management of your crew is shallow and it gets old after a few battles, so before half the game I didn't bother much with it. Other games do a far better job at it. For me the ammo scarcity was also a problem, having to find the right ammo type during each battle felt like a gimmick just to get me out deeper into the battlefield rather than hanging back. A little bit more capacity would have done the trick for me.The last two hours I had to force myself to finish the game, just because it was so repetitive.I'd still recommend this game, but... at a highly reduced price, and only if you are a fan of X-com.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												This game was simply pretty fun. A lot of the negative reviews come talk about the bad AI, but I never had huge problems with that. Sure, occasionally they'd leave cover for no reason or do other stupid positioning things, but it was never anything game-breaking, just an occasional minor annoyance. My one main problem with the game was that when you go into tactical mode where you're giving orders to your team, it doesn't paus the action, just puts it in slow-motion. This can lead to issues with trying to set up combos or time certain things correctly, because by the time you're done giving orders, the enemy might have moved or your first operative will have already started doing their action. But once you get used to the timing, it stops being really noticable. The story was pretty good, and I enjoyed getting to choose which classes to take into the field, therefore completely changing up how you fight in battles. This isn't anything like the other XCOM games, but if you go into it knowing that, then it's a fine game on its own.So my conclusion is, this was a decent game that doesn't deserve all the negativity it got. I don't know if I would have paid full price for it (and I didn't, because of reading the negative reviews), but if you can catch it on sale, it's definitely worth it if you enjoy third-person, squad-based shooters.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												As someone who enjoys the difficulty associated with the unforgiving nature of strategic, turn-based combat that is the hallmark of previous games under the XCOM title, all I can do is be honest and say that this game did not live up to that, even on harder difficulties.The bullet-time planning mode, while convenient if anything unexpected happened, was otherwise unnecessary, besides combat being fairly linear and predictable anyway: For the majority of battles, you can simply sit behind cover and murder anyone who pops their head up to try and shoot you. Every major combat area provides more than enough ammo to restock anything you would have used. Using abilities serves only to finish a particular battle a few seconds quicker and conserve a clip or two.You can ignore your teammates entirely since they deal substantially less damage over time than you and their AI's are remarkably self-sufficient, plus they never run out of ammo and will revive each other unless otherwise ordered by you.Without leaking spoilers, it can at least be said that the plot is forced and the ending anti-climactic. Plus the achievements offer essentially no challenge, most of which I unlocked by accident without even trying.The only conceivable highlight about the game, the one that kept me playing, was the variance in settings, which was enjoyable. Still, about mid-game it becomes clearly noticeable that the basic layout of all maps is the same, especially in combat areas, and it is only the appearance of the obstacles and backgrounds that differentiates them.All-in-all, a disappointing experience that I would not recommend to any sincere XCOM fan, and not one I would replay even to 100% for the few achievements I managed to miss.

This can lead to issues with trying to set up combos or time certain things correctly, because by the time you're done giving orders, the enemy might have moved or your first operative will have already started doing their action. But once you get used to the timing, it stops being really noticable. The story was pretty good, and I enjoyed getting to choose which classes to take into the field, therefore completely changing up how you fight in battles. This isn't anything like the other XCOM games, but if you go into it knowing that, then it's a fine game on its own.So my conclusion is, this was a decent game that doesn't deserve all the negativity it got. I don't know if I would have paid full price for it (and I didn't, because of reading the negative reviews), but if you can catch it on sale, it's definitely worth it if you enjoy third-person, squad-based shooters.
