number of helpful: 6 of 9 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												The Bureau is a professionally-developed ‘prequel’ to arguably the best series of PC games ever developed. It attempts bring the infamous tactical combat series to the console with Mass Effect inspired squad-based real-time battles. It utterly fails as a PC game and shames the XCOM title.Writers attempted to push the envelope in a few areas: two major characters include a gay Australian medical doctor and a senior female agent who struggles with the patriarchy of the era. Unfortunately, there is still the trope German scientists and the uncreatively written, guilt-driven by typical lost-love protagonist. The main quest develops much too fast, introducing new characters and pivots before the lead agent has sufficiently investigated the story or the player can understand justification for the last plot twist. The non-combat ‘investigation’ missions teased early on in development were never realized.Checkpoint saves, specifically before [skip-able] cutscenes break the games flow. For large battles, this is very demoralizing as failure to defeat a large end-boss means playing through waves of weak enemies ramping up to the climax that you've already seen several times. Combat is at its best when it clones gameplay that we've already seen in BioWare games. Special abilities distributed amongst your always-leveling squad are over-powered compared to level design which teases tactical flanking but is never effective at harder difficulties.Several weapons and items are under-powered and the player has no motivation to explore strategies with them, others (e.g. the blaster launcher) are all-but-required for taking down large enemies. The 'equipment pack' modifier to soldier abilities doesn’t hold a candle to mother XCOM’s soldier customization options. A total conversion of the XCOM:EU for the 60s era would suffice better than this poorly executed attempt at a prequel. Not only would I recommend not buying this, I'd avoid playing it too.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
TL;DR at BottomIf you enjoyed this review,consider giving it a thumbs up!7/10Puchase on a sale


In my sights 
A Screenshot of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a 3rd person tactical shooter developed by 2K Marina and published by 2K Games. In The Bureau it seems as if 2K really tried to expand the XCOM name and branch off with the hopes of making XCOM more than just a turn-based strategy series. Most AAA game developers these days are scared to try new things and branch out into different areas so I give 2K props for at least trying to do something different. I have no problem with 2K trying something new but the fact that they seem to have used the XCOM name as little more than a cash-in is deplorable as this game has very little in common with the rest of the XCOM series. The only aspects The Bureau takes from its predecessors are a couple of the same enemies and a general setting outline. The game seems like it wanted to be an XCOM version of Mass Effect but The Bureau is neither particularly good at being an XCOM game or a third-person shooter.


Shields up! 
A Screenshot of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




The Bureau's story is essentially that the world has been hit with a series of alien attacks and you, Agent Carter, have to go on a variety of missions for the XCOM program, essentially humanities last line of defense, in order to stop the threat and save the world. There's obviously a bit more to it than that but overall the story is just your basic alien invasion story and has pretty much nothing unique about it to deserve the XCOM name. The setting is interesting as instead of modern weapons you engage the aliens with 70's era weaponry which means that early on in the game you'll be at a severe disadvantage when fighting aliens wielding plasma cannon and laser rifles. The environments that The Bureau has you trekking through are extraordinarily bland and offer very little in terms of uniqueness since the game is as linear as linear gets. The Bureau wants you to explore to find new weapons and backpacks, the only real customizable gear the game has to offer, but what it means by "exploring" is to just walk down another hallway or look behind you. I found all the characters to be absolutely repulsive save, ironically, the alien prisoner you acquire early on in the game. Every character has heaps of voice lines overusing phrases like "we're going to make the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s pay" and as the aggravating dialogue piles up you end up skipping through it all and not caring at all about the characters or what they have to say. The Bureau also features one or two moments where you have to choices and these moments make you feel as if The Bureau wanted to try and be an RPG in the vein of Mass Effect but instead just couldn't perform. In the end, after listening to nothing but the same old faux-patriotic quips from the whole character lineup you end the game begging for the aliens to hurry up and get on with it.


Mosaic 
A Screenshot of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified
By: Friedmudkips ツ #FreeMilo




The combat is really where you begin to see peeks of how The Bureau could have been something great but instead really defaces the XCOM name. The Bureau prides itself on tactical combat where you have to use a bit of tricky maneuvering and strategy in order to save the day and truly this is where most of the enjoyment is at. The gun progression is pretty bad since about halfway through the game you have all the weapons that you'll need and The Bureau doesn't give you good reason to use any of the rest. Some of the guns feel decent but other are like peashooters and even that seems like it may be an exaggeration. The gameplay itself though is very interesting as you really do have to use traditional XCOM tactics like positioning your men in cover or flaking your foes to do extra damage. Every one of the squadmates has a class and these classes each come with unique abilities that progressively unlock as you level each character up. These abilities allow not only for very satisfying visual shows but also for a suprising degree of synergy with the squad as a whole. For example, you could have one man throw down a turret, have another shield it, and then have the final man lift it up so it ignores cover. These abilities and how they synergize with each other is really what makes The Bureau unique and worth a purchase. However, the AI is quite possibly the worst I have ever seen in a game and certainly shouldn't be in a game with such a renowned name as XCOM. You spend most of your time babysitting the AI to make sure they don't run into enemy fire or charge a minefield and in some points it feels almost like artificial difficulty. The AI seriously impacts combat on the higher difficulties but even still there's enough here that I can say it's worth a try.TL;DRA third person tactical shooter with a mediocre plot and cliched characters that is only brought to light by the unique combat system.If you found this review helpful or entertaining then feel free to join my Steam Curator Group at  Mudkips Gaming

content:
Posted: July 30, 2014
												I got this game cheap from the Humble Bundle so I can't really complain too much. Overall, it's not a bad game, but I felt that I should warn anyone considering picking this game up. Best way I can describe this game is, it's like playing Mass Effect 2 with the first game's horrible horrible AI companion. I've had them randomly get up and run straight at the enemies or get out of cover for no reason. The combat areas are pretty well designed (some pretty big) giving you a chance to flank the enemies however, there seems to be a leash between you and your squad which makes it hard to set up some strategy because they'll randomly get ported to your location and sometime in the middle of the battle out of cover. Two things I liked about the combat in this game, and I hope we see it in future games like this, is the ability to tell your squad exactly where to go and the ability to queue up actions. Once you start unlocking more abilities for your squad, the game defnitely gets better. There are some cool interaction between different class' abilities. If you can put up with the horrible AI, you might enjoy the game.

number of helpful: 11 of 19 people (58%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a 3rd-person tactical shooter that takes place during the 1960's and absolutely nails its setting. The graphics and art design are fantastic, as long as you get the game running well on your machine. In The Bureau, aliens invade Earth and the XCOM group sends their best to take on the aliens.Combat is very similar to that of Mass Effect 2 + 3 - but combat here is much more tactical, since you have way more control of your party members. In fact, it's pretty much essential to survive that you must use the tactical "slow-down" to survive. It's not a BioWare-style tactical pause here - it only slow-down time a bit for you to make orders. You may create, randomize, and recruit agents and their actual looks, class, and everything at your own will and desire. Though, the down-side is that you'll never really feel attached to your teammates - since they do not have personal "Loyalty" missions, to make you care about them; this isn't Mass Effect here. If there's anything besides the excellent art direction and setting that 2K Marin gets absolutely right with this game, it's the excellent tactical combat. One thing that is never dull here is the tactical combat - and this is certainly the best reason to play this game. If you liked the combat in Mass Effect 2 + 3 but wanted something a bit more tactical and have more control over your party members when in combat - this is the game for you. Even on Squaddie (difficulty #2 out of 4), this game is tough - and this is coming from someone who plays a lot of games - especially shooters. The game actually suggests difficulty #3 by default - which given how tough Squaddie often is, given the number of times my party died, had to reload a save, or lost a party member to "perma-death"; I'm not sure if the 3rd difficulty should be suggested as its default! "Perma-death" is in effect here - so if you survive a mission and one of your party members doesn't, they're gone from your game entirely.2K Marin did a fantastic job with storytelling & character development in Bioshock 2: Minerva's Den DLC, but doesn't do so as much here. Storytelling events that occur either are quite obvious as to what's going happen next (predictable!); and/or the big pay-off moments just aren't well put-together or is under-developed. By the time the game's story gets very interesting & has an excellent twist, which is somewhere closer to the back 1/4th of the game - it makes the gamer wonder why this sort of execution also didn't happen earlier, as well. But, once this plot-twist happens, the game drops the ball again in another regard: by spreading out auto-save points, which can lead to moments of complete frustration when players have to replay long-winded shootouts. There's nothing wrong w/ grand, long-winded epic shootouts like these - but it could've used an auto-save, somewhere in the middle or before the game brings out the really tough moment - since the game does have difficulty spikes within some of these sections.What it all comes down to, is this: if you want a game with excellent art direction; an excellent setting; looks great in DX11 mode (if your PC can handle it); you enjoy 3rd-person shooting similar to Mass Effect 2 + 3; but you also want a shooter more tactical than Mass Effect 2 + 3 - then this game is for you and it shouldn't be missed. If you're looking for a game with great story and characters, most of the time - this is not that game. It doesn't always execute that stuff consistently. The Bureau could've been elevated to a much greater status, if it actually delivered more consistently on its character + story elements, since it actually does often try to emphasize these elements. Overall, when it's all said and done - The Bureau is a solid and worthwhile 3rd-person tactical shooter.Final Grade: C+

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
Recommended with a grain of salt  Review This game was a positive surprise to me. I got it from a bundle, and the bad reviews made me thought I might never even try this considering the amount of games in library still unplayed. Playfire reasons I ended up playing a bit from the start, and found that the criticism has been to harsh on this one.Basically the game is 3rd person action game with chest-high-walls. So a cover shooter in short. Very very similar to Mass Effect 2 without the rpg elements.It is surely not a perfect game, not even close, but also it's not as bad as it seems. It's gameplay wise well done, looks good, plays good and all that. A solid performance and not much to nitpick about. Voice acting is decent, animation mostly good and length of the game is good, around 14 hours. Tactics are somewhat hard to learn first, but after playing few hours I felt the system somewhat intuitive. There are major flaws in the way AI behaves with you, but mostly it didn't bother me as long as I didn't keep moving much. On harder difficulties it might prove a lot more stressing to know that you cannot count on your comrades staying where you want them to stay.To my surprise the game was pretty hard, especially in the beginning the game wasn't a walk in the park. Something to remind that this was still in the Xcom universe, if nothing else is the same. Though the game got gradually easier, it still held some harder moments near the end.The parts that this game is lacking is the fact this this isn't a polished game. It feels uncompleted, something like Kotor 2. You feel that there is or was supposed to be something deeper, something better, but it got cut out of the game. The plot is full of weird unexplained holes that only seem to be there because someone wanted a faster ending. It really could've had a potential for much better and even in the end the game surprises with some weird choice options that could've used more explanation or flesh around them. Even though I completed about 99% of the game, I felt that I had skipped some major content.Also the game's level design is somewhat lacking. Although there's a great 60's wibe, it's not much used. Most of the missions are in semi-alien environment where alien structures dot the landscape of 60's america. Also the design constantly spoiles the surprises by giving up when a fight is about to start.    Pros  Gameplay is mostly very smooth and I didn't find any bugs in it. Should work like a charm. Plot is somewhat interesting. Not the easiest game on the market. Gives some challenge.   Cons  Friendly AI is stupid and might have a huge effect on harder difficulties Plot is full of holes and seems uncompleted. Unpolished and poorly finished

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Definitely would not recommend it above $10.   Pros:  It has a interesting retro 50s feel to it.   Story seemed to be going okay, as far as I played.Cons: Just about everything else.  Notably the AI is absolutely terrible.   The game is designed around you controlling two partners that are supposed to help you fight.  They don't.   They simply disobey your orders at every conceivable opportunity and are mega-suicidal to boot, often breaking cover to run TOWARD the grenade.    Also notably bad is the UI.  Clearly was intended to be another badly ported game made only for controllers.   The UI to give commands requires you to navigate a checkpoint around obstacles and through mazes for every command, even when its not a line of sight action.    Frustrating is the best word for it when you can't even pause the game entirely to issue the orders.  Just doesn't work.   After watching my 10th squad member in a row, move away from where I told him to set up cover, I finally uninstalled it and dropped it into the trash category.    What exactly is the point of a squad level tactical game, when the AI refuses to do as its told?If it hits a steam sale at some point, maybe it might be worth it then, just don't set you expectation beyond "terrible".    A game should be meant to be challenging because of the content, not because the player is fighting with the game mechanics.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												In an alternate timeline: The year is 1950. Donald Draper never joined Sterling Cooper to work as an ad man, he remained in the army and rose through the ranks. Eventually recruited by the CIA, he becomes involved with The Bureau, and helps fight off an alien invasion of Earth. Thats this game in a nutshell: Donald Draper shooting aliens.The gameplay is fun, at first. The Third person shooter + squad combat is neat on the first mission, when you get agents with all their abilities unlocked. But then it takes that away and you have to -slowly- level them up again. Gameplay is largely the same, fighting the same 2 aliens over and over again, except when they occasionally throw in a muton or sectopod battle. Also, one of the big bosses froze up on me and just sat there as my squad gunned it down. Long set peices showing off the devestated cities lead up to cover based combat sections in a predictable pattern. For some reason, there's more ammo than you can carry in the areas without enemies.The characters suffer from a bad case of rubber face, and the shot-reverse-shot dialogue trees become tedious very fast. Which sucks, because apparently a bunch of content is hidden in the speech you go through in the base. It's a cool game in premise, but it doesnt quite live up to what it could have been. A few tweaks and a little more though into varying gameplay would have gone very far in making this better. Although it is a totally different game, XCOM Enemy Unknown does a better job at Squad based alien killin fun. I got this in the Humble Bundle, so its okay for the price, but I wouldnt recommend buying this game straight up, unless it's on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												In an alternate timeline: The year is 1950. Donald Draper never joined Sterling Cooper to work as an ad man, he remained in the army and rose through the ranks. Eventually recruited by the CIA, he becomes involved with The Bureau, and helps fight off an alien invasion of Earth. Thats this game in a nutshell: Donald Draper shooting aliens.The gameplay is fun, at first. The Third person shooter + squad combat is neat on the first mission, when you get agents with all their abilities unlocked. But then it takes that away and you have to -slowly- level them up again. Gameplay is largely the same, fighting the same 2 aliens over and over again, except when they occasionally throw in a muton or sectopod battle. Also, one of the big bosses froze up on me and just sat there as my squad gunned it down. Long set peices showing off the devestated cities lead up to cover based combat sections in a predictable pattern. For some reason, there's more ammo than you can carry in the areas without enemies.The characters suffer from a bad case of rubber face, and the shot-reverse-shot dialogue trees become tedious very fast. Which sucks, because apparently a bunch of content is hidden in the speech you go through in the base. It's a cool game in premise, but it doesnt quite live up to what it could have been. A few tweaks and a little more though into varying gameplay would have gone very far in making this better. Although it is a totally different game, XCOM Enemy Unknown does a better job at Squad based alien killin fun. I got this in the Humble Bundle, so its okay for the price, but I wouldnt recommend buying this game straight up, unless it's on sale.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2013
												I think it's an excellent, fun, accessible game and a great low-impact X-Com game to boot. It definitely takes the franchise in a different fork (more mission and story driven than strategy) but the strategic aspects aren't completely absent and at later levels if you have the difficulty up you actually need to control your agents and position them if you're going to survive.This is coming from someone who played X-COM and Terror From the Deep on the Amiga back in the day and loved the hell out of them, and I can honestly say I've thoroughly enjoyed the game. It has an LA Noire sense to it, with intrigue and loads of sideplots and stuff you can do if you wander the base and talk to people. I didn't particularly care for any of the X-Coms after Terror From the Deep aside from the X-Com remake, so if you're like me and you like the first two X-Coms and don't necessarily need a heavy squad-management and base builder sim, give it a try.My only lament is that any gear you want you must discover in missions, some of them completely optional. There is no 'research' beyond what the storyline demands, so the game loses some of the greatness of being able to research and retrofit the alien tech as you recover corpses and such. While it's something I missed in the game, the fact that once you salvage alien technology in the field X-Com can reproduce it for all of your agents is cool.I'd like to see a sequel to this game made with some more rpg elements like more skill branching, more skill levels, and research and development. Everything else I found to be quite refreshing, especially the timeline which hearkens back to good old Cold War era paranoia, Area 51 and 'the end of innocence'.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												Pro's;- Storyline was good (main reedemable feature)- Voice acting (although some was terribly cliche)- Not a bad shooter- Variaty of weapons- Artwork and level design was good - Loved the 60's vibe Cons;- Not challenging- Too short- Too linear- Empty (RPG and Game-wise)Pros explained;The storyline was great IMO, without ruining too much the start of the game starts out slow but then there is further development in the later stages of the game (although you do have to get to the end practically). It fits in with the universe, to an extent, and it ties itself off whilst still connecting itself to future game. Spoiler:  The multiple endings aren't worth replaying IMO as all the choices are at the end but I do like this feature. The voice acting was decent but I did get bored of Carters cliche 60's American hero, they tried to falw him and they did a good job, I hated the guy up until the end, Because i could see his point but still why does nobody in this game follow orders!?. The only other issue was Angelas character (Her emotions are warranted but she is suppose to be a CIA Operative, Comeon)It isn't a bad shooter either for the price (if it's on sale i'd easily say £10 is worth it) for what it has, so long as you dont have any high expectations. Combat is pretty much whack-a-mole style (duck when they fire and shoot when they've stopped/or have your teammates shoot them) still there is some tactics involved. The variaty of weapons are good but only being able to carry two is a drawback but neccessary (as you do need to conserve ammo and adds more realism and for the player to use tactics). But there are plenty of games that are worse than this as a fps.The artwork and design of the entire game I loved, there really isnt much I can critisise (unless we include Carters really annoying animations for hand gestures, where you just see him tapping his fist into his hands every second of the conversation) But overall they looked alien and i loved the contrast of America - Alien. Con's Explained;This game is not long. 20 hours on hardest difficulty and 30%-40% of that was the last mission, the long ending though did leave it enjoyable rather than alot of newer games with anti-climatic endings. But they really could of fleshed out more missions or longer ones. This leads to it not being difficult as enemies typically come in waves, which once you're behind cover you can pretty much eliminate 3-4 enemies before they position themseleves. I wish they used some of the more advanced units earlier or put more together so i felt pressured, like the end mission. (Permadeath on your agents really shouldnt be an issue so long as you keep together) I didn't lose a single agent on the hardest difficulty. I admit I was close a few times on the end mission. Xcom's I know arent linear games, but what i mean by this, especially stating it as empty, was there wasn't many side missions or consequences of certain missions like in the others (which would of been nice). To top it off the missions were linear and there wasn't try this approach or go down this way to get to the objective (unless you call using a different hallway that) the most detailed areas were the combat areas. (understandably) The few areas in a mission you can go another way they're dead-ends to pick up lore (scraps of paper or audio reels), nice but they could of added more. To add to the lore it was a shame they didnt have more for the "scan", yes you can scan enemies and it details them and weapons for you which was pretty unique but it was a shame (part from one side-mission) that scanning wasn't used to find hidden things in the campaign or to research enemies or something similar.Lastly the second point of it being or feeling empty is the RPG portion, although you have 4 types of squad mates and yourself you're probably only going to use the engineer and scout class (they have the best abilities by far deploying turrets and mines added with diversion and airstirke) the other two feel lackluster compared (the engineer was only redeemable for the turrent TBH). Adding to that they only have 5 levels, of which each class usually has three abilities and two upgrades for said abilities, YOU HAVE TO USE THESE ABILITIES, it's not a choice between two abilities, its a choice between two classes pretty much. The same thing applies to the protagonist. If youre a fan of Xcom its good for lore and a chnage of pace, just dont think it's going to be as great as the traditional ones.If not and you're looking for a casual gears of war/mass effect Third-Person (which the emphasis on cover, abilities and ammo conservation) This is pretty decent, Unless you fall into one of the two categories I wouldn't buy it.Overall 7/10 Because of the gameplay and I didn't have my hopes up (I expected it to be terrible) But the gameplay aint bad. Then again I paid like £5 for this and i played 30+ hours, deffo worth it for that.

content:
Posted: April 27, 2016
												This is a game that (we) X-Com fans wanted to love, but just couldn't. But I believe it has enough to be liked.The first thing that the game has going for it is the noir theme, such an amazing atmosphere, and good voice acting (although the face animations are not up to par with the dialogues). The setting, 1963 IIRC, is spectacularly used to breathe fresh air to the game. There are a lot of little details that really help to build the X-Com world. Also, those are the key elements that save The Bureau from being just a complete rip-off of the first Mass Effect.The whole squad tactical FPS combat is not as bad (some combo between abilities are actually really fun and easy to pull off) as long as you don't mind micromanaging (pausing all the time to give instructions to your teammates). Even so, your teammates will do stupid things, like ignore cover orders and never use their abilities. It's not terrible, but it is frustrating. In fact, you can argue that by the end those AI mistakes are the real difficult level, since by the end of the game you become really powerful and destroy your enemies by using just a little bit of tactical awareness.In general, the plot is well handled, the atmosphere is amazing and everything else is Mass Effect 1 with some minor changes. I loved ME 1. This game? I liked it just ok.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												Back in 2010, 2k Marin decided that it wanted to develop its own cheap knockoff of Mass Effect, but "Cheap Knockoff of Mass Effect" was not a very popular title in focus testing, so they licensed the XCOM name to apply on top like a smiley face sticker might be applied next to the "F" on your child's report card.  It bears almost no resemblance to the beloved franchise, with no research or base building, tiny squad sizes, very little squad management, and a plot that is incongruous with the original games as well as Firaxis' recent release.In the course of development, it was then determined that creating additional missions or even coming up with a form of randomization would be too costly, and besides, what people really loved most about Mass Effect was running around the Citadel over and over and over.  So with The Bureau 2k Marin adopted the philosophy of Twice the Fedexing, Twice the Fun, and you'll find approximately 90% of your time in game is spent shuffling at a slow pace, unable to sprint or run or jog or walk briskly, up the stairs, down the hall, up some more stairs, down another hall just to talk to someone, and then back down again because even though you have a plasma pistol and laser rifle, nobody has yet invented the walkie talkie and everyone wants to talk to you.  Unfortunately you will occasionally be accosted by actual gameplay, forcing you to briefly abandon your quest for a new world record in Most Stairs Climbed in a Video Game and shoot some aliens, but luckily these missions are short, incredibly easy, and entirely forgettable.  In summation, I highly recommend picking up this game if you intend to play it only while honing your real-life drinking skills, though don't mistakenly assume that your in-game character's past drinking problem will make him more identifiable to you or provide any sort of character depth to make you at all invested in the backstory to the game, because 2k Marin thinks "character development" is a reference to the linear upgrade system available in the extremely limited RPG element of the game.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												  While no particular aspect of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is earth shattering, the overall experience is quite enjoyable and makes for a solid addition to the fairly niche tactical shooter lineup.  Given the fantastic games that get made by 2K, it is strange to me that their development process can so frequently be described as problematic, as was the case for 2K Marin.  This title had some interesting features planned such as detective work and stealth based gameplay, but those unfortunately got cut as the game underwent repeated revisions and delays.  It sounded promising.  As is, The Bureau fails to inspire much passion but nonetheless contains plenty of fun and is without question worth a play.  I have to admit I was very excited about The Bureau prior to getting my hands on it, and even now have a certain amount of bias favoring this one, because of: 60's Cold War Setting Action Shooter w/Squad Based Tactics Scifi Theme  I love speculative, historical fiction.  I loved the Brothers in Arms IP and was ready for more such action, and of course like everyone, I love convincing science fiction.  The Bureau delivered in some regards and not others.  The story expands upon what's already established by previous titles in the IP.  The plot had some clever ideas that I liked, and some that baffled, none of which I can describe without spoilers, so I won't go there.  I didn't play the classic series back when it came out in the mid '90s, so as story and gameplay go, I - unlike the core fans - am blessedly free of the urge to decry any deviations from what made those games great.  My impression is that XCOM is one of those rare IP's that just doesn't need an overly involved story; it is enough that aliens are here wreaking havoc on Earth and humanity must pull together to survive and conquer.    Combat is fun.  It didn't get old before I reached the end, not even after I attempted a new playthrough on the Commander difficulty.  On standard difficulty you can play it all tactical, all shooter or anything in between.  It all works and satisfies.  Putting around the base between missions is okay and rewards the player with bits of background story and unlockable side missions.  Most of the campaign is linear, which is fine by me.  The bugs were few and far enough between that they don't merit mention.  The visuals with graphic settings maxed are excellent and the audio does its job.  My only technical complaint is that the actual movement and placement of your agents (and targeted abilities) with the ground cursor feels a bit console port.  You use skills and reposition often in combat encounters, so this might get tiresome.  I don't have the DLC's and have no knowledge of Hangar 6 R&D.  My thoughts on this game included how a cooperative or competitive mode might work: the player pauses to access skills and issue squad orders in a tactical mode.  So, instead of being able to pause and use that interface indefinitely, start players with only a few seconds of the tactical mode but reward them (jointly in co-op, individually in competitive) with extra seconds of tactical time for skillful play (flanking and exposed attacks, environmental kills, combo and skill kills, etcetera).    After finishing the game, I went and read some major reviews.  In my opinion they're a bit unfair.  My advice is to judge the game on its own merit and decide for yourself.  It may or may not feel like an XCOM title but at the end of the day The Bureau is an entertaining, fun and brief experience that I recommend to anyone who shares the tastes I listed here.TIP: Avoid Rookie difficulty; it is trivial and will bore you.TIP: Don't jump straight into Commander difficulty - instead get a feel for the mechanics first.TIP: Once you are at Commander, remember the game punishes even slight deviations from ideal tactics.  You will consistently have to use everything at your disposal including skills, environment, rapid repositioning and your own sharpshooting.  If you don't, be ready to restart checkpoints a lot..TIP: If you're digging the story and setting, there are side activities to hunt down in base and also letters and audio clips both at base and in the field.  Plus, if you stand near people they will have some funny conversations.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Fans of XCOM will probably think this is some squad-shooter that someone just slapped the "xcom" tag on to try and boost sales after the success of XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  With the exception of the setting and mobs you fight, this game has virtually nothing in common with XCOM.First off there is no research or crafting of any kind.  This was one of the staples of XCOM, that you had to collect alien tech and research it quickly to keep up with the alien escalation.  In this game, the aliens conveniently leave weapons lying around for you to find.  Once found they can be equipped on every squadmate capable of using the specific type of gun.  No manufacturing required either.  Thus, two of the main features of an XCOM game (R&D) are eliminated.Second, your squadmates are utterly braindead.  Seriously, they will stand there getting shot it the face while yelling "commander what do I do?"  Often after you tell them to move to full cover, they will inexplicably run out of said cover right into enemy fire.  This requires constant babysitting by you, breaking up the flow of the real time combat.  Their special abilities are somewhat useful, but you'll find that most of the mobs you'll have to kill yourself, as they apparently cannot shoot the side of the proverbial barn.Talking to people at HQ is someone annoying.  You cannot run inside the base, forcing you to walk to everywhere you want to go.  Frequently you'll have to move from one side of the base to another in order to proceed.  Then when you do get there the animations are a bit "robotic".  The voice acting is fine, but everyone you speak to looks like they just got the body 10 mins ago and are still trying to figure out how to work it.The game map allows you to pick missions, but unlike previous XCOM games there is no pressure to pick the most pressing.  Before, you'd only be able to deal with one threat and have to decide which one is more pressing.  In this game, no problem the aliens take their time and you can beat the missions one at a time at your convenience.  Finally, the main protagonist, Carter, is possibly the most unlikeable character in gaming.  He has the stereotyped "angry guy who lost his family but blames himself" backstory.  Yet, he never tries to redeem himself.  Pretty much he starts the game an a-hole and just continues being an a-hole.   At one point, he does something so stupid you want to reach into the game and strangle him.  Overall, this is a half-baked attempt to cash in on the resurgence of XCOM popularity.  Even if you're not a fan of XCOM games, there are far better squad-based shooter games out there.  If you do love XCOM I'd strongly suggest skipping this game.  Even though I got it on sale it was not worth the sale price,

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												When I bought this game I thought, "Well, it doesn't have anything like X-Com gameplay at all, but maybe it wont be too bad."I was wrong. Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥where do I begin, how about gameplay. It plays like a bad, uninspired Mass Effect, the only cool feature being the slow-mo that comes up when you're selecting which skills to use and deciding where to put your AI partners. Theres not much in the way of team management outside of combat. Your AI partners by the way are essentially blank slate goons whose skills and appearance you can customize, and they show up in cutscenes, and thats about it. No dialog aside from stuff they yell in combat. Equipment wise all you got are guns and backpacks, and there are about a thousand god damn backpacks, all with different bonuses, but after you get the straight damage increase or defense increase ones you probably wont bother experimenting, because the bonuses themselves are pretty lack luster. You get most of those backpacks from side missions you send AI dudes to go handle solo so they can get a free level up.Story wise it's a mess. Without getting into spoilers the gist of it is a "SAVE THE WORLD FROM THE ALIENS" plot like you'd expect, but aside from the angle of the mass cover up, it's pretty forgettable. Speaking of forgettable, I honestly cant recall the name of the protagonist, he's that bland. With a backstory of "SOLDIER/AGENT BADASS" you'd think they'd think of something more interesting that "He's seen some♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;. There are side plots that are straight up dropped, there are moral choices that dont actually matter (aside from one I think, and its not even one at the end) and the general theme of censorship and "NO ONE MUST KNOW" is pretty much not there aside from the occasional dialog snippet from NPCs. You dont burn or hide evidence yourself, its more or less just an alien murder ride from start to finish. The game tries to connect itself with the Enemy Unknown/Within game, I wont go into spoilers but it doesnt do it very well, and there are a lot of "What" moments.The setting is Americana/Cold War, and while you can sort of see it in the levels and loving on characters, the actually COLD WAR, even though it would be rightly overshadowed by the wide scale alien invasion, only comes up like twice.And besides all that, heres some nit picking!Why are there audio logs everywhere? EVERYWHERE.How does everyone already know the names to each of the alien enemy types? Theres never any "What do we call it?" moments, its just "MUTON! SECTOPOD!"Why does the artillery skill work indoors?Why does this game try to force itself into the EU/W story when it doesnt want to be consistant? "Nah, we bulldozed all that sick plasma tech and got rid of the info we had on the aliens, have fun starting from scratch while fighting off a second invasion, but its cool, you can have a fedora."WHY IS IT SO EASY. I played on the hardest difficult and it doesnt make the enemy AI any smarter, just harder to kill.Final verdict: Wasted Potential/10, do not buy.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												  While no particular aspect of The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is earth shattering, the overall experience is quite enjoyable and makes for a solid addition to the fairly niche tactical shooter lineup.  Given the fantastic games that get made by 2K, it is strange to me that their development process can so frequently be described as problematic, as was the case for 2K Marin.  This title had some interesting features planned such as detective work and stealth based gameplay, but those unfortunately got cut as the game underwent repeated revisions and delays.  It sounded promising.  As is, The Bureau fails to inspire much passion but nonetheless contains plenty of fun and is without question worth a play.  I have to admit I was very excited about The Bureau prior to getting my hands on it, and even now have a certain amount of bias favoring this one, because of: 60's Cold War Setting Action Shooter w/Squad Based Tactics Scifi Theme  I love speculative, historical fiction.  I loved the Brothers in Arms IP and was ready for more such action, and of course like everyone, I love convincing science fiction.  The Bureau delivered in some regards and not others.  The story expands upon what's already established by previous titles in the IP.  The plot had some clever ideas that I liked, and some that baffled, none of which I can describe without spoilers, so I won't go there.  I didn't play the classic series back when it came out in the mid '90s, so as story and gameplay go, I - unlike the core fans - am blessedly free of the urge to decry any deviations from what made those games great.  My impression is that XCOM is one of those rare IP's that just doesn't need an overly involved story; it is enough that aliens are here wreaking havoc on Earth and humanity must pull together to survive and conquer.    Combat is fun.  It didn't get old before I reached the end, not even after I attempted a new playthrough on the Commander difficulty.  On standard difficulty you can play it all tactical, all shooter or anything in between.  It all works and satisfies.  Putting around the base between missions is okay and rewards the player with bits of background story and unlockable side missions.  Most of the campaign is linear, which is fine by me.  The bugs were few and far enough between that they don't merit mention.  The visuals with graphic settings maxed are excellent and the audio does its job.  My only technical complaint is that the actual movement and placement of your agents (and targeted abilities) with the ground cursor feels a bit console port.  You use skills and reposition often in combat encounters, so this might get tiresome.  I don't have the DLC's and have no knowledge of Hangar 6 R&D.  My thoughts on this game included how a cooperative or competitive mode might work: the player pauses to access skills and issue squad orders in a tactical mode.  So, instead of being able to pause and use that interface indefinitely, start players with only a few seconds of the tactical mode but reward them (jointly in co-op, individually in competitive) with extra seconds of tactical time for skillful play (flanking and exposed attacks, environmental kills, combo and skill kills, etcetera).    After finishing the game, I went and read some major reviews.  In my opinion they're a bit unfair.  My advice is to judge the game on its own merit and decide for yourself.  It may or may not feel like an XCOM title but at the end of the day The Bureau is an entertaining, fun and brief experience that I recommend to anyone who shares the tastes I listed here.TIP: Avoid Rookie difficulty; it is trivial and will bore you.TIP: Don't jump straight into Commander difficulty - instead get a feel for the mechanics first.TIP: Once you are at Commander, remember the game punishes even slight deviations from ideal tactics.  You will consistently have to use everything at your disposal including skills, environment, rapid repositioning and your own sharpshooting.  If you don't, be ready to restart checkpoints a lot..TIP: If you're digging the story and setting, there are side activities to hunt down in base and also letters and audio clips both at base and in the field.  Plus, if you stand near people they will have some funny conversations.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2014
												Fans of XCOM will probably think this is some squad-shooter that someone just slapped the "xcom" tag on to try and boost sales after the success of XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  With the exception of the setting and mobs you fight, this game has virtually nothing in common with XCOM.First off there is no research or crafting of any kind.  This was one of the staples of XCOM, that you had to collect alien tech and research it quickly to keep up with the alien escalation.  In this game, the aliens conveniently leave weapons lying around for you to find.  Once found they can be equipped on every squadmate capable of using the specific type of gun.  No manufacturing required either.  Thus, two of the main features of an XCOM game (R&D) are eliminated.Second, your squadmates are utterly braindead.  Seriously, they will stand there getting shot it the face while yelling "commander what do I do?"  Often after you tell them to move to full cover, they will inexplicably run out of said cover right into enemy fire.  This requires constant babysitting by you, breaking up the flow of the real time combat.  Their special abilities are somewhat useful, but you'll find that most of the mobs you'll have to kill yourself, as they apparently cannot shoot the side of the proverbial barn.Talking to people at HQ is someone annoying.  You cannot run inside the base, forcing you to walk to everywhere you want to go.  Frequently you'll have to move from one side of the base to another in order to proceed.  Then when you do get there the animations are a bit "robotic".  The voice acting is fine, but everyone you speak to looks like they just got the body 10 mins ago and are still trying to figure out how to work it.The game map allows you to pick missions, but unlike previous XCOM games there is no pressure to pick the most pressing.  Before, you'd only be able to deal with one threat and have to decide which one is more pressing.  In this game, no problem the aliens take their time and you can beat the missions one at a time at your convenience.  Finally, the main protagonist, Carter, is possibly the most unlikeable character in gaming.  He has the stereotyped "angry guy who lost his family but blames himself" backstory.  Yet, he never tries to redeem himself.  Pretty much he starts the game an a-hole and just continues being an a-hole.   At one point, he does something so stupid you want to reach into the game and strangle him.  Overall, this is a half-baked attempt to cash in on the resurgence of XCOM popularity.  Even if you're not a fan of XCOM games, there are far better squad-based shooter games out there.  If you do love XCOM I'd strongly suggest skipping this game.  Even though I got it on sale it was not worth the sale price,

SECTOPOD!"Why does the artillery skill work indoors?Why does this game try to force itself into the EU/W story when it doesnt want to be consistant? content:
Posted: February 3, 2014
												I never read a review of this game until after I had beaten it.  I wasn't terribly interested in buying it based on the poor review scores it received.  I decided to pick it up on a weekend sale based on a friend telling me they enjoyed playing it.  All I can say is that I'm glad I did.  While I understand where a lot of the reviews are coming from, the story at the end goes batshit very quickly, especially with unexpected and uncharacteristic responses from the main character due to what's happening in the story.  Also the mechanic where you get punished more for partial success than for failure in that if an agent dies and you succeed, he stays dead.  But if he dies and you fail, you start up at the last checkpoint.That being said, the combat is pretty awesome.  It feels like it's taking a page from Mass Effect 2/3 combat but also combining it with a bunch of X-COM: Enemy Unknown's tactics/aesthetics.  It's a pretty game, although my computer struggled with DX11 a little bit, so I ran standard.I plan on playing it again on a more difficult setting.  On normal it was an alright challenge.  I managed to finish the game without losing any agents, though there were times that I'd fail encounters outright multiple times before completing them due to managing my team better.SPOILER(ish)The one thing I did and also very much did not like about the story, all at the same time is that very near the end they give a very good explanation for the 3rd person perspective and the slow down time mechanic of battle tactics.  If you played it, you'll definitely understand what I'm getting at.I definitely recommend this game to fans of Mass Effect 2/3 combat.  For X-COM purists, I hear it's a tough pill to swallow regarding canon, so take it with a grain of salt perhaps?

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified was not well received by mainstream reviewers, but I personally enjoyed it a lot. Overall, it feels like a stripped down version of Mass Effect, but the combat stands out above other cover shooters. The game has a lot of flaws, but I encountered no bugs in the core game. The Hangar 6 DLC, however, would freeze briefly every few seconds and rendered the game nearly unplayable. The Bureau's combat puts you in control of William Carter, a rather generic protagonist with a gravelly voice. Conversations in the game are carried out with a radial menu lifted directly from Mass Effect. The dialogue isn't terribly interesting, and some of the characters facial animations appeared to not actually be finished. Their mouths move with odd robotic motions, and their eyes look eerily dead. Carter himself, and some of the other core characters have much better, albeit repetitive animations. The story is forgettable overall, but moves the game on well enough. It doesn't come anywhere close to the likes of Mass Effect though, and the fact that the developers chose to base their game design so heavily on Mass Effect is unfortunate given the weak story. Even still, the combat made the experience worthwhile.Combat in the Bureau is at it's core a cover shooter in the vein of Mass Effect or Gears of War. It also gives you a pair of squadmates and allows you to give direct orders to them. The rookies you start with only have one or two abilities, as well as a command to focus on a specific target, and move to a location. Choosing where to move your squadmates is where the game gets a lot of it's strategic depth. You have to take into account how long they'll be exposed for, how far the nearest ally is if they need a revive, where the enemies are, how much protection the cover offers, and how easily they can use their abilities from their location. Overall it makes for a far more interesting experience than your standard cover shooter. Abilities range from dropping mines, shield domes, artillery strikes, and others.The combat isn't perfect though. Your squadmates seem to move into stupid locations occasionally, either exposing themselves to unnecessary fire, going down somewhere difficult to revive them, or both. It's not quite clear why this happens, but it doesn't happen very often at least. The encounters feel somewhat repetitive, but they ramp up in difficulty at a good rate. The weapons are fairly standard for a cover shooter; human and alien variations of the standard rifle, pistol, sniper and so on. Enemies on the other hand provide a bit more variety, healing their allies, granting them shields, spawning new enemies, or even mind controlling your squadmates.The graphics generally look good, with a variety of scenes ranging from idyllic small towns to metallic alien structures. Some elements though stand out like a sore thumb. An ugly low res skybox in one of the first scenes of the game is jarringly bad to look at in stark contrast to the cutscene that precedes it. Other elements like a destroyed tank with an ugly texture and a low poly model, or the abyss below an alien tower filled with an ugly brown fog that would have been acceptable years ago, but looks disappointing today. The rest of the game, however, especially the weapon reload animations look and sound good.The Bureau's worst offense however, is sure to be a dealbreaker for some fans of the mainstream XCOM games. The only thing The Bureau has in common with XCOM itself is the aliens and the weapon types. Unlocking new weapons is done merely by picking them up off the ground rather than researching them. Dying only puts you back to the latest checkpoint, and while you can lose squadmates permanently if they bleed out in some difficulty settings, I'm fairly sure if you die yourself they'll be back with you at the last checkpoint. By removing research, permadeath, and forcing the player down a linear path, I'm sure some players will deem the game unworthy of the XCOM title. While these issues did grate on me at first, it was the combat that kept me playing and enjoying every minute of it. Even though the story is just average, it isn't particularly time consuming like it is in Mass Effect. While I feel the game could have played more to it's strengths, it was still well worth the time and money while on sale. I wouldn't hesitate to reccomend this game to fans of Mass Effect, though fans of the classic XCOM games or Enemy Unknown will not enjoy it unless they also enjoy a good cover shooter.

A (poor) mix of Mass Effect gameplay with XCom universePlaying this game wasn't a horrible experiece, but wasn't a good one eighter.The only really good thing I can say about it is that it really captures the spirit of the Cold War times.-Buggy: at least 3 times I had to reload a chackpoint because the trigger wouldn't kick in;-Bad save system based on checkpoints;-Moral decision have almost null impact in the game (even at the ending where it SEEMS to change something). The truth is that this is a linear "on the tracks game" masked as more free decision thing.-There is very low customization options and there is no effort to create an emotional attachment with the characters;-The IA is pretty terrible, forcing you in some parts to to lower the game difficulty to get past them;-The user IA is REALLY terrible;-Combat is clumsy  (this one is hard to explain, the best way to say it is that in Mass Effect, running and shooting is much more "fluid" than in The Bureau XCOM;-Short list of sidequest with little to no meaning.I could list some other things. I admit it, maybe I placed the bets to high in this game expecting it to be like Mass Effect or XCOM - Enemy Unknown. But the truth is that this seems like a game that tried to much stuff for the budget they had and at the end we have only a superficial experience of what this "stuff" could really have been.

												The negative reviews for this game are mainly exaggerated and dumb. Many journalists and fans discredited the game BEFORE IT WAS EVEN RELEASED with the great argument:' A third-person-shooter for the XCOM-Franchise can't.' content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												I knew The Bureau had some poor reviews, but the Xcom reboot was one of my favourite games of 2012, so I decided to take a chance. I wasn't expecting a great game, but I hoped the Xcom theme could provide some entertainment. I regret my decision.There are some moments when The Bureau feels like it has the potential to be a good game. There are a wide range of classes and abilities to choose for your squad members, which lays the groundwork for deep tactical combat. You have some freedom to choose which order to play side missions. Most of the familiar Xcom aliens appear, and the campaign lasts an impressive 15 hours.However, all this is completely undermined by some of the worst friendly AI I've seen for a long time, which prevents the combat from being enjoyable. In theory, you can slow down combat at any time and give orders to your two squadmates. In practice, they don't care about your orders. They will run away from cover at random times, leaving themselves vulnerable to attack, frequently resulting in them getting incapacitated. The player then has to quickly revive them before they bleed out and die permanently, which of course means you take massive damage trying to save them. The poorly placed checkpoint only save system didn't help my frustration.Even when they are alive, your squadmates rarely do anything useful. I refer to my screenshot where on one mission I got 95 of 104 kills. Every mission had a similar theme. I only started to feel comfortable when I'd got some squadmates up to level 4 (max level is 5), and gained powerful abilities like the laser turret and the hologram decoy. Plus every level up increases health, so the AI would stay alive a bit longer. But that is a case of too little, too late.I might recommend a game with poor gameplay if the story was entertaining, but the Bureau fails this too. Its a prequel set in the 1960's, but the continuity doesn't even make sense. During the course of the game you'll gain access to laser and plasma weapons, flying drones and psionic abilities. Meanwhile you'll encounter Sectoids, Mutons, Sectopods and Ethereals. But when the present day Xcom strategy game starts we don't have information about any of those things, and this is never justified.Furthermore, the dialogue is poor. Sentences feel like disconnected lines, instead of flowing like a natural conversation, more a fault of the script writers than the voice actors. Lip syncing during in-engine cutscenes is awful and distracting.My advice would be to skip The Bureau and just replay the other Xcom game(s) again.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												The Bureau is an uninspired, and standardised third-person shooter in the vein of Gears of War, with little hints of the 'tactical' play of Mass Effect thrown in for flavour. Set in a parallel 1950s america, with many levels seeming to take place in the stereotypical midwest small towns popularised in so many UFO abduction stories, the player takes the role of a Secret Service agent tasked with delivering a mysterious artefact to the head of 'The Bureau', an unknown and oft-ridiculed section of the US government.Attempting to provide history for the X-COM project as present in the firaxis game, The Bureau toys with themes of sexism in organisations, loyalty, and the importance of self...all with the ham-fisted bashing on a keyboard one would expect of most popular shooters. It takes itself and it's cheesy encironment with far too much seriousness and not enough self-awareness to really make the slightly B-movie plotline work.I was actually impressed with the announce trailers for the original 'XCOM' first person shooter, and thought that while not an 'X-COM' game, it could have been an entertaining and uniue exploration of clandestine UFO investigation from the point of view of a squaddie or corporal. The numerous rewrites and alterations of the project's lifespan, and the apparent dusting under the rug after the success of Firaxis' 'XCOM; Enemy Unknown' have hurt this title.If the pre-order bonuses were still available, I would suggest buying this game only for the X-Com complete pack as a pre-order bonus. Unfortunately, without that particular enticement, I can only suggest to avoid this game unless you feel an unhealthy urge to open plot holes and experience painfully obvious twists in storytelling.

												Вы любите тактические игры ? Любите посидеть и поразмышлять о своих действиях, придумать какой нибудь план для победы над врагами ? Если да -  эта игра не для вас. Бюро представляли как тактический экшен, но самой тактики там кот наплакал, да же на самой высшей сложности игра не заставляет тактически думать, всего по одной причине - тут самые идиотские напарники! Им плевать что вы отдаёте им приказы, им нужно лишь несколько вещей - Высовыватся из укрытия, когда по ним стреляет куча врагов; Стоять на одном месте и пялится в прилетевшую гранату; Выбегать на босса с криками "ВАААААГХ" и пасть смертью храбрых за несколько секунд. Если бы игра не позиционировалась как тактический экшен, я бы не так сильно обращал на это внимание. На удивление, враги действительно умно себя ведут, действуют сообща, закидывают гранатами (Ваши напарники даже этого делать не умеют) и обходят с фланга. Геймплейно игра превращается в обычный шутан, аля Gears of War, где всю каманду тащит на себе игрок. На тяжелом уровне сложности, пока не появятся мощные способности - это просто мука. Во всем остальном игра хороша - отличнейшая графика; хороший саундтрек; и отличнейший сюжет и атмосфера. Очень правильно разработчики выбрали время действия игры - редко нам дадут поубивать пришельцев в 60-е года. Что касается сюжета, он никак не удивлял практически до самого конца игры, но то что я увидел под конец, действительно очень и очень сильно порадовало. Рекомендую всем ознакомиться с игрой, только не ждите тактики от неё и все будет хорошо ;)

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												Ok,it's like this. Take Mass Effect. Dip in 1960s G-Man sauce and sprinkle lightly with XCOM tidbits. Fill with the fluffiest story you can sleep through and that's The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. What could've been a nice prequel to the XCOM games is instead a boring,soulless,buggy 3rd person cover shooter with a very "been there,done that" feel to it. You get the sniper rifle,you use cover,it's so by the numbers it's basically Counting with Elmo. Not even The Court,just Elmo. So,yeah,Mass Effect offers a better story and more customization options and more varity of companions. However,if you're looking for a 3rd rate shooter who's AI breaks if you go back out the enterence to the combat area and your snipers can shoot through walls,then by all means,enjoy.Update: As of recent patches,the game is now completely broken. What was once bad is made worse as it now lags and cracks and stutters all over. Really,don't buy this game unless you enjoy torturing yourself with everything that could concievably go wrong.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												♥♥♥♥♥Tracy meets the best of the X-Com franchise and fails miserably.  The environment they create is excellent until the characters speak.  Dialog tends to run on about less than important information.  Base management is virtually non-existant and the gameplay itself in tactical mode is mostly redundant and boring.  This game fails to create strategic value or tactical tension that is the hallmark of the X-Com series.  This is indie developer quality at best and worse, indie games tend to be more fun! Nothing about this game is great other than the environment and I would argue the gameplay actually takes away from that heavily.  The other thing is the game runs heavy on even high end systems for no discernable reason.  It is likely that the time to properly optimize this game was never made.  The best correlation to system demand is X-Rebirth which is simulating an entire universe of things happening per frame.  How The Bureau requires and equal amount of processing power is beyond me.  The AI isn't good at all.  Bypass this title entirely.  Even on sale for 10$ it isn't worth it.  Buy some DLC for XCom: Enemy Unknown or Within and have hours of entertainment.  Even the original release of Sword of the Stars II didn't have me wishing for a return policy with STEAM so badly.My Score: 3/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 6, 2014
												A cover-based shooter trying to blend itself with the tactical features of its strategy forefathers. Despite its messy development history it's now a decent game for a decent price. As long as you remember that The Bureau is an action spinoff you will have your fun.Pros* Managing your agents is cool and their capacities will make a difference considering you are not given enough ammo to work alone* The story lay down the foundations for the modern XCOM organization with a nice '60s twist* The underground base is quite alive (as long as you visit it once per main mission) with plenty of dialogs and little animationsCons* The gameplay is not varied and you will often yawn at seeing predictable chest-high walls and meeting the same enemies just with more and more health points* The IA of your teammates is pretty bad and will require you to micromanage them, but is overall tolerable if you stick to the Squaddie difficulty* The RPG elements are light with the game itself being rather linearSome polish would have been a welcome improvement but you can still see in the details that much love was poured into the game. It is also pretty easy to get most, if not all of the achievements!

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												A great prequel to the XCOM series.  Purely looking at it only as an action 3PS, with no prior interest in XCOM, you will probably not like it.  If you ignore expectations built up from playing other 3PS games (it is not pure 3PS, rather it is sort of halfway between the turn-based isometric XCOM games and a tactical command 3PS), and suspend your disbelief, allowing yourself to get immersed into this great backstory to the XCOM storyline, it's actually fairly enjoyable.  At the risk of comparing the two games (beause TB:XD is in a totally different league to X:E), I see the poor reaction to "The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" as somewhat similar to that of "XCOM: Enforcer," people just don't know how to enjoy a game for its intended feel / storyline, and get too caught up in game mechanics!  That said, I think they do some interesting things with it.  Try it out if it's on special.  Enjoy!

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2014
												I wanted to like this game! It pushes several of my happy buttons, from the XCOM branding, to the Cold War paranoia, to the retrofuturistic aesthetic. This could have been the ambitious first entry in a new spin-off franchise... but unfortunately, nearly everything in the game is marred by a clear lack of polish. I could write about the outdated interface (no mission objectives onscreen or all the other nice little UI touches we've come to expect over the last 20 years), the poor level design (lots of railroading and impassable waist-high obstacles), or several other issues, but by far the worst offender is the combat system. Instead of a fluid, enjoyable experience like Mass Effect 2 or 3, the tactical squad combat is clunky, poorly explained, and extremely unforgiving. It's the heart of the game, and it simply isn't fun.Overall, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified isn't a bad game... just a mediocre one. It does nothing terribly, but nothing particularly well, either. I found myself simply grinding through each little combat set-piece in the hopes that I could reach a more rewarding part of the game, but eventually I just gave up -- my leisure hours are limited, and there are simply more entertaining ways to spend them.

It has a lot of the right parts to be a good game, unfortunately I feel they missed the mark on making it excellent and instead ended up making a slightly less than average game. Only worth it if you want the experience and if you get it for a discount.Combat:     - It is difficult at times to place your abilities such as mines and turrets, especially when the height changes.     - The shift key controls your sprint and also ducking into and around cover which can get finicky at times.     - While in the tactical command screen it is sensitive and swaps between characters a little too easily.Story:     - Not much to it.     - They don't emotionally pull you in or make you feel connected to any characters.     - Your choices don't seem to matter at all.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2015
												I think this is an example of a game which has poor reviews for the wrong reasons. Like many, I'd just finished playing XCOM - Enemy Unknown and was hungry for a continuation of that. While still set in the XCOM 'universe', it's a very different style of game and many of the negative reviews will be because of that, which is unfair to what is actually a pretty good game. They've made a brave attempt at making a game which isn't a guaranteed money maker, and I think they've done a pretty good job. I love it when developers don't paint by numbers.It's a third-person shooter not dissimilar in gameplay to Mass Effect, though set in the swinging 60's (with a very 50's feel), you have 2 squadmates who you give commands to during Battle Focus (slo-mo), as you work your way through linear mission levels. Personally I'm not fussed by linear levels - I'll take them over non-linear ones which just give the illusion of choice to fill out gameplay time.The game itself is fairly short if you just go through the main missions, though if you're a completionist doing all the side missions and exploring the base properly, and going after achievements, you'll get roughly triple the game time to about 20-25 hours.The graphics are good, and the scenery and level design excellent. They've clearly put alot of work into quality over quantity, and I actually feel bad about not standing around too long to just look at what's been put into it, especially mid to late game. However, if your computer's falling behind on the ol' hardware department, you might find your framerate dropping noticeably in areas.Aliens are what you would expect from an xcom game, and I found the later game to get a bit easy due to a strong compliment of abilities. Still, I enjoyed all the combat, and if you're having trouble with your agents chasing after you when you try to flank the enemy, just manually move them to cover first so they aren't in follow mode.This game's not for everyone. Some will find the pace a bit slow, especially in the base, but honestly the game is 80% off at the time of writing this review (£2.99 ..$4.43 at current rate), which is an absolute steal for the work that's gone into it. If people reviewed the game removing both their expectations, and personal preference for what games they like, and instead based it on the quality of the game itself for its genre (which is what reviews should be based on, not personal taste), then it would be somewhere in the positives for sure.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 6, 2016
												The only fact I've managed to declassify from The Bureau is that the game suffers from repetitive combat sequences with poor incentives to progress. Team AI and coordination is clunky and far from intelligent. I spent most of my time spamming squad regroup while just taking on everything by myself. However, if you're a patient soul, you'll come to realize that your squadmates will have powers that are well worth the wait. For completionists, you will have to grind your recruits up a significant amount to succeed in the game's side quests and recruit send-away missions. There isn't a diverse array of weapon options, with no customization options. While I'm sure that this game has a great deal of content in terms of its side quests and collectable discussions, there's just nothing wonderful or immersive about the story that grabbed me. Yes, the allure of a top secret agency is there and the core conflict is imminent. But what has always killed a narrative for me was how predictably static and hollow the protagonists were. Rather than present their information throughout the story, you have to go the extra mile and read about it from dossiers on their desks. As edgy as Carter comes across through his backstory, he loses all his charm when he begins to speak lines you've heard a million times before. The Bureau miscarried the merge of a tactical third-person shooter in what appeared to be a promising premise. It's tepid mechanics and bland characters justify the game's ranking of being mediocre to poor. Don't be fooled by it, even in a humble bundle.

content:
Posted: June 5, 2016
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified feels like a frustratingly incomplete mixture of Bioshock and Gears of War. This could have been a great game. Here are my specific gripes with the game:Some abilities are over-powered, others are underwhelming. Aiming doesn't seem to matter too much aside from headshots. Guns take a back seat to the abilities and you will spend much of combat waiting for cooldowns. Upgrades and items don't include important percentages so that you can determine which gear is best for your characters (this is fixed in the DLC). Levels are sprawling but often feel too sterile or empty. Many of the NPC interactions and other world building elements feel hollow and pointless.You know that point where you are halfway through a bag of potato chips, no longer hungry and filled with self-loathing, but you eat the rest anyway? I had a similar moment halfway through XCOM: The Bureau.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												I went into this game expecting to hate it. I really wanted to hate it because of the name it carried and the fact it had departed so much from what the core of the series was actually about. But I just couldn't. It reminded me of all of those B-list sci-fi shows that were on television in re-run when I was younger and I'm a sucker for that era of science fiction. My one complaint as I began to play the game was laughably that I felt that they had a better design for the aliens before they tried to incorperate elements of the usual X-com lineup into the game. Back when they were stark and strange and unknowable. Shapes and blobs and infiltrations. Dark noises in the middle of the night and having to fight things you'd never hope to understand. That -- is what I wish this game would've kept more of.  That said? I enjoyed it. Friendly AI is . . . frustratingly bad, but it never really impeded my progress any. Voice acting was pretty good. Story was fantastic, with the one complaint I mentioned above. Buy it on a sale. It's seriously not a bad game, for what it is.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 18, 2014
												Don't let the phrase X-Com in the title fool you, this is nothing like Enemy Unknown, in style, quality, or replayability. I had such high hopes for this game that I preordered it, picturing tactical combat against all the classic X-Com enemies. Basically, I wanted to be the soldiers I was sending to their doooms in Enemy Unknown. What I got was basically all the most boring parts of Mass Effect's combat system, and a story that couldn't be more forgettable. Combat isn't tactics, it's patience. It is incredibly hard to die, and if you do your completely replaecable squadmates will usually be able to revive you. Enemies take forever to die, most boss fights devolving into you running around looking for ammo as your teammates slowly tick down their gigantic health bars. The ability to customize your companions is very limited, you can only change their guns and add an enhancement item that reduces damage, cooldowns, etc. Oh, and you can change the color of their suits.     The story doesn't make you feel any sort of emotion, it's just Mission X and Agent Y, mixed with a 60's thematic and sci-fi cliches. The X-Com headquarters is kind of neat, but once you realize there is nothing to do there it loses some charm. Maybe it gets better in the last third of the game, but I have a hard time believing dessert will be excellent after spooning down so much gruel.     As I said, I was very high on this game based on the trailers and the excellence of its strategy counterpart, but there is nothing in the execution of this title that backed up that promise. Of my 6 hours, I don't think I had fun for more than 5-10 minutes, and I don't think I will ever play it again. I bought it at ~50 dollars, and a month later it was on sale for 19.99.   That is not an accident.

content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												It's like Mass Effect except with awful writing, voice acting and AI, plus a distinct lack of choices and any incentive to stray from the narrow linear path.Here is an example of how broken it is. When a team member goes down, they can be revived by a colleague. During this process, the healer is completely immune from damage. They can be getting blasted and smashed by all manner of enemies, but won't be hurt. Of course, once they have finished reviving their colleague, they can be promptly killed - and now the former patient can become invulnerable healer. It's utter nonsense and terrible design.As for having the same button to run, take cover and leap over said cover - well, it just screams console port.Oddly enough, the game improves quite a bit in the late stages. The story finally starts to get a bit interesting, if uninspired, and gameplay actually becomes quite frenetic and challenging. It requires battling through mediocrity to get there, though.
