number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Animations: 5/10Graphics: 8.5/10Storyline: 10/10Gameplay: 9/10Overall: 8.1/10In this game you play as Ex Agent Carter during the year 1962, in the starting wake of an alien invasion which leads to the formation of an organization known as the Bureau.For being in production since late 2006 i belive this game could have been a bit better asthetically and functionally than it is.The A.I. used for the NPC Teammates is rather scetchy at best as you find yourself having to babysit them 99% of the battle, on the plus side they do come with various abilities and classes as well as weapons which if used properly can easily beat enemy encounters.Graphically this game is above top notch. being released during the end of last gen and including the Nvidia PhysX particle effects it really reaches the bar set by others. though it does take a pretty decent PC to run everything maxed out with DX11.Animations during in game scenes (and some out game scenes) could have been brushed up on. Characters seem too chopy at some points, and too stiff at others. Aside from this if animations don't really bug you too much the dialog and V.O.s were done rather nicely and do set some justice to in game cinimatics.Gameplay is rather tricky to get the hang of if you aren't into Tactical TPS games. you controll your two NPCs as well as yourself and must utilize all the teams abilities and each classes strengths and weaknesses to guide them to victory. that being said by themselfs the NPC's are rather useless as stated earlier. but given you can practically controll their every move it makes for interesting game. Another mechanic that's rather interesting is agents, you must keep a "roster" stocked of agents all starting at level 1 and choose weather to rotate them, send some on npc only missions, or pick favorites and take only them at all times, as a tactics based game though you are also given multiple classes to used based on the missions and can even swap them out mid mission as needed. adding to the system is deaths, a consiquence to not coordinating your agents and keeping them alive is once an agent is down, he is gone. reguardless of level and abilities thus leaving you only to choose another agent to take his place.Storyline to this game is rather immersive. you can find info on NPC's and current situations laying around, and get side missions. The main missions all of course tie in as any storyline based game should. but getting into it is rather touch and go. they start by throwing you right into the start of the invasion and piece the events before it as you go along. but after getting past the beginning it smoothens out as you play through the rest.Overall though I belive this installment to the XCOM series was done rather nicely. given the time they had i belive it could have been slightly better but as it stands is a pretty strong release and in personal opinion a great game to play. I would deffinately recommend giving this game a shot if you're into Tactical TPS'.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Despite all the bad reviews, I really enjoyed The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. It's not a perfect game and many things could have been done different, but I had a lot of fun beating the game and it's nice to go back again to the Xcom universe, even if the game has, gameplay-wise, nothing to do with the former games of the franchise. Giving commands was neat, the controls were okay, the voice acting was excellent, the story was okaysh at first, and awesome at the end and during my almost 20 hour playthrough I encountered just one bug, which was easily fixed by reloading the last checkpoint. I played it on the hardest difficulty, so I am not sure this always applies, but the fights were sometimes just too long. Even on the hardest difficulty, it was not as hard as I imagined it would be, but you do have to plan your men movements and always stay behind cover. The variety of enemies is nice and the abilities in the field were a lot of fun to use and combine. Combat was similar to the one in Mass Effect, but there was almost no interaction with anyone in the base and when there was, it was pretty boring. I liked the layout of the maps, though, and how they were all very detailed and were usually used to convey little stories, which can be ignored completely if you want to rush to the end though. Yes, the maps are certainly linear, but I think they were supposed to be that way, just as in most games.So, although the game may not be perfect, I had a lot of fun playing it and defending Earth once again against the aliens. The story got awesome towards the end and it actually leaves you thinking about it. So yeah, I definitely recommend The Bureau: Xcom Declassified... as long as you understand this has little to do with Xcom: Enemy Unknown. They may share the Xcom part, but whereas EU is completely innovative and one of my favorite games for a reason, The Bureau is just an average shooter that will grant you about 15 hours of shooting and fun. Both great games, but completely different genres. I say go for it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												An excellent third person tactical shooter where there's a lot of emphasis on giving the right orders at the right time to your agents.You play as William Carter who at the start of the game is delivering a very important briefcase to the director of the Bureau of Operations and Command, Myron Faulke, at Groom Range when he is suddenly attacked in the room he was given while waiting to go inside the facility by a female officer who starts discharging a strange black substance from her eyes before she turns her attention to the briefcase that then explodes in a blinding white light that completely and utterly incinerates the infected female officer and knocks Carter out, who later wakes up with the gun wound he sustained inexplicably healed.But that is only the start of Carter's problems as an unknown enemy force has attacked the facility and now he must try and get to Faulke and find out just what is going on.This game doesn't go easy on you, even on the easiest setting, as the enemies are extremely relentless and cunning as they will attempt to flank you, toss grenades to flush you out of cover and many other tactics to eliminate you.You can also send your agents out on dispatch missions that can give you access to new technology, a new recruit and other things that can turn the tide of this secret war in your favor.There's also several documents and photos scattered about the base and mission areas that can provide a bit more backstory aside from talking to the agents and personal.The Bureau borrows a lot of elements from the Mass Effect games, especially when it comes to how you give orders to the agents, the various powers that you will unlock and many others, but I feel like its done a bit better here then in the Mass Effect games, especially considering the setting of the game itself.This is without a doubt one of the most interesting and fun tactical shooters for quite sometime to be released on home computers and consoles alike and I highly recommend it, especially to those who are fans of the XCOM series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
												First impression review. Might write a more detailed one later. This game... isn't good. But it's the really frustrating sort of "not good" because there's potential brilliance in it. The story would be good thanks to the environment and detail, but the pacing is awful and the dialogue sounds like it was badly translated from another language. Since X-Com doesn't have much story to begin with it needed time to build the pacing and atmosphere that it didn't give itself. The early game is also grossly imbalanced  since your health is much too low to survive for long and your rookies (beyond the intro) start with no remarkable abilities and won't even do much to defend themselves without being told. The interface is slippery and unintuitive, at least with a mouse and keyboard with some truly baffling choices for keybindings. You can rebind some keys and not others, and guess what? There is no removing "cancel orders" from backspace. All this said I'd still eagerly recommend the game to a student of game design curious about how to come *close* to something great while still screwing it up. I also think once you adjust to its crap factor, I'm willing to bet it's a lot of fun and rewards creative tactics. It really could have used more development time and polish.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
												I really enjoyed playing this game, especially since I'm a huge fan of the XCOM franchise. First of all, they've done a really good job on the setting. The game really gave me the feeling of being immersed in the sixties. And although the levels are linear and offer almost no opportunities for exploration the atmosphere can clearly be felt. The game features the squad tactics we are familiar with but gives them more depth by controlling the squad as a member of the team. Sadly, you can only take two more men with you. At times, I felt I really could use an aditional field agent here and there. And this considering there are four classes to choose your agents from. Plus, you cannot modify the agents with nothing except weapons and backpacks, that give the agents different buffs like increased health and increased ability range. Speaking of weapons, there's not a great deal you can do with them in terms of modifications and/or research. It makes sense from the story point of view but it kinda doesn't give you the XCOM feeling. Still this is a good game if you want to play a squad-tactics third person shooter and shoot some alien invaders back to their homeworld.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												I recommend this game at a good price (less than $10). It was a bit shorter than I expected but still fun. There are many missions you can select from back at HQ but each mission is very linear with one route to follow. When you meet up with the aliens then it opens into an arena type area to move around.  Having to run around inside HQ to meet up with different folks was was much more irritating that just selecting the part of the base you wanted to visit. I also found myself skipping a lot of the dialog as it went on for too long but at least you have the option to do that. Overall I'd give it a 6 out 10 rating. Nothing special, very little re-playability, but I enjoyed it enough my first play through to feel I did not waste my $10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
												Incredibly under-rated game. Sure it's not the best game ever made in the 3rd person shooter genre but it's obvious that a lot of time and effort went into making this game authentic looking to fit the 1950's style retro sci-fi theme.  It's got a nice easy to use command system and the battles are satisfying. The visuals are the games best asset and for that alone it warrants the games purchase. I bought it at full price when it first came out and have played through it twice. No regrets for paying full price either! The insane sales this game has seen would be FOOLISH to pass up. The only thing I really wish it had was multiplayer specifically co-op... Co-op would've been an awesome addition to this already fun game. Well the game tanked and we'll never see another which is too bad so I highly recommend you give this one a shot, you really can't go wroing with the price. I'd give it a 7.5 out of 10.

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												The Bureau is a bad XCOM. Even with the mediocre storylines they XCOM games were fun because they had solid gameplay and high replayability. The Bureau doesn't have any of these. It's very linear with little to none RPG elements and side missions. It lacks the feel of "progressing" when you play the story.Gameplay is much simpler than Enemy Unknown--more like a shooter, it has a faster pace but it was dumbed down too much and it struggles between an action game and a strategy game.You can have (only) 2 companions and you can give orders by slowing the game down. Command screen UI is simple and useful enough but it has a few control issues when you play with keyboard/mouse. Your squadmates' AI is c**ppy, they just die when you don't give them orders for 10 secondsPros:-60's theme with aliens and conspiracies-Nice atmosphere-Simple UI and command system-Fast gameplay is good if you want a shooter gameCons:-Fast gameplay is bad if you want a strategy game, it's oversimplified and dumbed down-Upgrades and progressing are weak-Story isn't so exciting-Teammates usually become bullet magnets and die if you don't command them-Devs made the worst lip-sync ever in gaming history-It doesn't have the good part in XCOM: Enemy Unknown where you build a good squad and try to protect all of them against powerful alien forces-Many audio problems-Doesn't have much replayability value-Repetitive after some pointI think The Bureau's potenitals were wasted and it became worse and worse in long "development hell" that involved multiple studios. If you didn't play any XCOM games before, you should buy Enemy Unknown, not this. If you're a hardcore XCOM fan, it'll probably be a disappointment for you.  If you're looking for an action-TPS, you can find better games in Steam. Worth a try only if it's on sale.

												There's a lot of promise here but unfortuanately The Bureau fails to excel in any area and trips over itself into mediocrity. The Good+Maintaining and leveling up squad agents is fun and adds stakes to making sure everyone comes back from a mission alive. +Lots of different abilities to change how encounters can play.+The story was fairly interesting and had some fun turns.The Disappointing-Terrible Squad AI; frequent pathing issues and breaking cover during firefights.-The Bureau makes very poor use of its setting and fails to make anything feel like it's taking place in the 50's.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												All in all this was a pretty good game. The controls could have been mapped better and there could have been a bit more done for the storyline. There should have been a bit more done with the Russians as it was a Cold War era game. There also could have been a wider range of human weapons and the recruitment seemed very limited.Once you get past that the game does require a lot of tactical flexibility and a bit of fast thinking (I played through on Veteran the first time). With a limited squad size it forces you to pick, choose, and design your tactics for every occasion. The storyline was a bit short but it did do a good job of sucking you in. I found it to be a good first attempt at the game in this style and will be hoping that they do a bit more with the game down the road.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												Despite all the bad reviews, I really enjoyed The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. It's not a perfect game and many things could have been done different, but I had a lot of fun beating the game and it's nice to go back again to the Xcom universe, even if the game has, gameplay-wise, nothing to do with the former games of the franchise. Giving commands was neat, the controls were okay, the voice acting was excellent, the story was okaysh at first, and awesome at the end and during my almost 20 hour playthrough I encountered just one bug, which was easily fixed by reloading the last checkpoint. I played it on the hardest difficulty, so I am not sure this always applies, but the fights were sometimes just too long. Even on the hardest difficulty, it was not as hard as I imagined it would be, but you do have to plan your men movements and always stay behind cover. The variety of enemies is nice and the abilities in the field were a lot of fun to use and combine. Combat was similar to the one in Mass Effect, but there was almost no interaction with anyone in the base and when there was, it was pretty boring. I liked the layout of the maps, though, and how they were all very detailed and were usually used to convey little stories, which can be ignored completely if you want to rush to the end though. Yes, the maps are certainly linear, but I think they were supposed to be that way, just as in most games.So, although the game may not be perfect, I had a lot of fun playing it and defending Earth once again against the aliens. The story got awesome towards the end and it actually leaves you thinking about it. So yeah, I definitely recommend The Bureau: Xcom Declassified... as long as you understand this has little to do with Xcom: Enemy Unknown. They may share the Xcom part, but whereas EU is completely innovative and one of my favorite games for a reason, The Bureau is just an average shooter that will grant you about 15 hours of shooting and fun. Both great games, but completely different genres. I say go for it!

Posted: June 30, 2014
												I had really high hopes for this game, but it unfortunately hits all of my pet peeves for a 3rd person shooter. Friendly AI is not smart enough to handle combat without significant micro management which is extremely difficult to manage in the super slow motion tactical orders mode.To be fair the alien AI isn't any better, however it hardly matters since even your basic enemies require far more damage to neutralize than is reasonable considering your ammunition capacity, and the fact that your own ability to take damage is nil.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2013
												An excellent third person tactical shooter where there's a lot of emphasis on giving the right orders at the right time to your agents.You play as William Carter who at the start of the game is delivering a very important briefcase to the director of the Bureau of Operations and Command, Myron Faulke, at Groom Range when he is suddenly attacked in the room he was given while waiting to go inside the facility by a female officer who starts discharging a strange black substance from her eyes before she turns her attention to the briefcase that then explodes in a blinding white light that completely and utterly incinerates the infected female officer and knocks Carter out, who later wakes up with the gun wound he sustained inexplicably healed.But that is only the start of Carter's problems as an unknown enemy force has attacked the facility and now he must try and get to Faulke and find out just what is going on.This game doesn't go easy on you, even on the easiest setting, as the enemies are extremely relentless and cunning as they will attempt to flank you, toss grenades to flush you out of cover and many other tactics to eliminate you.You can also send your agents out on dispatch missions that can give you access to new technology, a new recruit and other things that can turn the tide of this secret war in your favor.There's also several documents and photos scattered about the base and mission areas that can provide a bit more backstory aside from talking to the agents and personal.The Bureau borrows a lot of elements from the Mass Effect games, especially when it comes to how you give orders to the agents, the various powers that you will unlock and many others, but I feel like its done a bit better here then in the Mass Effect games, especially considering the setting of the game itself.This is without a doubt one of the most interesting and fun tactical shooters for quite sometime to be released on home computers and consoles alike and I highly recommend it, especially to those who are fans of the XCOM series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This is a squad-based action game similar to Mass Effect so if you expect it to be just like XCOM: Enemy Unknown you may be disappointed, it is not turn-based tactics on a grid. That said, it is a good game in its own right and focuses much more heavily on the story and character development than its tactics counterpart. There are still different classes and a leveling system of sorts in which you can choose bonuses or upgrades similar to the leveling in Enemy Unknown. The story reveals a lot more about the background of XCOM but don't expect all your questions to be answered either.Hangar 6 R&D - Definitely worth the cost, you get several extra missions to play as DaSilva and take on some more aliens. If you completed the main story and are looking for some more of the same then I recommend this. Don't expect a lot of new content or anything though, it's the same weapons and aliens. The only really new things are the missions and story, and DaSilva's perks are kind of a mix but mostly familiar. This campaign runs entirely separate from the regular campaign (you start a whole new file) so it won't interfere or matter where you are in the regular story.

content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												Contrary to most other reviews, I think this game is amazing. I agree that it shouldn't have the XCOM name, as it is far from the strategical gameplay of Enemy Unknown, but it really is a good TPS. It's probably not worth the current $30, but I got Enemy Unknown and this for $8 during the summer sale and it is definitely worth that.PROS- Great gameplay- In my opinion, a great team control system- Decent storyline- How it has some of the same aliens as other XCOM gamesCONS- Short campaign, could have been made longer and better- Strange conversation system- How you cannot go back to this base after finishing the game (to do side missions)VERDICTIf it goes on sale for under $15, I would say get it.8/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18
												While the game has some janky elements (a few bugs, sounds not triggering and in one instance I had to restart a checkpoint since my ride didn't turn up) it's a fairly solid game that has some neat story elements. The 60s setting is a plus as well; on the harder difficulty setting combat required a fair amount of tactical manuevring and I found myself using the squad command features in every fight which takes it above a gimmick.If you can overlook some lack of polish, The Bureau is an interesting take on the XCOM genre and gives its own spin on the franchise pretty well. It's a shame some stalwharts of the series couldn't make an appearence but otherwise it's a good game and worth a play if you're a fan of both the series and action games in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												Mass Effect but with a 60s art style. Teammate AI is a mess with them choosing to take cover in front of enemies or keep running around doing nothing unless you decide to issue commands for them every single second, thankfully this gets slightly better once they level up and can take more damage, and once you level up a few times in which the game becomes a total cakewalk. Other than that the combat is alright and can even become ~~intense~~ sometimes in harder difficulties. The storyline is a mess; outside the twist near the end it's very disjointed with the game assuming you know things you haven't been told yet (your character acts as if he knows these things too) and some characters vanishing two levels from the end of the game and never being mentioned again. Like I mentioned before the entire game plays and feels like Mass Effect but set in the 60s (there's even a base you can walk around in and talk to people after missions). I liked the art style a lot and it kept me playing until the end, but the game itself is kind of a mess due to it being stuck in development hell for 5+ years. Even so it's not Aliens Colonial Marines/Duke Forever horrible garbage, just average. If you think the setting looks interesting and want a slightly strategical third person shooter (think Brother in Arms and Mass Effect as previously mentioned) buy it when it's on sale for u$20 and you'll have fun. Hopefully it'll get a sequel in the future that fixes the issues it has (but it bombed so it won't).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Was really suprised that this game was good! I actually enjoyed it a hell of a lot.My first experience with the XCOM franchise was the 2012 game, which I also enjoyed a whole lot. I would say that The Bureau is a fairly accurate translation of XCOM into a 3rd person shooter. You can give commands on the field, cover is very much essential as is position on the battle field. Even the way missions are seperated into side missions and main story missions, giving the game a similar pace to XCOM (shorter missions taking anywhere from 10 minutes to 30 minutes, and the longer ones up to over an hour). Of course in depth this game differs from XCOM in that you will not be maintaining the base yourself, doing research, your boss does that. You simply go out and shoot dudes and command the field and♥♥♥♥♥♥The games weaknesses mostly revolve around the plot in my opinion. It's suprisingly good in parts, but does get ridiculous at times. It crosses the suspension of disbelief line a few to manty times.But the game has a lot of strengths that I don't think it was given enough credit for. The shooting feels great, the weapons are really cool, and the field commands just make you feel powerful and responsible for your squad. The setting is also fantastic, a really slick "Mad Men" vibe. So give this game a chance. It is the XCOM experience for people who might not be into hardcore strategy games, and that's ok. Get it on sale!Also: It works on Nvidia Shield

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2016
												I picked this game up for 2.99 so I am taking that into account in this review, and I think it is probably even worth full price.The game is, in a nut-shell a poor man's Mass Effect set in the Xcom universe's version of the 60's. The atmosphere is good, and the game itself is 'ok' in so far that it is almost good at a lot of things. It doesn't quite manage to pull off what it wants to though, but still falls into the 'ok' category.Most of what I am about to say is negative, because the game is so close to being good that I am disappointed in how it turned out, but I would still say buy the game - especially if you are a fan of xcom or mass effect, or perhaps only if you fall into those camps.Combat is tough, at least early on which is where I am, because you are vastly outgunned and frequently find enemies that you can hardly hurt. You are also forced (Pretty close to forced anyway) into an Alien shotgun if you want to kill those enamies, and personally I hate shotguns. I expect when you unlock more guns the game will improve, but I haven't made it through that far yet.The big issue with combat for me is that when you bring up the orders menu the camera isn't the most responsive, and since time isn't fully paused it can lead to you giving messed up orders (Such as sending one man left and the other right when you want them both down the same flank).AI is also pretty poor too, especially for your own team who have a bad habit of getting their heads blown off when they should be in cover.Character development is a miss since you only have one progression tree to go down. Why you go down that tree makes sense, but I like more options in my games.The other miss is the research element from the base xcom series, here you just find the odd gun lying around. They make an explanation for why you can pick up some but not other, but it is a bit half hearted.So overall there is a good game trying to get out from under a not quite there exterior, worth playing, worth the £10-15 they are asking, but probably not much more, Go in knowing what you are getting, and you will come out with hope for The Bureau 2 (If they ever make it) rather than disappointment at this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Playing this game was like picking out your favorite flavor of peanut butter & jelly sandwich and getting pickles & sardines instead.  THIS. IS. NOT. XCOM.  It has the name and some of the elements but ultimately it's a huge disservice. This is the game that when it was announced and it's game elements revealed, the fans of the franchise threw up in their mouth a little bit and promptly told 2K the exact texture and flavor of it. They still proceeded to pour this puke flavored goop into a sack with the X-Com logo roughly hand drawn in fecal matter.TL;DR Version:All fan-rage aside, this is a small squad, real-time, cover based, third/first person shooter game with a super slow-mo system for giving commands and using abilities. One of those horrid fusions between fast paced action and strategy that always feels forced and awkward made worse by terrible controls. It has a linear and gag-inducing story with some side missions for plot add-ons with unlikeable, unengaging characters.The mechanics:The controls are clunky and difficult to be precise with since this is a badly done console port, but even if I had a controller for my PC they would still be obnoxious. The movement and area targeting cursor is more like an entity in that you have to 'jump' the off map elements or steer it around objects like a drunken water buffalo to get it where you want it to go. Individual unit targeting is done with a visually jarring 'thermal view' from your character's point of view that is annoying to use and confusing when enemies overlap from your forced perspective. They clearly favored style choices over a useable interface.Your NPC team mates are rather suicidal and often entirely unhelpful.  They never stay in place when sniping or providing suppressing fire and you have to constantly re-issue move commands. I found myself shouting "NO YOU NINNY, GO BACK WHERE YOU WERE!" at the screen in frustration several times as I try to flank the enemy like they teach you to do in the tutorial phase. They are also distance-leashed to your main character so if you get too far away from them they break cover and frequently get splattered by a turret or hoard of enemies coating their position in plasma fire.  Alternately when you want them to move, they're slow to comply and take the worst possible path unless you stage their movements out step by step and even then, (!!!) they often still shove their stupid faces into the barrels of enemy weapons.They have this LOVELY habit of bum-rushing giant aliens that promptly curb stomp their squishy heads into red paste rather than using the sniper or assault rifle they're equipped with from range, no matter their behavior settings. They also love to dive on to grenades as if they were at a belly flop competition event, which if it saved you or your other NPC, might make sense, but usually just makes you spam the revive command at the other one if they didn't get taken out as well. Their combat abilities are laughable unless they are targeting something weak or using their special skills. You spend half the game at least either reviving them or being revived yourself, so it made sense that that mechanic was as terrible as possible. You're limited to 2 of these chuckleheads on a mission, thus forcing you to choose which skill set you want with you, often depriving yourself of tactical choices more appropriate for the battlefield. Meanwhile, the rest either are dispatched on non-playable missions to gather resources, NPC's, or unlock new weapons just so they appear to be useful instead of waiting for one of your more frequently used characters to die.On the subject of weapons, your squad mates are limited to a single weapon type that 'fits' their 'class', just so they can shoe horn weapon skills in rather than allow you more customization of your squad to your tastes.  You are constantly out of ammo and you're locked from going back to pick up any you skipped before the next fight.  Despite combat being the main focus of the game, you refuse to carry more than 3 clips of ammo and enemies frequently take at least one full clip to kill, even with the sniper rifle, as you have to break their shields, take down their armor and THEN you can shoot them in the head.  Your NPC's bring unlimited ammo but refuse to share with you of course.  You're forced to comb the battlefield to pick up more from downed enemies, but often you end up swapping to a less desireable gun just so you can kill something. The random ammo boxes sprinkled around are usually in inconvenient locations, forcing you to dive out into the kill zone to retrieve. The combat is reduced to 'attack the weak spot for massive damage' in most cases, especially boss fights with a tedious cycle of hiding in cover between volleys of spam fire and waiting for it to power up and expose it's tender bits.Story:The main plot is just bad. There's a 'zombie' element that is slightly creepy, but ultimately bland, unsatisfying and inconsistent. The use of the 50's time period was made worthless by using modern day slang in the dialogue. While every character is voiced, the conversation trees are irritating to navigate, often making you listen to the main character say the same thing several times just to hear all of the choices, fortunately you can skip it, but if you're not careful you'll have to repeat the conversation AGAIN if you accidentally skip one you wanted to hear. There was an annoying blend of too much exposition and not enough.  Things you wanted to know more about were left vague or skimmed over while trivial elements were expounded on at exhaustive length.The aliens were bad mockeries of the original concepts in some cases with a few new additions.  Sillicoids went from being tough, rocky tank-class monsters to fart-joke comic relief dispatched with a single punch and generally just used as an annoyance or a 'Boo' scare during cut scenes. Mutons went from being numerous foot soldiers to single huge, plodding, damage-soaking monsters that walk at you in a straight line and again eat up all your ammo trying to kill. In the place of Muton foot-soldiers you now have a new race of aliens that are the majority of your opponents and come in many different flavors of annoying; Cloaked, minion-summoning, shield buffers, and snipers as well as just grunts with guns.  Sectoids went from intelligent, psychic, physically weak 'greys' to more comic relief, even to the point of having them thrown out as target practice at the shooting range. The worst was still the Etherials. Used as a plot device somewhere between "Gaia" type entities and possession-demons rather than their former glory as the very powerful psychic combatants.I got this game for free and generally treated it as a satire on the X-Com franchise. I have no interest in replaying it again, unlike the original and the newer remake, the story and mission choices are limited and uninteresting and have little relevance or impact on the plot. If you want a good game, buy the remake or get the original. I never want to see a sequel or DLC for this game. I advise against paying for this X-Com decorated vomit-bag.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												My experience with XCOM games started with XCOM: Enemy Unknown. It was a great game! I recently saw a sale with The Bureau for only about 4 bucks, so I decided to pick it up. Knowing it was different than XCOM, I was a little leary of it being worth playing but hey, it was only 4 bucks. Man was this a diamond in the rough! I'm quite familiar with (and happen to like) 3rd person shooters. So this game was very comfortable for me. On that of that, I loved Enemy Unkown and the strategy part was similar. You probably know by now The Bureau isn't turned based, but you can significantly slow down time while you issue commands. I'm not sure why the meta score is only 66/100. I give this game a good 87 - 92 out of 100. I would have been satisfied paying 30 bucks for it. If you like Enemy Unkown and don't mind 3rd person shooter action, I recommend trying this one out. Especially if it goes on sale again!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												The concept of this - creating an FPS out of a different genre whilst retaining a number of elements from the original - reminded me of Command & Conquer: Renegade (anybody else remember that?). I recall the fun of walking around and in a Hand of Nod and being pretty excited about it. Decent game, that, though a bug meant I never did finish it. Anyway, this takes some of the things we know and love about X:Com (a base, an Avenger, Sectoids, laser and plasma weapons etc) and turns it into a Mass Effect-lite squad-based shooter. You have companion agents, some rudimentary squad management and abilities and (limited) command in the field. I say limited because, whilst you can move your teammates to exploit flanking opportunities, as soon as you move, they move with you, thus negating any positioning you set-up - the AI for them isn't great. It's far from perfect - it's not exactly a looker, there isn't a great deal going on with the environments (it's small-town America, a farm or an alien base pretty much), there's not anything to actually anything to do in the base and it's never anything more than walk forward, shoot, walk some more on missions. Still, I found this to be quite fun. The story was decent, though completely silly, there is variety in the skills you and your teammates get, numerous weapons (though you'll probably stick to 2 or 3 favourites) and the various systems all work. Given that game had a rather torturous development it turned out ok; at least, for the £3 or so I got it for, I certainly got value for money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
												It's not as interesting as I thought. But it does add on more story to the X-COM universe. It's neither a First Person Shooter nor a strategy game. It's more of an ability-aiming/timing game. The world is really very dead and the most interactivity you have is opening a door.PROS1. StoryExtends the story for X-COM. Supposedly, if you were to join the 2 stories together. Earth knew about the aliens in the 60's, but kept it secret. In the 21st century, the Aliens came back and for some reason, X-COM had to redo all their efforts again.CONS1. RepetitiveEvery map is approximately a hide and shoot. Use your ability, hide, shoot and rinse and repeat.2. InteractivityYou can't intereact with the world. Everything is like a wall. Most NPCs are lamp posts.3. WeaponsJust take the Alien weapons instead of human weapons.4. Slow-timeNot exactly interesting. You need to use it to activate your abilities.5. DLC3 DLCs on top of this game. It's really a profit squeezing experiment where they give you a very low level game and expect players to buy more DLC to "complete" the game.6. Aiming SystemGrenades don't work well with the aiming system. Can't go past obstacles properly. Powers such as Artillery don't aim well as you have to navigate a bombardment point that is stuck to the floor, causing you to move up and around objects to reach your desired location.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Is it a good game? Yes. Do I wholeheartedly recommended it? It depends.Don't let the whiny fans throw you off: this is a good game. Now don't get me wrong, it isn't without it's flaws, partially due to how short it is for what was once a $50 dollar game. I feel that it was anything but worth that price tag, so when the price came down, I was pretty pleased.In my opinion, the gameplay was fun, but it's biggest flaw was it's linearity and roller-coaster flow of missions. The thing that makes XCOM: Enemy Unknown so great is how no experience is the same. You could've started your HQ anywhere in the world, and the missions you are given, despite having the same map spreadout, always felt unique and random in their own way. This game would be much better if a tactical interface was included; like being able to choose where XCOM HQ is, like in New York City or Los Angeles, each with their own different bonuses. I feel that the most needed change the games would've benefited from would be each mission being unique: I.E., 120 maps, different objectives, can only keep one area in line between three. While you begin dealing with these threats, you can research numerous "perks" in a sense - not that you can get these weapons, but benefits that'll come from making your plasma guns hurt more, to other tech that'll help advance the story.Make no mistake, Major Operations will still be there: however, it'd be awesome if the story progresses as you research technology while you deal with the threat across the nation. That alone would make the game that much fresher.Overall, this is a good game, but it's linearity and lack of depth understandably dissapointed a lot of fans. I just felt that I should write this review to show how it would've been better. Overall, a good game, but not perfect. Really, it's your taste if you want to buy it or not.

												I picked this game up for 2.99 so I am taking that into account in this review, and I think it is probably even worth full price.The game is, in a nut-shell a poor man's Mass Effect set in the Xcom universe's version of the 60's. The atmosphere is good, and the game itself is 'ok' in so far that it is almost good at a lot of things. It doesn't quite manage to pull off what it wants to though, but still falls into the 'ok' category.Most of what I am about to say is negative, because the game is so close to being good that I am disappointed in how it turned out, but I would still say buy the game - especially if you are a fan of xcom or mass effect, or perhaps only if you fall into those camps.Combat is tough, at least early on which is where I am, because you are vastly outgunned and frequently find enemies that you can hardly hurt. You are also forced (Pretty close to forced anyway) into an Alien shotgun if you want to kill those enamies, and personally I hate shotguns. I expect when you unlock more guns the game will improve, but I haven't made it through that far yet.The big issue with combat for me is that when you bring up the orders menu the camera isn't the most responsive, and since time isn't fully paused it can lead to you giving messed up orders (Such as sending one man left and the other right when you want them both down the same flank).AI is also pretty poor too, especially for your own team who have a bad habit of getting their heads blown off when they should be in cover.Character development is a miss since you only have one progression tree to go down. Why you go down that tree makes sense, but I like more options in my games.The other miss is the research element from the base xcom series, here you just find the odd gun lying around. They make an explanation for why you can pick up some but not other, but it is a bit half hearted.So overall there is a good game trying to get out from under a not quite there exterior, worth playing, worth the £10-15 they are asking, but probably not much more, Go in knowing what you are getting, and you will come out with hope for The Bureau 2 (If they ever make it) rather than disappointment at this one.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												This is a squad-based action game similar to Mass Effect so if you expect it to be just like XCOM: Enemy Unknown you may be disappointed, it is not turn-based tactics on a grid. That said, it is a good game in its own right and focuses much more heavily on the story and character development than its tactics counterpart. There are still different classes and a leveling system of sorts in which you can choose bonuses or upgrades similar to the leveling in Enemy Unknown. The story reveals a lot more about the background of XCOM but don't expect all your questions to be answered either.Hangar 6 R&D - Definitely worth the cost, you get several extra missions to play as DaSilva and take on some more aliens. If you completed the main story and are looking for some more of the same then I recommend this. Don't expect a lot of new content or anything though, it's the same weapons and aliens. The only really new things are the missions and story, and DaSilva's perks are kind of a mix but mostly familiar. This campaign runs entirely separate from the regular campaign (you start a whole new file) so it won't interfere or matter where you are in the regular story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Beautiful environments, engaging combat, and a very entertaining story (with an interesting and unexpected twist, to boot!). I enjoyed this game a ton. The AI can be a bit lacking at times, sure, but what that meant for me was more micro-management. During the chaos of combat, I was forced to account for my other squaddies, positioning them, utilizing their skills, and trying to out-maneuver the enemy. That's really what this game is all about. It's not a shooter, despite it having guns which you aim. It's not some story-driven RPG, despite there being a good story and RPG elements, albeit rather shallow ones. It's pure tactical: time only slows, not stops, while giving orders; positioning and cover counts. You need to care for your squad. That's what I loved about this game.And the setting. And the story. And Carter.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31, 2016
												The concept of this - creating an FPS out of a different genre whilst retaining a number of elements from the original - reminded me of Command & Conquer: Renegade (anybody else remember that?). I recall the fun of walking around and in a Hand of Nod and being pretty excited about it. Decent game, that, though a bug meant I never did finish it. Anyway, this takes some of the things we know and love about X:Com (a base, an Avenger, Sectoids, laser and plasma weapons etc) and turns it into a Mass Effect-lite squad-based shooter. You have companion agents, some rudimentary squad management and abilities and (limited) command in the field. I say limited because, whilst you can move your teammates to exploit flanking opportunities, as soon as you move, they move with you, thus negating any positioning you set-up - the AI for them isn't great. It's far from perfect - it's not exactly a looker, there isn't a great deal going on with the environments (it's small-town America, a farm or an alien base pretty much), there's not anything to actually anything to do in the base and it's never anything more than walk forward, shoot, walk some more on missions. Still, I found this to be quite fun. The story was decent, though completely silly, there is variety in the skills you and your teammates get, numerous weapons (though you'll probably stick to 2 or 3 favourites) and the various systems all work. Given that game had a rather torturous development it turned out ok; at least, for the £3 or so I got it for, I certainly got value for money.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2013
												Mass Effect but with a 60s art style. Teammate AI is a mess with them choosing to take cover in front of enemies or keep running around doing nothing unless you decide to issue commands for them every single second, thankfully this gets slightly better once they level up and can take more damage, and once you level up a few times in which the game becomes a total cakewalk. Other than that the combat is alright and can even become ~~intense~~ sometimes in harder difficulties. The storyline is a mess; outside the twist near the end it's very disjointed with the game assuming you know things you haven't been told yet (your character acts as if he knows these things too) and some characters vanishing two levels from the end of the game and never being mentioned again. Like I mentioned before the entire game plays and feels like Mass Effect but set in the 60s (there's even a base you can walk around in and talk to people after missions). I liked the art style a lot and it kept me playing until the end, but the game itself is kind of a mess due to it being stuck in development hell for 5+ years. Even so it's not Aliens Colonial Marines/Duke Forever horrible garbage, just average. If you think the setting looks interesting and want a slightly strategical third person shooter (think Brother in Arms and Mass Effect as previously mentioned) buy it when it's on sale for u$20 and you'll have fun. Hopefully it'll get a sequel in the future that fixes the issues it has (but it bombed so it won't).

If you're just looking for another XCOM game, this is not it, its much more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18
												Recommended.Basically, it's the XCOM universe as far as I understand it, just earlier than XCOM.But BE ADVISED:It's NOT like the XCOM games. This is an arcadish third-person shooter, and it's more focused towards arcade. Still, it's a storydriven campaign, very nice graphics, and if you've played XCOM you'll recognize your adversaries. Part from that this plays out during the early 60's, and it's sort of a return to the drive-in movies of alien invasions from the 50's.On top of the third-person setup of this game, it also includes tactical elements due to you being allowed to order and direct your "squad" or allies that join you. Depending on the difficulty that this game is played at, tactics can either make things easier, or make things possible. What this game does though, is to put you in the role of one of the frontline soldiers of XCOM. The guys and gals you're commanding in the XCOM games, here you're one of them. As such it's a very nice approach to that universe and those games, and as long as you keep that in mind, playing it is a very fun complement to the other XCOM games.But, if you expect an XCOM game in it's full with squad command, turn-based, top-down and so forth, this is not for you. If you're still curious, pick it up on sale and try it out.If you on the other hand fancy third-person shooters, like the XCOM universe and don't mind linear campaigns and some arcadish approaches, by all means pick this game up at full price.

												Contrary to most online reviews out there, I consider this to be one of the best games out there.First of, it is cannon but not in the obvious in your face way that modern gamers may expect. The way I see it My skyrangers in the 60ties were bells helicopters while the vanguard invasion force was flying craft that suprisingly enough looked a lot like my skyrangers in 1999. Most aliens were using laser weapons in the sixties with a couple plasma prototypes for the crack troops, well guess what weapons you already can research at the beginning of the 1999 invasion... (lasers duh, gotta work for plasmas) The way I see most reviewers bi**ing bout how come most of this tech never worked at the latter invasions? well E115 is naturally an unstable element, and it does get used up, and there is no natural source of it on our world, srry, no gas no ride....kk game, tactical combat better than that in Mass Effect (if u know what you are doing). Shooting gallery a lot worse than CoD, never buy it if ur expecting to go rambo on thar alien hineys, u wont, ur chances are slimmer than doing the same in ARMA. Dialoges and lip sinc, and voice acting, Thar♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ true, but for me this acctually boosts the game, it plays out like the B class movie it was supposed to mimic, I loved it for the lifeless "look good sound smart actors". Overall, its awesome. Give it a try if you like old black and white horror sci-fi from the 50, from mars, ...of Death, of terror of Death, and Zombie chipmunk brainsnatchers from out there but right here now... yadda yadda...GOOD GAME! don't be swayed by the crappy cannon lets gang up on the new kid reviewers. Tis a rocking game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												If you are a big Xcom fan like I am, you will consider this a more than fine addition to the Xcom Franchise -- although it is a significant departure from the "canon" of the other games. Set in the 50s, It pits the protagonist and two squad-mates against an alien invasion with WW2 weaponry until you can capture the weapons of your foes. Your squad mates can be different classes, and develop cool powers over time, which should allow for different play styles, but sadly there is little motivation to swap between your favorite (and most experienced) soldiers most of the time. Graphics are cool, power implementation is cool, and you can "bullet time" at any point in combat to decide exactly what your squad does (and positioning as well as skill management MATTERS) but the time does not go SO slowly that you don't have to think fast to avoid trouble (cooking grenades, sudden flanking) -- combat is fun and really makes you think... I drew satisfaction both from pitched battles and finding clever solutions to situations. The story is engaging, in a genre where there's been enough retread over the same types of mysterious baddies this game has a novel take on the enemy -- they are both worthy of wanting to understand, contempt, and fear. Types of enemies are QUITE varied, too.The Bad?: Game is pretty linear, though tries not to be. Squad size a step back from every other Xcom game. No research or Alien Autopsy (which is arguably one of the cooler elements of Xcom) though there IS some alien interrogation.Overall, a pretty spiffy game that is fun to play and has a cool story and it's own flavor. Both different enough to be novel, and familiar enough to please the Xcom fan. No regrets here, great squad-based 3rd-person tactical.

												It's a real XCOM. The team's control is not a Rainbow Six, but you can give them the appropriate orders to survive and win on the battlefield. Yours and your team's abilities are really awesome (mine, turret, shield, critical shot, invisibility, etc) and they're really come in handy in the fight. The missions and the maps are various, not just go there, kill that type. I really like running around on the base, talk to everyone, doing side missions. It adds a lot to the game and you'll find out a lot about the backstory. And last but not least, I love the cold war atmosphere.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2014
												I remember this game getting a lot of "meh" reviews when it came out, but I think it deserved better.  The story isn't life-changing, but it is very interesting and different.  A huge amount of love clearly went into building the world and all the little stories within; the attention to detail should impress most who look.  Controlling the game, with it's heavy reliance on managing one's squad, is a little clunky and takes some getting used to.  However, you get to be good at it and feel pretty fancy when a plan goes like you want it to.Honestly, my biggest complaint is that Carter's voice is a parody of Modern Shooter Protagonist.  It's not Mark Hildreth's best work; he sounds like he's trying too hard to be gravelly.  Everyone else is good, though!  This game is definitely worth a play.  It's long enough to be a good value and fun enough that I didn't want to put it down for hours.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I really wanted to like this game. It has a really cool 60's aesthetic, the shooting isn't bad, and production values are good. Besides, I love the Xcom series. But this is such a pain to play through I'm not sure I'll ever finish it. You are saddled with two incompetent teammates at all times the game really wants you to use. But they're too stupid to be of any use if you don't micromanage them constantly, breaking the flow of combat. They die quick, and since their AI is bad, they often get out of cover to die in a few shots. The Bureau is a frustrating and poorly designed game that is more likely to infuriate than entertain, sadly.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												I would rate this game 7/10.Note for windows 10 users like me: The Game is not working on win 10 with newest physX drivers. Crashes all the time. The only way to play it, is to disable physX. Without PhysX it works just fine.About the game: + I really like the 60s look+ The graphics are good even compared to games of today (2016)+ The game is heavely story driven and the story is interesting+ Fighting is fun (mostly), but the aiming seems not be very accurate+ The game is not a traditional third-person shooter because having a team you can give orders adds some strategy elements to the game+ The orders UI is well done and easy to use+ I love the personality of agent william carter, he is a cold, kinda bored anti hero guy+ there is a direct x 11 version of the game (even though the game is pretty old now)+ Today it costs a fraction of what it did when it got first released+ Game in the X-Com universe (yeah it's not an X-Com turn-based strategy game)- autosave really sucks, I really hate autosave, please game devs stop making games with autosave - the physX bug mentioned earlier, but I did not find any other bugs so far- AI is far from being perfect, your team members as well as the aliens have problems to find good cover spotsThis strategical part is a welcome change compared to other similar shooter games where you have no team to command. It also has some RPG aspects as there are lots of dialogs and you can evolve your character.Personally I think it's a good game. It's a good 3rd person strategical shooter and for the price it costs today it's not overpriced.I saw a lot of reviewers saying this is not like X-Com and giving it a thumbs down because of that, I think this is really stupid. It's nowhere written this an X-Com sequel. This is clearly not an X-Com turn based strategy game like the other X-Com games, it is another kind of game in the X-Com universe, but clearly not a turn based strategy game (no idea where people read this or why they think it is)! It's an 3rd person action game, some sort of stragical shooter, nothing less and nothing more.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is NOTHING like xcom. Don't go in expecting anything similar. They'd be as well just removing XCOM from the name.If you can get it for 10 euro, it's worth it. Otherwise, there are games with far better gameplay out there.If you do buy it, buy the plasma pistol as well it's a massive help to get past the initial boring bits. The game is quite polished and isn't outright BAD but falls down with:- The AI. It's dumb as hell. If you tell them to stand somewhere, and you yourself move, they will often run to keep close to you - making flanking irritating to impossible- some of the encounters will cause you to die out of just bad luck and sheer number of enemies spamming grenades at you. With no mid level saves it's a pain to do an entire segment again.- reloading will wipe any buffs, so you have to spend a while reshielding or rebuffing- there's nothing tactical about it. It's cluster frack management. - there no explanation why half your guys have "magic" abilities at the start. They just do.- reference to the gear on your arm is made at several points. It's not explained why you have it or where it came from- the base segments are irritatingly slow to navigate as you cannot sprint- when your team mate's abilities are on cooldown, they are essentially useless.- the engineer can only have a shotgun for about 80% of the game, and the shotgun is severely pointless. yes, they can place a turret but they can't keep the turret up themselves so if it died he'll mince about doing very little- combat is unsatisfying- stats of each backpack (character modifier) aren't clear, so it's not really obvious what will be better.- light plasma pistol is a must. the enemy has a massive upperhand early on really dragging the "bad" part of the game on.- and on that note, the game doesn't really get remotely fun till your guys start hitting level 4 or 5.- some ammo capacities are overly restrictive making some weapons not really feel like an upgrade when they should- inexplicably you cannot have female followers, despite the animations clearly being available given that the female agent weaver joins you to provide fire support

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												If you are a big Xcom fan like I am, you will consider this a more than fine addition to the Xcom Franchise -- although it is a significant departure from the "canon" of the other games. Set in the 50s, It pits the protagonist and two squad-mates against an alien invasion with WW2 weaponry until you can capture the weapons of your foes. Your squad mates can be different classes, and develop cool powers over time, which should allow for different play styles, but sadly there is little motivation to swap between your favorite (and most experienced) soldiers most of the time. Graphics are cool, power implementation is cool, and you can "bullet time" at any point in combat to decide exactly what your squad does (and positioning as well as skill management MATTERS) but the time does not go SO slowly that you don't have to think fast to avoid trouble (cooking grenades, sudden flanking) -- combat is fun and really makes you think... I drew satisfaction both from pitched battles and finding clever solutions to situations. The story is engaging, in a genre where there's been enough retread over the same types of mysterious baddies this game has a novel take on the enemy -- they are both worthy of wanting to understand, contempt, and fear. Types of enemies are QUITE varied, too.The Bad?: Game is pretty linear, though tries not to be. Squad size a step back from every other Xcom game. No research or Alien Autopsy (which is arguably one of the cooler elements of Xcom) though there IS some alien interrogation.Overall, a pretty spiffy game that is fun to play and has a cool story and it's own flavor. Both different enough to be novel, and familiar enough to please the Xcom fan. No regrets here, great squad-based 3rd-person tactical.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												"Oh, it's a... third-person shooter."  I was a bit surprised, expecting something a little more like the previous XCOM game, Enemy Unknown.  The setting looked quite promising, at first.  I even snickered a little bit in the first mission, when I picked up an 1962-vintage M14 battle rifle to shoot aliens with.Of course, it has the obligatory cover system which seems to be required of any run n' gun game of this sort, but only some manage to execute effectively.  Does this game?  Well... sort of: considering the fact that some other games' cover systems can manage any maneuver with nothing more than WASD, the direction you're looking, and the Spacebar, The Bureau seems to go more for a style where each little variation on "jumping from cover to cover" needs its own key.  Good, I suppose, if you've had trouble getting the more "intuitive" cover systems to do what you want, but for me it breaks up the action a little too much.  "Okay, I need to get to that desk which is a bit ahead of me and to my left.  So, I hold Left, and press... V, I think, and then..."A bit of a learning curve on the cover controls, though, is not a game-breaker.  It did, however, all fall apart for me eventually.Pretty soon after you've gotten a taste of "how to shoot" and "how to not get shot," you're presented with a big, steaming pile of a squad command system.  The Bureau has you giving commands to your agents, not too unlike Enemy Unknown did - apart from the fact that you *are* also one of the agents.  What you end up with, then, is a game where you play a real-time, but dumbed-down version of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, in between bouts of playing an okay-but-not-amazing third-person shooter game, using a clumsier version of the dynamic pause squad-command system from the Mass Effect trilogy.So, if you *liked* XCOM: Enemy Unknown, or the Mass Effect trilogy... don't play this.  If you like the XCOM series enough that you simply must at least *try* The Bureau, do yourself a favour and at least wait for a sale, which will reduce the sting if you end up being as disappointed as I was.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I really wanted to like this game. It has a really cool 60's aesthetic, the shooting isn't bad, and production values are good. Besides, I love the Xcom series. But this is such a pain to play through I'm not sure I'll ever finish it. You are saddled with two incompetent teammates at all times the game really wants you to use. But they're too stupid to be of any use if you don't micromanage them constantly, breaking the flow of combat. They die quick, and since their AI is bad, they often get out of cover to die in a few shots. The Bureau is a frustrating and poorly designed game that is more likely to infuriate than entertain, sadly.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												It's a real XCOM. The team's control is not a Rainbow Six, but you can give them the appropriate orders to survive and win on the battlefield. Yours and your team's abilities are really awesome (mine, turret, shield, critical shot, invisibility, etc) and they're really come in handy in the fight. The missions and the maps are various, not just go there, kill that type. I really like running around on the base, talk to everyone, doing side missions. It adds a lot to the game and you'll find out a lot about the backstory. And last but not least, I love the cold war atmosphere.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												This is NOTHING like xcom. Don't go in expecting anything similar. They'd be as well just removing XCOM from the name.If you can get it for 10 euro, it's worth it. Otherwise, there are games with far better gameplay out there.If you do buy it, buy the plasma pistol as well it's a massive help to get past the initial boring bits. The game is quite polished and isn't outright BAD but falls down with:- The AI. It's dumb as hell. If you tell them to stand somewhere, and you yourself move, they will often run to keep close to you - making flanking irritating to impossible- some of the encounters will cause you to die out of just bad luck and sheer number of enemies spamming grenades at you. With no mid level saves it's a pain to do an entire segment again.- reloading will wipe any buffs, so you have to spend a while reshielding or rebuffing- there's nothing tactical about it. It's cluster frack management. - there no explanation why half your guys have "magic" abilities at the start. They just do.- reference to the gear on your arm is made at several points. It's not explained why you have it or where it came from- the base segments are irritatingly slow to navigate as you cannot sprint- when your team mate's abilities are on cooldown, they are essentially useless.- the engineer can only have a shotgun for about 80% of the game, and the shotgun is severely pointless. yes, they can place a turret but they can't keep the turret up themselves so if it died he'll mince about doing very little- combat is unsatisfying- stats of each backpack (character modifier) aren't clear, so it's not really obvious what will be better.- light plasma pistol is a must. the enemy has a massive upperhand early on really dragging the "bad" part of the game on.- and on that note, the game doesn't really get remotely fun till your guys start hitting level 4 or 5.- some ammo capacities are overly restrictive making some weapons not really feel like an upgrade when they should- inexplicably you cannot have female followers, despite the animations clearly being available given that the female agent weaver joins you to provide fire support

content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
												I don't know if I'm the only person in the world who still remembers them, but The Bureau is a lot like Gearbox's old Brothers in Arms series: it's a third person, tactical squad shooter where you're expected to win by ordering your men to flank and use their special abilities rather than killing everything yourself. A more recent comparison, and this is fairly obvious based on the UI and such, is Mass Effect 2/3's combat (but again, with less focus on the protagonist killing everything himself).It's a pretty good-looking game (it's UE3 with fairly pretty lighting, and a really solid aesthetic direction), and I've only run into a couple of minor bugs (a flying enemy got stuck under the level a couple of times because they were spawning behind a tall wall and attempting to go under it) - performance and stability are solid on my system. It's a good port, too, with lots of video options and a good FoV slider (it's dumb to have to mention this, but hey, modern gaming).I really don't get why it got the review scores it did. It's a really polished, fun title in what is admittedly a fairly niche genre, and to cap things off, it has one of the more intelligent war plots I've seen in video games (yes, despite being a game about the 1950s FBI fighting little grey men). It's also fun seeing what are basically levels from XCOM: Enemy Unknown translated to third person.All in all, if you're a fan of tactical third-person shooters, I can only recommend this. It's great.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												I would rate this game 7/10.Note for windows 10 users like me: The Game is not working on win 10 with newest physX drivers. Crashes all the time. The only way to play it, is to disable physX. Without PhysX it works just fine.About the game: + I really like the 60s look+ The graphics are good even compared to games of today (2016)+ The game is heavely story driven and the story is interesting+ Fighting is fun (mostly), but the aiming seems not be very accurate+ The game is not a traditional third-person shooter because having a team you can give orders adds some strategy elements to the game+ The orders UI is well done and easy to use+ I love the personality of agent william carter, he is a cold, kinda bored anti hero guy+ there is a direct x 11 version of the game (even though the game is pretty old now)+ Today it costs a fraction of what it did when it got first released+ Game in the X-Com universe (yeah it's not an X-Com turn-based strategy game)- autosave really sucks, I really hate autosave, please game devs stop making games with autosave - the physX bug mentioned earlier, but I did not find any other bugs so far- AI is far from being perfect, your team members as well as the aliens have problems to find good cover spotsThis strategical part is a welcome change compared to other similar shooter games where you have no team to command. It also has some RPG aspects as there are lots of dialogs and you can evolve your character.Personally I think it's a good game. It's a good 3rd person strategical shooter and for the price it costs today it's not overpriced.I saw a lot of reviewers saying this is not like X-Com and giving it a thumbs down because of that, I think this is really stupid. It's nowhere written this an X-Com sequel. This is clearly not an X-Com turn based strategy game like the other X-Com games, it is another kind of game in the X-Com universe, but clearly not a turn based strategy game (no idea where people read this or why they think it is)! It's an 3rd person action game, some sort of stragical shooter, nothing less and nothing more.

Posted: July 18, 2014
												Basically this entire game is starting a mission, walk 5 feet, battle, talk, battle, battle, battle. You go back to base where you can't do anything except listen to a couple people with no actual impact on the game. You then select your next mission and just battle your way through it. There seems to be no actual point to this game. Your NPC team mates can't hit the broad side of a barn, leaving you to do 90% of the damage even when you have control of what they are doing. No research to be done, nothing cool whatsoever. Fight after fight after fight. Such a crazy disappointment. If you liked any of the XCOM games, don't bother with this one. I wouldn't pay more than 5$ for this. Thank god I bought it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 22, 2014
												Bleh - I couldn't be bothered to finish this. It had a lot of potential, but it just isn't much fun.- Team AI is horrid. I can live with them being mostly pointless or just serving as special ability vehicles, ala Mass Effect. However they are aggressively stupid. Periodically they will decide their cover is bad, and charge forward into the enemy, or way over-extend themselves. This would be a stupid nuisance, if it wasn't for the permadeath. If you could tell them "go here" and rely on them STAYING there, that would be ok too.. but the moment an enemy lobs a grenade, they take off.- Abilities are lackluster. Only 3-4 abilities per class is sort of boring. Often a guy would level and I would bring up their level-up menu to see what neat stuff they would get, and be disapointed.- Enemies are bullet sponges.- Most weapons don't feel very effective.- While the game starts by sort of implying there will be upgrades and upgrade trees, it is boring. There are laser upgrades to the main weapons (that are not even reliably an upgrade.. I'm convinced the Laser SMB is worse then all the bullet weapons). Every character gets basically 1 gun, and 1 backpack. The backpacks each have a different type of buff (+dmg to shielded enemies, +dmg to headshots, etc), and thats it for their equipment.All told, I was fairly disapointed in this. I figured at 7 bucks or so (the sale price I paid) it would be a good time with action similar to mass effect but meh. If they kept the combat system but had more depth to the powers, more depth to leveling, better AI, and more depth to equipment, this could have been awesome.

content:
Posted: January 27
												Checking the steam score I had very low expectations with The Bureau. However, after finishing the game the final impression is positive. For sure it is not an excellent 3rd-person tactical shooter but also not a fiasco. If someone expects stratetic elements of the original Xcom titles he/she will be underwhelmed. But from my perspective the same is more or less true for the new Xcom games: while very good turn-based strategy titles they are nowhere near as perfect as the original masterpiece of the 1994.Pros:+ excellent graphics for models and environment, very concincing lighting effects + very good soundtrack+ variety of skills, weapons and team members to choose from+ nice recreation of the sixties+ interesting idea to walk/interact inside the base you build in the Xcom games+ story is, on average, good with some nice twists+ cover seems to work, same of team coordination although player actions have a much greater role than companions`.Cons:- I did not quite liked the introduction with the alien invasion and the plot seems to be played in fast forward at some instances. From the story perspective it feels like a sequel to a game we never played. I would prefer much more focusing on "first contact", i.e. early missions from the very beginning of the alien attack, searching crashed or landed ufos. The game starts from the middle or from near the end of the plot. Xcom organization gets hold of very advanced alien tech too early and too fast in the game.  - some important pacing issues. Parts in the missions include lots of walking without doing anything. A lot of back and forth is happening inside the base without any obvious reason. Running inside the base could be a good idea.- Some ideas/concepts seem incomplete. For example there are dialogue options without changing something in the main story line. You find some logs, infos etc but again they play little to no role.- Alien environment seems a bit repeated and boring compared to the earth setting. - sometimes AI players seem to follow strange paths leading to suicide.- veteran difficulty seems quite steep especially in confined environments (but you can change it).- some aspects of the main plot are left unexplained (what happened to Carter?) or are not very believable (the whole USA got invaded and almost obliterated by the aliens but eventially the goverment managed to cover everything up?)No comment on the DLCs as I have not bought/played them. DLCs with weapons etc leave me completely uninterested. All in all a flawed but still interesting squad-based action game. It plays in the Xcom universe but is very different from the turn-based strategy games. Recommended, especially at discount.

												I know this game got a lot of mediocre reviews and it does have it's problems but if you don't go in expecting a AAA game of the year candidate and take it for what it is you should have a fun time. It kinda reminds me of a janky, low-rent Mass Effect set in the 1960's. The battles can be tense as hell but it also knows when to be quiet and just let you wander around. If you're looking for a cheap 20 hour third person shooter you could do a hell of a lot worse than The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.
