content:
Posted: January 26
												Initially hated the game, but went back to it after a year. In the end, thought it wasn't too bad, even though it felt like some weird mass-effect rip-off.Cons: The agent management system is horrible, and the cover system feels very clunky and unrefined. Some parts of the game can be pretty frustrating on higher difficulties (but you have the option to lower the difficulty whenever through the menu). Missions can feel stale after a while as in the end you are always fighting against the same bunch of enemies, which become progressively more powerful.Pros: Has some fun RPG elements like advancing skills. Great voice acting. Overall story is engaging and interesting enough, but don't expect an AAA RPG story arc.Would recommend the game to XCOM fans.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Could've been, and should've been so much more.Over all, I've been entertained by this game...but it seems like such a missed opportunity.  The idea of a squad-based third person shooter as an installment of XCOM is interesting, but ultimately it's poorly executed in this game...a pale reflection of Mass Effect.  Better AI, a bigger diversity of weapons, and more interesting passive/active abilities would've been a significant boost.  As it is, the game is quick to master, and as there's little else in the way of gameplay, it begins to make the game feel repetitive.  The  RPG elements provide hardly any depth, the items ultimately seem like nothing more than skin changes.  I have no idea why they decided weapons should be picked up in missions (instead of researched or built at your own pace) and nothing should have a clear representation of what effects are provided.  Does this backpack (your only other piece of equipment besides weapons) provide more damage resistance than that one?  Who can say, because the game sure doesn't.  More on the management side could've been a bit of a boost to gameplay as well.The story is utterly disjointed...suddenly it will present information that I'm seeing for the first time as though I should be well versed in it.  It's poorly paced, characters can be a little bland and cheesey, all of which could be okay if the overall storyline and gameplay were more interesting.  As it is, it's just downright confusing at times.All in all, it's an okay game.  I'm just disappointed that for whatever reasons (be it bowing down to exterior pressure, excessive development time, too many changes of direction) it feels like it could've been a lot more.  From the review, it probably sounds like I think it's a bad game.  I don't.  It's just passable, and it's not something that I would imagine that I'd ever pick up again after my first play-through.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I have played all of the XCOM games and love the series, so being able to play a third-position shooter take on the XCOM universe was very nice and refreshing.If you like the series, alien themes, third-person action shooters, and squad-based tactics, you will really enjoy this game.The aesthetics are fantastic with lots of special effects in the form of mutons (mutations taken from the alien technology). The music fits very well with the theme and setting - it is appropriately intense whenever the action calls for it. The controls are fairly straightforward, and the tutorial mission is great at helping you understand both the controls and how to issue orders to your squad without being too long or too boring. The learning curve is moderate, however, the game can be extremely unforgiven in the commander (hardest) difficulty. There is permanent death if your squad members are downed and not revived in time on commander difficulty; furthermore, reviving them only stabilizes them - meaning they are out of combat until the instance is cleared of all enemies. I am playing on this difficulty, and have had many situations where I had to slow-play and defeat all the enemies on my own. Your squad members are heavily reliant on your orders, especially in the harder difficulties.The story is pretty good, and there is a lot of extras provided in the form of audio recordings and files if you choose to look for them. The gameplay reminded me a lot of Mass Effect, down to the very first muton power you unlock for your character - lift. The feedback is very good, showing the enemy's health at the top center of the screen, and having large grenade icons warning you of the blast radius. During battles, you can go into battle focus, which slows down time to a crawl and allows you to issue your orders. There is a range where you can order your squadmates to move/do actions, which I found to be very nice. You can have two weapons equipped at a time, and you will slowly unlock new equipment (the first being a bag that increases your headshot damage). You may have only 2 other active squad members at a time.Cover is extremely important, as the enemy will try to actively flank you and can become very aggressive. Most combat instances will have a few ammo drops to refill your weapons, and explosive barrels are littered in many areas to help you kill mobs of enemies quickly.As you gain experience, you will level up and can choose different perks for both you and your teammates. There is a decent variety of customization - you can change every agent's clothing color (pretty basic), and their background changes the type of perks that can be unlocked. You can recruit new agents, and when you do this you will be given an option to choose both their class and their background (ex: engineer class with technical expertise, leading to faster cooldowns on abilities). The XCOM base is not as explorable as I'd like, but it is still fun to walk around and talk to people - or read the extra content like agent dossiers.There are a number of side missions for you to play and unlock more mutons. Completing these help you gain levels and increase your psychic arsenal to defeat the alien invaders. Very good game, especially if you are a fan of the series.Definitely recommend!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2014
												First off, I have absolutely no experience with the XCOM franchise, so I can't say how the plot stands with the other games, or how faithful the universe is.Besides, I haven't played a tactical TPS in a long time, which means that I may overlook some aspects that avid players of the genre look forward to.But here are my general thoughts. I'll try not to be too detailed, since AAAs have such a bigger scale compared to what I'm used to playing.So. The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a tactical third person shooter, set in the 60's, in the first alien invasion of Earth. The best of the best are united in the XCOM to fight this invasion, and cover it up to protect the population.You'll go through several missions (some minor, some major), and you'll get to know the people you're working with between each, in the base.You have a squad of 3 people (you, and 2 AI partners), that you have some control over, during the fights. There are different classes in the game, and with each come different skills to aid you in battle. Some are support focused (providing shields, damage buffs, etc.), engineers (focus on tech, turrets, etc.), artillery (with long range deadly shots), you get the drill.Each of them can be leveled up to rank 5, and you go as far as rank 10. With each rank you choose 1 of 2 perks (sometimes, 1 of 1... tough choice, there).Let's start with the presentation.It's a AAA game, and that's very clear. Everything looks really nice, and it felt the theme surprisingly well, with the lighting effects giving the game an old sci-fi feel! Other parts of the game looked more generic, unfortunately. But overall, it certainly looked great, with good particle effects, lighting, and physics. The music also fit the theme very well, both the 60's feel, and the sci-fi. Unfortunately, it was very far apart. I don't feel like they've used the music very effectively, specially in the tense and emotional moments, the music in those was simply underwhelming.Overall, it didn't really feel as unique as it could have. As a AAA, it did very little to standout, despite being pretty good aside from that.One thing it did well in the beginning, was portraying the time setting well, using posters, and even the conversations with the different people.Moving on. The gameplay started out pretty good, but the probems soon started to reveal themselves. I chose to play in Commander Difficulty at first. The problem with that, was the friendly AI. They died within 4 seconds of the start of the fight. And I'm not exaggerating!If I sent someone to revive them, they'd just stand in the middle of the shots and would die as well. And that was pretty much the experience. That kind of challenge wasn't welcome at all. I spent way more time trying to keep my squad alive than fighting! So... after about 5 missions I decided I had enough with it, and turned it to Veteran. I died twice in the whole game after that. Once in the last mission, with throws wave after wave of enemies after you.There's just such a big discrepancy between Hard and Very Hard... that's not a very good balance, in my opinion.   Commander mode could have been really strategic and tense, if the AI was worth something.       Unfortunately, it was really bad. And you could see in the end, comparing their kills to yours. You alone did about 95% of the job, so yeah...   Other than that, it wasn't bad. You had several different weapons at your disposal, different enemies had to be taken out in different ways (not too different, but a bit different nonetheless), the skills lead to some nice teamwork... I wasn't bad!   It was not spectacular, but I was fairly enjoyable.   As I said before, between missions, you'll be in the Hub Area. Here, you can talk to the scientists, engineers, pretty much everyone, and get their view on the invasion. You'll also know why they're there, and what they're working on. That was cool. It didn't blow my mind, but it's good that it's there, if you feel like exploring a bit more.   There are also Notes, Photos, and Audio"Logs" spread out, during the breaks between battles. These also give you a bit more insight into the world, which is always good!   Something that really bothered me though, was the Audio Logs. You had to stand near to listen to it. ... Why? The whole point of audio logs is to keep the player exploring, while being presented with the backstory. And they managed to screw it up, and have you stop your playing to listen to it... It makes no sense! Might as well give you a note instead of an audio log... I don't understand.   There's not much else to say about it, really. The cover system works fine, for the most part. One complaint I have, is that you can't roll into cover! That's really important, in my view! You can roll out of the way fine. But if you roll into cover, it doesn't connect, so you'll stand up, fully vulnerable, after rolling. And you'll take unnecessary shots. I don't see why it's not in there either, but oh well...   I may seem overly negative about the game, for a positive review. The fact of the matter is, that it mostly functions very well. The gunplay is solid, movement in fluid, combat involves some level of tactic, while ordering your squad members, ...   It's not a bad game at all. It's simply not a very good one either, and for full price, I definitely do not recommend it. But if you're curious about the setting, or you're a fan of XCOM, I don't see a problem in getting in a sale, or something along those lines.   The character interactions, though, were really bad in my opinion. And so was the way they handled the ending. SPOILERS HERE. So, while you were playing with one character for the whole game, learned about his intentions, played his role, they decided to switch things up. In the end, you had to choose another character to control. (You're an alien controlling them,  basically) You had 3 choices that were not very well explained. Nor well executed, with the past they set up.   The new character played exactly the same way as the previous one! You go from a badass field agent to a scientist who barely every fought, and they have exactly the same abilities and skills! It makes no sense whatsoever! And they also expect you to make the choices you've made with the previous character, as if they were the same... Depending on the character you choose, you'll get a different ending, based on each person's ideals, and that was good. But aside from that one cutscene in the end, it felt a very shallow choice. And even before that, there was ONE seemingly important choice... Well, it was just a cameo. There was no choice at all, it was all an illusion. And a pretty bad one. Oh well.    Overall, I expected more. But for the price at which I got it, it was a fine game. Won't change the world in any way, but it was enjoyable.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
												I really wanted to love this game. I'm a huge fan of both the XCOM series and FPS games. It seemed like an awesome blending of things I love set in an awesome time period. However, the game just isn't polished. Your AI team mates make terrible decisions, forcing you to micromanage them which derails the pace of the game. The interface is clunky and the game crashes frequently.They want the game to be semi-tactical but they don't give you any options to do that outside of issuing orders. None of the gear you get has stats in any meaningful way. I.E. you'll get one piece of gear that says it increases critical hit damage, but then gives no clue as to how much compared to another piece of gear that does the same thing. You also lose all of the cool meta play of how XCOM is run except for in a few forced ways.*****Possible Spoilers*****Probably the worst part of the game is the writing. The voice acting is fine but the dialogue is cliche after cliche. The characters act inconsistently. In one scene you'll go rogue and in the next chew someone out for doing the same, then support someone else for going rogue in the scene after. The choices people make are unbelievable, including allowing agent after agent to disobey orders. The internal logic of the game is busted. For example in the opening mission you're paired with a guy who can throw out laser turrets even though XCOM hasn't gotten that technology yet. The game is constantly throwing out situations/abilities/technology that don't make any sense or follow the XCOM universe's rules.

content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												Typical console 3rd person port. Not a bad thing, actually using a controller is easier than KB/mouse. Has quite complex actions, puzzles are kind of different for me, but fun and having computer AI helping you is a cool thing. Sort of team based co-op. Graphics are pretty cool and I love blasting little green men! Its story based and pretty linear. But for a casual gamer as myself, I prefer that anyways. Not too deep or complicated.. Kill things, move on.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 24, 2014
												While this game departs sharply from the turn based mechanics found in the pervious XCOM games, I found it to be a compitantly excuted experience for a real time squad based strategy game. While this game is by no means original, borrowing from other games like Assassin Creed: Brotherhood and Mass Effect, it doesn't attempt anything it is uncapable of executing. There are some story line based elements, such as characters not facing the people they intend on talking to in what intends to be an immotional scene, one would think that this detracted from the experience. It only did so minorly. The mechancis of this game carry it. Only at the end when they throw you in a room with wave after wave of enemy did I ever feel that the game was being unfair, however I only wiped once. Any time I had died prior It had been my own tactical fault for playing the game for what is is not: A FPS. As the game proceeds, I found more and more fault with the team pathing AI, and sometimes in the later levels where the terriegn is more complex, I found I needed to baby sit thier movements, but the majority of of the time they handled fine.In Summary I would recomend this game, especially at the price it is at present.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												This game is something that had the potential to be great. The ability to slow down time to a near stop, and chose where your men go and abilities to use was well thought out. I'd even go as far as to say it was much smoother then mass effect. The aliens in this are okay, you can tell they rushed the game horribley. Where in the old games you would ge tthe slow invasion picking up strength as time goes by, you face several mutons and a mechtoid in the first real mission. The missions are cobbled together with barely any reason at all. One moment your being told theyre posioning the water, the next your assaulting one of their command spires. The upgrade system is just as bad, with abilities gained with experince. This would be a good thing, were it not for the fact you suddenly get the ability to throw a sentient blob at your foes that they were using for several issions before. They were clearly going to make you research them, but that was cut and the only thing left of it was 2 scientists goofing around and trying to test some things. They also hyped up the whole, your soldiers will die if they bleed out and don't come back. This was very sadly implemented, with them going into the bleed out state several seconds into a battle because they decided the cover you told them to go to wasn't enough against the muton making it way towards them. which you would then have to go and revive them, during that animation you will become invulnerable, and with handy timing can avoid even getting killed by a mechtoid point blank. Compared to you allies the alien AI seems like the terrifying force it's meant to be, but only because they can actually stay in cover and actually listen to their commanders. (Yes they have commanders.)This game should be passed at all costs, for no reason should you buy this game. The dl is half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥from the one I played. Code breakers, which was one mission and then I returned to worrying about the invasion and completley forgot it even happened. Pass this game, it's not worthy of the XCOM title.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I wasn't introduced to X-Com until the very recent X-com: Enemy Unknown, which I loved dearly. Upon seeing this third person shooter game based on the same game series, I was immediately skeptical. However, my love of Enemy Unknown got the better of me, and I ended up pre-ordering the game. I wanted to love this game. I really, really did. I love the other X-com with a passion; and this game truly could have been great. It is not. Everything about this game is just...dull. The dialogue is dry and predictable. The main character is as basic, sullen, and gloomy as you can get. Everything about this game is a stereotype. The gameplay is repetitive and boring. It's basically just go somewhere, shoot 70 aliens, go home. In the other X-com, it was an accomplishment to take down 10 aliens with a 6 member team. In this game, you're regularly taking down 50 or more with 3 people. There's really not much strategy to it, either. Your teammates are dumb and require constant instructions on where to go, and you'll find yourself more often than not just going to do everything yourself, because it's faster. It tries to incorporate a little bit of strategy by allowing you to do extra damage via flanking your enemies, but that's about as deep as it gets. Overall, this is dull, uninspired, and feels like a B-movie version of the worst Mass Effect game.  Even saying that feels like I'm giving it too much credit.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 27, 2014
												First off: It's not a bad game. It's solid for what it does - mostly being a Cover Shooter.But it feels lackluster in every regard.The main discipline, the actual tactical shooting doesn't feel very tactical unless late in the game. The AI is unreliable at best, the options are limited to targeting a specific enemy, moving to a position and a very limited set of active abilities which almost all offer some kind of damage output increase instead of supporting utility. The enemies feel very bullet spongy even on lower difficulties and only pose a challenge through their masses combined with the team-AI running into open field, especially in the second half of the game.Customizationwise the game doesn't offer much. A handful of weapons in the archetypes of assault rifle, shotgun, sniper rifle, sidearm and heavy arms divided into three ammunition types. Bullets against unarmored, Laser against shields and plasma with a damage over time effect, though the difference doesn't matter much in the field and your basically limited to whatever you find during the missions anyway. The skill trees offer some choices which again don't account for much, just as the backpacks. It all feels like more was planned but eventually cut.All of this makes the game play like a generic cover shooter for a long time.The level design offers some pretty nice scenary and fantastic atmosphere at times but with large gaps filled with generic corridors and obstacles (and some invisible walls) conviniently placed to only allow a narrow path. Whenever you see a wider area, be assured to have enemies incoming. Since the linear design doesn't allow much exploration, it is surprising that the paths branching left and right of the main path are often pointless and empty or give a new backpack schematic at best - which you can mostly also get from the dispatch side missions.The story is based on the older (50s - 60s) SciFi movies with slight horror mixed in between. Think of 'Invasion of the Body Snatchers' or similar - or Captain Scarlet and the Mysterons which has basically the same premise ;)Again it feels cut on every end. There are some illogical jumps in character behaviour, descissions which don't matter at all, dialogue which repeats itself or is even nonsensical and the campaign feels very rushed with various Dei ex machina. The writing also does a very good job of making the main character as unlikeable as humanly possibile, throwing out oneliners like Duke Nukem which drip from pathos and stupidity.The whole XCOM feeling from the classic games or the remake is barely there apart from the alien names - you're only fighting on US American soil, with US Americans and have no contact to or intel about any other nation. Even the mission map is limited to mainland USA, making the whole global invasion a very US-centric thing.There are also some very annonying design decissions in the game:Firstly it's Checkpoints only. Died in the 3rd wave of a shootout? Feel lucky if it places you right at the beginning of the fight instead of some rooms prior. It doesn't even allow free saving outside the missions during exploring the base.Placement of team members or deployable abilities makes you basically move them along the physical path in the same 3rd person view instead of ignoring obstacles, stairs or maybe giving you more of a bird's eye view. All while the battle doesn't pause but only slows down, which means moving a mortally wounded squad mate out of the danger zone may end up with him being shot during the command giving.Having sprint on the same button as taking cover leads to some strange positioning sometimes, especially since you can't stear during sprinting.During the first part of the game you will open doors, having a short scene of your character securing the room with raised weapon through which he is uncontrollable and which is always pointless since there are never enemies behing those doors. Nor anything other to speak of. Later in the game this suddenly stops but is replaced with long empty corridors and elevator rides during which nothing happens.

Posted: July 12, 2015
												Early coverage and reviews had me worried about this game.  Having now played it, however, I am pleasantly surprised.  It's a totally different game from the other XCOMs I know and love, but somehow it still captures much of the same feeling.  The tactical combat is a little confusing and clunky at first, but by the end of the game it's second nature.  The 60s-noire vibe is also a refreshing change.The bottom line is that this game is NOT like the other XCOMs in terms of gameplay so if that's what you want you will be disappointed.  It IS a creative re-telling of the XCOM story in a cover-based squad TPS set in the cold-war era.  It's pretty linear with the only hidden features being special 'packs' and dialog/story details.  However, the story and dialog are good enough and in terms of game mechanics it's one of the better cover-based shooters I've played.Takes 15-20 hours to beat the game based on difficulty and exploration.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I have played all of the XCOM games and love the series, so being able to play a third-position shooter take on the XCOM universe was very nice and refreshing.If you like the series, alien themes, third-person action shooters, and squad-based tactics, you will really enjoy this game.The aesthetics are fantastic with lots of special effects in the form of mutons (mutations taken from the alien technology). The music fits very well with the theme and setting - it is appropriately intense whenever the action calls for it. The controls are fairly straightforward, and the tutorial mission is great at helping you understand both the controls and how to issue orders to your squad without being too long or too boring. The learning curve is moderate, however, the game can be extremely unforgiven in the commander (hardest) difficulty. There is permanent death if your squad members are downed and not revived in time on commander difficulty; furthermore, reviving them only stabilizes them - meaning they are out of combat until the instance is cleared of all enemies. I am playing on this difficulty, and have had many situations where I had to slow-play and defeat all the enemies on my own. Your squad members are heavily reliant on your orders, especially in the harder difficulties.The story is pretty good, and there is a lot of extras provided in the form of audio recordings and files if you choose to look for them. The gameplay reminded me a lot of Mass Effect, down to the very first muton power you unlock for your character - lift. The feedback is very good, showing the enemy's health at the top center of the screen, and having large grenade icons warning you of the blast radius. During battles, you can go into battle focus, which slows down time to a crawl and allows you to issue your orders. There is a range where you can order your squadmates to move/do actions, which I found to be very nice. You can have two weapons equipped at a time, and you will slowly unlock new equipment (the first being a bag that increases your headshot damage). You may have only 2 other active squad members at a time.Cover is extremely important, as the enemy will try to actively flank you and can become very aggressive. Most combat instances will have a few ammo drops to refill your weapons, and explosive barrels are littered in many areas to help you kill mobs of enemies quickly.As you gain experience, you will level up and can choose different perks for both you and your teammates. There is a decent variety of customization - you can change every agent's clothing color (pretty basic), and their background changes the type of perks that can be unlocked. You can recruit new agents, and when you do this you will be given an option to choose both their class and their background (ex: engineer class with technical expertise, leading to faster cooldowns on abilities). The XCOM base is not as explorable as I'd like, but it is still fun to walk around and talk to people - or read the extra content like agent dossiers.There are a number of side missions for you to play and unlock more mutons. Completing these help you gain levels and increase your psychic arsenal to defeat the alien invaders. Very good game, especially if you are a fan of the series.Definitely recommend!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Insanely underrated game. Those who expect a sequel to XCOM Enemy Unknown/Within, will be extraordinarily disappointed with The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.This is not a turn-based strategy game. This is a squad-based third person shooter. There is definitely strategy involved with selecting the proper soldiers (two squadmates to assist you at a time) with the appropriate weapons and knowing how to manage their abilities in order to conserve the most ammo, maximize opportunities for kills, etc.; but it's incredibly different from the previous entry to the XCOM series.But change is not a bad thing, anyone interested in the (albeit fairly cliche at this point in time) concept of an alien invasion in the midst of a futuristic-styled 60's era, will enjoy The Bureau's story. It throws a few interesting twists to keep it from being entirely cliche, and overall executes the concept it goes for, perfectly.While XCOM Declassified is definitely not for everyone, fans of alien sci-fi with an open mind to change for a series, who are willing to learn how to properly manage their soldiers (there is a bit of a learning curve and frustration in the beginning), will certainly enjoy this game. Especially on its frequent dirt-cheap sales, it's impossible to go wrong. Buy this game.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												I recommend this game, but only under specific terms. As anyone with a working understanding of what XCOM is, this one only counts as an XCOM game under similar terms. If you want deep tactical combat and a sense of existential dread fighting back a cybernetic, mindfraying enemy ages ahead of humanity, this is not the game for you. The combat amounts to skulking around and shooting heads poking around cover and making sure all your crazy ill-begotten alien abilities are in constant cooldown. I'd be surprised to see if someone in the credits took credit for designing these levels, because there's almost no incentive to even try to play strategically--you'll win by getting killed a lot and hoping you won't die the next time you respawn at the checkpoint just behind you.Not a lot going on with it mechanically. It's enjoyable. It's plain. It was on its way to being a top-grade squad shooter, then never articulated itself past the poorly-aging mechanics of games like Freedom Fighters and Republic Commando.Sadly, if it's lore you want, you're likely going to be left wanting. The game fleshes out the XCOM universe with fleeting moments of coherence, almost like the devs knew what they were doing was only wearing XCOM clothes and never going to breach into full-fledged canon. Conspiracy theorists may take issue with that proclamation, but yeah well so what.There's one specific thing this team got really right. If you're old enough to know what Man's Life magazine is, you're going to get some nostalgic chills when you take in the game's hypermasculine adventure-pulp vibe. Bad game or good game, there's a campy satisfaction in playing as our leading man--Oklahoma-born, corn-fed, brick-chinned Central Intelligence Alcoholic William Carter against deathray-wielding moon men, wearing his best plum-purple tactical sweater on black ops deployments. If your hat gets shot off in a firefight, it's gone for the rest of the game.The atmosphere is, in the early moments of the game, breathtaking. The insidious quiet of landing in these freshly-ravaged towns is stunning and sobering. The moment I first entered XCOM HQ and strode past a bunch of brass wearing pinstripe slacks, suspenders, sleeves rolled up, smart ties and slicked hair, smoking listlessly on tabletops watching radio intel slowly etch onto churning paper printouts, I was completely hooked. It felt like I was somewhere whole and real.But really, in this game, the aliens' perfect, inscrutable plan of attack is to make sure all their ranking officers at the frontline are wearing elaborate, glowing, Please Shoot Me First armor. Checkmate, says Jeff Goldblum. The game is a sickly, sci-fi-obsessed child of Cold War-era American exceptionalism without the heart to go too far down the satire path, but this is not the platform for a foreign policy ethics essay, so pass along, nothing to see here.Development hell doesn't always kill everything, and value survives in this little curio of a shooter. Hear the chilly, blurry radio feedback in your headphones when you enter Tactical View to take out a pod of flanking Sectoids. Just listen to the earnestness with which one of your squadmates asks, in the middle of a burning forest, "We're gonna make'em pay, right boss?""Yeah boys, we're gonna make'em pay, all right."

content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												tl;dr: This game was fun and felt fresh, but your followers' AI is♥♥♥♥♥♥ and TPS makes movement a little awkward. Certain useful commands are missing that you can't issue to your followers. It's also short. I still recommend.I got into this thinking it was going to be another turn-based tactical game, but I was pleasantly surprised. It turns out it's a TPS where you can slow time and issue commands to your three-man squad while moving around and shooting the faces off of aliens. Much like the other XCOM games, you and your comrades can activate skills which you acquire by levelling through a skill tree based on your class. Also like the other XCOM games, there's a cover system.Overall, the game was fun, and the mechanics felt fresh. It's like experiencing XCOM through the eyes of a field agent, and that's awesome. With all that said, the game had two main drawbacks. The biggest one is that your followers are clinically ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. They're highly inaccurate with weapons, they have a tendency to run straight into enemy fire or out of advantageous positions, and they often do stupid♥♥♥♥♥♥like dive away from a grenade and then run straight back into its blast radius. As a result, you have to micromanage them just to keep them alive, using them mainly for their abilities or to draw fire. That isn't to say they don't do damage; you just can't trust them to take down any enemy on their own, so your strategy generally ends up revolving around you personally taking out key targets. The second issue is more minor: movement is clunky, at least on the PC. Part of it has to do with it being a TPS, but there are other problems as well. As far as I know, in order to jump over a wall, you need to take cover behind it first. Also, when you're sprinting, you automatically take cover behind any wall or obstacle you run into, which is frustrating when that either causes you to get killed or fail to revive an ally before he bleeds out. I feel like this could have been avoided this if the button for taking cover wasn't the same as the button for sprinting.I feel like the game would have been a lot better if you could at least tell a follower to hold a position, take cover without firing, or provide cover fire (along with an improvement in follower accuracy). Too often, an ally gets killed because you can't tell him not to move or not to shoot. And without using any abilities, you have to personally provide cover fire for your allies in order to have them move safely to another location.Overall though, I had fun so I'm giving this a thumbs up. The only thing is that since it's so short, I recommend that you try to get it at a cheaper price than $20.

content:
Posted: April 15
												First off, the game is actually fairly good. It tries to emulate the gameplay of Mass Effect, both in combat with a cover 3d person shooter style, and with multiple dialogues choices during the downtime you have at the XCOM's base or during the main missions. As a fan of both i have to say that it does it decently. All this packed with XCOM's alien invasion background, and the historical period in wich the story takes place, makes for an interesting spin off even considering the flaws. For example, soldiers are a bit of a chore to manage on the field and outside of their abilities are basically useless, and more often than not they will fall in combat requiring you to help them or watch them die. The permadeath of yours squad members is basically the only element of the original titles that traslates in this specific game: you will not have to manage resources, build your base, or research alien tech. So don't expect a game that plays like XCOM going into this. If, and only if, you are a fan of the things i have mentioned above you'll most likely enjoy the game for what it is. However i feel i cannot recommend this title to anybody, because even years after the release it keeps crashing. A lot. We are not talking about some random freezes, i had around 20 crashes during the whole campaign and it has been very frustrating, expecially when occurred in the middle of long fights. Some have reported that by disabling PhysX it gets better, but it was not my case, and even if the game is good at his core i can't say i had a good experience playing it. At the end i don't feel it was worth the hassle. Keep this in mind if you decide to buy it.

												An intriguing third-person shooter set in the XCOM universe. A lot of familiar monsters are on view, and familiar weapons too. The plot is at least somewhat interesting, with a lot of choice about what missions you perform when. And there are a few unexpected plot twists that keep you guessing.The game's big "gimmick" is that you can engage in some limited small-unit tactics, giving orders to your squadmates who can deploy different abilities to help you. You can send them to catch the bad guys in a crossfire, or tell them to revive you when you take too much damage. It offers some intriguing possibilities, but the control scheme can be a little bit too finicky. More than once I've accidentally activated the wrong ability by having selected onto the wrong person without intending to.If you can get it cheaply on Steam sale, go for it. Not sure I'd pay full price, though.

												Ok scrubs here's the scoop: If you're looking for a game that's going to add another tint of rose to your nostalgia goggles and allow you to relive the so-called "golden age of gaming" before the plebes rose up and helped the Vandals overthrow Rome, then this is not your game. 												I recommend this game to anyone who enjoys the Xcom universe. To anyone else, you'll probably find it pretty bland. I enjoyed it but it can be a little unforgiving at first until you power up. The visuals are a little drab and you'll get tired of Carter's constantly gruff voice and fist to hand animation in cutscenes. number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is the Third-Person shooter which places you in the shoes of Agent Carter. A CIA Agent turned X-COM Agent. The game's start is well paced, it isn't an hour long mission which gives you the details in one whole package, instead, it is phased in little cutscenes throughout major missions and through your own exploration of the surroundings. The game is very similar to Bioshock Infinite in the way your companions behave, the gunplay and also the collectable notes, audio logs and the image which appears on the right hand side of the screen, similar to the way the audio logs do in Infinite.The collectables are easilly noticable and have little actual challenge to them, however there are a lot you can miss if you just run and gun through the missions. The AI support you have are actually quite good from my experience, I had read many reviews claiming the AI were bullet sponges etc, but for me they were well placed during combat and only got injured through my own fault in dealing with enemies. The game uses a system which allows you to control what you and your teammates do during combat. For example, moving them behind cover and marking a specific target. The game also has customisation for your character and teammates, so you can get attatched to your team and then watch them die... But, luckily that didn't happen to me. And if you want to break away from the immersion of a full scale alien invasion... if you can really get immersed in that... and customise your teammates to have 'fabulous' (for lack of a word) colour schemes such as Pink, Purple, White and more Pink!The gunplay is great, each weapon has a different leve of damage or recoil and the sound isn't just reused throughout. The only issue I have with the guns is that later on, picking up a laser weapon is the easy way out, as it is just running around after the enemy collecting ammo afterwards, without that fear of running out and having to push back to collect more. The maps for each level is also a brilliant feature, as far as I saw each map is unique and has lots of different routes and ranges of cover to make each fight unique and to also really allow each player to have his own tactics played out just perfectly, in my case that was send a sniper to flank whilst myself and my other teammate stuck behind cover keeping them distracted. The enemy AI is at times silly but they do take cover and pose a threat should a teammate down and need reviving, the capatilize on errors such as a lack of ammo too, pushing forwards when you don't expect it. This being my first XCOM game I can't really say if the enemies are the same but I can only assume so. In addition to this being my first XCOM game, I would recommend watching or playing Enemy Unknown before saying it isn't as good as Declassified, as from some gameplay I have seen, they look quite different.The Bureau doesn't follow the usual turn-based style which other XCOM games do, which allows for much better, flowing combat and tactics. However, this takes away time to think  about what is happening as sometimes I found myself going off my plan to cope with enemies. The game features quite a few cutscenes, some of which are in HD, some are in SD, which at times can be quite confusing and annoying as it doesn't look and sound as good. But I managed to get used to the cinematics in the lower definition, the game itself has brilliant high quality level, gun and character designs, with nice little touches on things like hats, ties and cloth which sway in the wind, get shot off in the case of hats and also get knocked around when you pass by or shoot through.Overall, The Bureau for me is a huge success, thoroughly enjoyable and exciting at all times. I never found myself bored and found the story gripping and suprisingly well written. The multiple choice system allows for a unique knowledge of each character, (If you go through all the options in dialogue with them.) and the games ending is well done as well. I would say behind GTA 5 on console, (Hopefully PC soon!), The Bureau is my favourite game I have played in this year, and last since we are very early into 2014! I would recommend this to anyone who liked the Mass Effect or Bioshock series and to anyone looking for something else to play.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
 XCOM Declassified  Some secrets to hold onto for forever... I heard from several reviewers and friends that this game was absolutely horrible and to an extent I agree with them. Declassified I found was much more interesting when I first read about it in a gaming magazine. It WAS supposed to be a pulp sci-fi suspense story played in First-Person, however several happenings in 2K forced its re-purposing into the 3rd Person shooter we have here.The game does manage to hold onto the pulp 60's sci-fi style, unfortunately it quickly gets buried under all the shooting and with that becomes almost irrelevant. A sad thing, in my opinion. For I enjoyed the early previews of the original project, even IF it being an FPS. I did hope that the writers would have managed to create a good suspenseful story to cover the somewhat generic feel of the FPS, it was a bit naive to think that in retrospect. Since the only thing that runs the games industry these days is the AAA's and they only care about money and I could argue that the game is partly bad because of that.However, to the game.Sadly under performing and uninteresting, I did not hold much hope for it. Given what I've heard about it, but to finally see and play it.. Urgh. The game is a good example of a good concept ruined, it does manage to be a decent enough precursor to the XCOM series as a whole, but it does it so badly. It's almost not worth mentioning.The games story managed to underwhelm me and I now understand why that certain mission ended rather abruptly, the "pop a cap in ye ♥♥♥♥♥ " part, to quote a man more articulate than me.The game suffers from AI problems, namely the AI team-members being complete idiots. Unless you give them the order to take cover into a specified location, they might walk right to the enemy and get downed. Most of my crew died due to that fatal flaw in their brain development. Otherwise the fighting is O.K and that's pretty much it, I can't for the life of me tell you a good combat mission the game had.I feel like my time has been wasted, there is no reason for the game to be this dull. It feels like the developers just up and quit halfway through after the project was re-organized.I cannot say anything more, for my head is starting to ache from thinking about this.XCOM Declassified gets a D.For it fails to be interesting in every aspect, the story is dull and uneventful, the action is boring, nothing eventful happens for the entirety of its runtime. A sad example of spoiled possibilities.

												------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Short Version-Story is full of plotholes-Main characters are honestly very boring characters an not very memoriable-Need more control over my soldiers-DLC adds more plotholes. -It can be very fun at times-it is a very solid shooter no problems at all in the shooting department.----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------GameplayThis game is a decent 3rd person shooter. your companion AI is pretty bad they will do stuff like take cover in stupid positions where everyone can shoot them.  but if you give them orders they are pretty usefull at times. i see where they were trying to go with the xcom side of things but i wish you had more control over your squad like an xcom game. The main cast overall is just not very memoriable.Final thoughts Not worth 20 bucks maybe 10 or 5 get it if its on sale.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												All in all it was well worth the bundled price with the predecessors of the series. I love enemy unknown and grew up on terror from the deep. This is nothing like these, expect a cover tactical shooter that is driven by a narrative akin to the series. Life forms from somewhere else have arrived, and they are terribly aggressive and we apes (sorry creationists), being the busy little warriors we are are now tasked with overcoming a dominant invasion force by doing what we love--killing stuff with noisy things.This is a story-driven XCOM shooter. It was refreshing to play as the agents themselves and the story was good enough to keep the player going. Fighting enemies in real and slowed time makes mutons much more menacing. You also can't count on a team of snipers as your squad will always be three people. Fights are exciting as maps are well arranged to encourage scattering your team to flank, support, or divert enemies. I would recommend keeping the difficulty up high as lower levels allow for easily exploitable AI. At one point I was dropping teams of five monsters in a couple seconds mainly through well placed powers and team members. Unfortunately, there isn't much in the way of variation in outcomes so don't expect anything quite so dynamic.Worth a single run through but I do not feel compelled to replay it. I'd give it a 6.5 out of 10, fun but borrows too much to stand out.

content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												This game was a blast to play. It isn't a hardcore FPS, so don't go into it expecting those sorts of mechanics. It has the basic FPS down and some interesting progression-based abilities. It's more of an interactive story, than a true FPS.The kitschy, historical feel of the game is spot on; you feel like you are in a 50's/60's sci-fi movie. The story is well-written, even if some choices are a bit one-sided in the outcome. However, there are a few places the story can turn so sharply from a single choice I was surprised.I feel this game has gotten a bad rap. There are far too many bad reviews with derogatory comments that are not deserved. I had originally skipped this game and only received it as part of a combo sale some time later and I can say I am so glad that I had the chance to play it.Edit:Over a year later and I still hold the same opinion of this game.

content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												Are you thinking about taking advantage of a sale?  Do you think this is a game that will combine your love of strategy, shooters and the intriguing world of XCom? For the love of god DON'T DO IT!  I recommend that you save your money or literally throw it in to a sewer, either way you'll be better off.Now, I'll admit I ended up mildly addicted to The Bureau and I have pretty much played it to completion (to be honest... I couldn't wait to finish it so I could uninstall it and never see it again).  However, while this game may appear to offer a lot, believe me, it will deliver only frustration.MY THOUGHTS:1.  It is the buggiest game I have played in recent memory.  I started playing at launch and thought 'oh well if I give the dev's some time to patch things maybe it won't crash every 15 seconds...' WRONG.  Stupid me.  Three years later and this game is still a soup of CTD bugs, gameplay bugs, stupid autosave locations and even more CTD bugs.  I can't begin to express how frustrating or frequent these bugs are.  It is insane, the only reason I haven't finished the game is it keeps dying on me.2.  For gamers looking for a strategic shooter, prepare to be disappointed.  The AI is useless and the squad/order/bullet-time mode may as well not exist.  Your squadmates offer nothing of value other than the occasional revive and they're so damn squishy the only orders you'll make are to tell them to get out of your way.  The only time this game is difficult is when it spawns so many waves of aliens that you run out of ammo.3.  For gamers looking for a well balanced shoot 'em up, prepare to be even more disappointed.  The guns are completely unbalanced and unchallenging; human weapons are useless and alien weapons are a range of boring lasers with no recoil that are virtually indistinguisahble from each other.  4.  For gamers after an exciting first-person story in the XCom Universe, start crying now.  Stilted dialogue, an unintelligble plotline and terrible characters await.  The game tries hard to throw up a few 'dilemmas' but fails miserably.  You form no attachment to the stupid two dimensional main characters/plot devices.  This is in large part because any interaction with NPCs has no bearing on the game at all (it just sinks hours of your time in pointless dialogue and loading screens).  So, what does The Bureau: XCOM Declassified do right?  + It is a mindless point/click shooter (which can be rewarding if you want to disengage your brain)+ You *do* get to shoot at some of your favourite XCom baddies+ There is a brief novelty of M14'ing an alien in the headWhat does The Bureau: XCOM Declassified do wrong?- They took my money before I realised how bad and rushed this game was- Three years later it is still an unplayable bugs nest- Story was written by a five year old- Characters are less plausable than D-Grade anime- Gameplay is so dull you'll need to be waterboarded awake- Graphics are rubbishIn summary, this is a bad console port with basically no redeeming qualities.  If you're silly enough to blow $50 on this game, come back after 5 hours and all I'll have to say is... told ya so!

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												I know this is a very controversial game, hence it's mixed reviews. My son was all into XCOM and I picked this up for him during a Steam sale and he seemed to love it, quickly finishing it and it's DLC. It took me a while, but finally through the magic of Steam Family Sharing, I decided to give it a go. And honestly, to my shock and dismay. I liked it. No, it's not XCOM the strategy game. No, it doesn't seem to follow the established "lore", such as it is. But if you can approach the game as a tactical rpg-lite squad shooter with a decent story, I think you'll be impressed. For hardcore XCOM fans, think of this as an alternate universe version of XCOM or treat it as it should be, it's own thing. Now onto the review!+/- Graphics, being built on the Unreal engine, are pretty good. It has some nice particle effects, models are pretty good, and a decently variety of both enemy models and settings. It very much has the "Bioshock" look to the UI and world, while art direction pulls a good 50's vibe and flavor to most everything. Weaknesses are mostly confined to poor facial animations and sometimes stiff looking movements, but overall the game has a clean and consistent look that works really well for the game.+/- Story and voice acting is played upon very heavily in this title, far, far more in this title than any previous XCOM game. There are multiple NPC's and your own character that are all developed decently well, if not anything exceptional. You can tell they were heavily inspired by the Mass Effect school of Story but they never quite reach those heights. Most dialog is decently written and spoke well, but while enjoyable, there is no top tier level story telling to be had and much of it feels like it contridicts much of what is presented in the XCOM game. Purists might cry foul and let what is presented distract them, but again, pretend it's an alternate version of the XCOM universe and enjoy the more personal ride.+/- Combat and powers are obviously the main focus here and this is what drives most people batty. One thing I've learned playing through this entire game is that moving your squad mates is mostly an exercise in futility. Just save yourself some pain and let them move themselves. That doesn't mean you don't coordinate them because this is not a game that you win  by playing it as a shooter. Do that and you WILL cry. Powers are everything in this game and using your teams varied abilities is paramount to winning the game. Using your abilities will greatly slow down time (but not pause), allowing you to choose both your and your teammates abilities and their targets. In this respect (opposed to moving your teammates) the game works very well. Nothing is more satisfying than being pinned down by a sniper, Lifting him out of cover, and focusing fire to take them out quickly. Or taunting an Outsider, which makes them focus on one character and advance, right into a mine dropped by an Engineer. Realizing you can queue up multiple attacks helps you power attack the most dangerous enemiese quickly. I spent much of combat making sure everyone's powers are constantly being used AND upgrading them in a manner that fit my playstyle greatly improved the flow of combat and made the game more enjoyable. I will warn you, as at the start of the game, when you have few abilities, that the game is much more frustrating as the gunplay is at best, competent. This is not a run and gun game - that will kill you fast. Cover, flanking, short bursts, grenades, and abilities will win fights. Nothing else.This game isn't for everyone, but if you like more tactical FPS, something that's a little different, and something with an interesting 50's take on XCOM, I'd recommend it. You can get it cheap regularly during steam sales and for those sale prices, it's highly recommended. Final score - 3.5/5

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Heyyo,Sadly? The AI ruins what could have been a fun Tactical Squad-Based Third-Person Shooter... Which is too bad since the squad AI can actually kill enemies unlike most other squad-based games as of late so they actually contribute to combat... but at the same time? They do detract by being idiots whom if you don't give move orders will usually stick too close to the player and not run from grenades which enemies use quite a bit...Now that I've mentioned the major weakness of the game? I'll talk about the strength which is the visuals... and wow are they good! Just look at the screenshots even. The Art, 3D modeling and mapping department definitely did their job on this game. The use of Unreal Engine 3 shines with Direct3D 11 goodness to show off the visuals of the game. The only thing that could have made this game better is better Anti-Aliasing.. I have the ingame Anti-Aliasing set to "High" which is the highest setting yet there's still quite a lot of pixelation. My guess is they used FXAA which doesn't compare to proper Multisampling Anti-Aliasing of times past.Voice acting is also pretty good. Varied cast and decent attention to detail helps add to the game as I felt like the voice actors actually game a damn about the lines they were reading.The storyline is also pretty decent about how the aliens invaded and how you're fighting to gain their technology to combat them with and that makes this game feel like a good spin off of X-COM... and it would have been if the damn AI wasn't so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Whomever worked on the AI coding of this game sadly let down the rest of the team since this is a singleplayer game thus AI is extremely important... maybe they needed more time or more staff dedicated to making the AI better? Either way, it's too late for this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 4, 2015
												The Bureau is a solid squad based cover shooter with tactical and RPG elements.  You must fight off an alien invasion to 1960ies earth and unravel the mysterious forces at work.  You command a squad of agents with different specialties and you and your agents can be leveled up with different abilities and buffs as the game progress.  You can control your 2 allies on the field (very similar combat to Mass Effect 2 & 3) by placing them in different positions and assign powers to use.  The powers are fun and vary from bio and machine allies, bombs, turrets, mind control, levitation and more!  Combat is fluid and fun and the best part of the game.The setting feels like 1960ies America, or at least what the movies describe as 60ies America, and I really enjoyed the ambiance from the visual appeal of a town, college or rural area.  There are lots of aesthetics thrown in like old TV screens, lab equipment, diners, cars,  etc that really capture the feel of 60ies living.  Unfortunately your squad and other characters you interact with are wooden and bland.   However you are able to make choices in conversation and there are a few interesting twists near the end that your choice will have some impact on the story.  For a sci-fi invasion angle, I enjoyed the story, it’s just that the wooden NPC’s drag it down and take away some of the immersion created by the set pieces and combat.I hate to review a game in the context of another, but my advice is if you have played Mass Effect 2 & 3 and loved it, you need to play The Bureau as it’s the closest thing to more Mass Effect.  On its own the Bureau has enjoyable gameplay, solid atmosphere with a fun campy story that is brought down by bland characters but is still a worthwhile light RPG experience, plays great with a gamepad.  FYI – if you have an AMD graphics card turn the physics options off to have a high frame rate.  Otherwise X-com Declassified is a looker even on mid-level machines.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 5, 2014
												If you like tactical RPG shooting games, mainly Mass Effect, then you'll find this game to be an enjoyable, yet not amazing or incredible, game.The story is alright, you defend 1950's-60's America from alien invaders who have better technology and numbers than you. It isn't as good as others in the genre but with a few twists here and there it doesn't drag down the enjoyment. The characters, an important part of these kinds of games since you will be talking to them so much, are only passingly enjoyable and many of them don't have enough going for them to make them memorable. Some of the main characters are fine but they aren't as good as the ones in other games.The setting is a refreshing change from the norm of today's shooters. The clash between olden day America and the futuristic alien architecture is pleasing to look at as you see the destruction between the two. I liked the clash so much that I was a little disappointed when it changed to primarily alien bases later on in the game.The graphics are nice, using the unreal engine 3 to a great extent. Character models look nice and the effects are fun to look at. The game has additional Physx support and so cloth and particles flow smoothly. I have AMD so I couldn't really use it. The graphics aren't spectacular to look at, but I enjoyed what I saw.Gameplay is fun and challenges you to direct your team to victory. I played on the hardest difficulty, commander, and it wasn't too difficult once I got a handle on things. You can't take too much damage in this game, and unlike other games health doesn't really regenerate and you can't heal too often. This forces you to use your squad to its fullest capacity instead of going Rambo and doing everything yourself. The abilities are useful and directing your team in slow motion, since the game doesn't pause when you plan out your actions, is engaging and enjoyable.The enemies are a little boring as many of them are just humanoid soldiers that don't act any different than any other game. The bosses, on the other hand, are fun and challenge you in tough fights. Things like Mutons, Sectopods, and Gunships become even scarier as they soak up damage and force you to rely on your team's abilities to slow down, damage, and distract the enemy. It really gives you an accomplished feeling when you can plan and take one down without anyone getting really hurt.In the end, I enjoyed this game and recommend it to anyone on the fence on getting it during a sale like I did. It may not be the best of its kind in the genre, but you won't really have a bad time while playing it.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												6.5/10Great look and feel, fun gameplay, a bunch of fun characters and a storyline that’s gritty at times and campy at times. Overall I enjoyed the game, but unfortunately The Bureau keeps teasing so much more that it doesn’t deliver on. I was constantly left in a state of feeling mislead and disappointed (spoilery examples below). I recomend this game if:1. You liked the combat mechanics of Mass Effect 2. Didn't like it in Mass Effect when your decisions impacted the storyline    2b. Can convince yourself this is a sort of retro Mass Effect DLC3. Like watching Facilities and Operations personnel do their jobs.4. You really enjoyed watching Super 85. You think smoking is cool.--MILD SPOILERS and WITTY CRITICISMS ahead—Me: Hey game, you really nailed that 1960’s look and feel. You’d think nobody could look tough in 1960’s tweed pants and sweaters, but boy! My character looks tough as nails!  And I love how you contrast the quintessential, idyllic setting of small-town america against the cold gruesome architecture of the invading aliens.Game: Why thank you! Did you notice how I even touch on some of the social tensions of the 1960s? Like racial issues, sexism, and the paranoia inherent in McCarthyism?Me: I did! It’s maybe a little heavy-handed at times, but no biggie; I’m still really excited to see how these social issues are explored as the game progresses.Game: I’m glad you noticed! Because soon enough these concepts will all just fade into the background and even though you’ll want to discuss them with NPCs, it’ll never come up as an option!Me: Oh… okay.----Game: Hey, look at all these unique NPCs, each with thier own unique personality. You know, if the combat reminds you of Mass Effect, then I bet it's just as important to invest in these characters like you do in Mass Effect. After all, I stress SUPER HARD that this game is about collaboration and teamwork under pressure. And the dialogue mechanics are eerily similar to Mass Effect!Me: I liked that about Mass Effect, Mr. Game, so I'll totally spend as much time interacting with NPCs between missions as I spend on the missions themselves. Plus, as I talk with them I learn more about my own characters' personality and grizzled past. I want to know more about the mysterious, hard-headed protagonist than just about any of the other characters.Game: Good idea! Dig up his story as much as you can. That way, you totally won't expect how that “I’m difficult to work with, but always get the job done" Clint Eastwood-style protagonist totally loses his effin marbles at the end and you have the play the last chapter as some omnipotent alien puppet-master taking possession of characters you never really care about.Me: I'm sorry, what? Wait, in that last chapter where are all those folks I spent the whole game learning about? The ones I DID care about?Game: I’m sorry, who?----Game: You captured an alien combatant! Hey, his attitude towards humanity is changing—maybe later he'll be able to join your squad. Wouldn't that be cool?Me: Hell yeah. I'll keep checking up on him between missions and help him on the road to acceptance as he matures as a character.Game: HA GOT YOU! Kill him. Like literally, I am making you. Do it.Me:    :’(----Game: Oh no! There's an enemy in your base, tearing it up! You better catch him!Me: Right you are Mr. Game! I spent so much time investigating all the different departments in my base, I don't want him to wreck any of it.Game: Right! Well then you better chase him through all these super interesting labs filled with neat experiments and devices and people, none of which were ever accessible to you up until now! Hurry and catch him!Me: Oh, wow these places do look really cool as I sprint through them. I'm excited to go back through here and interact with all this new content after I’m done with this chase!Game: TOO BAD LOSER. You will literally never set foot back in ANY part of your precious base after this current plot point is finished. GOOD DAY.Me:    :’( ----Game: Uh-oh! Two characters are pinned down in different areas of the map. It looks like you have to chose which NPC you want to go help! Don’t worry, I’ll let you know now that someone else is going to help the character you don’t choose, so IN NO WAY is this an arbitrary way of making you choose which character is going to die. Me: Game... why do you hate me...

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												As a guy who was able to find some enjoyment in the call of duty story lines, this game wasn't much of a difference. The repetive "Pew Pew" gameplay, the upscaling enemies having no skill on the easiest difficulties and picking up a random gun on the field and instantly aquiring the knowledge on how to use said weapon(don't forget shooting down an alien spaceship with your Colt M1911!). Besides that, I really like the concept of the game, just the way they did it. First off, the base, i don't know if it's just me, but i got lost so many times in the base, i would always be at the weapon range when i meant to go to research, the amount of people in the base was not preportionate the size, and the people on duty, just looked like they were "derping around".When i started combat it felt like Cod+Mass effect gameplay, so it was pretty much 3 guys hiding behind a car taking potshots at aliens who were stupid enough to poke their heads around corners.The troop system is interesting, with a 3 person sqaud going out leaving the 20 other guys back at base doing nothing because all the other missions are done. The only way you can get everyone to a good enough level is by sending everyone on a side mission.The story is filled with "many" oppurtunities to get to know the game, but it's just a bunch of talking and Agent Carter doing weird hand motions while he talks. Also the plot twist about the suitcase makes no sense, and it doesn't give any explanation as to how agent Carter got it. Also how it's only concentrated on the US and we have no clue about the rest of the world(Could make for some great DLC). There's not much about Carter's past except for the random flashbacks that he get's. The game is in no way similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown at all with the style of the enemies, and the 1960 US styled. Of course this is on purpose to give a different view, but there needs to be more about how tense the cold war made everyone in the US besides that one cutscene at the military base.Ah the DLC, the first DLC is just a pay-to-win thing where you get a cool gun at the beginning of the the game, the other 2 DLCs add some content which add some more to the story, but it doesn't really resolve the glaring story problems that already exist.Overall, if u enjoy CoD and was able to like the story, and the Mass Effect Gameplay, then u will have a great time with this game

content:
Posted: May 17, 2015
												Both the spiritual successor and spiritual predecessor to XCOM: ENEMY UNKNOWN, in this thrilling reboot, the enemy is both KNOWN and DECLASSIFIED. Although I confess that I don't actually understand the title, because in XCOM DECLASSIFIED, the enemy is not only.. well, classified.. but you engage in a vast cover-up campaign in the epilogue. Sooo. There's that. Whatever. That's not important. What IS important is that if you can overlook the gameplay, music, and writing, this game was really good! Unfortunately, and with much regret, those three things were included in the game and for some unknowable reason were made integral, and so the final score must suffer slightly as a result. The ending was very strange with a weird narrative device that would have been interesting in a written format, but felt a little frustrating with you being ripped out of the driver's seat of your own character. Final score: 42 tiny sectoids in my♥♥♥♥♥♥cavity

content:
Posted: December 24, 2015
												The game is clunky, the squadmate A.I. is suicidal in a game with perma-death and gear for your soldiers along with traits is badly explained and nebulous on what it does. There is no research or capturing for upgrades, though there is a leveling system that gives you access to more abilities as you go. Back to the game's clunkiness, guns have obscene amounts of recoil and if you don't use a mouse and keyboard you can't aim worth a damn. However the movement is also clunky and only really manageable with a controller. Enemies are massive bullet sponges as well. Had potential to be great, it's sub-par at best. Maybe good for a few hours at the current sales price.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												When I first heard about "The Bureau: X-COM" I was both happy and sad, I was excited that it was going to be set in the 60's, I'm a sucker for old timer stuff (L.A. Noire, Mad Men etc.) but I also found out it wasn't a strategy game like "X-COM: Ememy Unknown"... I was very skeptical at first, however after playing it for a couple of days now, I have to say I'm thoroughly impressed and my earlier skepticism was completely wrong, this truely is a great game!The visuals are absolutly marvelous, so much detail put into almost everything, the games style really captures the 60's era beautifully, as well as the sci-fi elements, all executed perfectly, beatiful and surreal at the same time. The sounds were also top notch, from the perfectly tuned soundtrack to the subtle ambiance of computers humming in the background, distant battles and leaky pipes, gun fire and explosions, the pew pew pews of laser cannons and the screams of Grey's being splattered on the battlefield, it all truely sucks you into the gameworld.The combat is much better then I expected, a great merger of 3rd person shooting and tactical strategy feel very comfortable, lots of skills/perks and 2 partners to issue orders to at any time, a little bit of management thrown in for good measure and lots and lots of skillful headshots and well placed grenades fill the action quite nicely, I was never bored, the difficulty was just right, unlike "Enemy Within" which could be hellish at times.Lastly is the story, overall it was quite good, had a great start, good pace, very strong arc.... then sadly fizzled at the end, I was a bit confused on the complete 180 the main character pulls in the last 30 minutes of the game, didn't make sense to me, besides that tho, it was quite good, lots of notes, photos, recordings and characters to interact with to enrich the backstory.In the end, I had a great time with "The Bureau" not quite sure why all the negativity towards it, I was a little skeptical at first but I'm glad I gave it a chance, one of the better games I've played all year, a great little mix of X-COM meets L.A. Noire meets Mass Effect, three games I absolutely love! 9/10

content:
Posted: February 8, 2014
												XCOM Declassified is a third person cover shooter with a somewhat turn based combat (its not really turn based but the game slowed down when you bring up the squad menu). Think of Mass Effect in XCOM universe but not that polished. The AI is somewhat dumb and you have to ordered it most of the time.The first part of the game is annoying because of your squad's AI, many times I almost gave up on the game and thought to bury it in my backlog. But once you finished a mission or two and you leveled up a bit, the game kinda grow on you. I suggest that you turn down the difficulty to easy in the first part of the game then just turn it up again when you leveled up a bit and got some laser/plasma weapon.Overall, its an ok game. Not great but not bad either. IMO, its worth the time that I spent on it finishing up the game and the 3.99 euro that I paid for it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Game is essentially Mass Effect set in 1960's XCOM without any meaningful dialogue options or deviations in the storyline based on choices you've made. Combat is fine other than your squadmates having no self-preservation, and the interaction of certain abilities with other objects is interesting. Voice acting is great, dialogue and story are pretty good. "Customization" is essentially useless. As more guns are introduced, it's quit clear that you essentially trade ammunition for firepower. Of the 20 or so backpacks available, a handful stick out as being viable. The lack of written companion characters left a huge hole open, I would have loved to take agents Weaver and DeSilva out on some missions. Instead, you get throw away red-shirts, who you only keep around because they need to be leveled up.Specific problems:-Short campaign (16 hours or so, with the optional missions)-No replay value-Lack of customization-Storyline inconsistencies-The entire end of the gameBuy this on sale. It's fun while it's good, but I wouldn't pay higher than $5.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												This is a good game in essence but in execution its not. The Bureau is a butchered console port that crashes every 5 meters you travel in game. I have tried multiple solutions such as windowed mode, running it in compatiblity mode and disabling PhysX, none of these things fix the crashes, making the game unplayable. This is the main reason for the negative review.If not for this issue, I would give the game a yes recommendation for how bad the plot is but for how good the actual gameplay is. Yes there are issues with sqaddies running into crossfires and dying, or not taking cover whilst being shot at but the gunplay works well when you are controlling Carter. Unfortunately, I have not been able to see more then about 15 mins of gameplay as the game constantly crashes for no reason.Also if you are looking for an XCOM/X-COM game, this is not it. This is its own game. If you want XCOM that does not crash and is an RTS, stick with the original trilogy or the remake of the original X-COM.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												It's a mediocre FPS. The idea is that you're running a squad and are supposed to flank enemies but the maps are too narrow to do that effectively. Your squadmates are awful - you either need to micromanage them or do everything yourself.I didn't play that long, but from what I saw strategies are limited. As I said before, the maps are narrow, usually a road with wrecked vehicles or the equivalent, and the enemies are pretty close to you when they appear, so it's not like you've got a lot of choices about where to move. I can't see a sniper being any use at all.It's not the worst game I've ever played by a long shot. They did a good job of recreating the atmosphere of 1962, and I enjoyed that vibe they created. But this game is just not very good. I got this as part of a bundle and wouldn't recommend you buy this alone.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2014
												What to say..  If you're looking for a turn based experiance of squad VS. mobs of alien hoards you may have come to the wrong game but...I really enjoyed The Bureau.  It might not be in the traditional spirit of previous Xcom games.. and feels like a mashup between Mass Effect and Gears Of Wars, but it really seemed to deliver.The Burearu is a game about the struggle of a classy detective and his squadmates against inhuman odds.  The action is live and every order you make counts.  The combat is full of tension and adrenaline, and I enjoyed every minute of it.  If you're a fan of the Xcom lore and don't mind a deviation in gameplay style I'd definately recommend XCOM declassified.If you are in it for the turn based mechanic however, I plead with you to wait for the next xcom title, as the active third person shooter gameplay may not be up your alley. It is quite polished and I can not think of a single complaint to make, but it does not follow the gameplay tradition of the games of the series that game before it.That said, I have played all of The Bureau main campaign before writing this review (save for the post final boss content) and am 100% satisfied with the game save that I wish it was a little longer.
