number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2013
												The Bureau tries very hard to be Mass Effect with an XCOM setting. It doesn't quite make the mark.The combat system has the potential to be better than what's found in Mass Effect with more opportunity for tactics with positioning, traps, and area denial abilities however they gunplay is unpolished and lacks the visceral feedback a headshot should have. The controls lack polish and the ability pathing system often gets stuck on certain edges and often times require awkward positioning to hit the intended marker.Backgrounds and scenery range from pretty damn good to foogly and character models feel dated and jarring inside of cutscenes. The ingame engine looks far better than the cutscenes which leaves one to question why the bawls they decided to not use the better of the two.Voice acting is well done though the dialogue lacks oomph and can come off as droney due to the dull characters. Sound and music miss their cue more often than not and when they function properly, lacks presence. Sound effects are missing from many scenes or muted for no apparent reason and some select recordings are overly loud.Pacing of the story was actually decent until they hit a jarring "PLOT TWIST!" moment and everything went into rollercoaster super fast action mode and not in a good way. It is like skimming through half of a story when it was just starting to get good.The Bureau lacks tries very hard to do what Mass Effect did but it lacks the interesting characters, budget, and polish to pull it off. XCOM has very interesting lore that this game somewhat tapped into via the scientists with their wacky inventions or the technology strapped to your character's arm and back. Sadly, good characters, story, and dialogue are almost non existent leaving the game feeling bland and average at best.Still, the combat abilities of this game are interesting and hopefully expanded upon in other games.  Third person shooters needs something else to do besides hide behind a wall and shoot once in a while and The Bureau's crack at it is a good start.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 7, 2014
												This is a third person gears of war style cover shooter mixed with a hipsterific alternate sixties setting and topped off with strategy elements on cooldown. Basically Mass Effect meets Mad Men meets Men in Black. If you play this game on the veteran setting and spend most of your time in battle focus mode, it makes for a decently entertaining challenge. The combat is solid, the strategy elements make it fun as long as you baby sit your teammates. Throw down turrets, lift enemies out of cover, sniper shots, stim buffs, it's got a nice variety of classes and skills, making most builds useful. The graphics are top notch, with support for DX11 and very cool eerie atmospheric environments and events. This game could have easily been a triple A epic, but in the end falls short of the hype to forever be destined to only be decently average experience.The story, unfortunately is all over the place, the game can't decide if it's a linear action heavy popcorn flick, a deep choice driven narrative, or a half-baked open sandbox rpg and just ends up with a sort of muddled, forgettable plot with everything thrown in. I have a feeling many cutscenes were endlessly revised by the devs.If you love the xcom games, then you'll probably hate this game, but if you like Mass Effect, then pick this up and you'll have a weekend rental ... errr whatever steam's equivalent is, sale price, yea ... thats it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												Reviews were unfairly unkind to this game.. The story is ok, until the end where a twist makes it very interesting and worth experiencing on that fact alone (is it trolling ME3 ending controversy?). Combat is the closest I've played to the Mass Effect series, with an apropriate level of challenge which makes encounters satisfying and fun. It may need a bit of refining but still solid, tactics is very important. So yes, I'd recommend this game if you come in with tempered expectations, this is not an X-COM strategy game and it is not a typical 3rd Person shooter, and it is not an RPG even if it has dialogue trees and side missions, it's a mixture of all these things. It is, in my opinion a solid and fun game that deserved more than credit than most critics gave it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												First Impressions:Impressive amount of depth for a squad-based third person shooter - clearly built with a lot of love.It's the first in what hopefully becomes a very successful spin-off of the much beloved XCOM series.  In traditional XCOM, the entire game is played from a tactical point of view, giving orders to a unit of soldiers fighting against the alien menace. In the Bureau, you play as the commander of a squad, participating in combat as well as using a pretty unique "Battle Focus" system to issue orders.The actual issuing of orders is a bit tricky at times - the soldiers don't always do what you want them to do.  However, once you get used to the goofy little nuances, it easily becomes the most compelling and interesting feature of the game.A lot of people will tell you that this game isn't XCOM or it's some kind of abomination.  Those people are known as idiots.  This game was always intended to be a spinoff - If you're looking for something truer to the original experience, you're looking for XCOM: Enemy Unknown.  It has all the flavor and intrigue of XCOM, but again, it's a spinoff - it has a non-traditional gameplay style. It's my opinion that this is good. Others can disagree, but I don't actually care what they think.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												If you like stradegy games and third person shooters, this game is definitely the game for you. To me the third person shooter made me feel like I was playing 'Red Dead Redemption' without the crazy fast lock on mechanic. For the stradegy potion of it well, it was awesome, I mean I really haven't ever played any XCOM games but the ones I have actually tried have been somewhat boring for me. Don't get me wrong, I love stradegy games, but I just haven't ever really been a big fan of turn based stradegy.The game features a captivating storyline that may or may not keep you on the edge of your seat, I mean come on who doesn't like space and aliens?In this game you'll get a squad on every mission, all having their own abilities just like in any XCOM game. You can customize the character's name, class, suit colors, and face. I do wish you had more to work with on the clothing portion of every character. But I won't take off score just for that!Each character you can arm with pretty much any gun as long as it's related to that specific class. For example, the support class starts with an M14 rifle, he can only use guns related to that so he is NOT able to use sniper rifles or shotguns.Lets dive in to the enemies, some are weak, some are strong. The weak ones you can just blow off your shoulder, you could run into a group of them and you may live. But in time you will start facing repair drones, and some aliens even have armor that you have to shoot off of them to even start to do damage to them. I thought the game was too easy until I got to those guys. Now, it's a descent challenge. And I like it.I love the story and gameplay. 9/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Short Version:7.5/10Overall, this game has nice visuals, solid squad-based tactical shooting, an OK story, and OK character and squadmate progression.Think Men in Black's weapons and effects meets Fallout 4's Pre-War setting.Longer VersionA reasonably well fleshed-out spin-off to the XCOM series, but it doesn't really carry and of XCOM's signature traits such as base-building, research, global council etc. For progression, you and your squadmates gain XP for killing aliens, and you find new equipment dotted around the linear levels. There is a base, but its purpose is more of a hub where you can talk to characters, edit your squad, and sign up for misions.It's not amazing outside of missions, but you will spend the majority of your time on assignments, blasting away at aliens. This is where the game shines; the levels are fairly linear, but each combat area is well-designed so that it is somewhat challenging, but gives you the chance (or sometimes forces you) to use all the weapons and abilities at your disposal. In doing this, very few, if any of the pieces of equipment and abilities feel redundant. The visuals are simple but nicely stylised, and the story is pretty much what you'd expect; a bit dry, but makes sense, and is just good enough to string the missions together.The obvious comparisons to the XCOM strategy game are: it's like manually leading a small, 3-man XCOM squad but there's no base-building elements character progression/loadouts are much more simplified no real consequences for your actions; permadeath of squadmates can be circumvented by loading the last checkpoint (very frequently saved) slightly stronger emphasis on story more linear, but has side-missions and one or two other diversions much nicer graphics, both in terms of quality and style, in my opinion

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Having played XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I must say The Bureau is an entirely different experience altogether. Unlike Enemy Unknown, the Bureau is more like a rewritten story of how XCOM came about. Despite many reviews criticising it for being too rigid and not really an enjoyable experience, I feel otherwise.In my humble opinion, The Bureau storyline was splendidly written. Never once did I feel a sense of boredom. The gameplay can be cruel too, one wrong move and bam your created teammate/AI dies. Perhaps most people won't feel the lost but for me it did. When my AI died in one of the later missions I felt the full brunt of the impact, as I had to resort to using one of my lower level-ed AI in his stead. However that gives the game realism and in that sense the player have to make each and every decision wisely. On a side note, the gameplay(3rd person FPS) reminds me a lot of GRAW2(Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2). As for replay value, it really depends on individuals. I probably would give the game another go and try out different classes but at the same time maybe not. Please pardon me for sidetracking, but I couldn't finish Bioshock Infinite, although it was spectacular I felt that it was overhyped, and not really my type of game whereas Dishonored had me engaged. Therefore as I said it depends on individuals! Just to give anyone reading this a hint: THERE WOULD BE A PLOT TWIST :D All in all, I give the Bureau the mighty thumbs up it deserves and would recommend it to anyone that is a fan of FPS!

content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												This game is simply amazing. I don't normally game for more than one hour every few days but The Bureau had me playing nonstop for 6 hours straight two days in a row. I understand that this XCOM game is not like the others in the series as the point of view is different and there are no turns but it really is worth playing. You still however can assign tasks to each of your team mates. The game is more of a first person shooter unlike the previous XCOM games but it trutly is an amazing game. I'm in chronic pain and sitting for even an hour is hard so sitting for 6 is normally impossible for me but I was so enthrolled with the gameplay and story that I was able to ignore my increasing pain. Normally in games I don't really care about the story, my main interests are the gameplay and the graphics but with The Bureau I actually listened to every converstation and cut scene and went around reading all of the paper work left on desks. I have beat the main game and am now working on the DLC (this by the way is also really good) but I really suggest people try it out. I'm not sure if there is a demo but if there is give that whorl.. I truly do think it will be worth it. If there isn't a demo watch a YouTube gameplay video without comentary (that way it's not biased). Overall I give this game a 10/10. Totally worth the money I spent! Give it a chance, I really don't think you'll regret it!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2013
												If the gameplay of BioWare's Mass Effect and Telltale's The Walking Dead had a child, and if the ambiance of X-Com and Fallout had a child, and those two children grew up and had their own child together, that child would be The Bureau: XCOM Declassified.  The game is a lot of fun, and presents itself very accurately in its advertisements.  It's a squad-based tactical game where you control the main character and two squadmates.  You put your squad together as you run around the base solving dialogue mini-quests and then launch when you feel you are prepared.  The game stays true to its XCOM lore, and you are given lots of scenarios to test your tactics.  The game took me about 20 hours to beat on Veteran, and I didn't get all the achievements.  The game is fun, can be challenging, and appropriate for all ages.  For $25 this game is an absolute steal, for $35 it's a great grab, and for $45 you get what you pay for.  8/10

content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
												I'm just going to clerify this now. I love the original XCOM games. The ones that were hard as hell, and made everything into a exceedingly one sided game of Russian Roulette.That being said, I can't honestly recommend The Bureau. While it is an XCOM game, it just lacks the feeling of XCOM. The chance to hit doesn't mean anything like it did in the old games, and as long as you have line of sight it's almost always a hit. There is strategy in it, and I do appreciate their attempt to make height and range a factor in battle. But the skills that your units gain from combat make it too easy to bulldoze through the aliens.On the other hand, it does have a very interesting story. One that shows history in a stranger light, and almost seems like it came from a tabloid magazine or some conspiracy theorist's mind. It's interesting, but could have been so much more. XCOM is known as a world organization, yet in this game is only shown as a United States one. Yes, there is reasoning for it in the story, but that doesn't mean that you have to limit the game map to just the US. What about Canada? Or Mexico? Maybe Europe or Asia? What happened there? How did they fight? Did they fight?Maybe thats just me asking too many questions. But there are plot holes that could have been filled. Overall, it is ok. Not good enough for me to recommend it to anyone, but still stable enough to be played and enjoyed by some. Graphicly, it looked nice. Explosions and blood was somewhat realistic, and the details in the aliens was nice. Gameplay wise, it could have been stronger, and less formulated like most 3rd person shooters.I'd honestly give it a 3/5 rating, with a strong warning to anyone who wants to buy it.

												This game has one good feature: -Cool graphics.Then there is the rest:-The game progresses by the choices you make. You usually have one option, so that is just laughably horrible, and a waste of time.-The gameplay characters are iconic idiots, through and through. Example: The sniper is the best weapon (most fun and actually useful), but you can only carry 15 rounds. If you know a little bit about weapons, you will know that it uses almost the same ammo as the autorifle, and you can carry 200 rounds for that. For no reason other than annoying the player. Just horrible and unexplainable...-And the game controls themselves are bad and unprecise. -Almost every major encounter starts with a cutscene. Standard "OMFG this was never playtested but anyone with a brain"-experience. This usually means your character (and his stupid followers, more on that later) will run out in the middle of any place to make sure any tactical advantage or chance of survival is forfit before the fight starts.-The followers ability to only follow orders for a short period of time makes you want to kill them yourselves. And giving orders is a slowmo of real time, which means the unprecise tactical view is, on it's own, a reason not to play this poor excuse for a game.

												If you're looking for a classic turn-based XCOM game, this one isn't for you. StoryAlien invasion in the 60s!  Kept me interested, though it feels detached from other XCOM games.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2015
												If you want a TLDR review: this is Mass Effect's combat system 1:1, in Mafia I-II world, with enemies from XCOM:EU. Nothing more, nothing less, and with a few spots that could have been better.First of all, the story is close to non existent. Basicly everyone is functional as role that keeps an undercover agency working, instead of having any kind of personality. This isn't a negative thing, it's not why we ever liked any XCOM for, and this one isn't any different - until the very end. That where the devs decided to go for Mass Effect 3 storytelling, and not only they achieved a similar, but an even worse disaster of things that doesn't make sense anyhow, even on a single character's decision level or as game in a whole. Or just basic logic. But, this is mainly the last hour, and you'll have about 10-13 before that. How's that?That part, is actually great. Just don't even think about touching a console controller or playing on normal difficulty. The combat is really challanging, smart and tactical, later on however can become slightly automatic and boring even on Veteran difficulty, just because you naturally reached better technology, levels and abilities. Other than that, it's like you have a dream Star Wars: Republic Commando, just not Star Wars, and there is more customization to it. Which leads me to my last point where I can throw anything bad on this game: customization. XCOM:EU could have been better on visual customization of our soldiers (and it's sequel is really good looking on this part!), but Declassified is another step back from that. You can change names, 3 or 4 colors on a suit, and that's it. When you recruit a new agent, you can also choose from ~8 premade faces, plus skin color. You cannot have women as agents, or customize visual looks, which is really a miss because you are not supposed to blend in to the crowd, you meet noone but aliens anyway.Overall: Declassified is good, as an average good game can be. It has some unique touches here and there, the action depending on your chosen difficulty level can be really great, but it's one of those games that have absolutely great gameplay, but nothing else. The story is non existent, the customization in it's current form is really hurting that it's not deeper, the characters are throwaway faces. And that's totally fine for XCOM:EU that is a strategy game, but the whole reason Declassified exists as it is, is changing the perspective and bringing it down to a personal level of a group of agents, and it's a failure at that. If there is ever a sequel on this and they can improve on that, it's potentially GOTY material. For this, it's great, but you have to know why you buy it, to not have expectations the game cannot meet. My only problem is, that it still tries, and does it bad. But that's only the last hour, don't let me made you back off if you are thinking about buying it. That means you are looking for a good, really tactical TPS. Declassified, is really good at that.

content:
Posted: August 24, 2013
												First things first. This game has most of XCom lore I can think of. Except for explanation why present-day XCom has no idea about these events. Even though in the game they specifically said that whoever have that knowledge is either dead or with XCom already. So that plot hole is pretty much only bad thing. Now to good parts. FIrst of all - they explained aliens structure properly via dialogs and not mumbling of an alien in the end of a game. That's cool. In fact they even explained why this game is in third person view.Gameplay is probably one of the most solid gameplay I've seen for a while. AI is amazing! They constantly try to push you into the open and♥♥♥♥♥♥you with plasma/lasers. So u have to use your full arsenal of guns and abilities.Graphics - m-m... it's a game which I think most likely was targeted for current gen consoles. And it wasn't made by Naughty Dog or DICE. So don't expect mind blowing graphics. It's only good.Voice acting will bring ya into that era of movies from 90s where main character speaks with crazy action hero voice while constantly croaking.I'd give it something like 8/10 and recommend to buy and play it. Go on Veteran for your first playthrough. You'll love what game will throw into ya :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2013
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified got mediocre reviews for a reason... For eight hours you play a mostly fun tactical shooter, with a solid, kind of quirky story. Then, IT (IT being a story spoiler) happens. The games throws in this twist that kills it. I mean, really kills it. It tries so hard to get that shock "OH♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;, and it does. And here comes the big 'BUUUuuuUUT", it then proceeds to have the main character of the game, no foreshadowing, nothing... GO BAT♥♥♥♥♥♥CRAZY. I mean nuts. He's tries to reject IT, and IT doesn't like that. They force feed you something that just makes the storyline extra dumb. I really wish everyone would wait for this game to be worth 15 - 20$ (or your regional equivalent) and then give this game a shot. Even if you only play it for, say, three hours. By that point you will have seen all that the game has to offer, and be able to say "Yes, i do want to see what this game did wrong. Why does everyone think this game is so bad?". And trust me.. When you get to the twist, and hear what IT has to say, it will be followed by "oh, that's what it was"i realize this isn't a recommendation... but, atleast someone will see it. Right?

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 9, 2014
												This game is nothing like XCOM: Enemy Unknown. I was expecting a strategy game, instead I got a first person shooter with awkward controls and an AI that couldn't fight it's way out of a paper bag. The cinematics and the conversations are well done, and the game looks good, but it lacks the polish of a properly finished game. The characters can only level up to level 5, and their new skills underwhelm. The game is a cover based shooter, but I find myself stuck to the cover as I try to leave due to the awkward controls. They don't explain why the main character gets the ability to lift people at level 2, I think they put it in there to copy Mass Effect. And what's this with the DLC weapons? The game basically gives you weapons, there is no R&D. An there is really only a couple different weapons in the game without DLC. The DLC is an obvious cash grab, not something that adds to the game, but something that should have been included in the first place! The game is still entertaining, but definitely not a blockbuster hit.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												The Bureau was a joyless game. The characters were flat and stiff, as was the story. The combat is a watered-down version of Mass Effect, also devoid of any real fun. Easily a third, if not more, of the game play time is spent simply running from room to room in your base; tedious and dull. I never felt really rewarded for any of the missions, it was just and endless progression towards the end. Even when you unlock the UFO, your combat sessions still begin by showing you arrive in the same old copter from the beginning of the game. The game simply refuses to give you any memorable moments, almost spitefully pulling you forward on a short leash.The combat works, but feels more like an initial draft and not a fully fleshed out system. Since the rest of the game is simply running from room to room on your base endlessly, you'd think they would have crafted a deep, engaging combat system. You would be wrong. It's relatively fast paced, ammo is limited which forces you to scavenge the levels for weapons. I can see how they intended this to keep players from nesting in secure spots for very long. Your party has abilities, several of them directly taken from ME's biotic powers, it's just nowhere near as enjoyable. Even though the maps change throughout the game, the combat itself begins to feel repetitive very early on.Even at the end, which I won't spoil for those who feel they must play this game, you are asked to make a choice between characters from the story, characters you have no reason to care for one way or the other. It's as if they felt suddenly at the end you must face a terrible decision and arbitrarily shoehorned one in. The ending was terrible and left me very unsatisfied. I did complete it. At 17 hours it's barely a few evenings worth of play, which is a good thing. By that point I was ready to be done.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												When I saw all the early previews for what they wanted this game to be I was excited. It was creepy, it was tense, it was dangerous, and it looked fun.This is not that game.This is a third person shooter with a stilted plotline, meaningless choices, and hours of walking down a straight path shooting at aliens from behind a chest high wall.At one point in the game you are told that your forces are doing terribly against the aliens. I was never sure how that could be as I was killing hundreds of them each level.The problem was that they were trying to build up the tension of putting you in a world where you were outgunned, outmanned, and pretty much screwed. And then put you into a third person shooter which requires you to shoot and defeat enemies left right and center for it to be fun.The combination doesn't work well.There's no unlocking weapons, technology, or anything else. You will recieve weapons when you pass levels, and you will gain equipment when your people level up. There's no sense in reall changing loadouts because they'll all feel the same in the end.Your allies will be remarkably usless at doing anything other than getting themselves killed. I can not remember a single time they pulled me out of a dangerous situation, even when they had the single remaining enemy flanked.And the choices you can make are rendered moot by the end game. I fought to save one character. Did it make a difference? Maybe, depends on the ME3 "Which button did you choose" ending. Anything before that? Never gets mentioned.There are better third person shooters, dont' waste your time or money on this one. It just never lived up to it's potential.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
Short Version:7.5/10Overall, this game has nice visuals, solid squad-based tactical shooting, an OK story, and OK character and squadmate progression.Think Men in Black's weapons and effects meets Fallout 4's Pre-War setting.Longer VersionA reasonably well fleshed-out spin-off to the XCOM series, but it doesn't really carry and of XCOM's signature traits such as base-building, research, global council etc. For progression, you and your squadmates gain XP for killing aliens, and you find new equipment dotted around the linear levels. There is a base, but its purpose is more of a hub where you can talk to characters, edit your squad, and sign up for misions.It's not amazing outside of missions, but you will spend the majority of your time on assignments, blasting away at aliens. This is where the game shines; the levels are fairly linear, but each combat area is well-designed so that it is somewhat challenging, but gives you the chance (or sometimes forces you) to use all the weapons and abilities at your disposal. In doing this, very few, if any of the pieces of equipment and abilities feel redundant. The visuals are simple but nicely stylised, and the story is pretty much what you'd expect; a bit dry, but makes sense, and is just good enough to string the missions together.The obvious comparisons to the XCOM strategy game are: it's like manually leading a small, 3-man XCOM squad but there's no base-building elements character progression/loadouts are much more simplified no real consequences for your actions; permadeath of squadmates can be circumvented by loading the last checkpoint (very frequently saved) slightly stronger emphasis on story more linear, but has side-missions and one or two other diversions much nicer graphics, both in terms of quality and style, in my opinion

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 2, 2014
												Having played XCOM: Enemy Unknown, I must say The Bureau is an entirely different experience altogether. Unlike Enemy Unknown, the Bureau is more like a rewritten story of how XCOM came about. Despite many reviews criticising it for being too rigid and not really an enjoyable experience, I feel otherwise.In my humble opinion, The Bureau storyline was splendidly written. Never once did I feel a sense of boredom. The gameplay can be cruel too, one wrong move and bam your created teammate/AI dies. Perhaps most people won't feel the lost but for me it did. When my AI died in one of the later missions I felt the full brunt of the impact, as I had to resort to using one of my lower level-ed AI in his stead. However that gives the game realism and in that sense the player have to make each and every decision wisely. On a side note, the gameplay(3rd person FPS) reminds me a lot of GRAW2(Ghost Recon Advanced Warfighter 2). As for replay value, it really depends on individuals. I probably would give the game another go and try out different classes but at the same time maybe not. Please pardon me for sidetracking, but I couldn't finish Bioshock Infinite, although it was spectacular I felt that it was overhyped, and not really my type of game whereas Dishonored had me engaged. Therefore as I said it depends on individuals! Just to give anyone reading this a hint: THERE WOULD BE A PLOT TWIST :D All in all, I give the Bureau the mighty thumbs up it deserves and would recommend it to anyone that is a fan of FPS!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2016
												3rd person, squad based, action, tactical shooter versus aliens. This game is about Alien invasion on a late 1900's Earth. You play as a XCOM Agent, carefully selected people who were professionals in their field of work, before joining the The Bureau. Be it in CIA, FBI, NSA and other agencies.XCOM is a secret US government facility, made to counter invasion attempts on US soil. Game has really good story but a bit not realistic with all the "borrowing alien technology" aspect. World art style is mix of 1950-1970's retro and futuristic alien sci-fi elements.There are many weapons in the game, from WWII pistols, rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, grenades to sci-fi alien weapons, that share similar concepts (plasma pistols, plasma rifles, shotguns, sniper rifles, etc.). All alien weapons are energy based, with their own ammunition.You can recruit different types of soldier classes, that are experts in their field of combat. Be it simple engineer, that can deploy turrets, sniper that can deal heavy damage from range, commando who can absorb damage and taunt enemies, or support class that can boost your squads damage, increase survivability, etc.Each class has their own skill tree, abilities and weapon preferences. One is good at range, other can survive a lot of punishment, third can manipulate the battlefield to your advantage, etc.. Personal and squad abilities can be chained from tactical "Focus" mode, you can very easily position your soldiers, order them to focus one target, revive injured ally.AI is very good and will often flank you, flush you out of cover and rush up on you, depending on what alien unit it is. Game environment and level design is great, with a lot of room for flanking and surprise attacks. Enemy variation is also good, with close range, long range units mixed with air and stealth units.Game is somewhat similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown in some aspects. You control, improve, gear up your squad, send them on rescue, Intel missions or accompany them on more harder side missions apart from main story missions. You can recruit only male soldiers for your squad, if someone wanted females, it's not possible. Sadly you don't research alien technology yourself, or make items, those are automatically managed by game and XCOM Agency itself.Game has a lot of character dialogues, with choice and effect, consequence system. Voice acting is good, texture quality and visuals are good, character control and animations were decent. Game is about 15 hours long and was a blast to playthrough. It's not as punishing as XCOM: Enemy Unknown, being a shooter, game is fairly forgiving and there's a lot of room for personal error, compared to XCOM: Enemy Unknown.Game was very fun and enjoyable.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2014
												The Bureau XCOM Declassified isn’t bad game as people say it is (especially XCOM hardcore fans).I know that it isn’t a classic XCOM game and that it struggles to find its place in the XCOM-series. But it provides a solid experience if you´re a person who likes 3rd person shooters and sometimes meaningless shooting.The story is quite intriguing.  The combat is decent and the AI of the enemies is surprisingly good. The command system works remarkably well because you have to constantly issue new orders to your NPCs. Things that I disliked was that the combats weren’t that strategic as the other XCOM games, sometimes it was just too much meaningless shooting.  The world felt like the game Resistance, and it felt really empty which made the game a little boring time to time. The DLC that the game has to offer is just not worth is because it does not add anything new. If you want the DLC buy it when the game is on sale.I give this game a solid 7.5/10.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Gameplay - Mass Effect 2 clone. However, I felt it was more crucial to employ squadmember skills during battle than what i was used to in Mass Effect 2 on similar difficult. This is a good thing. (Saying Mass Effect 2 since i haven't yet completed 3)Difficulty - I played it on the second hardest difficulty and although the learning curve was alright, it started out alot tougher than expected. Expect a hard time against your first Muton unless you're above average in tactics and how you pick your squads.Graphics - The graphics are alright. I'm not really that good on judging them though since i put gameplay first. Everything reminded me again of Mass Effect 2, though the the backdrop is the early 60s in the US. The main character animation during story dialogues was repetive though.Story - I expected a lot more shallow story from the get go. It really suprised me how it twists and turns later on. The side missions were quite a bit lacking though, and again something picked up from the Mass Effect franchise. I didn't really feel there were any rewards to them either.Sound - Music and sound effects were solid. Voice acting above average and in style with what i feel is true for the 60s. There are also quite a few references to early 60s rock music.The Bad - Although i encountered no gamebreaking bugs, there are a few annoying ones. Like dialogue looping after the sequence is finished, items that have been checked will glow again after a side mission if you have tips on in options and a few glitchy things now and then.Bottom line - Anyone with interest in 3rd person action, bioshock rpgs or the Xcom franchise should find value here. I really enjoyed it while not expecting it to be anything more than a twitchy, corridor, action game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												First things first. 1, Forget about metascore (currently around 6.5), this game is far better than this.2, This is not a strategy, it´s a tactical TPS.3, I am not hardcore XCOM fan (I played only XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within - and I love those games)4, I´m fat and I have a bad haircut. Deal with it.When The Bureau was announced, I was super excited, because the trailer looked amazing, the premise of alien attack situated in the USA in 60s as FPS with some tactical elements seemed great. We all know that there were some problems during the development and that the game was reworked many times. That sounds like a bad thing ( *cough* Colonial Marines *cough*), eh? Well it is NOT. GRAPHICS are stunning (I played on DX11). Seriously, I´ve never seen a game with better lightning of a scene. I often caught myself just staring on the scene and taking screenshots, because it simply looked beautiful. It required a decent hardware though on HIGH setting, I played on MID-HIGH. No cons. 10/10 GAMEPLAY The main part of the game are fights of course. Ever played Mass Effect? Imagine that, but better ( HERESY!). Far better. Yea, I said that. Here is the thing. On a mission, you can take two agents with you. Each agent can have one of four classes (Engineer, Recon, Commando, Support). I´ve ended up using Support and Engineer (Engineer can put a turret or mines on the battlefield, Support creates a shield, can give a stims to the whole team etc). You have a special class, called Agent. You can Heal, do some kind telekinetics, put a drone on a battlefield, and at level 9 out 10, you can use a mind control ( yea, those are not the agents you are looking for). You can give the commands to your team via command list (imagine KOTOR). When you press SPACE key, it will put you in slow motion mod and you have lot of time to think (not that much though, the game is not completely freezed). At the beginning of the game you will not use it that much, but when the♥♥♥♥♥♥hit the fan (that means when Sectopod or Muton introduce themselves on a scene), you will beg for mercy and most of the time, you will end up planning what to do, where to put your agents, and wondering how the ♥♥♥♥ you are supposed to kill them all. This game is challenging on a first walkthrough. Not THAT hard, but decently hard.    The weaponry of this game is not too big ( Colt 1911, M14, Springfield,  then laser and plasma variations, grenades), but nothing to complain, the main power of this game is within the abilities/perks of the team).   One thing bothered me though. A.I. of the squadmates. There are not dumb, not really, but they are not shooting much when no order is given to them, and they do not roll out when a ♥♥♥♥ing grenade is under them! That was the only thing that was frustrating me. 8.5/10STORY is decent, nothing original of course, but it drives you towards the end, because you will want to know what the hell is happening here (or ... well, THERE). The main character, William Carter, is and old school badass agent with some serious issues from the past, but when the♥♥♥♥♥♥needs to be done, he is called for duty.  I do not want to spoil anything, so let´s just say that story is kinda "mass-effectish". 7/10FINAL VERDICTI enjoyed this game very much, it was challenging, with not original, but interesting story. Together with awesome graphics and gameplay, I must say to the world - ♥♥♥♥ METACRITICS. I do regret that I didn´t bought this game at launch but on Summer Sale, and it´s shame that there will be no sequel ( the game was not succesful in terms of sales)9/10

content:

												Not quite in the same style as XCom: Enemy Unknown, this XCom title takes on a more first person/squad approach.  It's playstyle is a mix between real time and turn based.  To compare it to the original 1990s XCom series, this game's combat system mirrors the attempts at real time integration with turn based strategy which was attempted in the XCom Apocolypse game.  If you're looking for a game similar to XCom Enemy Unknown, this is likely NOT the game for you.  I recommend the DLC of Enemy Within.  If you're looking for a stand-alone, good game, in the XCom universe, that's a mix between FPS, TBS, and RTS, pick up this title.

content:
Posted: October 12, 2015
												This is a good enough game but has some pretty bad points as well. It's a good  game, good bit of fun alternate history however it does contain a few problems. Namely, an issue with a lot of games where it gives you command over a squad, is the AI squad. The game gives you full control over two teammates, little good that is as they don't listen to you... at all. It's like leading the two blind mice (it would've been the three blind mice but the third one didn't listen to what he was told and died.). You can give a move command and he'll move there but only for a short period of time and then decide it's time to rush the enemy that's the size of The Hulk. You tell them to attack a specific enemy but as they are in fact, the blind mice, they start to shoot at a completely different enemy. You can even have them flank the enemy, getting the perfect angle and shot onto the unknowing little alien but they'll still miss or fire in short enough bursts that a turtle could evade them. So you pretty much end up doing everything yourself and just using your teammates abilities, if they haven't died from trying to scare the enemy away by running really fast at them that is.Another issue is how they throw massive enemies at you without telling you anything about them, little hints or giving you appropriate weaponry to defeat them. I remember the first time they threw an enemy gunship at me and expected me to take it down with a rifle. I think it's rather obvious to say that it took a while.Other than those two points which do continuously get really rather annoying it is an alright game. I haven't played the original XCOM games so I have nothing to compare it to or moan about as "It's not like the originals" or whatever so yeah. Good game, awful teammates. Buy this game, Or don't. Whatever. It's your money. Make your own decisions. You'll never get far in life looking for some random persons approval.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2014
												The Bureau is a game with a lot of baggage. It was first announced as the way 2K was choosing to revive the X-Com franchise, a decision that was understandably received with a considerable amount of bafflement and ill will. Yes, people wanted a modern X-Com, but that meant a turn-based strategy game of research and tactical battles, not some shooter. The fact that, as shooters went, it actually looked pretty interesting and ambitious was largely lost in the outpouring of disgust over the brand they chose to attach to it. Then it faded from view, and in the meantime Firaxis' much more faithful franchise reboot was announced and even released before The Bureau came back into view, now branded with that name. Unfortunately, it was clear that some ambition had been lost along the way, and its development was revealed to have been troubled and fraught with drama. It came out to a general wave of indifference, and was promptly dismissed.Having now completed it, I believe this indifference was unwarranted. It's true that it's not X-Com. And the game originally previewed might well have been a better one. But the end result is a rather enjoyable melding of squad tactics and quality shooting, with light RPG elements; attached to a fairly compelling scenario of apocalyptic alien assault. Both major and side missions have interesting things to show you, and reveal more about the nature and motivations of your foe, and there's even a pretty spiffy late game twist. And I really appreciated the sequences where you walk around the XCOM base between missions. The various people you can converse with are all fairly well drawn as characters, if not horribly deep, and there are additional story tidbits and several layers of ambient conversations and announcements throughout, changing after every major mission.Mind you, it's not perfect, either. The notion that all of this is a secret that's been covered up for decades is, well, just not plausible at all, especially when the rest of the time they want to give you a sense of the appalling scale of events. Some of the conversations are a little prone to repetition. And there are some disappointing technical issues, some of which seem to be specific to AMD cards from what I've read, but others seem more generally problematic. I had severe framerate issues with either PhysX setting on and active (i.e. if I was around PhysXed cloth or effects), and on settings above Medium (at least in the DirectX 11 client), the shadows were prone to very distracting and glitchy flickering. I've also read some people have had issues with crashes, although I personally did not experience these.The technical issues were pretty easy to work around, and if you're prepared to quietly ignore the premise that any of the game's events are covert, that's not the biggest deal in the world either. So I don't feel either of these things should put you off The Bureau. I quite enjoyed myself all the way to the end, and I would definitely recommend it.

The combat is decent and the AI of the enemies is surprisingly good. The command system works remarkably well because you have to constantly issue new orders to your NPCs. Things that I disliked was that the combats weren’t that strategic as the other XCOM games, sometimes it was just too much meaningless shooting.  The world felt like the game Resistance, and it felt really empty which made the game a little boring time to time. The DLC that the game has to offer is just not worth is because it does not add anything new. If you want the DLC buy it when the game is on sale.I give this game a solid 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: October 25, 2014
												Gameplay - Mass Effect 2 clone. However, I felt it was more crucial to employ squadmember skills during battle than what i was used to in Mass Effect 2 on similar difficult. This is a good thing. (Saying Mass Effect 2 since i haven't yet completed 3)Difficulty - I played it on the second hardest difficulty and although the learning curve was alright, it started out alot tougher than expected. Expect a hard time against your first Muton unless you're above average in tactics and how you pick your squads.Graphics - The graphics are alright. I'm not really that good on judging them though since i put gameplay first. Everything reminded me again of Mass Effect 2, though the the backdrop is the early 60s in the US. The main character animation during story dialogues was repetive though.Story - I expected a lot more shallow story from the get go. It really suprised me how it twists and turns later on. The side missions were quite a bit lacking though, and again something picked up from the Mass Effect franchise. I didn't really feel there were any rewards to them either.Sound - Music and sound effects were solid. Voice acting above average and in style with what i feel is true for the 60s. There are also quite a few references to early 60s rock music.The Bad - Although i encountered no gamebreaking bugs, there are a few annoying ones. Like dialogue looping after the sequence is finished, items that have been checked will glow again after a side mission if you have tips on in options and a few glitchy things now and then.Bottom line - Anyone with interest in 3rd person action, bioshock rpgs or the Xcom franchise should find value here. I really enjoyed it while not expecting it to be anything more than a twitchy, corridor, action game.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2014
												NOTE: Reviewer's game difficulty was set to Commander, finishing the game with no deaths. The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a squad-based third-person tactical shooter not unlike the Mass Effect Series. Although it does not quite reach the heights of Bioware's Magna Opera, it still delivers moments of greatness throughout its 10-hour campaign. --CAMPAIGNThe storytelling is well-paced, although some cutscenes can use some work with regards to its fluidity. These cutscenes attempt a more filmic look, but it transitions poorly once control is handed to the player. The characters themselves could have had a more fleshed-out backgroud, but as it stands, most of the them fall under recognizable tropes.Lore can be found scattered throughout the world, and they greatly contribute to the atmosphere of the game. Of course they don't directly contribute to the game itself, but for players who enjoy getting themselves immersed in such world-building, they are certainly a neat touch. The locations for each level are also highly varied and colorful. Hyper-modern games have a tendency to look really brown or greyish, but The Bureau breaks away from the pack and surprisingly manages to convey a sense of desperation even amid the richness of the color palette. The developers could have certainly put more effort into the battle areas though--an organic and subtle approach would have gone a long way into keeping the player engaged. Boxes and railings suddenly take on a symmetrical form, walls and cars inexplicably appear in positions that don't make much sense except as cover. Still, it is only a minor gripe and it doesn't take away from the presentation of the game. --MECHANICSThe gameplay is akin to many third person cover-based shooters. It patterns itself closer to Mass Effect--one button is highly contextualized, from sticking to cover to sprinting, or vaulting objects. It works for the most part, although having individual buttons for different things could have allowed the game to be more precise. The shooting aspect is enjoyable, and the ability to issue commands to your squad is an exercise of thinking. Running and gunning is not a viable option, especially on higher difficulties. As such, patience and a quick mind is integral to the success of your team. Each encounter is similar to a puzzle begging to be solved: do you distract the enemy with a diversion and plant a mine behind them? Or should you force them to scatter and pick them off one by one? Nothing is binary within a firefight. Everything is dynamic, and it is the player's responsibility to constantly assess and reassess the situation. Friendly AI could definitely use some tuning though (mainly on autonomous cover choices), but it does not detract from the overall usefulness of the squad AI. RPG aficionados also have some options in tinkering with their squad composition. Differing playstyles can easily be accomodated by the game, with each agent being highly customizable from their perks right down to their equipments , although changeable outfits would have been a welcome inclusion in the game. --CONCLUSIONAll in all, The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a welcome addition the XCOM franchise. It may not be on the same level as the Mass Effect Series (which it seems to have patterned itself to) but it is definitely an enjoyable game. Critics and naysayers alike have been too quick to dismiss the game without actually paying attention to it, just because of the silly notion that it is NOT XCOM. Well, no♥♥♥♥♥♥ its The Bureau--it's simply its own game within a larger XCOM universe.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												Despite my initial hesitance toward the change of style for this game (from its initial showings), it's a surprisingly competent tactical TPS set in the early XCOM universe. It begins as your standard cover based shooter, but once you've moved onto the first main operation, opens up quite a bit as you unlock new abilities for both yourself and your squad mates. In some early game operations you can still sit behind cover for most firefights and take potshots at enemies, but a) that's *really* boring and b) doesn't work on harder difficulties (I played on "hard," I guess, but there's still one difficulty above that).In many of the later operations, enemies will flank your position, throw grenades to flush you out, or rush you head on with cloaked enemies and mutons with jetpacks. The fun (and frustration) comes from flanking enemies with your squad mates (giving you a damage bonus) and using their abilites to funnel enemies into your line of fire, but I found myself in many battles to constantly be waiting for my heal ability to be on cooldown, or running around reviving my squad who have run out of cover for no reason. The game doesn't seemingly give you the ability to "keep" your squad in certain positions; sure, you can order them around, but it always felt that once I moved far enough away (far enough being not very far) they would move out of cover and subsequently die, forcing me to take a ton of damage to revive them and waste my heal ability on myself.All that aside (and despite some minor quirks I had with the controls) I enjoyed my time with it. It's no XCOM UFO Defense or even Enemy Unknown for that matter, but it offers enough challenge and tactical options to be worth one playthrough.

												Well, I don't understand all the criticism towards this game. I actually genuinely liked it. It isn't the best game I have ever played, but it is really well done.First of all, the graphics are incredible - character animations, locations design - everything works for the atmosphere. I just wish they added some elements destruction, such as destroying chairs and tables.The game itself is third-person shooter with covers and tactical pause during which you can give orders to 2 your companions. I constantly used such abilities as put the turret or use critical shot during my playthrough.The story starts very slow, but closer to the end it runs so fast and is full or different twists and revelations. Sure, it has lots of cliches, but it isn't that bad. There are even three different endings depending on your choice.All in all, the game is above mediocre thanks to very well done shooting and giving orders mechanics and thanks to great graphics. 7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I followed the wandering development of The Bureau: Xcom Declassified for a number of years. Patiently I observed as it transitioned from FPS to 3rd person hoping that it would not suffer in it’s long development cycle. I’m sorry to say that despite some rather nice visuals it suffers from serious design bloat. As teams changed, development laboured and it seems as they moved onward they continuing to tack on new fresh ideas. Perhaps this was done to show progression and relevancy for upper management. But it comes across as a series of continuously muddled concepts that were never truly flushed out.Combat jumps between uninspired to slightly broken. Agents can take shots through some obstacles or take excessive damage sitting flush against walls. The sparks of laserfire can be seen clipping through various barriers and my snipers can shoot through several layers of walls. Grenades are a bit off. The enemies can seem to toss them across the stage while my weak human arms can only lobe a grenade a few feet further than a effective shotgun blast. I bet the enemies can lobe grenades a bit further if they were to throw them towards me. Rather they throw the grenade upwards and vaguely in my direction. I’ve been counting the number of seconds from when a enemy throws a grenade and when it lands on my feet. On average I’m aware of a grenade is on it’s way for 4-6 seconds. Then another 4-5 seconds before it detonation I could be half way across the map before it goes off. Not a very effective weapon, at least for them.Speaking of ineffective you learn quickly that as your allies are made of paper and the close combat of the shotgun, and alien equivalent shotgun are the most useless weapons in the game and I can not think of a single instance where close combat would be recommend unless you want to kill you allies. But they seem to do that quite well on their own. They are eager to jump into the action early in the game, but while I enjoy their eagerness to prove who can go down in a fight the fastest its recommend you keep them out of harms way until they prove themselves to be useful in a couple of levels.Although being a powerhouse can be fun overtime the missions are tedious. Pop all skills and target the biggest enemy. Rinse and repeat. It's rare to jump between cover with a few expections during the last few missions. Other than a single boss battle all combat mission play out the same. The variety of enemy types is varied but can nearly all be destroyed with the same tactics again and again. But enough about the combat because that’s the best part of the game. While it’s a bit too easy, too-linear, and mostly uninhabited "hot" zones  there are far worse offenders.In the brilliant 2012 X-Com the time spent at your bunker was filled with activities to improve all your stats build new areas etc...Let’s not dwell too long in comparisons as it’s simply not fair. The return to your bunker goes between serviceable to unbearable. The conversations you have with the members of X:Com are done with dialog trees. Perhaps showing it’s influence from mass effect a bit too much! But the conversations are pointless. Full of false choices or at their best tedium to unlock a extra mission you can’t participate in. The nuggets exploring this area are banal conversations, in-active NPC’s & and fetch quests. Most of them can be skipped or simply forgotten. Some of these conversations will lead you to a mini game where you scan an area by holding L (360 controller) where you can see objects that need your attention a-la detective mode. These seem totally optional and only open paths for your extra team mates to go explore and level while you are following the main story. Frankly I’m having an ok time with it. I don’t want to throw it under the bus, it’s pretty boring outside of combat and after you get a few levels on yourself and your team mates it simply becomes a slaughter fest where nothing can harm you. I highly doubt we will hear about this franchise again and it’s a shame because at it’s best you can see what it could've been. It takes too much inspiration from better games and does not improve on them. It's a project that just needed to get out the door. Too much time, money and engery was spent re-hashing a collection of mechanices, techniques, artistic approaches over year to simply have them all go to waste. At least it was released and we'll never have to wonder, "what -if?"5.5/10Recommend by if it's on sale. I'd kick myself for spending more than $20.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Source[playertheory.com]The squad presses up against the cover, silent as can be. Peeking over the edge, they get a view of the alien patrols that wander the Small Town, USA street – the tiny squad of three is easily outnumbered five to one.These odds aren't anything new, though.Times slows down as William Carter, the commander of the mission, whispers his commands. "Spread out. Take flanking positions." He has one soldier throw out a turret on that side of the street to flush the outsiders out of cover. The other, armed with a sniper rifle, he has targeted an opposing sniper on the far end of the street. ommands given, Carter targets a shielded unit mid-street, and using some advanced technology strapped to his wrist, plans to lift him up into the air to be used as target practice.Time returns to normal, and in unison, the squad moves and begins their planned attack.The outsiders don't stand a chance."The Bureau" is the latest addition to the XCOM series of strategy-based, humans vs. aliens games. What separates "The Bureau" from most of the other games in the popular series is how it puts you on the ground with your squad as an individual, rather than a commander seeing everything from above. You're given a third-person perspective of the battlefield, and you're allowed to move around freely like in any other shooter. Unlike any other shooter, however, you're also given the responsibility of giving commands to your squad, lest they stand behind cover and take badly aimed pot-shots at the enemy until the End of Time.That responsibility to command your squad is what makes "The Bureau" an irrefutable part of the "XCOM" series and is also one of the more frustrating functions of the game. "The Bureau" is not a turn-based game. You aren't able to stop the time once a mission begins, which makes timing squad commands a very difficult thing to manage, especially in the middle of a particularly rough firefight. As a bit of an aid to the player, time does slow down when Carter goes into "command mode," but it doesn't ever seem to be slow enough. Without the top-down view of the battlefield, it's much tougher to send your squad to the exact area that you need, which I suppose is more realistic given your on-the-ground commander perspective of the game, but it also occasionally leaves the player sending his squad to locations where they stand idiotically next to cover and get riddled with laser fire.For that reason, the game really does reward the player for being strategic and patient during the fights in the game. The only problem with that is that the fights start becoming really predictable. You'll be traveling through war-torn America and turn down a street with a view of the road covered with rows of flipped cars and boxes and other types of cover. And suddenly, aliens appear and start running at you!That is how each mission basically goes. You walk around, have two to three fights in carefully prepared battlefields, and then you win. Occasionally, they throw a new enemy at you or some reinforcements drop down in a flanking position so you have to rethink your strategy, but it's never horribly difficult to get yourself out of those situations.If there was ever a reason that I lost a battle, it was because I made a mistake trying to rush through it. A lot of fights feel exactly like the last fight, and you end up just wanting to get through them to get to the other side.There is the RPG element to the game, which is very similar to what was seen in "Enemy Unknown." There are various squad classes, and each one has a skill tree they are able to climb up to get new abilities. That tree is very small however, so the decision process is kind of underwhelming, and any strategy you have during character advancement is rather limited.Like in "Enemy Unknown," you have the ability to customize your squad mates when you hire them, which is a feature I really like in games like this. I love building up teams based on my real-life friends, and I do it every time a game gives me the chance. Typically, those characters are always the first to die, but I still try to do it. I always get attached fastest to characters that I'm able to create, and that bond to to your squad is a key part of the "XCOM" games. The player is able to customize a lot about their squaddies, down to the color of their tie in the suit that they wear into battle. The one thing they can't change is gender. "The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" is a boy's only club, which I suppose goes with the atmosphere of the era the game is set in; just about everything was a boys only club in that time. There is a female NPC character that occasionally helps Carter in battles, so the potential for female teammates was there, but the players just don't get to have access to it. I guess we'll just have to chalk it up to adorable/nostalgic 1960's sexism.One of the things that I found cool and amusing about "The Bureau" is what the typical "XCOM" squad wears into battle. They don't rely on kevlar or any kind of body armor. They go out in their suits. Sure, some do wear camouflage, but most of the squad classes are dressed to the nines for their battle against invaders from space. Agent Carter goes between being dressed like he's a character in "Mad Men" to looking like a twin of Sterling Archer (black turtleneck and all). The "XCOM" squad, Earth's only defense against complete and utter annihilation at the end of super advanced aliens, has never looked as good as they look in "The Bureau."The story of "The Bureau" starts off as nothing special. Earth gets attacked by an alien force, the military is destroyed, and it comes to the brand new XCOM team to overcome this threat. You do all the cliche things that a team working as Earth's last hope would do. You rescue the guy that's an expert in the alien technology. You do your best to save civilian populations. You capture a live outsider. And eventually, use their own technology against them to do an "Independence-Day-Shut-Down-Everything" type of mission. It's really standard stuff with completely average voice-acting carrying you through it all.That said, there are a couple redeeming things about the story. You encounter the first pretty early on - a mysterious virus from the outsiders that infects civilians population and turns them into "Sleepwalkers." They ooze black stuff from their eyes and just walk around in circles repeating whatever it was the last thing they were doing before the ailment completely took hold. They don't attack you; they just continuously mutter their "last words" and walk around aimlessly. It creates a lot of creepy atmosphere in the destroyed American towns in which most of the game's missions take place.In the final act of the game, the story veers dramatically off the path of the predictable and does some crazy stuff that I did not expect. I won't go into it to avoid spoilers, but it's an alright twist with multiple possible endings.I played through "The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" trying really hard to like it. It was interesting at first, but the average story and clunky game play really strayed from what I loved so much about "Enemy Unknown." This newest addition to the "XCOM" series was definitely a risk by developer 2k Marin, especially with the fantastic and immensely popular formula for "Enemy Unknown" sitting right there, and I'm not sure that risk paid off. "The Bureau" just isn't a very interesting game in comparison. It has its moments for sure, but those moments are fleeting and in the end, they're not really memorable. If you're a fan of the "XCOM" series, you probably shouldn't miss what "The Bureau" adds to the series, but if you're looking for something as strategic and difficult as "Enemy Unknown," you're going to be disappointed.But at least you'll be dressed well.6/10

												Mass Effect 1: XCOM Declassified the game.  this is how i could best describe it.  excelent cover based 3rd-person tactical game.  while this isn't a traditional top down turn based strategy x-com, i give them credit for at least trying something new.  While this isn't the best 3rd person squad based tactics game out there, its by no means bad either.  if you liked how mass effect played and you like the xcom storyline then this game is a good match for you.  if you're only looking for the traditional xcom experience, you will not like this game.  its a mixed bag of goodies but of course not everyone will like it.  Personally I love 3rd person squad shooters so i can definately recommend it.  Those that are on the fence about it, take a look at more than one review site, look at different reviews and opinions or youtubes and find out for yourself!

Also is a game that will have you play through 10 minute fire fights again if you die and have to restart. Picked it up at $12 and think it was worth it as an XCOM fan. Pay anymore than $15 and I would have felt ripped off.

												Honestly, it a solid game. Sure there are some things that are off in this game, such as the enemies being bullet sponges, the exclusion of a jump button, and how the abilities interfere chronologically with the story, but overall the gunplay is solid and the strategical squad commands feel like XCOM at it's simplist core. However, your squad AI doesn't always listen to you and they usually end up in the enemy's line of sight. Music is repetative, but fitting. The visuals are fantastic. It has a vibrant cartoony feel that's very Bioshock Infinitesque. Overall, even though the 3rd person setting is a weird departure from the traditional Turn Based gameplay, it still holds up with the XCOM name. 2012's Enemy Unknown is far better than this, but if you enjoy games like Mass Effect, then you should get this. 7/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I followed the wandering development of The Bureau: Xcom Declassified for a number of years. Patiently I observed as it transitioned from FPS to 3rd person hoping that it would not suffer in it’s long development cycle. I’m sorry to say that despite some rather nice visuals it suffers from serious design bloat. As teams changed, development laboured and it seems as they moved onward they continuing to tack on new fresh ideas. Perhaps this was done to show progression and relevancy for upper management. But it comes across as a series of continuously muddled concepts that were never truly flushed out.Combat jumps between uninspired to slightly broken. Agents can take shots through some obstacles or take excessive damage sitting flush against walls. The sparks of laserfire can be seen clipping through various barriers and my snipers can shoot through several layers of walls. Grenades are a bit off. The enemies can seem to toss them across the stage while my weak human arms can only lobe a grenade a few feet further than a effective shotgun blast. I bet the enemies can lobe grenades a bit further if they were to throw them towards me. Rather they throw the grenade upwards and vaguely in my direction. I’ve been counting the number of seconds from when a enemy throws a grenade and when it lands on my feet. On average I’m aware of a grenade is on it’s way for 4-6 seconds. Then another 4-5 seconds before it detonation I could be half way across the map before it goes off. Not a very effective weapon, at least for them.Speaking of ineffective you learn quickly that as your allies are made of paper and the close combat of the shotgun, and alien equivalent shotgun are the most useless weapons in the game and I can not think of a single instance where close combat would be recommend unless you want to kill you allies. But they seem to do that quite well on their own. They are eager to jump into the action early in the game, but while I enjoy their eagerness to prove who can go down in a fight the fastest its recommend you keep them out of harms way until they prove themselves to be useful in a couple of levels.Although being a powerhouse can be fun overtime the missions are tedious. Pop all skills and target the biggest enemy. Rinse and repeat. It's rare to jump between cover with a few expections during the last few missions. Other than a single boss battle all combat mission play out the same. The variety of enemy types is varied but can nearly all be destroyed with the same tactics again and again. But enough about the combat because that’s the best part of the game. While it’s a bit too easy, too-linear, and mostly uninhabited "hot" zones  there are far worse offenders.In the brilliant 2012 X-Com the time spent at your bunker was filled with activities to improve all your stats build new areas etc...Let’s not dwell too long in comparisons as it’s simply not fair. The return to your bunker goes between serviceable to unbearable. The conversations you have with the members of X:Com are done with dialog trees. Perhaps showing it’s influence from mass effect a bit too much! But the conversations are pointless. Full of false choices or at their best tedium to unlock a extra mission you can’t participate in. The nuggets exploring this area are banal conversations, in-active NPC’s & and fetch quests. Most of them can be skipped or simply forgotten. Some of these conversations will lead you to a mini game where you scan an area by holding L (360 controller) where you can see objects that need your attention a-la detective mode. These seem totally optional and only open paths for your extra team mates to go explore and level while you are following the main story. Frankly I’m having an ok time with it. I don’t want to throw it under the bus, it’s pretty boring outside of combat and after you get a few levels on yourself and your team mates it simply becomes a slaughter fest where nothing can harm you. I highly doubt we will hear about this franchise again and it’s a shame because at it’s best you can see what it could've been. It takes too much inspiration from better games and does not improve on them. It's a project that just needed to get out the door. Too much time, money and engery was spent re-hashing a collection of mechanices, techniques, artistic approaches over year to simply have them all go to waste. At least it was released and we'll never have to wonder, "what -if?"5.5/10Recommend by if it's on sale. I'd kick myself for spending more than $20.
