content:
Posted: March 26, 2014
Source[playertheory.com]The squad presses up against the cover, silent as can be. Peeking over the edge, they get a view of the alien patrols that wander the Small Town, USA street – the tiny squad of three is easily outnumbered five to one.These odds aren't anything new, though.Times slows down as William Carter, the commander of the mission, whispers his commands. "Spread out. Take flanking positions." He has one soldier throw out a turret on that side of the street to flush the outsiders out of cover. The other, armed with a sniper rifle, he has targeted an opposing sniper on the far end of the street. ommands given, Carter targets a shielded unit mid-street, and using some advanced technology strapped to his wrist, plans to lift him up into the air to be used as target practice.Time returns to normal, and in unison, the squad moves and begins their planned attack.The outsiders don't stand a chance."The Bureau" is the latest addition to the XCOM series of strategy-based, humans vs. aliens games. What separates "The Bureau" from most of the other games in the popular series is how it puts you on the ground with your squad as an individual, rather than a commander seeing everything from above. You're given a third-person perspective of the battlefield, and you're allowed to move around freely like in any other shooter. Unlike any other shooter, however, you're also given the responsibility of giving commands to your squad, lest they stand behind cover and take badly aimed pot-shots at the enemy until the End of Time.That responsibility to command your squad is what makes "The Bureau" an irrefutable part of the "XCOM" series and is also one of the more frustrating functions of the game. "The Bureau" is not a turn-based game. You aren't able to stop the time once a mission begins, which makes timing squad commands a very difficult thing to manage, especially in the middle of a particularly rough firefight. As a bit of an aid to the player, time does slow down when Carter goes into "command mode," but it doesn't ever seem to be slow enough. Without the top-down view of the battlefield, it's much tougher to send your squad to the exact area that you need, which I suppose is more realistic given your on-the-ground commander perspective of the game, but it also occasionally leaves the player sending his squad to locations where they stand idiotically next to cover and get riddled with laser fire.For that reason, the game really does reward the player for being strategic and patient during the fights in the game. The only problem with that is that the fights start becoming really predictable. You'll be traveling through war-torn America and turn down a street with a view of the road covered with rows of flipped cars and boxes and other types of cover. And suddenly, aliens appear and start running at you!That is how each mission basically goes. You walk around, have two to three fights in carefully prepared battlefields, and then you win. Occasionally, they throw a new enemy at you or some reinforcements drop down in a flanking position so you have to rethink your strategy, but it's never horribly difficult to get yourself out of those situations.If there was ever a reason that I lost a battle, it was because I made a mistake trying to rush through it. A lot of fights feel exactly like the last fight, and you end up just wanting to get through them to get to the other side.There is the RPG element to the game, which is very similar to what was seen in "Enemy Unknown." There are various squad classes, and each one has a skill tree they are able to climb up to get new abilities. That tree is very small however, so the decision process is kind of underwhelming, and any strategy you have during character advancement is rather limited.Like in "Enemy Unknown," you have the ability to customize your squad mates when you hire them, which is a feature I really like in games like this. I love building up teams based on my real-life friends, and I do it every time a game gives me the chance. Typically, those characters are always the first to die, but I still try to do it. I always get attached fastest to characters that I'm able to create, and that bond to to your squad is a key part of the "XCOM" games. The player is able to customize a lot about their squaddies, down to the color of their tie in the suit that they wear into battle. The one thing they can't change is gender. "The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" is a boy's only club, which I suppose goes with the atmosphere of the era the game is set in; just about everything was a boys only club in that time. There is a female NPC character that occasionally helps Carter in battles, so the potential for female teammates was there, but the players just don't get to have access to it. I guess we'll just have to chalk it up to adorable/nostalgic 1960's sexism.One of the things that I found cool and amusing about "The Bureau" is what the typical "XCOM" squad wears into battle. They don't rely on kevlar or any kind of body armor. They go out in their suits. Sure, some do wear camouflage, but most of the squad classes are dressed to the nines for their battle against invaders from space. Agent Carter goes between being dressed like he's a character in "Mad Men" to looking like a twin of Sterling Archer (black turtleneck and all). The "XCOM" squad, Earth's only defense against complete and utter annihilation at the end of super advanced aliens, has never looked as good as they look in "The Bureau."The story of "The Bureau" starts off as nothing special. Earth gets attacked by an alien force, the military is destroyed, and it comes to the brand new XCOM team to overcome this threat. You do all the cliche things that a team working as Earth's last hope would do. You rescue the guy that's an expert in the alien technology. You do your best to save civilian populations. You capture a live outsider. And eventually, use their own technology against them to do an "Independence-Day-Shut-Down-Everything" type of mission. It's really standard stuff with completely average voice-acting carrying you through it all.That said, there are a couple redeeming things about the story. You encounter the first pretty early on - a mysterious virus from the outsiders that infects civilians population and turns them into "Sleepwalkers." They ooze black stuff from their eyes and just walk around in circles repeating whatever it was the last thing they were doing before the ailment completely took hold. They don't attack you; they just continuously mutter their "last words" and walk around aimlessly. It creates a lot of creepy atmosphere in the destroyed American towns in which most of the game's missions take place.In the final act of the game, the story veers dramatically off the path of the predictable and does some crazy stuff that I did not expect. I won't go into it to avoid spoilers, but it's an alright twist with multiple possible endings.I played through "The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" trying really hard to like it. It was interesting at first, but the average story and clunky game play really strayed from what I loved so much about "Enemy Unknown." This newest addition to the "XCOM" series was definitely a risk by developer 2k Marin, especially with the fantastic and immensely popular formula for "Enemy Unknown" sitting right there, and I'm not sure that risk paid off. "The Bureau" just isn't a very interesting game in comparison. It has its moments for sure, but those moments are fleeting and in the end, they're not really memorable. If you're a fan of the "XCOM" series, you probably shouldn't miss what "The Bureau" adds to the series, but if you're looking for something as strategic and difficult as "Enemy Unknown," you're going to be disappointed.But at least you'll be dressed well.6/10

content:
Posted: January 8, 2014
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a third-person tactical shooter set in the 1960's and allows the player to take control of Agent William Carter, a washed up agent with a haunted past. This game is different to the other entries in the XCOM series in that the game does not play like an RTS game or feature an isometric view, and is instead played as a standard cover shooter with an over the shoulder view. Does this make it a good game? Yes.While hardcore fans will of XCOM will find this change of formula jarring, I personally found this formula to be a unique technique and a fresh flavour specific to the XCOM series. While the game plays a bit more like Mass Effect this time around (you can pause the game and command your team mates via a command screen, such as ordering them to move or use special abilities, etc) , it still feels like XCOM, as you still have to take strategic care in how you enter combat situations. I liked how you had to be strategic in how you placed your team mates, and how you must constantly adapt to combat as enemies flank you and draw you out of cover. This made for a tense and enjoyable gameplay experience, and is definitely a must on the harder difficulties. Unfortunately, the AI of your squadmates leaves a lot to be desired, and you will definitely get frustrated by their lack of competence. You will also get frustrated by the generic and often boring characters as well as the lacklustre plotline; this is standard alien-invasion fare, and anyone else looking for a riveting science fiction story will need to look elsewhere. I rarely find moments of the plot interesting, except for the rare dialogue encounters with the aliens themselves, which were a joy to behold. However, none of the other characters offered much in the way of development and voice acting, and I found them bland and uninteresting.The graphics are quite nice, and lots of love and care have been dedicated to the lighting and detailed environments in the game. Many of the details in this game are quite nice, and this game looks extremely good when cranked up to max settings whilst running on DX11.In short? The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a unique yet unusual entry in the XCOM franchise, and is a reward to fans of tactical shooters in general. Despite the occassional stumble in gameplay, incompetent team-mate AI and a lacklustre story, The Bureau is a solid game and I recommend it highly despite its flaws. I give this game a 7.5 / 10.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Despite what the professional reviewers may say about this game, it is a solid third-person shooter. The game mechanics borrow heavily from Mass Effect 1, since you can give orders to squad mates, use alien powers such as lift or summon a friendly blob, and talk to NPC's between missions. Even the dialogue uses the multiple answer wheel from the game. The story is deserving of the XCOM title, contrary to what others may say. I'm not an XCOM elitest, so the fact that this game wasn't an RTS didn't bother me. Enemy Unknown was a great game, and to me The Bureau can proudly call itself an XCOM game as well. The final act has an interesting twist and the post-finale voiceover has a cool nod to EU. The game is not perfect though. Your squad mates are far from intelligent. Alyx Vance or Elizabeth, they are not. They are not completely useless either. Give them an order and they follow it just fine. The problem is that major baby-sitting is required. There are some graphical issues, such as ties clipping through the characters chest, or textures taking some time to load in. As well, there is a base hub you can walk around in-between missions to explore for documents, but there's not much in it. As I said already, The Bureau is a solid third-person shooter with an interesting story, good voice acting, and amazing looking locales. If it's on sale, give it a buy. As for the DLC, it can probably be left alone. Code breakers is a side mission that takes all of 10-15 minutes, the pistol is just that, a pistol, and Hangar 6 is a horde mode style game type that provides some background information on the game's plot. Overall I give The Bureau a  7/10.

content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												'The Bureau' is yet another prequel, this time for 'XCOM: Enemy Unknown', the hard as nails turn-based strategy game. Xcom is mainstreaming and it works rather well: decisions are now made in real time (with a Max Payne like slow mo break when you are commanding your other troops), and you can control 'Carter', the hero, like in any third person shooter. The beginning of the adventure is impressive, going around in the 60s USA under an alien invasion brings back some proper 2K Nostalgia with touches of steampunk (telekinesis, and tesla rifles) but eventually gameplay becomes repetitive as there is no progression like in the first game. Your soldiers only have 5 ranks (but the new turret throwing engineer category is cool) and the levels are totally linear. You just push through with your 3 man team (you can't make it bigger later in the game - even if some NPC do join on certain missions) and there is very little strategy involved. It's probably worth playing on veteran at least for more of a challenge. All in all there are about 20 missions (around a dozen 1-2h major ones and a few 15min minor ones), so it's basically half the gameplay time of the original. The story and dialogue are rather good and the new outsiders with vertical mouths are fun to chat with. You don't have the same sense of Doom and crisis management you felt in the original but it's still pretty fun.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												This game combines good third-person shooter with the field strategy elements in the original xcom games. It has a really nice combat system making you think each of your moves before excuting them. While fun for the first half of the game, I quickly got bored because of the repetitive gameplay. It is basically moving to an area, killing a bunch of ailens, and then move to another area, kill more ailens, etc. and finally get the objective. It gets really boring espicially witout the base-management system in the traditional xcom game. The enemy AI is really good espically if you play on the harder difficulties; however, the friendly AI are really bad. In my play through, my agents got stuck in corners and wouldn't move when I tell them to regroup; they constantly ran into gernades; sometimes stand still for minutes before moving to their assigned location. My most memerable experience was when I got shot down right beside one of my agents. I ordered him to revive me, while the other agent taunts the enemy. But the agent kept on shooting, even after I commanded him several more times to revive me, leading me to die and reload the last checkpoint.As for the story and the interactions between you and the other characters, it is well made and indepth. The characters are intresting and you can read their files to find out more about them. Each characters have different personalities making it very intresting to talk with them.In conclusion, the game is repetitive and sometimes frustrating witht he glitchy friendly AI, however the challenging enemy AI and the intresting story made up for it. I would give it a 5/10 if there was a rating system.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Despite what the professional reviewers may say about this game, it is a solid third-person shooter. The game mechanics borrow heavily from Mass Effect 1, since you can give orders to squad mates, use alien powers such as lift or summon a friendly blob, and talk to NPC's between missions. Even the dialogue uses the multiple answer wheel from the game. The story is deserving of the XCOM title, contrary to what others may say. I'm not an XCOM elitest, so the fact that this game wasn't an RTS didn't bother me. Enemy Unknown was a great game, and to me The Bureau can proudly call itself an XCOM game as well. The final act has an interesting twist and the post-finale voiceover has a cool nod to EU. The game is not perfect though. Your squad mates are far from intelligent. Alyx Vance or Elizabeth, they are not. They are not completely useless either. Give them an order and they follow it just fine. The problem is that major baby-sitting is required. There are some graphical issues, such as ties clipping through the characters chest, or textures taking some time to load in. As well, there is a base hub you can walk around in-between missions to explore for documents, but there's not much in it. As I said already, The Bureau is a solid third-person shooter with an interesting story, good voice acting, and amazing looking locales. If it's on sale, give it a buy. As for the DLC, it can probably be left alone. Code breakers is a side mission that takes all of 10-15 minutes, the pistol is just that, a pistol, and Hangar 6 is a horde mode style game type that provides some background information on the game's plot. Overall I give The Bureau a  7/10.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												Not quite in the same style as XCom: Enemy Unknown, this XCom title takes on a more first person/squad approach.  It's playstyle is a mix between real time and turn based.  To compare it to the original 1990s XCom series, this game's combat system mirrors the attempts at real time integration with turn based strategy which was attempted in the XCom Apocolypse game.  If you're looking for a game similar to XCom Enemy Unknown, this is likely NOT the game for you.  I recommend the DLC of Enemy Within.  If you're looking for a stand-alone, good game, in the XCom universe, that's a mix between FPS, TBS, and RTS, pick up this title.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
												'The Bureau' is yet another prequel, this time for 'XCOM: Enemy Unknown', the hard as nails turn-based strategy game. Xcom is mainstreaming and it works rather well: decisions are now made in real time (with a Max Payne like slow mo break when you are commanding your other troops), and you can control 'Carter', the hero, like in any third person shooter. The beginning of the adventure is impressive, going around in the 60s USA under an alien invasion brings back some proper 2K Nostalgia with touches of steampunk (telekinesis, and tesla rifles) but eventually gameplay becomes repetitive as there is no progression like in the first game. Your soldiers only have 5 ranks (but the new turret throwing engineer category is cool) and the levels are totally linear. You just push through with your 3 man team (you can't make it bigger later in the game - even if some NPC do join on certain missions) and there is very little strategy involved. It's probably worth playing on veteran at least for more of a challenge. All in all there are about 20 missions (around a dozen 1-2h major ones and a few 15min minor ones), so it's basically half the gameplay time of the original. The story and dialogue are rather good and the new outsiders with vertical mouths are fun to chat with. You don't have the same sense of Doom and crisis management you felt in the original but it's still pretty fun.

												Not sure why this game is so hated. It isn't exactly groundbreaking, but it was certainly fun. Pros-Mechanics are fairly easy to figure out-Enemies are varied and enjoyable to fight-Missions aren't terribly difficult, but there are some nasty (and fun!) fights that require some thinking and planning to win-Storyline is a bit of a mystery until later game, but the wait was worth the pay off, imho-If you are an avid XCOM fan like me, this game is a solid shooter entry into our beloved franchiseCons-Storyline is somewhat short, especially for a game that is primarily about the single-player experience-As far as shooters go, this game is average. The basic shooting mechanics aren't going to win any awards. Doesn't mean they are bad though-Even a token multiplayer co-op experience would have been nice

content:

 The Bureau: XCOM Declassified - Compact Review ===> Essential Purchase> Recommended Purchase >> Purchase if on sale > Purchase if greatly discounted> Purchase not recommended=== Challenge Rating (Maximum Difficulty): Medium  Average Longevity (All Missions, No DLCs): 10-12 Hours === Overview This XCOM spin-off detatches itself from the turn-based strategy typical of the series, aiming instead for real time, slowable combat, very similar in style to the system seen in the Mass Effect series, if you happen to be familiar with it.You will be tasked to command a 3-man team and engage various missions against the enemy alien forces, who threathen to destroy humanity. There is character progression, 5 different classes with unique abilities, possibility to manage a fairly sized agent roster, varied weapons and special backapcks to unlock and use.Variety in equipment and skills is good, but the gameplay will basically be skirmish after skirmish with aliens, which is not bad because enemies are also quite varied and lethal, but on the long run it might get boring for players who seek a lot of diversity.However, let's dig into details.=== What is Good + Tactical Real-Time combat system is well done, satisfying, accessible, but deep enough for veterans+ Good variety of weapons, upgrades, skills and enemies to fight+ Collectible diaries, notes, and additional dialogues and tasks are good for extending lore / story+ Good variety of settings for missions+ Artifical Intelligece of enemies is decent, they'll make you sweat in some occasions+ Decent graphics and models [Advice: disable PhysX because it is the cause of 99% of game crashes]=== What is Bad - Artifical Intelligence of Teammates is terrible and they will run into horrible deaths on multiple occasions- Babysitting teammates constantly causes huge headaches and can lead to tactical disasters- Dispatch Missions where you send agents can never fail and they always return successful and upgraded- Certain skill / weapon combinations on single enemies are overpowered, can kill any enemy in seconds if done right- 5 Levels for Teammates fill too fast, over half campaign with no progression, should have been 10 as main character- Difficulty spike in first levels, becomes way easier once you get Alien Weapons, difficulty balance could be better- Most Backpacks have gimmicky passives that are never really useful, only few really are=== RATING: 73 / 100 - A decent XCOM spinoff with some dents and sufficent longevity, worth if on sale.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												If you are a PC player, SAVE YOUR MONEY! The keyboard/mouse controls are the worst I have ever seen in a PC game.  It's like trying to play Beethoven's 5th Symphony on the piano when you've never had a piano lesson. (It can be done but not by many.)If you don't press the correct sequence of movement keys (W,LShift, LShift, for example) you can't do anything (shoot, move, command others). You just stand there getting killed while you try to figure out what keys you are supposed to press that will unfreeze you. Tool tips and commentary appear in various areas of the screen so you don't reallly know where to look. The tutorial, such as it is, flashes by the screen so quickly you often miss the instructions.Perhaps it plays better if you connect a game pad to your PC... I don't know because I don't use a game pad. The story line is decent. For a TPS game the field of view is very limited and, once again, the keyboard controls are an abortion. On top of all of that, even when you do get the right key sequence, the game software is VERY slow to respond (I have an i5 quad core and an Nvidia GTX750, so I don't think it's my gear).Ambitious project. Major FAIL.  Major disappointment.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												The story feels like it was written by a 14 year old who just found out about what conspiracy theories are; the voice acting is at an average AAA level, the gameplay is your standard third person cover shooting, but is dragged down due to enemies being bullet sponges, movement is somewhat fluid, but not nearly as fluid as something like gears of war. The tactical element is close to non-existant; you can send orders to your squad mates, but you'll spend most of your time just sending them back due to them often moving without you ordering them to and placing themselves in bad positions that gets them shot down. Also, the fact that every dying squadmate just comes back, makes death feel unimportant unlike previous XCOM games. Visually it's pretty good looking, but the graphics nor aestetichs will leave a lasting impression on you considering that there are games like Metro: Last Light out there.IMO it's a ♥♥♥♥ you/10 but at some moments I was almost entertained so there's that.

All in a day’s work.)Characters: A-Rank Details: S-Rank (I’ll just say this: if I have to do any evasive maneuver, you’d better hold onto your barf bag with both of your hands.)Tactical demand: B-Rank Story: A-Rank Combat & Controls: S-Rank (Our own guns aren’t good enough anymore! Now they want some crazy ray-guns.)--To conquer all achievements of The Bureau: X-COM Declassified, including the DLC Hangar 6, you will most likely spend around 20 hours. I recommend to start the main campaign on the highest difficulty for ‘Vigilo Confido’ and pick up all other achievements on the way. 												Awesome Game overall , underrated and maligned by all the Hypocrites.-Fluent Gameplay.-Stunning Graphics.-Realtime strategys rather than Roundbased as it was in it's predecessors-RNG is still in the game , but can be minimized by positioning your squad advantageous.-Your choices still have influent on the game.-The Realtime combat system is well made for an 3rd person shooter allowing people with aim to headshot everything.That much being said about how awesome this Game is there are some things that i wanna warn you about..-Requirements are incorrect , game sucks alot more than listed below.-Audio glitches.-The Squad will literally suicide if you don't command them exactly what to do.if you can live with those 3 little cons and the fact that this isn't necessarily a link to the original XCOM's, go pick the game up and ENJOY IT for the  Scifi 3rd Person Shooter with RPG Elements and Realtime Strategy that it is.

Posted: November 10, 2014
												Wow, this game is terrible. Shoddy command mechanics (done better by Mass Effect), dull writing, terrible voice acting, samey combat, and more. The game isn't even sure if it's set in the 1950s or the 1960s either - Sherman tanks are serving alongside M14 rifles and many men still wear hats even though they were on their way out. This game deosn't even have the central mechanic that drove your strategy in XCOM - the capture of materials to upgrade your technology. Sometimes you just find equipment lying around and that's that. No live capture mechanics, no research, nothing. I got this in a Humble Bundle for a fraction of its original price, and I still feel like I paid too much.

												What is it with games now days that try as hard as possible to use as many words as possible? Is this an English class, or do they throw darts and pick what seems "cool"? I suppose an upside is that they don't re-use the same names all the time. Yes I'm looking at you Prince of Persia. Which one? ♥♥♥♥ed if I knew.So XCOM: Enemy Unknown is a top-down RTS where you have six soldiers and can make your own guns to take into- What? Wrong game? We're talking about the other one? Alright...So The Bureau: XCOM Declassified -and yes I have to copy and paste that name every time because it's about as long and complicated as your relationship as your recent sexual partner- is a third person shooter where you can take two brain dead ♥♥♥♥♥ and pick up any gun that seems to have the coolest "pew pew" sounds off the ground. Can I go back to the other XCOM now? No? Another six paragraphs? Alright...So you play as Jimmy Raynor- I mean William Carter who, similarly to Raynor, wears Clichés like he picked up a pile suits made of them at a cheap clothes store and decided to smother himself in them because he didn't wake up dapper enough that morning. His family was murdered, which explains the clothes shop, and he is now haunted by it because of course he is. He must have obtained his grizzly♥♥♥♥♥♥voice by drinking their liquefied corpses. Well, You're supposed to feel sympathy for them but you never have any reason to. I once turned to a friend and say one of his lines in his grizzly as hell voice , but that line could have come anywhere, say... Batman.The story is that Carter made out with this alien chick, probably a bit too rough though, and it turns out that his box of clichés went missing, and the alien chick probably took them to have a little gander. So he goes on a mystical adventure to re-obtain them but is interrupted and escorted by some ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to this Bureau that Carter has never heard about, and pretends doesn't exist, but just like mass effect, everyone sees you as some kind of war hero, and treat you as god, despite you having no idea what the hell is going on.Similar to Mass Effect, you have a choice in what you want to say, with awkward eye-contact, but unlike mass effect, there is not good or evil options, which I suppose is good, so you don't have to decide whether you want to be good, bad, or in the middle which gets you no-♥♥♥♥ing-where. But you also aren't talking to party members with interesting back stories, you talk to random ♥♥♥♥♥ in suits.What the ♥♥♥♥ is with all the suits? Why is everyone in a suit during an alien invasion. Should they not be in armour? Let's put it this way, aliens invade, like they do, and everyone was too busy looking dapper and thought it looked cool. Are they ironically being hipsters? Got'ta wear a suit. Every other game wears armour, so we have to wear suits because we're posh and♥♥♥♥♥♥ Then again, it does make a nice change from dressing up in skulls, pots and pans such as in, say, Borderlands.Maybe I should actually talk about the combat, as that's the only thing that hasn't been terrible so far. So the combat is hopefully good while everything else is quite lackluster.Pahahaha! Good is it ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥! The AI are  about as smart as mother chickens. Something, let's say... A cardboard cut out of a cat lobbed a grenade, the AI yells "Grenade!" then sort of sits on it, aiming to keep it warm and birth a baby chicken because no one else would want a child with them, and then they wonder after about five awkward seconds of me yelling they wonder why their brains are against the wall. So the AI is ♥♥♥♥ed. What about the guns? Well unlike Unknown COM Enemy X you don't make your own weapons from scrap, or research, or days of sitting outside the engineering bay staring at it, and then when it's done you dress it up in a bow tie. and throw a birthday party, and then use it in the field and fan girl about how awesome it is. But in XCOM Bureau Declassified The, you jus sortof find it. Which completely goes against anything in XCOM, where in other games the alien weaponry self destruct so you can't use it.Oh, but don't worry. There's still the regular SMG, Shotgun, Pistol, sniper ect. But there is no special slot for the pistol to go, and you can only hold two guns at a time which feels like Duke Nukem Forever. Euugh! I just thought of Duke Nukem forever, thank you XCOM Declassified Bureau The.Speaking of the pistol, it's completely pointless other than for precision head shotting that do ♥♥♥♥ all within Bureau XCOM The Declassified as enemies have so much health you might as well fire BB pellet's at their powderizd uterus. Though the pistol reminds me of Tomb Raider's combat. The new one that is, not the old one. I'm reminded of it due to the way you can sit behind a chest high wall and make a nice sized hole in their head. Or uterus. Oh ♥♥♥♥ me how have I not mentioned chest <dry heave> chest high walls. The game puts chest high walls -or cars- anywhere that there is some kind of combat. Even if you had to swat a fly, suddenly chest high walls fall from space and crush the fly that you were fighting. Thanks a ♥♥♥♥ing lot now get out my game. When you try to move on, carter just cello tapes to any wall that he happens to subtly brush past, as if he's scared of the next room, or he's trying to tell you something but he's a man of cliché's and can't be arsed. Oh, but when you actually do enter combat he refuses to stick to the damn wall. On multiple occasions I exited a cut scene, which threw me into combat, I ran at a wall, He swiftly avoided it and straight into open, and got gunned down. So I then turned around, in attempt to get to the wall, and he ran straight past it again and dropped dead. So my partners panicked, and tried to revive me by running in the complete opposite direction and get headshot.All in all, my favourite part of the game was that at the end you have to go on a suicide mission with the chosen one- What? Wrong game? I was talking about the XCOM: Enemy Unknown? Sorry, I was playing XCOM: Enemy Unknown, It's a top-down RTS that 2K gave us while threatening to make this garbage- oh no The Bureau has gone playing with the birds again. I'd better call the 020-9ADVICE-ON-BETTER-GAMES

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												The Bureau Xcom Declassified was at first an FPS but then it got scrapped and we got a strategic Third person shooter but will you want to play this game ? In the Bureau you play as William Carter who is a CIA agent who is trying to deliver an artifact to a secret goverment facility but an Alien Invasion happens and its up to you to stop the alien invasion. So how is this game ? Its actually quite good and the reviews for this are way too harsh because its not that bad actually. So first of all if you like mass effect you will simply love this game because theres alot of things similar to Mass Effect. Like the talk wheel and also the combat is quite similar. So now for the good. Amazing story with twist and turns along the way which is a great expierence. The game has a huge hub before the missions and in missions the maps are quite good. The game is quite short maybe 7 to 6 hours long. The game also graphiclly looks great. The combat is fun and simple all the diffrent members are awesome to use in the battlefield. now for the bad. The game might get repetetive after a while and the talking sections might drive you insane sometimes. Some bugs as well. So overall The Bureau: Xcom Declassified is a great game which you should own no matter if youre an Xcom fan or not. I Give The Bureau: Xcom Declassified a 8/10.Now for the the dlcFirst of all we have the Light Plasma Pistol. Its a great weapon which pretty much one shots everything so if you want to breeze through the game get it. I give the Light Plasma Pistol DLC a 8/10Now for the Codebreakers mission. In the mission you play as Carter who goes to a radio transmission facility after the alien invasion because it went silent. Overall this mission is only 10 minutes long and is not worth the full price only get it on sale i give the Code Breakers Dlc a 4/10And finnaly we have Hangar 6 R and D. In this dlc pack you play as Nico DaSilva before the events that lead to the main game. In this Dlc you work on a SleepWalker case and you try to relive the memories of the victim to find out whats causing the infection. Overall This dlc is amazingly bad. All you do is fight waves of enemies every level and it gets boring incredibly fast. This Dlc is also quite buggy as well. Only get this dlc on sale For the achievements or to witness how it all began. I give Hangar 6 R and D a 3/10

												after quite a few hrs,,and a stab at the dlcs that added quest and missions(i bought a 2k games bundle that had this in it..so i was only out the 5 bucks for dlc that was on steam sale)...i havent been disapointed...i played..and was entertained...it had story..and reminded me of 60's sci-fi...if not used to mass effect...the game could be overwhelming to some...and the bugs mentioned in the other coimments..they must have fixed by the time i played..my system is nothing special...ran it both in dx9 and dx 11.. ran ok either way...i could see spending 15 bucks on it for steam sale..20 bucks with dlc.. i thought the game was goodthe problem with most reviewers/reviews is that they compare games to other games....you see it all the timehow i rate games..i rate on entertainment value...think of a movie for example...buy a dvd or go to a theater(i prefer theater as an example)....thats using something simple.. $10 dollars for ticket..anything else is extra...so if just basics 10 bucks for 2hrs...to me thats fair for entertainmentwas the game more like work or play?...was the game entertaining..did i play more than the hours i would have spent on price if same amount spent in movies(equation example..$50/10=5x2=10hrs) right now game lists on steam for 20...have i played more than 4 hrs... yep.......was i entertained...yep.......will i play again...maybe...was the game too hard...nope...was it too easy...nope...would you recomend it to your friends.....depends on the friend.. gamers yes...posers(ones that think the game has to look good for it to be good) nope.....i will give it a 7/10...ive played better and i have played a hell of a lot worse

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 10, 2014
												I was pretty disappointed in this game.  There was 1 gem, the rest was very underwhelming.Gameplay: highly repetative.  Every level is a corridor.  You skill up quickly and you're using max level agents all with the same abilities for more than half the game.  Gun play and cover system feels like it was ripped directly from Mass Effect.Story: *Spolier warning* highly problematic.  While it reuses the familiar aliens, some of them are jumbled up in terms of ability and concept.  We can tell this game is intended as a prequel to Enemy Unkown (which I played first), based on general story elements and the music (ending music for The Bureau is the theme for Enemy Unknown).  In EU the aliens are all controlled by the Etherials, in TB the Outsiders control all the aliens.  EU: Outsider is a "being of pure energy" while the Etherial is physicalish.  TB: Etherial is pure energy, Outsiders are very tangible.Also, if you get any of the "good" endings in TB, you have to wonder why you don't start out EU with plasma weapons and cool backpacks that give you shields and other goodies.  The only logical conclusion is that you chose the Weaver ending...which is an annoying ending as you watch all the tech vanish for no good reason.*Major Spoiler* Continuity aside, there is one well written section where gameplay and story meld together to form a cool experience.  It's the point where Carter tries to break away from the Etherial that you realize, you haven't been playing Carter, you've playing as Asaru controlling Carter, and all of the Player based abilities to slow time and issue orders while gaining a 3rd person view of the field is merely a part of Asaru's abilities when riding a host.  That was well written.  Whoever did that ought to write more games.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2015
												The 60's setting could be so nice, something fresh. The idea of a Squad shooter in XCOM Universe sounded interesting. Bought it in a Sale and now after almost 5h i gave up on it.The game runs awfully(Core i5 4500K - 8GB DDR3 RAM - Raedon R9 280X OC)- In the First Mission you go to a Small town and the first combat ran at 5 - 10 FPS. Try managing your Squad like this -.-- Shadow and light flickering randomly- Switching to or from DX11 didn't help at all. get to the townsquare, FPS goes downhill.- The AI is a Joke for a Squad based game. You are more busy, trying to keep these Idiots alive than actually combating somehting. Even if you manually order them to a cover, they manage to get shot behind that cover in about 10 seconds. because these idiots mostly pop their heads out right when the enemy starts shooting.In the First 2 Missions i spent more time running between my Squadmates, reviving them, at app. 20 FPS than doing anything other. TL;DR:Don't Buy. The cool 60's Flair isn't worth it. The game get's this flair because it's a secret timemachine, warping your PC back to the 60's too.

content:
Posted: May 23, 2014
												I wish I would have given The Bureau: XCOM Declassified the time of day a while ago. Having played it now, I can see that I was wrong to judge it based solely on it’s cover. The Bureau is a fantastic game. Once they can figure out how to work A.I. a bit smarter without creating a robotic uprising ending in the near extinction of humanity, games like this will get drastically better. Not having your allies shove their faces into bullets will be a great addition to most games. The cursor thing is still my biggest gripe though. I know you can increase the range of abilities, but that only partially fixes the problem. The cursor movement in this game needed a bit more love. The looks, sounds, and most of the voice acting were all great to experience if you just weren’t ripped back into reality when your cursor wouldn’t do something properly. Having the live action fights and a 3rd person shooter aspect were a nice way to change up the XCOM series. I hope we see a sequel someday.Full Review: TheVideogameBacklog.com

Posted: October 20, 2015
												I picked up this game on a steam sale, amid the lackluster reviews. While the general concept of the game was good, the story and the replayability is seriously lacking. I was hoping for a first person take on the popular X-COM games of late. This game was too linear, and too short. Side missions were pointless. Tons of backpack upgrades, but for what? With a team of only 3, you're left with very few choices. If you're an X-COM fan and this is cheap, pick it up. If you're on the fence, wait until the next X-COM game or pick up the OTHER X-COM titles.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Bureau is an interesting departure from the norm for the XCOM series. It sees the hero battling through aliens in a 3rd person semi tactical interface using special powers and abilities to overcome foes through the complementary skills of the squad as a whole. Use a turret to pin enemies down then stealth a squad member around the side to flank and kill them. The graphics are pretty good but it is a bit of a system hog needing a hefty PC to run at full detail levels. Whilst the gameplay is in no ways bad it is not exemplary and plays pretty much like a re-skinned Mass Effect 3 but without as detailed or engrossing a storyline. Worth a budget price or interest from fans of the series.

												เกมส์ยังทำได้ไม่ดีเท่าที่ควรทั้งระบบการเล่น เนื้อเรื่อง ที่ควรได้รับการขัดเกลาเพิ่มเติมให้ดีกว่านี้1.ระบบการเล่น เป็นแอคชัน+วางแผน ซึ่งทำได้น่าสนใจ(ในตอนแรกที่ดูตัวอย่าง) เราไม่สามารถยืนโชว์พาวรับกระสุนได้ต้องหลบหลังที่กำบังและใช้การวางแผน แต่พอเล่นจริงกลับเจอเรื่องขัดใจอยู่ไม่น้อยไม่ว่าจะเป็นการเลือกสกิลต่างๆ ที่ไม่ลื่นใหล การสั่งให้เพื่อนยิงเป้าหมายหนึ่งแต่กลับไปยิงอีกเป้าหมายหนึ่ง เป็นต้น    1.1 รูปแบบการเล่นจะคล้ายๆ mass effect คือวิ่งๆ คุย แล้วไปสู้ในฉากๆนึง แต่ขอโทษเหอะมันไม่ได้สนุกเหมือน mass effect เลย          กับการวิ่งๆคุยๆเนี่ย ถึงจะมีการตอบคำถามแต่ก็เป็นแค่การถามเรื่องราวต่างๆเพิ่มเติม ไม่ได้มีผลกระทบกับเนื้อเรื่องเลย    1.2 ตัวละครเราพัฒนาความสามารถได้ตื้นเขินมากๆ ไม่หลากมีความหลากหลายเท่าที่ควร     1.3 ศัตรูและอาวุธมีน้อยนิดถึงจะเปลี่ยนรูปร่างไปบ้างแต่วิธีกำจัดก็เหมือนกัน ไม่มีความท้าทาย2.AI ที่ขาดๆเกิน ฉลาด รู้จะหลบหลังที่กำบัง รู้จักมาโอบล้อมเรา เพิ่มเลือด/เกราะให้เพื่อน แต่ให้ตายเหอะบางทีอยู่ใกล้กันจนจมูกจะแตะกันพี่แกยังไม่เห็นเลย โถๆ 3.บั๊คคคคคคคคค มีอยู่ด่านหนึ่งที่ถ้าคุณไม่เจอบั๊คก็ถือว่าโชคดี แต่หากคุณโชคร้ายเหมือนผมคุณจะไปเจอกับบัคที่ร้ายแรงอย่างการตกฉากตายแบบงงๆ าทงแก้เดียวที่ทำได้คือต้องรีคอมใหม่ ผมลองรีเซตภารกิจ หรือ โหลดออโตเซพก่อนหน้าก็ไม่หาย จนเกือบได้เลิกเล่น4.เนื้อเรื่องเฉยๆมากไม่ได้น่าติดตามเท่าไรเลย ช่วงต้นเกมส์คือช่วงสนุกสุดแล้วมั้งสรุป 6.5/10 แนะนำให้ซื้อตอนมันลดราคานะ ถือว่าเล่นได้เพลินๆถ้าไม่คิดไรมาก

content:
Posted: February 15, 2016
												Deeply lacking in originality ..  It pains me to see the XCOM ip used on this.I was so bored, I started dissecting what could have possibly went through the producers minds as they hacked this game together." Kids like that Mass Effect game, let's take their tactical system .. "" Oh !  You know what else they like ?  That wrist thingy from Fallout 4, and Fedoras! "This is not to say that it isn't satisfying to have your team go to point A while you lay cover fire, and have them shoot at bad guys.  In a way, it made me think of XCOM agents drawing attention from hostiles and fighting tactically ..But it's buried behind gimmicks stolen from other games that it hardly feels like XCOM at all.Just some creativeless, soulless use of an IP that just happened to have been noticed by some AAA producers.After beating the second mission, I talked to everyone and read every bit of detail and thought to myself ..  Do I really want to put myself through another round of ..  Go here, tell my two agents to move to A and shoot at enemies that can't find cover and spam abilities ?  There's nothing hard about, no creative solutions.Immersion breaking in how often you'll find yourself cut off from a shortcut because you can't do a pullup onto a platform ..  That and all of your other agents are being shipped in Ammo Crates too so you can switch them out in mid mission.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												There are numerous factors to this game, some are positive, some are negative but overall I believe the balance is tipped towards the negative side. I will cover each factor to keep the review clean.StoryThe game has an interesting and overall fresh setting which I have to admit I liked a lot. Coldwar era, everyone scared of Reds, and overall one can't help but wonder that in such an era, where not just disbelief and distrust hinder the human side but even technically, they are way behind than the "modern" human resistance of Xcom: Enemy unknown, a game from the same developers, that is connected to this one.On the other hand the story develops towards open confrontation with the aliens which makes the whole thing unbelievable - especially after the developers going out of their way of providing hints about the connection with the other Xcom game, where we know nothing about previous alien encounters... while an open war with aliens ought to be something hard to forget for humanity.Even not considering the connection to the other game's storyline, it feels strange that while we are practically in open war with the aliens yet it just doesn't feel like it.  Aand this is where gameplay kicks in.GameplayYou control the protagonist, commanding a small team of men, issuing tactical orders in the heat of battle. Sounds nice. Problem is the way this plays out.Control can be truly clunky at times, certain abilities do things that just doesn't seem logical (an ability that forces an enemy out of cover looks the same as any other shot etc.) or just plain skip explanation how they do it but what truly kills it is the ai. Dishing out orders can be a pain while under fire and while time slows to a near complete halt you find yourself panicing. Not because of enemies outnumbering you or anything but simply because even seemingly solid orders can get yourself killed since your teammates tend to perform actions in a suicidal manner. That becomes apparent first when you are hit by a grenade attack and they either run away in fear (mostly right towards the enemy, exposing themselves even with tons of cover around, etc.) or just stay and get fried. Another problem is the effect of cover which tends to be erratic. You are in cover yet the enemy seems to have no problem whatsoever hitting you - and your teammates die fast.Enemies tend to be foolish too and while they do expose a lot of themselves it is still hard to take them down - even the weakest sectoids. Sure, later you can get upgraded equipment but honestly, when I see an enemy that is supposeldy physically weak (sectoids) soak up 10+ shots to the head from a carbine without flinching... I feel somewhat annoyed.GraphicsThe game has what it takes to provide proper visuals while it's engine would be capable of far more realistic looks - this art style is alright. Certainly not the best looking one around (even considering age) but no problem. On the other hand the design of certain things can be... strange, even forced.Some aliens look like the generally known versions, greys etc., modelled practically the same way as the ones in Xcom Enemy Unkown, thus providing a certain amount of consistency which is always nice while the other group of enemies consist of metallic... machines?... mainly following a geometric theme. Both groups are fine on their own but making them appear together, they just don't fit. Not because alien enemies cannot be diverse and varied or sorts - simply because the technological level of the metallic enemies seem to vastly outclass the "flesh and blood" enemies, resulting in a difference that makes one think that they are not even from the same game.Overall the game can be good, with enough patience you can ignore the problems I have mentioned... but honestly, not worth it. Ai and controls are core mechanics, if they are messed up, your whole experience will be plagued by fails that you can hardly do anything about. I as a player don't like it when the game just decides that I win or lose and honestly, that's how this felt.

												First of all, this isn't a bad game. I just wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Why? Because this game is essentially a 11 hour stripped down version of mass effect. Even the story shares similarities...+ Looks pretty good+ Story isn't that bad+ General gameplay is pretty good+ Most of the characters are pretty good (not much character development though, unless you want to read through every single 'note' in the game.- Main character is an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥- Had some fps issues every now and then- Had some lighting/shadow issues every now and then- Game is super short - timescale doens't really seem realistic within game- AI team is pretty useless in terms of kills and positioningIf you like the look of this game then just buy Mass Effect. You'll get more hours out of it and it's way better. (Apart from the first one... that sucks). If you've played Mass Effect and want something similar then this isn't a bad choice. Pick it up if it's on sale. 6/10

content:
Posted: March 22, 2015
												I really dont understand all the frack this game is getting, it doesnt deserve to be a "Mixed" rated review game. Ive played all XCom games on release and i have not liked them all but this one i gotta say it tooked me by suprise. Its NOT your regular XCOM game, that much is obvious, but its a new a fresh approach to the XCOM universe. It gives you the chance to explore the lore and the real fisical instalations of a base like no previous game let you before, you get to talk to engineers, researchers, medics, coms, etc, increasing the game imersion in the XCOM world and has the bonus of happening in the 60´s, the golden era... Elvis, James Dean, milkshakes, jukeboxes, rock&roll, its Back to the future man!!! The Graphics are very good, sound and music are top notch and the voice acting is prob one of the best ive seen in games so far. The story is quite good and the gameplay is not that diferent from what we have seen from the past, the only diference is that we have to develop our tactics alot faster now which in this case makes the action parts alot faster paced. The only regret ive got its that it ends, i really want more of this.

												เกมส์ยังทำได้ไม่ดีเท่าที่ควรทั้งระบบการเล่น เนื้อเรื่อง ที่ควรได้รับการขัดเกลาเพิ่มเติมให้ดีกว่านี้1.ระบบการเล่น เป็นแอคชัน+วางแผน ซึ่งทำได้น่าสนใจ(ในตอนแรกที่ดูตัวอย่าง) เราไม่สามารถยืนโชว์พาวรับกระสุนได้ต้องหลบหลังที่กำบังและใช้การวางแผน แต่พอเล่นจริงกลับเจอเรื่องขัดใจอยู่ไม่น้อยไม่ว่าจะเป็นการเลือกสกิลต่างๆ ที่ไม่ลื่นใหล การสั่งให้เพื่อนยิงเป้าหมายหนึ่งแต่กลับไปยิงอีกเป้าหมายหนึ่ง เป็นต้น    1.1 รูปแบบการเล่นจะคล้ายๆ mass effect คือวิ่งๆ คุย แล้วไปสู้ในฉากๆนึง แต่ขอโทษเหอะมันไม่ได้สนุกเหมือน mass effect เลย          กับการวิ่งๆคุยๆเนี่ย ถึงจะมีการตอบคำถามแต่ก็เป็นแค่การถามเรื่องราวต่างๆเพิ่มเติม ไม่ได้มีผลกระทบกับเนื้อเรื่องเลย    1.2 ตัวละครเราพัฒนาความสามารถได้ตื้นเขินมากๆ ไม่หลากมีความหลากหลายเท่าที่ควร     1.3 ศัตรูและอาวุธมีน้อยนิดถึงจะเปลี่ยนรูปร่างไปบ้างแต่วิธีกำจัดก็เหมือนกัน ไม่มีความท้าทาย2.AI ที่ขาดๆเกิน ฉลาด รู้จะหลบหลังที่กำบัง รู้จักมาโอบล้อมเรา เพิ่มเลือด/เกราะให้เพื่อน แต่ให้ตายเหอะบางทีอยู่ใกล้กันจนจมูกจะแตะกันพี่แกยังไม่เห็นเลย โถๆ 3.บั๊คคคคคคคคค มีอยู่ด่านหนึ่งที่ถ้าคุณไม่เจอบั๊คก็ถือว่าโชคดี แต่หากคุณโชคร้ายเหมือนผมคุณจะไปเจอกับบัคที่ร้ายแรงอย่างการตกฉากตายแบบงงๆ าทงแก้เดียวที่ทำได้คือต้องรีคอมใหม่ ผมลองรีเซตภารกิจ หรือ โหลดออโตเซพก่อนหน้าก็ไม่หาย จนเกือบได้เลิกเล่น4.เนื้อเรื่องเฉยๆมากไม่ได้น่าติดตามเท่าไรเลย ช่วงต้นเกมส์คือช่วงสนุกสุดแล้วมั้งสรุป 6.5/10 แนะนำให้ซื้อตอนมันลดราคานะ ถือว่าเล่นได้เพลินๆถ้าไม่คิดไรมาก

												I love 1950-60 games. And I love this one too. Everything is fitting and the commander mode is very smooth. It feels like I am actually one of the units in 'Enemy Unknown'. There are some main complaints I have about the game tho'. The glitches, they are not common, but they get in your way. Also the AI is horrible. All I wanted one of my men to do was come to my cover, but he just ran infront of our enemy. Also, its not so much something bad, but annoying, he calls every dead person he sees a  "Poor b######". I understand if he knew them or like they were trapped and had now way to help themselves. But come on.Over all, its good but not worth $30. Get it on a sale for about %40 or higher. I doubt you will be too dissapointed.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												There are numerous factors to this game, some are positive, some are negative but overall I believe the balance is tipped towards the negative side. I will cover each factor to keep the review clean.StoryThe game has an interesting and overall fresh setting which I have to admit I liked a lot. Coldwar era, everyone scared of Reds, and overall one can't help but wonder that in such an era, where not just disbelief and distrust hinder the human side but even technically, they are way behind than the "modern" human resistance of Xcom: Enemy unknown, a game from the same developers, that is connected to this one.On the other hand the story develops towards open confrontation with the aliens which makes the whole thing unbelievable - especially after the developers going out of their way of providing hints about the connection with the other Xcom game, where we know nothing about previous alien encounters... while an open war with aliens ought to be something hard to forget for humanity.Even not considering the connection to the other game's storyline, it feels strange that while we are practically in open war with the aliens yet it just doesn't feel like it.  Aand this is where gameplay kicks in.GameplayYou control the protagonist, commanding a small team of men, issuing tactical orders in the heat of battle. Sounds nice. Problem is the way this plays out.Control can be truly clunky at times, certain abilities do things that just doesn't seem logical (an ability that forces an enemy out of cover looks the same as any other shot etc.) or just plain skip explanation how they do it but what truly kills it is the ai. Dishing out orders can be a pain while under fire and while time slows to a near complete halt you find yourself panicing. Not because of enemies outnumbering you or anything but simply because even seemingly solid orders can get yourself killed since your teammates tend to perform actions in a suicidal manner. That becomes apparent first when you are hit by a grenade attack and they either run away in fear (mostly right towards the enemy, exposing themselves even with tons of cover around, etc.) or just stay and get fried. Another problem is the effect of cover which tends to be erratic. You are in cover yet the enemy seems to have no problem whatsoever hitting you - and your teammates die fast.Enemies tend to be foolish too and while they do expose a lot of themselves it is still hard to take them down - even the weakest sectoids. Sure, later you can get upgraded equipment but honestly, when I see an enemy that is supposeldy physically weak (sectoids) soak up 10+ shots to the head from a carbine without flinching... I feel somewhat annoyed.GraphicsThe game has what it takes to provide proper visuals while it's engine would be capable of far more realistic looks - this art style is alright. Certainly not the best looking one around (even considering age) but no problem. On the other hand the design of certain things can be... strange, even forced.Some aliens look like the generally known versions, greys etc., modelled practically the same way as the ones in Xcom Enemy Unkown, thus providing a certain amount of consistency which is always nice while the other group of enemies consist of metallic... machines?... mainly following a geometric theme. Both groups are fine on their own but making them appear together, they just don't fit. Not because alien enemies cannot be diverse and varied or sorts - simply because the technological level of the metallic enemies seem to vastly outclass the "flesh and blood" enemies, resulting in a difference that makes one think that they are not even from the same game.Overall the game can be good, with enough patience you can ignore the problems I have mentioned... but honestly, not worth it. Ai and controls are core mechanics, if they are messed up, your whole experience will be plagued by fails that you can hardly do anything about. I as a player don't like it when the game just decides that I win or lose and honestly, that's how this felt.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												This is a poorly made pile of garbage that should've never seen release. Even knowing that there's new dlc for it makes me want nothing more than my money back, and some mind bleach so I can forget I ever played it.Allow me to go into detail as to why:First and foremost, the game isn't finished. There are graphical and technical glitches all over the place, but not so much as to make the game unplayable. The game also looks like something from 2003, but with an extreme bloom filter and some shiney guns. Remember the whole research and progressing threat thing from xcom? Yeah, that's nowhere to be found in here. You have a series of very linear missions, with some side missions, and a cast of side characters who really are completely underdeveloped. Your soldiers all have one voice. One voice, with no variations, like in xcom EU/EW.The only condition I'd see as feasible ground for buying this pile of donkey♥♥♥♥♥♥would be if the developers were holding you ransom, with a gun to your freaking head, and were telling you to buy it. It took me about 14 hours to beat, so I guess it's kind of a long-ish game, but so's getting your♥♥♥♥♥♥probed with a spoon. A long game isn't necessarily a good thing, if the game itself is garbage.The only really good thing I can say is that there's a relatively good twist at the end. It actually comes very close to being the best part of the game for me--but it's at the end, so the best part was when I finally beat this pile of♥♥♥♥♥♥ and uninstalled it. In short: DO NOT BUY UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												edit: this game keeps crashing randomly. Thumbs down period.This game attempts to lift off but sort of falls flat while doing so.I havent't played any of the XCOM games but from what I've read from other reviews, it doesn't come close to the XCOM series.The pros:Graphics aren't bad.You can achieve success in battles by correctly positioning your guys.The game pulls off a 1960s era feel.The cons:Controls feel clunky and awkward, making running, crouching and taking cover clumsy at times.You will wrestle with your character as he takes cover when all you want him to do is run away.The options to select different conversational points with characters in the game when you are not in a mission allows for greater depth and exploration of the story. But you can simply go to the next mission without speaking to everyone. At one point before you go on the ship, the game has you literally go back and forth between Faulke and characters in another section of the headquarters. I am literally running from one place to the next. Thank god there is a skip button for the boring conversation.Off-mission you are pretty much relegated to running around headquarters talkign to people. Because of the size of the complex, it gets boring fast having to weave back and forth from one room to the next. It's not very easy to keep track of all of your goals after having spoken to someone and they change the second some new information comes up. 45 minutes into this game you realize that the game is B O R I N G.6/10

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 26, 2014
												STOP! Don't spend full price on this game. Its not worth it. Here's why:The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a game that went through tremendous development hell. In its early stages, as the game was being made, there was a tremendous backlash from fans of the original X-Com series. The problem was the use of the name X-Com for a game that had none of the look or relation to the original X-Com series outside of alien invasion. If 2K simply called it The Bureau UFO Invasion Declassified, they could've made the game as intended... But no, they stubbornly decided to keep the X-Com name attached to the project which only served to severely interfere with and cripple its development process. Playing this game, its clear it was far along in development before the s*** hit the fan, and the project stalled as 2K struggled with methods to make the game more familiar to fans of the original X-com (by finding ways to make references to 2K's X-com reboot. A game I don't think would have been made if The Bureau X-com Declassified didn't♥♥♥♥♥♥off those fans of the original X-com)The result is a 3rd person shooter whose quality swings between mediocre and ok. Periodically you'll come across areas and level designs that seem overly generic and somewhat rushed or unfinished. The Bureau also has a sort of identity crisis by featuring Enemy Unknown fodder enemies fighting along side the aliens unique to this game.The story itself is a trainwreck. The end game story isn't just insulting and confusing, its practically nonsensical. Without spoiling anything, its hard not to feel bad for agent Carter.Personally, I find the game ok at best. I've already played it to completion on PS3 and I wouldn't recommend it. Especially not to an X-com fan. The only reason I have it is Steam keeps running a sale where you can buy X-Com Enemy Unknown and get this game with it for spare change.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												All I remember about this game is  hating it just based on the idea of it. I've played every Xcom since the release day of the original UFO Defense, and have logged more time in it over the years than I have spent sleeping and eating combined. I've seen some horrible attempts at shoe-horning IPs into every new hot genre to come to gaming, and they all stunk. So when I saw the previews of Mad Men Vs Giant Oil Spills, I thought it was the dumbest thing yet to happen to a franchise that had been abused like a prisoner of war over the years.While it is horrible on almost every computer that tries to run it (the framerate will dive so bad, that the audio stutters), the design of the game (think Gears of War without the size 85 boots) is fun. But where this game REALLY steps out and earns its recommendation is the story and it's presentation. If you set your graphics filter to 'film grain' the game really comes to life as a period piece of fiction.The dialogue is amateurish as many of the characters seem to have an uncanny grasp of modern slang (including the aliens!) and use language and phrases not accurate to the time period, but the story still works on a fundamental level. If you are a die hard XCOM fan who passed on this just out of defiance, you'll find that the only existance of anything XCOM is more along the lines of an easter egg rather than an actual theme. (You hear many references to the SKYRANGER, but when you see it, the few chuckles you get are worth it).get this game on sale, and play it - you'll enjoy it.

												who doesn't love 1960s cops?. Anyway, The Graphics were great, Gameplay was also great. You can actually command you group of officers where to move and who to atack so that's pretty cool. But come to the minors, You can't actually jump. yes that's right no jump button otherthan the jumping over boxes or ledges no regualar jumps. the mouth movement during dialogue was also good and the story and mystery of the game is brilliant. There are actually some pretty cool upgrades, after you get your hands on enemy weaponry you can lift a target and have your squad gang up on him, or you can push them back with a burst of the outsider guns. Each Squad member has his own specialties like taunting, critical strike etc. which make it interesting to explore the potential of all squad members. The Controls were pretty simple i really enjoy the game. 8/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2014
												I bought this game for only $4.99, so my judgement of this game would be quite different from someone who purchased it for $59.99. That being said, the game is good as it is bad. The story starts out pretty good, but by the end, becomes little more than incomprehensible gibberish. The combat is solid enough, and forces you to use cover, but enemies love grenade spam tactics. To make it worse, the snap-lock cover can become really finicky and stick you to places you rather not be ending your life with a quick dose of lasers and grenades. I like the reliance on abilites, including your squadmates, however, the pitiful AI makes more than half encounters end in fustruation as you are forced to babysit them and manually extract any real use out of them. DirectX11 API is broken with framerates dipping into the low 20's, and this is on a very powerful rig. The graphics are pretty, nothing exceptional but the variance of American landscapes powered by Unreal 3 is a nice treat to the eyes. The Alien locales, on the other hand, are of the generic "shiny grey metallic tile" SCI-FI variety.The best way to summarize this game is to call it a inferior Mass Effect clone set in 1962. It is by no means a bad game, and surely worth $4.99 in entertainment money, but to expect more from such a quality developer of the Bioshock games, you'll only end up dissapointed.

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												I tried this game at a friends for a couple of hours, loved it, then bought it. I quickly noticed it isn't worth more than $15 due to one main thing: the intelligence of your teammates. If it weren't for your teammates doing bonehead things often, like instead of, when ordered, relocating to behind a wall they go in front of it and get ♥♥♥♥ing shot down instantly, this game probably would have gotten much higher scores from critics. So far, in only the second mission that I have played, the sound glitched out half way through a mission and I could weirdly only hear a few sound effects and the sound kept doing a static glitch in and out that I have never heard before in a game. Even after restarting the game, the mission was still sound-bugged. Thankfully, the next two missions I did were not. The auto-save function during play is done kinda poorly. Whenever it autosaves, which is often, it does a hard lag-lock stutter for a second. Something else that is very annoying, sometimes my graphics settings revert back to default when I launch and I have to change them back and restart the game.The Difficulty - There is no middle ground in the difficulty, there are four choices. It's like do I want to play just above noob mode or just below get murdered instantly mode? No medium difficulty is inexcusable in any game. especially this one, and here is why:Your ♥♥♥♥ing teammate AI is some of the dumbest AI I have ever seen in a game. On the 3rd difficulty, veteran, they just get downed instantly in fights forcing you to go pick them up and then YOU get downed. But you have no choice because if you lose a guy that is a high rank that you have been working on for a long time, he is gone for good. And even if you command them to go to a certain spot, they will still eventually randomly reposition, meaning they stand up and take massive dmg from enemy fire while taking the stupidest route possible to their next cover, ignoring the cover they could be using to get there. But this does not always happen, thankfully. If I had known that when your teammates die they are dead permanently, I would have seriously rethought buying this game. There is nothing on this earth more frustrating than losing something you worked hard for because of the AI being the dumbest AI I have seen in a very long time in a game. Why even have perma-death when it would be stupid to accept it when it is a far superior idea to just reload a checkpoint? The only way to combat this is by setting the difficulty to level 2 out of 4. If you tell your teammate to reposition, they do not always do it intelligently. I told my guy to move to a new spot and assumed he would use the provided cover, which there was plenty of, to work his way to the spot. No. He stood up and ran across the middle of the battlefield, took massive dmg, then was downed at his new spot instantly. Having literally no choice but to run and pick him up so he didn't die and I lose him for good, I ran to pick him up and was also downed because while reviving you are exposed, and it was mission fail, restart at checkpoint.To be fair, playing on veteran mode is entirely possible, it is just not fun at all because of how the developers decided to make your teammates ♥♥♥♥ing stupid bags of sh-t. And when it is time to gear up before a mission, there is zero point whatsoever in taking more than two seconds to know what backpacks to have your teammates wear since they are stupid as f-ck and will be often taking dmg when they should not be: A PACK THAT REDUCES ALL ENEMY DMG like the Guardian Pack! The fact that they give you the option to give them other packs is a slap in the face when you can/should only choose the one I said. And their skill trees have choices, lol. Again, if you have any brains, you will choose the skills in their trees that are going to best help them survive longer, and if they have none of those, choose skills that aim to help support you in whatever way possible or get a different squad mate.Besides all of this ignorant programming done by blindfolded starved caged confused monkeys headbutting/jumping on typewriters, the game is actually really fun provided you are playing on "squaddie" difficulty and nothing higher, unless you are a pretentious liar who says "no man it's fine I enjoy it on the highest difficulty you just need to get better". Keep lying to yourself, queer.On a more positive note, the whole idea of a 3rd person shooter in which you can at any time hit space bar and give orders to your teammates (which is the only thing that keeps them alive) and everyone has cool down timer skills is a great idea and when your teammates aren't doing stupid sh-t and ruining the fun, is a blast to play. When everything is going well, I find myself having a great time. The skills are cool and fun and the weapons are your standard fun fare, plus alien energy weapons which are cool and fun to use so far. It can sometimes depend on the situation, but if I had to give someone one tip about this game and one only, it would be take a short or mid-range gun like a assault rifle or shotgun, and ALWAYS keep a sniper rifle as your secondary weapon, especially if you are trying to play in veteran mode. Every head shot you can get with it, regardless of the mode you are in, is a precious thing that can turn a battle from total catastrophe and losing teammates, to a decisive victory. Yes, the sniper rifle is that important, provided you have good aim and get lucky and your dumb as rocks teammates haven’t gotten downed by the time you can snipe anything. Giving orders to your squad is very simple and intuitive and they perform what you want the first time, so no re-issuing orders are needed.The sounds are great (minus the God awful glitch I encountered on only the second mission) and the graphics are above average, except when textures are still filling/popping in and it looks like minecraft for a few seconds. That does not happen often though, thankfully. The best part about the game are the effects which are done quite well. The mission structure and upgrade system is done well also.Verdict:Buy this on sale and only on sale for $15 or less. The single and only reason to avoid paying more than $15 is because the developers did not put enough care and time into making your teammates act intelligently. Instead, they are some of the dumbest AI teammates I have ever seen in a game. And that takes what could have easily been my score of 9/10 for this game and smashes it over the head with a bowling pin into a 6/10 like Daniel Plainview did to Eli at the end of the movie There Will Be Blood, which is what you will want to do to yourself after fussing about with your sub-human intelligence level AI teammates.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												So... What happens when an overly ambitious publishing house (Take Two Interactive) is jealous of the marketing potential of one of its development houses' franchises... And wants to milk the franchise more thoroughly/ more quickly than that franchises' home development house (Firaxis) is willing to? It hands the franchise over to one of its other development houses (2K Marin) and tells it to make a derivative product that by-and-large is derivative at-best, and delivers no unqiue value... But manages to grab more money more quickly from unsuspecting fanboys of the franchise. That's what "The Bureau: XCOM Declassified" is, IMO: A money grab. Fortunately, though... The game is good enough in its own right for me to not completely feel as is I've been screwed over twice. (Once by being hoodwinked, and twice by buying a bad game.)Make no mistake: this isn't XCOM, in the classical sense. Instead, think of it as a complete mod for Mass Effect. That is... Mass Effect with an XCOM skin.Combat is *not* turn-based. Rather, it is "real-time + bullet-time-style slow-down"  for sake of using special abilities (a la mass effect - complete with selection wheel and everything...). Time is *not* paused when in the selection wheel; rather, time is greatly reduced. Relative to "pure/true XCOM" games, strategy and item management are *greatly* simplified in favor of tactical gunplay. There's no base-building element at all. Weapon and gear are simplified, relative to traditional XCOM games. Flanking/ hidden/ exposed attack bonuses are similar.(Story-wise... This game is best considered a prequel to the XCOM series (I'm specifically thinking of XCOM: Enemy Unknown - don't have experience with the previous ones).)Presuming one's expectations are "reset" with the above... I'd recommend purchasing this *at 50% or greater discount only* (not at full price). It *is* sufficiently immersive, has a decent enough of a story line, and a couple of neat twists... Such that it's worth playing through, IMO. Although it has about the right playthrough timelength (when bought at discount), note that it has zero replay value. (IMO)Simply put... This game looks like (a "period-correct" variant of) XCOM, and resembles XCOM... But it certainly doesn't *feel* like XCOM... And it sure as hell doesn't *play* like XCOM. Despite all of that, however... It's worth a discount buy, as it's not a bad game in its own right.I do wish they would have left the name "XCOM" out of the title, though. It would have prevented some player disaapointments due to false expectations, IMO.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												Give it a chance.XCOM's return to prominence has been an interesting one, originally an FPS with little to do with the original series, it was scrapped, and it's side project, Enemy Unknown, became an unexpected hit. Following in the wake of it's success is The Bureau, kind of a half way house between the original FPS concept and the popular strategy remake. Many of the original concepts from the scrapped FPS return here, such as the 1950s setting, the 'silicoids' and the investigative themes.What on the surface looks like a shallow cash-in, is actually a very deep and enjoyable hybrid TPS/RTS game, but in order to really enjoy The Bureau you have to be willing to give it a chance and excuse some of it's shortcomings.It's story is paint-by-numbers, it's characters are shallow, the levels are linear, it's everything you'd expect from a mediocre shooter, but for those willing to invest in the game, there's a deep and tactical experience to be had, not to mention some genuinely clever plot twists that most people won't see coming. The Bureau boasts many of the features of a 'true' XCOM game, you'll unlock better equipment as the game progresses, you'll recruit and train soldiers who can die permenantly, and you'll need to be strategic and use your assets creatively in order to win against increasingly grim odds. What sets it apart from the traditional XCOM games is the story driven campaign and the more personal perspective of being a soldier in the field. It features quite nice graphics at times, and the 50s setting and aesthetic is charming, reminiscent of Bioshock and Fallout. The cover-based shooting is simple but tight, and using the tactical view, which slows time and allows you to issue orders and use skills, is a joy to use, you'll get immense satisfaction from pulling off combos. For those fans of the XCOM universe, old and new, this is a must have game, and for fans of third person shooters and strategy games, this is a solid addition to your library.
