content:
Posted: October 28, 2014
												Coming from a new to the XCOM series perspective, I find it hard to understand why this game got such negative reviews. I'll admit my first reaction to the game was that it was underwhelming and would get repetive fast. However the further I played into the game I was drawn in by the story. I already liked the idea of a 50s era noir setting with aliens and I just wanted to know what would happen next. Sure there are a few areas which could have used a bit more depth, however I feel the story makes up for that. For example, my agents reached level 5 with much of the game left to go so it was a bit dissappointing to see that they had reached their maximum capability with so much left of the game to complete. That being said, the graphics in this game are really nice for the most part. The AI I can see could have used a bit of work, although I can understand the choices they made to keep them 'dumb'. If all the enemies just rushed you on the hard difficulty there would be no way to defend youself, literally, and the game would be impossible.Overall, I really enjoyed this game though. The story was gripping, yet a tad dry at times with the 'investigations',8/10

content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												This game gets a bad rep because it's not like other XCOM games. Standing on it's own, this game is pretty darn good. If you are a Mass Effect I would definitely give this game a shot. The game play is engaging as you control your team in tactical fashion by way of pausing and giving orders. You build your team and agents up throughout missions, even dispensing new recurits on their own misisons where they can gain experience and join you in future battles. If you get caught in some mayhem and an agent on your team goes down, you'll fight for your life until the end of the battle at which point your trusted pilot Barnes will dispatch you a new recruit. While the characters are quite thin, the dialog options terrible, the story hooks you in enough to enjoy the ride as you try to save the world. This game is definitely underrated and far better than expected when giving the chance.

												I must say that this game is one of the best I have ever played. Great graphics, wonderful characters, good gameplay mechanics and very beautiful settings. There is only two problems I have with the game. First of all, you have to get used to the character's voices, because in the beginning, everyone's voice sounds like that stereotypical government voice that closely resembles a chicken bone being lodged down your throat. Next is the ending... it's bloody awful. It's not the event that ends the game that kills it off, it's the events leading up to it. The fact that you HAVE to switch characters was a bad idea no matter which character you took. This killed the game off completely and ruined it for me. Honestly, take Weir was next playable character, as I was connected to Carter too much and Weir's ending is much more pleasant. Other than that, I completely recommend this game, but make sure you know who to trust and who to stay connected to the most.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2014
												Setting aside the style change from tactical top down to first person shooter, this game is a mess.The first issue to strike most is the that code is not optimized, and places a strain well beyond what should be required to run what is at heart a relatively simple game (from the perspective of a major studio production).Secondly, the play style is a poor rip off of Mass Effect style, but instead of giving you teammates who can almost function, the developers here have given you two berserkering mentally deficient man-children as partners.Third, the plot structure is awful. It's almost as if written by a a gang of 12 year olds who weren't allowed to communicate. This lack of plot structure becomes readily apparent when you first arrive at the Xcom base, where you are told that the location has to be ultra secret, or the aliens will just blitzkrieg it like they did the other bases. After that tidbit, you'll told that the Major (or whoever, I don't remember) has an urgent mission for you, while at the same time being told you should just wander around the base and acclimate yourself. When you finally decide to check this mission out, it turns out an alien has snuck into the base and is trying to plant a bomb. Seems like that would have been mildly urgent, but naw, not a big deal. Plus, this doesn't blow your base's hidden location for, um, some reason?Fourth, the game will only appeal to arcade-style folks, anyone looking for a remotely indepth game play will be disappointed. Random alien weapons are left laying around for you to basically run over and pick up, destroying any hope of making an indepth game.Between the terrible performance issues, god awful teammate AI, poor plot structure, and simplistic play style results in a game that should never have gotten 66/100 from the critic average. I think they got blinded by the pretty graphics, which only really work on a great machine.Oh, and the studio closed, so don't expect patches. Don't buy it. Ever. Even on sale.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												The game starts on a positive not with great atmosphere and an interesting story. Alas, this does not last long. Atmoshpere goes away as we go from the America in 60s to generic boring alien ships/bases. And story quickly loses its positive qualities too. The gameplay, on the other hand, does not lose positive qualities. That's because it has none. With stupid AI, horrendous interface and boring shooting it's hard to force yourself to continue playing. The game manages to look both too short and too long at the same time. That's because developers attempted to comensate the small number of actual missions by prolonging each mission with long stretches of empty space where nothing happesn and huge amount of enemies when something does happen. The result is terrible.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 23, 2013
												The Bureau is a solid tactical shooter that had an intresting twist in the story and played out rather well overall. My impressions are based on a playthrough at the highest difficulty level so I don't know how easy it gets if you crank it down.Combat in the Bureau is not your typical shooter gameplay at all - if you run and gun you will very quickly get murdered by even the most basic of encounters. Most of your combat time is spent in a slow motion tactical menu where you can utilize soldier skills and designate targets and where to move.  Your soldiers level up as you use them in missions and gain skills based off what class they are and what you choose for them. While playing on the harder difficulties if they bleed out they will die for good adding an extra level of tension but if you stabilize them before they bleed out they will come back to life after you've killed everything in the area.I really did feel like the commander because of the combat system and how it is very strictly defined by what you tell each soldier to do - they aren't AI's that will do everything on their own, if that's what you want this isn't the game for you at all and you will hate the combat. I felt combat was very fun and was the strong point of the game.The story.. I have to admit after like 5 hours in I just started skipping all the dialog I really didn't care about the story at all in this particular game for some reason. Even skipping through it though it did yield a cool twist towards the end of the game that very likely causes different endings, though how different I don't know.I recommend giving this game a shot, atleast at a discount maybe. On the hardest settings and doing every side mission I came across the game was not even 20 hours and it has no multiplayer - you could very likely cut that in half rather easily on lower settings and skipping side missions.

Combat isn't challanging a bit - which might be a good thing becouse AI of your teammates is terrible. content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												First of all, if you have played previous xcom games, this one is totally different. 3rd person shooter with tactics on combat. I enjoyed it a lot in my first walkthrough. The atmosphere is great, detailed enough, story based at 60's is really funny, reminding me old classic sci-fi/noir movies. The characters are also good.The gameplay now is what you make it to be. You have 2 soldiers in your squad, who obey to your orders (well not always). You have some choices of what you want them to do. So you either just give orders and let them have their fun, or you grab your gun and kill every alien comes your way. You choose. My overall rating:PLUS:-unique atmosphere, detailed enough with a great taste of old sci-fi and noir movies-music-missionsMINUS:-gameplay's AI is bad (squad is basically dumb sometimes, in a ridiculus way)-dialogs and story make in some points no sense at all-graphics are good but with low fps (i think this has changed with a patch, i havent tried it yet)So my rating: 7/10

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Oh man, this is a good game. If you like XCOM and Third-Person Shooters, you will LOVE this game. Seriously. I started with XCOM: Enemy Unknown, completed it and bought this. I downloaded it yesterday. I have spent hours on this game.The start of the game is really gripping and immersive. This stays throughout the entire game. And you can relate to most of the characters. Apart from Carter, but that is explained later. The missions are enjoyable and, I don't know if this was just me, but you end up doing everything you can to ensure all of your agents survive. The talking feature is a nice touch, and just helps you feel like you are the character. Almost as if you are another entity forcefully controlling humans. And holy s**t is the ending good. I'm not going to spoil it for anyone, but it is a great and unexpected ending. It depends on your ending though. Although, I don't actually know if there are alternative ending- it'd just make sense if there were. At the end of the day, I would reccomend you buy this game, especially if you like XCOM, Strategy Games, Action Games or you just want to try something new. And remember to survive, adapt, win.

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Fun game. Combat feels a bit like the Gears of War mechanics with a splash of Army of Two.  Team of 2 units and you, as the commanding officer.  Orders are very easy to issue.  Agents have 4 different classes.  I don't recall the names specifically, but you have a sniper, engineer, support class, and a tankier character who uses an assault rifle.  Graphics aren't superior, but they're not god awful.  This game can be played on the weakest of PC builds.  Story is interesting but bland at the same time.  It reminds me of the Cowboys Vs Aliens movie.  When I started playing, I thought the game would be bad since I got it with the BioShock humble bundle and I've never heard of XCOM.  Turned out to be really fun and I fully enjoyed every moment spent playing.  I haven't noticed any glitches either :)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												It is quite a pity that this game has such a low score on Metacritic...probably because most people expect it to play like the original XCOM...Anyway, this is quite fun - the story is over the top and nonsensical until close to the end, where a few things are explained.Regardless of that, though, combat is nice - you control yourself (3rd person) and 2 other agents against various groups of aliens. You fight in real time in the usual way - aim and shoot; and you can also go in a slow motion mode temporarily to issue orders to your squad, so that they can go into cover, focus on specific enemies, etc.On top of the normal shooting mechanics, you and your squad "level up" with experience and get perks, which make the combat a lot more interesting - for example by deploying turrets, levitating enemies, etc.Graphics are nicely done, writing is full of cliches and a bit annoying sometimes. Time spent in the base organising for fights and moving the main story along is quite boring, and I would have preferred to simply watch some short clips instead.It works great with a gamepad. And it took me around 20 hours to do pretty much everything available.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2014
												Lackluster Alien Killing. Combat style of Mass Effect and facial structure / character depth of LA Noir. It's fun for bursts at a time the leveling system is alright but little is affected by picking different paths in the skill tree. Whatever perks you miss you can have another person pick up making your choices meaningless. With the difficulty set at its highest the AI is there however most of the difficulty comes from the nerf bullets that are placed in the gun in this setting. Lots of talking and paltry character background for some of the main characters but it all feels cliche, (e.g.), the main character is a lone gun who lost his family and blames himself. The nicest thing I can say about this game is how things react with nvidia physx turned up. Cloth moves properly and when doors fall apart it looks very nice. This doesn't happen much and it doesn't mean you can make your own path as you are shoved down this corridor into slightly different aliens. Being that this game is only a year old you would think the graphics would still be decent which they are but the same can be said for metro last light and that just got a graphics release meaning they both were not made to meet the demands of the pc gaming community. If you love other XCOM games this adds to the lore and is worth the time. If you are like me however and could take it or leave you will get bored with the occasional oh and aw of flashy explosions and hopes for a challenging situation only to be found forced through another beigh town, hallway, or steile enviornment with the same few enemies. 7/10 Average, boring with tight controls .

												RECOMMENDED.Third person action / shooter with Peloton Orders and some strategic approach.Well ambiented, 1969, Kennedy around and an alien invasion as a background.Not well optimized, movement is a bit lazzy but, overall, the story board is interesting, ambientation also is and, probably one of the very few games that choosed that particular time in history to develop its story line.Takes a while to learn to control battle orders but, once you get it, the interface is smart and easy to handle.While you are in battle orders mode, time goes slowly (bullet time) so you can queue several orders for each man.Very interesting battle orders management system.It has some RPG tints also.I had no good expectation on this game and just tried it because it came as a gift with other game I've bought but, it greatefully surprised me.It worths a try.

												I liked the idea of this game, but the tactical elements it tries to do are just so poorly done. The team AI is so brain dead and issuing commands with such a limited perspective just slows the game down because you're spending so much time running around reviving your dumb team mates. They should have just let you simply switch to teammates and control them outright instead of selecting them and moving the camera around the screen all day and issuing commands. If they wanted to make a spin-off XCOM game that was a cover shooter they should have committed to that instead of putting in a very poor tactical system just for the sake of using one to make it relevant to the XCOM setting.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												I enjoyed The Bureau.  While it is not quite up to the snuff of Enemy Unknown, I still feel it did a solid job as far as the XCOM franchise goes.  However, I would recommend that its purchased during a sale rather than pay full price for it.  The most solid trait for me was the quintessential feel of 1960s.  The grainy film effects to McCarthyism  and big government doing all they can to hide the facts recreate the essence of Big Brother.  The fact that you can create agents from military to agency backgrounds also helps embellish this idea.The only downside I feel is that the endings feel a bit lackluster.  Then again, its one of the few XCOM games I have been able to play to also have multiple endings (though not requiring the player to be so focused on their choices from the very start.  You'll understand by the end what I mean.)

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 31, 2015
												First off, I am a huge X-Com fan, Ive put way too many hours into the game, and is probably my all time favorite game. That being said, I was not too excited about The Bureau, but it was on sale for like 4 dollars and I couldnt pass it up. And least to say, i was pleasantly surprised. it wasnt the best game I have ever played, but it deserves much more credit it has been given. The game mechanics are decent, and your squad does suck at the beginning, but later one as you level them up and get better equiptment, they become more useful. And yes you do have to order them what to do a lot of the time, but it is what makes the game strategic. Overall, ity is a pretty good game, with a story that will surprise you. if it is on sale, i would suggest getting.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
												it's hard to appreciate this game in its own right. i've been a fan of the x-com tactical turn based games since the UFO Enemy Unknown release back in the 90's, so this incarnation as a 3rd person cover shooter for me, is really jarring.it's cool to see the whole alian invasion from a different perspective but there is SO much unexplained, or without depth - such as your characters ability to heal. So you have a device on you arm that .. uses sci-fi magic to heal? okay.. sure.Overall the game plays like a poor man's Mass Effect. Excelling at little, but not really failing at anything it attempts. Just skirting around the line between curious mediocrity and boredom.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												It is quite a pity that this game has such a low score on Metacritic...probably because most people expect it to play like the original XCOM...Anyway, this is quite fun - the story is over the top and nonsensical until close to the end, where a few things are explained.Regardless of that, though, combat is nice - you control yourself (3rd person) and 2 other agents against various groups of aliens. You fight in real time in the usual way - aim and shoot; and you can also go in a slow motion mode temporarily to issue orders to your squad, so that they can go into cover, focus on specific enemies, etc.On top of the normal shooting mechanics, you and your squad "level up" with experience and get perks, which make the combat a lot more interesting - for example by deploying turrets, levitating enemies, etc.Graphics are nicely done, writing is full of cliches and a bit annoying sometimes. Time spent in the base organising for fights and moving the main story along is quite boring, and I would have preferred to simply watch some short clips instead.It works great with a gamepad. And it took me around 20 hours to do pretty much everything available.

content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												First of all, if you have played previous xcom games, this one is totally different. 3rd person shooter with tactics on combat. I enjoyed it a lot in my first walkthrough. The atmosphere is great, detailed enough, story based at 60's is really funny, reminding me old classic sci-fi/noir movies. The characters are also good.The gameplay now is what you make it to be. You have 2 soldiers in your squad, who obey to your orders (well not always). You have some choices of what you want them to do. So you either just give orders and let them have their fun, or you grab your gun and kill every alien comes your way. You choose. My overall rating:PLUS:-unique atmosphere, detailed enough with a great taste of old sci-fi and noir movies-music-missionsMINUS:-gameplay's AI is bad (squad is basically dumb sometimes, in a ridiculus way)-dialogs and story make in some points no sense at all-graphics are good but with low fps (i think this has changed with a patch, i havent tried it yet)So my rating: 7/10

content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												Fun game. Combat feels a bit like the Gears of War mechanics with a splash of Army of Two.  Team of 2 units and you, as the commanding officer.  Orders are very easy to issue.  Agents have 4 different classes.  I don't recall the names specifically, but you have a sniper, engineer, support class, and a tankier character who uses an assault rifle.  Graphics aren't superior, but they're not god awful.  This game can be played on the weakest of PC builds.  Story is interesting but bland at the same time.  It reminds me of the Cowboys Vs Aliens movie.  When I started playing, I thought the game would be bad since I got it with the BioShock humble bundle and I've never heard of XCOM.  Turned out to be really fun and I fully enjoyed every moment spent playing.  I haven't noticed any glitches either :)

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I expected a knockoff of Mass Effect, not an X-COM game, so this review is not based on anger that this isn't a "true" X-COM, whatever that means.  Frankly, as a squad shooter, the game feels clunky, there are too many menus to navigate, and it failed to hook me in the first few hours.  There's a lot of games out there, and I'm not willing to put five or ten hours in a game before it begins to get interesting.  Either I simply didn't get the strategy element of the squad (and I beat all 3 ME games on hard) or there's something broken in the way squaddies die every couple of seconds even if they're behind cover.  Idiot AI has them running across open ground when I order them to stay put, and jumping in front of me when I'm shooting.  If you've got a high tolerance for frustration, maybe you can get through to the "fun" part of the game, but I'll go try Wolfenstein instead.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												I am a massive fan of the XCOM serries but I feel this game was extremely sub par and struggled to play the few hours I did. I have been a gamer a long time and hold things to higher standards probably more so than most. There are too many good games in this genre to waste time playing this. Story - The voice diagloues are similar to a Mass Effect but have 0 consequence based on choice as far as I got. The mouth movements are very harsh and there are only 3 or 4 body animations the main character will do. Even in the few hours I played, this REALLY bothered me. I would of rather had still faces with text bubbles popping up like a SNES game versus what was done. The quality of the actual voice acting was decent but doesn't come close to making up for the rest. The story itself is dull, aliens have attacked and you scramble to get your defenses ready and find out why.  Combat - I find the Mass Effect serries combat to be MUCH more engaging than this, but they share a great deal of similarities. It is a 3rd person tactical shooter. You need to use cover and special abilities given to each class to win. Graphics - Very poor character animations in dialogue. Combat animations are okay. Nothing to brag about.Over all - I cannot recommend this game because it simply lacks polish. If you aren't good at shooters maybe this game will provide more in terms of tactical ability needed, but for it was put the troops on the flanks and shoot until the enemies are dead. I would absoutely recommend the Mass Effect serries over this because it is better in every aspect.

content:
Posted: February 17
												As an Avid Enemy Unknown and XCOM 2 player, I picked this game up because I had always thought an XCOM shooter game would be way cool. I was not dissapointed. BUT, it's imperative that you know that going into it, this is not so much an XCOM game as it is a shooter Stylized to be LIKE XCOM. Also it's in the 60s because why not. The story was alright, and explains how it *could* be part of the new XCOM universe, but honestly if you're looking for story driven games, there's much better out there (and if you're not, you can essentialy skip through the entire story part by just mashing the skip button and always choosing the lefternmost response). Listening to your squadmates talk gives a humerous aspect to the game, and although I've seen many complaints about it I had very few problems with the squadmate AI on my own run through the game. A few times they would find weird paths to do what I ordered them, or get stuck on a wall for a few seconds, but no serious problems. The gameplay is interesting enough that I could see myself replaying it eventually. Very fun, but a pretty short game (get it on sale unless you REALLY want it). All in all, a very fun time and worth the price.I'd also like to mention, I played this game entirely with a USB ported XBOX-360 controller, NOT a keyboard and mouse. I've heard terrible things about how the game handles with those, so be forwarned you might have to rebind some stuff to get a good control scheme on Keyboards.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is the imagination of a classic series of turn based strategy games as a first person shooter.  The game begins in Pima, New Mexico where strange happenings are afoot and suddenly a coordinated alien strike disrupts global communications, supply lines, etc.  The Bureau is an over-the-shoulder shooter with a “time-slow” button that allows the player to give commands to their squad.  Those who have played the Mass Effect games … the combat is exactly like Mass Effect.The Good:  The fights in this game a pretty fun.  Good battlefield layout made for lots of fun fights as you slip from cover to cover. Further, the ability to move your squaddies and deploy skills and hardware gave a neat strategic over lay that made the game more than just a “shoot-em-in-the-head-over-and-over” fest (in lower difficulties).The Bad: Sadly, everything else is ranging from not good to terrible.  The entire game is one long hall way; there’s never two ways to a fight, a way around a fight, etc.  The story … well dang, I am honor bound to never spoil anything no matter how good or how bad I think the writing may be.  That said I’ll be interested to talk to someone else who’s played this to see if the whole last 10% of the game was actually as bad as it seemed of it is super wonderful and I’m just a dope and didn’t get it … IDK, not worth playing again to find out.  The voice acting is mediocre at best and the tech-tree (or extreme lack thereof) is downright offensive to anyone who’s played the older X-Com games (there is no tech tree, you find a weapon just sitting there and pick it up … yours now).  The game is also SO comically straight forward that you almost have to avoid the “secrets” since they are mostly shiny things at the end of short hallways, like … you can nearly see them from the main rout!  Just in case you actually did miss anything the stuff in these “secret” passages you can take comfort in that it is either ammo you didn’t need or a gear schematic that they game will give you later.  This game also commits the cardinal sin of game difficulty: enemies get more HP and do more damage / run a head-shot script per level of difficulty which turns the game into a “shoot-em-in-the-head-over-and-over” fest.  The Funny: The game was also not bug free which, when games are bad, can be nice since it serves as comic relief.  I fell through the floor of places I was walking toward twice and once the camera locked onto my face and didn’t move after dialog.  The combat raged on and I proceeded to just sit there, adoring the main characters steely grimace while getting gunned down for being out of cover.  OH!  Whether or not you play the game though, be sure to look up the commercials!  The marketing for this game was more fun than the entire game!  Seriously, the stuff they did on Twitter and small webisodes and such were SUPERB!  The marketing people for this deserve to be on much better projects that’s for sure!  I’d hire then in a snap!The Summary:  I give this game 5 out of 10.  It’s not quite as bad as when they made Shadowrun into FPS but this is pretty bad.  Think of a game like Chess.  We know it as a game where strategy and a careful, mistake free execution are keys to success.  Then take the strategy out and let all the chess pieces run anywhere they want and shoot!  That’s what you get when you turn a game like X-Com into an FPS.  If you want to sit down and shoot at aliens for a few hours while you watch TV and the game is on Steam-sale for 5 bucks or less you won’t kick yourself for picking up a copy, I’ll give it that.  With all the good titles out there though I can’t imagine anyone so hard up for something to do that this would be a good buy.  The fights are fun if ya like a quick shoot-em-up but that’s all I can say.  Thank God Sid Meyers got the rights to this game as well and made a FANTASTIC turn based strategy X-Com; that is everything X-Com should have been!  GET THAT ONE INSTEAD!

content:
Posted: September 16, 2013
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified - это ответвление от легендарной серии тактической стратегии XCOM. И с другими играми серии она не имеет ничего общего, разве что присутствие сектоидов и название самой организации. Каким-то крутым геймплеем или хорошо придуманным сюжетом игра не блещет, но игра хорошо пропитанна атмосферой 60-х. Сам краеугольный камень игры, а именно её тактическая часть, хорошо реализованна. Также можно свободно побегать по базе XCOM и повыполнять какие-то побочные небольшие квесты в ней. В целом, первый шутер во вселенной XCOM оказался не без минусов, но на пару вечеров эта игра вполне сойдет. 7.5/10.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												The Bureau was born of a false assumption, and it shows. When development began on the game, the prevailing belief among its publisher and the industry at large was that games in the vein of the original XCOM lacked widespread appeal, and that gamers yearned for first person shooters. After the excellent XCOM Enemy Unknown helped refute this preconception, the Bureau and 2K Marin were clearly left in the awkward position of drastically rewriting a product that was already stung by criticism in advance of its launch. The result is a hybrid third person shooter that borrows its aesthetic from Mafia, its gameplay from Mass Effect, and a tactical facelift from XCOM. Its thus far underwhelming story no game should take the blame for. None of these elements click together neatly even if they are at times competent. It resembles four jigsaw puzzle sets cut to size fit with scissors. In order:1) The game's visual presentation is badly flawed. Clipping issues felt common, and even on moderate settings the game has repeated framerate stutters. Protagonist William Carter's hands repeatedly clips through his shoulder holster in dialogues that look stiff and uncanny even by the standards of the genre. One support character walked clean through Carter. Even when it's working the visuals can get quite goofy. Agent Carter resembles no one as much as Sterling Archer, down to the Tactleneck. That said, the 60's aesthetic is kind of fun. Old computers whirr in the background, the Pipboy lifted from Fallout is a nice touch, and the aliens ripped from XCOM look good. It's at least a colorful game, and the infected humans dubbed sleepwalkers do look suitably creepy as they glitch through the same moment over and over again with blood flowing from their eyes.2) At its core, the gameplay alternates between third person squad combat and some light base management. Whereas Enemy Unknown made the base feel aspect feel important, and gave weight to the decisions made, there is nothing of the sort here. Agents can be sent on missions, but success is simply a matter of dispatching the sufficient number of agents. Even Assassin's Creed has more depth than that in the metagame. On battle it's mostly functional. Guns have weight, powers plagiarized from other games (looking at you: lift) give the right level of "oomph" to fights. But even here there are fundamental problems. For a start, while the aliens are controlled by a hive mind, at least they collectively have a brain to speak of. The same cannot be said of your squadmates. Sending them to a spot is no guarantee they won't decide to run over to you. While they know enough to run from grenades and to attempt to take cover, the game's understanding of cover is so flawed I had one agent run straight into the sightline of a mechtoid repeatedly because the game thought the spot was "safe". To cap it off, each dumb decision can get an agent killed. If they felt expendable, that would be one thing, but with only two men and consistent checkpoints, just losing one is both annoying and easily fixed.  Weapons also lack sufficient ammo to take down the bullet sponge Mutons and Sectopods sent in to break up the monotony of play. At the end of most fights you're left scrounging for another gun to scratch off its last bit of health. Still, there were stretches where things held up enough to give some interest. 3) The XCOM additions to the game more or less boil down to visual tweaks. With the exception of the more boring and humanoid Outsiders, the aliens are straight from XCOM. As a result, they feel more interesting and varied than the mainline battle troops usually sent against Carter. The other aspect, the cover system that appears in the tactical menu seems to have little point other than to confuse the AI when it bugs out.4) Finally, and most damningly for a game with such heavy emphasis on story, the narrative is almost comically awful. If the mantra of movies is Show, Don't Tell, and that of gaming is Play, don't show, then the Bureau loses at both counts. Agent Carter is supposedly a drunk, but the two beers I drank this evening were two more doses of alcohol than I've seen him imbibe. He's also a loose cannon, who inexplicably obeys every order given. NSA Chief Faulk, the amoral boss is also supposedly paranoid, but I only hear about any of these traits when characters make a point of talking about them.  An alien invasion is underway in major cities like New York and DC, but I only hear of it in random text blurbs. The Bureau is also supposedly covering this all up, somehow including the disappreance of an entire mountain, the loss of several dozen army bases and towns, two nuclear launches, and the appearance of literal alien skyscrapers that create their own star cover. And I haven't even finished the game. Characters are introduced and killed off before we're given any reason to care about them, and memorably in one moment an infiltrating alien even switches sides after two lines of dialogue. Nothing makes sense, and all of it is presented with the same stiff armed, dead eyed conversation wheels Mass Effect could barely salvage with superior dialogue and voice acting. Even on sale this isn't worth the time and frustration, except as a laugh.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												There's a lot to like and dislike about The Bureau. The connection with it and Enemy Unknown are tenous at best; other than name, and a visual callback in the form of EXALT in Enemy Within, the two games are completely seperate. The visual style is good, and distinctive. The 60's era, Cold Era setting is unique and distinctive, and the game looks fantastic. Curiously, the game decides to give each of your individual classes a completely different look. While this helps you to identify them instantly, it also doesn't really lend a sense of being in an organized unit, more like a guerilla organization. Perhaps they meant to get the sense of desperation across, though it came across as more like a dysfunction junction.The story is passable. The twist is surprising, but not earth shattering. If you're perceptive in fact, perhaps you would've seen it coming.Audio work is steller. Weapons, they sound good. Other than the Scatter Laser, which for some reason is like an animal squealingl everytime you pull the trigger, the rest of the weapons sound solid and dependable, and you can really feel the hurt that you put out. The audio cues that your squadmates give are loud and clear, and the spoken dialogue is pretty good. Gameplay is okay. This is a cover based shooter, and it shows. In fact, it shows too much; you can tell an ambush is coming by the suspicious amount of cover. Though it generally blends well with the environment, it's a telling sign when you come across a series of low walls between you and your objective, and some conspicious explosive objects, but no enemies in sight. You always have two squadmates with you, but they might as well not be around. We'll get to that in a bit. With your squaddies you can outflank the enemy, but with the plethora of cover busting abilies at your disposal, you really just need to wait for your cooldowns. Oddly enough, the game doesn't let you free-throw your grenades, instead making them a targetted AoE ability with no cool down.Now on to the AI. The enemy AI is good. Stunning, even. It will pin you down with suppressing fire while flanking your position. It will flush you out with grenades. It will take advantage of an advancing muton to rush your position, flanking you while you deal with the muton, which by the way can take a literal storm of bullets and still keep coming. But surely, you must be thinking, with your two squadmates, it'll be difficult but manageable.No. It's fustrating, that's what it is.Because your own team AI is astoundingly bad. Your squadmates won't use their own abilities on their own initiative. They will often expose themselves to enemy fire to empty their clip, and get downed in the process. They won't relocate when getting flanked. They'll spend almost all of the time in combat asking you for orders or asking for healing. They get downed very easily, because I saw with my own two eyes my squadmates roll away from an enemy grenade, only to run back to it because it was the closest cover. It's not a squad based shooter. It's a solo shooter, with two of the enemy on your side. Its a shame, because as  the enemy AI shows, 2K CAN develop intelligent AI, they just decided to hand the player possibly one of the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ friendly AIs in video game history. Perhaps they didn't want it to be too easy for the player, but as the AI stands, it's the most fustrating thing to experience in the game. In conclusion, if you can weather the terrible friendly AI (which I did, just barely), the game isn't that bad. Taken on its own, as a seperate part of the XCOM family, it's a good inclusion in its own right. This game could have been so much more; all they had to do was increase the competence of your teammates. But as it stands, it's extremely fustrating.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is the imagination of a classic series of turn based strategy games as a first person shooter.  The game begins in Pima, New Mexico where strange happenings are afoot and suddenly a coordinated alien strike disrupts global communications, supply lines, etc.  The Bureau is an over-the-shoulder shooter with a “time-slow” button that allows the player to give commands to their squad.  Those who have played the Mass Effect games … the combat is exactly like Mass Effect.The Good:  The fights in this game a pretty fun.  Good battlefield layout made for lots of fun fights as you slip from cover to cover. Further, the ability to move your squaddies and deploy skills and hardware gave a neat strategic over lay that made the game more than just a “shoot-em-in-the-head-over-and-over” fest (in lower difficulties).The Bad: Sadly, everything else is ranging from not good to terrible.  The entire game is one long hall way; there’s never two ways to a fight, a way around a fight, etc.  The story … well dang, I am honor bound to never spoil anything no matter how good or how bad I think the writing may be.  That said I’ll be interested to talk to someone else who’s played this to see if the whole last 10% of the game was actually as bad as it seemed of it is super wonderful and I’m just a dope and didn’t get it … IDK, not worth playing again to find out.  The voice acting is mediocre at best and the tech-tree (or extreme lack thereof) is downright offensive to anyone who’s played the older X-Com games (there is no tech tree, you find a weapon just sitting there and pick it up … yours now).  The game is also SO comically straight forward that you almost have to avoid the “secrets” since they are mostly shiny things at the end of short hallways, like … you can nearly see them from the main rout!  Just in case you actually did miss anything the stuff in these “secret” passages you can take comfort in that it is either ammo you didn’t need or a gear schematic that they game will give you later.  This game also commits the cardinal sin of game difficulty: enemies get more HP and do more damage / run a head-shot script per level of difficulty which turns the game into a “shoot-em-in-the-head-over-and-over” fest.  The Funny: The game was also not bug free which, when games are bad, can be nice since it serves as comic relief.  I fell through the floor of places I was walking toward twice and once the camera locked onto my face and didn’t move after dialog.  The combat raged on and I proceeded to just sit there, adoring the main characters steely grimace while getting gunned down for being out of cover.  OH!  Whether or not you play the game though, be sure to look up the commercials!  The marketing for this game was more fun than the entire game!  Seriously, the stuff they did on Twitter and small webisodes and such were SUPERB!  The marketing people for this deserve to be on much better projects that’s for sure!  I’d hire then in a snap!The Summary:  I give this game 5 out of 10.  It’s not quite as bad as when they made Shadowrun into FPS but this is pretty bad.  Think of a game like Chess.  We know it as a game where strategy and a careful, mistake free execution are keys to success.  Then take the strategy out and let all the chess pieces run anywhere they want and shoot!  That’s what you get when you turn a game like X-Com into an FPS.  If you want to sit down and shoot at aliens for a few hours while you watch TV and the game is on Steam-sale for 5 bucks or less you won’t kick yourself for picking up a copy, I’ll give it that.  With all the good titles out there though I can’t imagine anyone so hard up for something to do that this would be a good buy.  The fights are fun if ya like a quick shoot-em-up but that’s all I can say.  Thank God Sid Meyers got the rights to this game as well and made a FANTASTIC turn based strategy X-Com; that is everything X-Com should have been!  GET THAT ONE INSTEAD!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												I am a massive fan of the XCOM serries but I feel this game was extremely sub par and struggled to play the few hours I did. I have been a gamer a long time and hold things to higher standards probably more so than most. There are too many good games in this genre to waste time playing this. Story - The voice diagloues are similar to a Mass Effect but have 0 consequence based on choice as far as I got. The mouth movements are very harsh and there are only 3 or 4 body animations the main character will do. Even in the few hours I played, this REALLY bothered me. I would of rather had still faces with text bubbles popping up like a SNES game versus what was done. The quality of the actual voice acting was decent but doesn't come close to making up for the rest. The story itself is dull, aliens have attacked and you scramble to get your defenses ready and find out why.  Combat - I find the Mass Effect serries combat to be MUCH more engaging than this, but they share a great deal of similarities. It is a 3rd person tactical shooter. You need to use cover and special abilities given to each class to win. Graphics - Very poor character animations in dialogue. Combat animations are okay. Nothing to brag about.Over all - I cannot recommend this game because it simply lacks polish. If you aren't good at shooters maybe this game will provide more in terms of tactical ability needed, but for it was put the troops on the flanks and shoot until the enemies are dead. I would absoutely recommend the Mass Effect serries over this because it is better in every aspect.

content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												I expected a knockoff of Mass Effect, not an X-COM game, so this review is not based on anger that this isn't a "true" X-COM, whatever that means.  Frankly, as a squad shooter, the game feels clunky, there are too many menus to navigate, and it failed to hook me in the first few hours.  There's a lot of games out there, and I'm not willing to put five or ten hours in a game before it begins to get interesting.  Either I simply didn't get the strategy element of the squad (and I beat all 3 ME games on hard) or there's something broken in the way squaddies die every couple of seconds even if they're behind cover.  Idiot AI has them running across open ground when I order them to stay put, and jumping in front of me when I'm shooting.  If you've got a high tolerance for frustration, maybe you can get through to the "fun" part of the game, but I'll go try Wolfenstein instead.

content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
												To make it short and painless, the game does nothing really well. Story: BadAction: not really excitingTactical elements: fakeBasically a cover shooter with some tactical elements, neither the shooter part nor the tactical part work satisfyingly. 3rd Person shooter controls feel cumbersome, getting into cover and especially getting out of it (due to the huge amounts of grenades thrown at you in higher difficulty), aiming, running, jumping over obstacles, and even picking up ammo often gets a challenge of its own. Your squad, even though equipped with nice abilities, constantly dies of AI stupidity, beating the game only becomes possible because enemy AI is not any better. Speaking of the enemy, combat is dull and gets repetitive soon, instead of playing out the strengths of the tactical command UI, the game constantly throws you into small arena-like areas where you fight waves after waves of increasingly armored and shielded enemies (gimmicks like the rocket turret soon become entirely useless against enemies they dont even scratch. Like Mutons. And there are a lot of Mutons). Little example for the badness of game design: There are enemies you better attack from behind. So the obvious idea would be to tell your squad to get into cover to divert the enemy to sneak behind it to get a good shot. Often though, there simply is no "behind the enemy", and even if there is, your stupid squad will follow you automatically if you get more than a few meters away from them (of course they not rarely die in this attempt to follow you). Regarding the story, a lot more potential was wasted here. Alien Invasion meeting 1960s Cold War Paranoia is a great idea but they dont really made anything interesting about it. Instead of facing the claustrophobia of living in a subterranean bunker base while hell breaks loose on the world, you have to persecute the obligatory Shodan-Skynet core villain who you just need to kill to stop the entire invasion. Biggest joke: in the end, it just gets covered up, but if you actually get so far to see the end you have already stopped following the idiotic plot anyway. Steam says I put 25 hs into this crap. Needless to say it was wasted time....

content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												I'm not very far into this yet and already I have tons of problems with it--problems that have nothing to do with X-Com loyalty. I'm not even that experienced with traditional X-Com. My problems stem from this being a very problematically designed tactical shooter with a story and writing that just doesn't add up...or make sense...or make me feel anything. First off lets talk mechanics. As a tactical shooter, this game does at least try to bring more complexity to the genre, but that complexity is undermined by a control system that feels very loose and innacurate (I'm talking about aiming and shooting here). In addition to that, the AI of your companions leaves much to be desired.  Even when you are giving them orders regularly and changing their positions often, you will find that they are generally inneffective and frustrating to work with. I'm sure that they improve some as they level, but I doubt even then that it will totally solve how chaotically and unpredictably they behave.As for the story, it is about as mediocre as they come. Neither the writing nor the cinematic presentation are very good at all. Often the cinematography and dialog are so bad that I have no idea what is happening. The result is a game that feels like it is coming apart at the seems. The presentation is so sloppy and disjointed that the only way anyone could possibly enjoy it is by not paying attention to it and filling in the blanks with their own imagination.This game should have had it all for me. I am huge fan of retro science fiction worlds and X-Files-esque conspiracy laden story telling. Despite that, I can only express dissatisfaction with this game as a product. It is simply a broken, unpolished, cash-in by a company that should know better at this point. For shame 2K. For shame.If you're just looking for a tactical shooter with a decent story, try Spec Ops: The Line instead. That game has an incredibly satisfying cinematic atmosphere, despite its tactical mechanics being simpler and more familiar. If you're looking for a good retro sci-fi game with aliens and government agents and all that stuff...well, tell me when you find one because I'd love to play it.Who I'd recommend this for:Virtually no one. This is one of those games that is only for people who have decided to like it before they ever even played it. If you're into the surfaces of the game world and have a lot of patience for poor mechanics, you might have a good time. If you're someone who is simply interested in playing bad games (and I say that earnestly because I do think there is nobility in that, especially for designers) you might want to give it a try as well, but I wouldn't pay full price if that's the case. Hell, I wouldn't even pay half price. I bought this game on sale for $15, and I wish I had waited until they were chuckin' it away for $5.

content:
Posted: February 17
												As an Avid Enemy Unknown and XCOM 2 player, I picked this game up because I had always thought an XCOM shooter game would be way cool. I was not dissapointed. BUT, it's imperative that you know that going into it, this is not so much an XCOM game as it is a shooter Stylized to be LIKE XCOM. Also it's in the 60s because why not. The story was alright, and explains how it *could* be part of the new XCOM universe, but honestly if you're looking for story driven games, there's much better out there (and if you're not, you can essentialy skip through the entire story part by just mashing the skip button and always choosing the lefternmost response). Listening to your squadmates talk gives a humerous aspect to the game, and although I've seen many complaints about it I had very few problems with the squadmate AI on my own run through the game. A few times they would find weird paths to do what I ordered them, or get stuck on a wall for a few seconds, but no serious problems. The gameplay is interesting enough that I could see myself replaying it eventually. Very fun, but a pretty short game (get it on sale unless you REALLY want it). All in all, a very fun time and worth the price.I'd also like to mention, I played this game entirely with a USB ported XBOX-360 controller, NOT a keyboard and mouse. I've heard terrible things about how the game handles with those, so be forwarned you might have to rebind some stuff to get a good control scheme on Keyboards.

content:
Posted: January 5
												I really wanted to like this game. And to a certain extend I even did. But first things first.If you consider whether to buy this game or not, the first thing you need to know is that it is not really X-Com. While the other games like Enemy Unknown are turn-based strategy games, this is a squad based shooter. Which is completely fine to me, you just need to know that beforehand.Coming to this game, the performance was actually pretty solid, slight performance issues and framerate droppings here and there, nothing to worry about. Graphically it's okay, not amazing, but I like the artstyle and they got the look right.Storywise it plays it safe I guess, nothing really shocking happened up to the point I got with this game, but I can't say anything about the ending.Which leads me to my main problem with this game: The mechanics. I like the fact that you can pause the game and issue commands, which your teammates will usually react to. Sometimes you will have to instruct them multiple times because they just sit there doing nothing. But again, this didn't happen too often.What did happen frequently however was that my squadmates ran out of cover and got shot down or didn't take cover to begin with. This will result in untimely deaths and is especially annoying if your soldiers were on a high level.That said, I didn't have a problem with soldiers running out. What really got me to stop playing was a game breaking bug, with which the game wouldn't load the floor of the room you need to go in. You just enter the room and a cutscene is about to start, but you just fall through the nonexistent floor and die while multiple death sounds play on top of each other.I tried reloading checkpoints, playing the whole mission again, re-installing the game, nothing changed. So I can't finish the game. GG

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												I'm not very far into this yet and already I have tons of problems with it--problems that have nothing to do with X-Com loyalty. I'm not even that experienced with traditional X-Com. My problems stem from this being a very problematically designed tactical shooter with a story and writing that just doesn't add up...or make sense...or make me feel anything. First off lets talk mechanics. As a tactical shooter, this game does at least try to bring more complexity to the genre, but that complexity is undermined by a control system that feels very loose and innacurate (I'm talking about aiming and shooting here). In addition to that, the AI of your companions leaves much to be desired.  Even when you are giving them orders regularly and changing their positions often, you will find that they are generally inneffective and frustrating to work with. I'm sure that they improve some as they level, but I doubt even then that it will totally solve how chaotically and unpredictably they behave.As for the story, it is about as mediocre as they come. Neither the writing nor the cinematic presentation are very good at all. Often the cinematography and dialog are so bad that I have no idea what is happening. The result is a game that feels like it is coming apart at the seems. The presentation is so sloppy and disjointed that the only way anyone could possibly enjoy it is by not paying attention to it and filling in the blanks with their own imagination.This game should have had it all for me. I am huge fan of retro science fiction worlds and X-Files-esque conspiracy laden story telling. Despite that, I can only express dissatisfaction with this game as a product. It is simply a broken, unpolished, cash-in by a company that should know better at this point. For shame 2K. For shame.If you're just looking for a tactical shooter with a decent story, try Spec Ops: The Line instead. That game has an incredibly satisfying cinematic atmosphere, despite its tactical mechanics being simpler and more familiar. If you're looking for a good retro sci-fi game with aliens and government agents and all that stuff...well, tell me when you find one because I'd love to play it.Who I'd recommend this for:Virtually no one. This is one of those games that is only for people who have decided to like it before they ever even played it. If you're into the surfaces of the game world and have a lot of patience for poor mechanics, you might have a good time. If you're someone who is simply interested in playing bad games (and I say that earnestly because I do think there is nobility in that, especially for designers) you might want to give it a try as well, but I wouldn't pay full price if that's the case. Hell, I wouldn't even pay half price. I bought this game on sale for $15, and I wish I had waited until they were chuckin' it away for $5.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												It's an XCOM game, alright. At least more than Enforcer ever was. Battles can get hectic, so staying in cover and ordering your teammates do the work for you is vital. But that's what XCOM is all about: hiding in bushes and commanding people to their death. And every death hurts you deep inside, even if not as much as in Enemy Unknown, but still. You just get fond to your teammates.Only thing missing are the redshirds you send to suicide runs to flush out stinky aliens from their holes, but two squad mates are enough, as witnessed by many other 3rd Person Shooters. Any more teammates just would make the battles even more cluttered.Was it worth it? To me: yes!  With a mindblowing scifi plot, where gameplay mechanics were well integrated, and 60's themed environments I can recommend it. Last level especially is something beautiful.

content:
Posted: July 28, 2016
												I have 168 hrs in XCOM EU/EW. I wanted "The Bureau" to be good, but it isn't. As of writing this, I've only played 45 min of "The Bureau" and might not play any more. Pros:-Technically in the XCom universe. If you like XCom, this might be a plus for you.-Has a squadmate command mode like Mass Effect. You might like this, I didn't think it was fun the way it is here.-Controller support is always appreciated.-No bugs in my short playtime so far. -Checks all the boxes of generic AAA story shooters. It is in fact a video game.Cons:-The shooting gameplay is just bad, movement is sluggish.-Controls are very awkward. A to sprint, RB to roll? Why? -Story so far is extremely boring. -Level design is super generic. -You can only hold 2 weapons for some reason, although more would be better. :( I suspect they did this just to copy CoD and Halo. After playing Borderlands, 4 weapons is a must in any shooter for me.-Main character is a boring 35 year old white male who sounds like a chronic smoker who thinks he's batman. This is still prevalent why?-Framerate is smoothed, no option to disable.-Game feels un-creative overall.If you lower your standards somewhat you might enjoy this. Part of me wonders if this is just a cashgrab or just AAA homogenization problems.

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												This game is the combination of Gears of War style gameplay with Call of Duty type presentation and XCOM:Enemy Uknown writing. That is to say it's mediocre and cliched game in all senses of the word. It is literally the amalgamation of all the bad design choices of those games blended together and sprayed with Mass Effect-ish dialogue wheels that  are redundant and pointless in a boring♥♥♥♥♥story like this. I've played this game for about 4 hours on commander difficulty (which is the highest setting) and I've died like once, and I'm only average at 3rd person shooters. That'll give you an idea of the "tactical challenge" this game poses. And  lack of challenge takes away the fun of the xcom franchise. This game cost me like 5 bucks on the steam sale and it's not worth even that price, in fact, it's not worth being played for free, because it's a dull, uninspired game with mediocre gameplay and cliched, unoriginal plot. It's somewhat sad seeing as how this game could have been fun if it wasn't just so serious all the time. Early in the game, you find an audiolag of a German scientist that looks back on his involvement in Nazi experiments and berates them for being inhumane and wrong. All done in a serious tone. Right before you interrogate a green space man tied to a chair to spill his alien beans. Nice transition there, game.TL;DR, this is "Baby's first 3rd-person shooter", so unless you've never played this type of game before, I suggest you skip it because you've seen it all before and you've played it bettter before.

content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												I really enjoyed The Bureau: XCOM Declassified. This game is Great, but it would be better if this game have Co-Op mode.The Bureau: XCOM Declassified is a science fiction video game in the X-COM series, developed by 2K Marin and released by 2K Games for Microsoft Windows, PlayStation 3 and Xbox 360.The Bureau is a third-person shooter with an emphasis on squad-based tactics. The player controls the agent William Carter and commands two additional agents in each mission. Carter has his own unique abilities, but other agents are divided into the Commando, Engineer, Support, and Recon classes. By entering "Battle Focus Mode", which slows time significantly, the player can order their agents to move to strategic positions and activate class-specific abilities. Agents have customizable outfits, weapons, equipment and abilities. As in XCOM: Enemy Unknown, soldiers will suffer from permanent death and if Carter is unable to revive agents who have taken too much damage, they will die (variable difficulty levels also determine whether or not it is possible for downed agents to become battle-ready when revived, or if replacement agents will appear during a mission).

content:
Posted: February 4, 2015
												First and foremost this game is a shame and a loss of real potential. Sadly, and arguably prematurely, my rage got the best of me and I quit the game in the middle of saving the professor at the university. First off, the terrible cutscenes, despite people arguing in favour of them and saying it only looks so ugly because of the purposeful grain effect; they are actually ugly because they are console port level badly encoded and low res. 720p for a videogame cutscene in this day and age is just mindboggling.The game itself is rather polished, I Experienced no bugs at all during the gameplay; however it still manages to feel like a beta. Small things, such as system shock-esque recordings found everywhere are a great way to add depth were it not for the fact that they are always in the same room as key characters; as such you can never hear the recordings over the repeated bleeting of "HEY CARTER!" "CARTER OVER HERE" "CARTER WE NEED TO TALK". The voice work itself is decent and gives a real sense that some of these characters have been through some♥♥♥♥♥♥as well as the writing being good enough to make me disappointed in my not wanting to play further. However there are some glaring core gameplay issues that are only highlighted by the game being well-optimised. Despite being a game where tactics are key the mode that allows you to control your units doesnt actually stop combat to allow you time to give orders but only slows it down, with each character having 5 orders to choose from this is rarely enough time to make a plan of action before your squadmates are being shot to pieces. To add insult to injury the squadmate AI is abysmal, they stand in direct fire way too long and within seconds can lose their entire health bar, they often avoid grenade damage by choosing to run headfirst into groups of 6+ enemies, they repeatedly ignore the regoup command and will often find some creative but painful route through the map (always leading to 6+ enemies) and finally and most upsetting of all there is no order/action to take cover. I can see looking at the skills how they may become better with ranking up, however at the rate at which they rank up you will spend 2/3 of this game babysitting the AI. This game reminded me of those awful missions that have always cropped up in FPS's over the years where you have to rescue and escort some sub-seasponge level intelligence character through a field of flying metal and blood and they would spend half the mission standing in direct fire when they shouldnt or repeatedly walking into walls. Well buckle up homestuck because in The Bureau that's the core mechanic.

content:
Posted: August 26, 2013
												The entire time I was playing, I kept thinking "This is a lot like Mass Effect, but where everything's a biit better".The gameplay is ME's style down to a tee, but more involved and teammate-based. But not so much that it could really be called "Strategic". But it's a bit better.The grapics are pretty much ME but a bit better.The story's... well, it's pretty plain, but it's still a bit better than ME's crappy B-movie one.The characters are pretty plain, but still a bit better than ME's (save, like, two). Voice acting isn't as good though.It's a bit more creative than ME, but not as much as XCOM's.Overall, it's rather fun. If you liked ME... then you're not me, so I don't know how well this advice holds up. But the gameplay's certainly more fun anyway.Oh, fair warning: it was hyped as a kind of prequel to XCOM, but really it's more like an alternate universe thing. Not that the story contradicts XCOM's, but simply because they don't have any sort of bearing on each other. And it's certainly not a strategy-type game, that's for sure!...oh, and the Codebreakers DLC sux.

The plot is stupid, the gameplay is Bioshock trying to look like Mass Effect and utterly failing and the NPC next to you keeps saying "♥♥♥♥" twice in every sentence, even when things are going reletively well. I'd rather shoot him than the aliens, but the Bioshock engine wont let me. content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												The game starts with a blurry pre-rendered cinematic to set up the premise. Then you see your character, Mr. Average White Male. Mr. AWM get a knock on the door from some woman. This woman asks for your briefcase then shoots Mr. AWM. Mr. AWM then (generically) gets back up after being shot and stands there pointing a gun at the lady (who is now possed by what was inside the briefcase) telling her to "back away from the case" even though this person JUST SHOT HIM. Of course he doesn't shoot her and she attacks him. -FADE TO BLACK-. Mr. AWM then wakes up hours later to find the woman burnt to a crisp and his wounds magically healed. It's at this time that you can finally play the game, but not really. You have to run through an empty building, walking past dead bodies. Right when you get to the end of a hallway, you're then CINEMATICALLY ATTACKED BY SPACESHIPS and have to find cover. As the tutorial prompts flash on your screen, you're forced to learn how to move between cover as the windows CINEMATICALLY get destroyed. Cue you walking past more dead bodies while Mr. AWM talks to himself about how horrible it all is. Eventually you walk outside and some cars in the street get CINEMATICALLY DESTROYED BY SPACESHIPS flying by and you're forced to learn how to mantle over cover. Finally you come across enemies you can shoot, and your character sits there talking to himself about how to "remain calm and take the shot" even though you're already blasting alien noggins with no problem. After your first battle you meet up with another white guy who looks exactly like you, and he tells you to talk to Command by picking up a radio. Then you are stripped of your ability to run and shoot while you walk to the next CINEMATIC MOMENT talking to Command. Screw this game.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 10, 2013
												I almost feel like I have to defend this game because it has taken a beating in some circles.  It is not pure X-COM...it is more like the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child of XCOM and Mass Effect.  I really enjoyed it - and while it took awhile to get used to, I enjoyed the third-person combat aspects as well.I didn't really dig running around the base doing story stuff - mostly because I feel compelled to check the whole base after every mission for changes or new background info or side-quest-things (some of which led me to bonus minor operations.)   I *did* enjoy the combat, the pacing of the game during missions, and the scaling up of both weapons and enemies.There are some minor flaky/buggy type things, but nothing that was a pain or gamebreaking.The single most annoying thing for how I play is the lack of a save feature.  I need to be able to save when I want and then leave - since the game is auto-save only, I had to resort to checkpoint checking...but you don't know how long until your next checkpoint, and you have to pull up the "Load Game" menu to determine how long since your *last* checkpoint.  When missions can seriously run 30-60 minutes, and you can spend significant time between missions in the base running around for no good reason - the lack of a save system really hurt the game, in my opinion.  The autosave is robust, and the checkpoints are fairly frequent - but it did not substitute for the standard "save game" function for my needs.All in all - if you like the XCOM world and enjoy conspiracy theories and cold war-era backgrounds - this can be a great game for you.  If you aren't into either - you'll find an above average game with some minor flaws.  What you won't find is something near the caliber of XCOM: Enemy Unknown, or other similarly-priced $50 AAA games.Enjoyable and entertaining: YesWorth the time taken to play: YesWorth the money to buy at full price: Probably not.Do I regret my purchase dollars or playtime: Definitely not.All told, I got this game for around $15 - so I was very happy with my purchase.  I would not buy it at $50, but I would buy at $25-30 or lower.For interesting additional background info on the troubled development of this game since it was conceived and pitched in 2006 - I recommend this article from Polygon: http://www.polygon.com/features/2013/8/19/4614410/xcom-the-bureau-development-2006-2013 .

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												This is not a great game, just an almost good third person shooter with covers and idiot allies. Think of Gears of War in XCOM setting with stupid AI teammates whom you have to micromanage all the time.Playing it on Commander (the highest difficulty) now, and the squad mates running into enemy grenades (or not able to run away from them) is the most frustrating thing. I have to micro manage those idiots and run away manually each time an alien throws a nade, and that's really annoying.Another game breaker is that squad members just cannot stay behind the cover. They try to attack enemies and get shot in the face. And while you can run away from grenades, can't really do anything with this thing. There should've been agressive/passive behavior for allies and also simple commands like hold ground, stay in cover, etc. As it is, The Bureau is really bad in this regard.However, the game becomes easier as agents get new abilities and you get accustomed to controls. On the lower difficulty settings you can even make mistakes and still win.Overall, you can totally buy the game on sale just to walk the corridors of XCOM base and shoot aliens with plasma and laser weapons. But don't expect too much.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 22, 2014
												I had hope for this game, the reviews had not been overwhelmingly positive but I thought maybe it would be a rough diamond.Alas, I really can't recommend this game, even if it was on sale for a couple of quid.The problems:- The story is terrible. Wait, no. It's not so much the story itself, the idea of alien invasion is obviously a solid trope that the XCOM theory thrives on. But it's handled in such a ham-fisted and clunky way. The 1960's is a brilliant setting for a game like this, but they just never make the most of it.- The main character. Another Scotch-soaked haunted soul with a shocking past... *yawn*.- The voice acting (and facial animation) is pretty poor.- The combat is bought wholesale from the Mass Effect series but it seems like they only played Mass Effect 1 (where they hadn't really perfected it yet). It tries to cram a lot of the tactical elements from XCOM: Enemy Unknown in a real-time experience, again it's clumsy as hell.- It really doesn't run all that well, I'm way above the recommended settings and there are certain parts of the environment that make the framerate tank.It's disasppointing because I really think this is so close to being an enjoyable game but it just misses the mark in every single department.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4
												TL;DR: Unless you're a big fan of the setting and it's discounted, don't bother, it's just too frustrating.As someone who didn't play the "real" XCOM games, I really liked the general idea of this spinoff as well as the setting and artstyle and did not care that this is no turn-based strategy game. However, even as a strategic cover shooter, I cannot recommend this game (not for the full price at least). 1) It runs like sh*t as it has insane framerate drops regularly for no apparent reason, making it unplayable (dropping in and out of the pause menu helps for a couple of seconds, no idea why).2) The AI is way too stubborn, remaining far behind your position, making most of your teammate's abilities worthless because the enemies are too far away from them. Command every step manually or they die regularly.3) Controlling this game is a mess. You want your teammate to throw a mine over a waist-high obstacle? Nah, try finding a way around. Throwing a mine to a lower floor? Impossible, unless you find stairs leading down. It's just frustrating trying to use abilities while the game tries everything to prevent you from it.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
The first third-person real-time RPG shooter XCOM game, and damn it's f*cking amazing!Set in th early 60's, the characters are very defined, the storyline is amazing and the gameplay is outstanding!The beginning is a little confusing at first, especially the controls, but you get used to them very quickly. The story is long but never gets old, you and your custom squad gains EXP, level up bonuses and new guns. There's a lot of alien bosses and just when you think the game's over, it's not and throws you back in!I highly recommend you get all the DLC for this game, the Light Plasma Pistol is the most OP (over-powered) gun in the game (aquired after beating 'The Doctor' mission), but even on normal (squaddie) mode it's f*cking useful because this game is VERY challenging! The other DLC is extra missions that show before & during the invasion.If you like shooting games, you'll love this! It's like Resident Evil, with Aliens, and actually done right with fun gameplay (f*ck you sh*tcom!)10/10
